HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Goldman Sachs tries something new: promoting itself to the public as a brand worth knowing.

BYLINE: By Joseph Kahn 

 BODY:
GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, which went public earlier this month when it sold shares, plans to go public again, this time with its first global advertising campaign.
Beginning with ads this week in print outlets worldwide, Goldman intends to define itself as the blue-chip investment bank that listens -- and never gives the same advice twice to its corporate clients. All its advertising will carry the same tag line: "Unrelenting Thinking." 
 The campaign will not catch competitors flat-footed. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Merrill Lynch & Company, Citigroup, J. P. Morgan and many others heavily outspend Goldman to market their brands. Indeed, many of these firms have recently introduced new ad programs.
Goldman, however, has long been a happy enigma, known by its clients but largely inscrutable to outsiders. Visitors have to look hard to find the Goldman name on its headquarters at 85 Broad Street in downtown Manhattan. Like all investment banks, Goldman promotes deals it is involved in with staid print ads, known as tombstones, in the financial press. But rarely has it tried to define itself publicly or reduce its mission to a pithy phrase.
Goldman executives insist that the timing of the campaign is purely coincidental with the stock offering earlier this month. But both are part of the firm's plan to emerge from its shell. It faces increasingly tough competition from investment banks that often have more capital and much bigger ad budgets.
"With all the noise out there, it's good to remind people who we are and how we do business," said David W. May, Goldman's vice president for global marketing. "We need to have a consistent presence for the brand regardless of market conditions."
Goldman declined to comment in detail on the campaign, citing Securities and Exchange Commission rules about seeking publicity just after a public stock offering.
As might be expected for a firm where employees have only recently begun to wear blue Oxford shirts instead of the once uniform white, Goldman's ads are tame and understated. By Madison Avenue standards, the message is subtle.
One print ad features identical twins. The caption reads: "If we ever find two companies that are exactly alike, we'll offer two recommendations that are exactly alike."
Another shows a wide-eyed man at a hair salon examining his pointy coiffure. The text: "An honest opinion. Extremely rare when asking about a future spouse, a new haircut, or whether you should sell your company."
Goldman will spend about $10 million on the campaign this year, according to industry experts. The ads, designed by Ammirati Puris Lintas of New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will appear in publications like The Financial Times of London, The Economist, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and Business Week.
"The firm does not have a client base of 50 million people like some of our competitors," Mr. May said. "It has a very small target audience."
Most other Wall Street firms are also scrambling to put out a fresh message, especially after a series of mergers that reduced some well-known independent firms, like Smith Barney and Dean Witter, to subsidiaries of giant corporations.
Merrill Lynch, one of the financial industry's heaviest marketers, introduced a campaign in March that plays down its historic symbol, the bull, in favor of the abstract theme, "human achievement." Merrill plans to spend $75 million on that campaign alone.
And Morgan Stanley now uses as its corporate slogan "We measure success one investor at a time" -- the ad line of the old Dean Witter, the retail brokerage firm it merged with in 1997. The firm's overall ad spending is estimated by industry experts at more than $200 million.
Even Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a smaller investment bank that is controlled by AXA's Equitable Companies, plans a significant marketing push after it sells shares in its on-line brokerage subsidiary, DLJ Direct, that would dwarf Goldman's outlay.
Brett Shevack, chief executive of Partners & Shevack/Wolf, an advertising agency in New York owned by the Wolf Group, said that Goldman needed to respond to the brand-building efforts of its rivals.
"They really need to pre-emptively brand the company vis a vis the competition," Mr. Shevack, whose agency does not represent any of the companies discussed here, said. "They're trying to communicate with a rarefied business population. But otherwise, it's no different than Tide. You have to distinguish yourself."
He said Goldman had an opportunity to achieve that while other firms are consolidating. Some well-honed brands, Mr. Shevack said, are getting lost in the merger mix.
"Many of the other firms are worried about how to maintain the equity they built up in their brands, while Goldman can approach it with a clean slate," he said.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BEIJING;
Bombing May Have Hardened China's Line

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 17

 BODY:
China's leaders are continuing to condemn the United States in harsh terms as seeking global domination in the wake of the NATO attack on the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, reflecting what may be an important shift in China's view of global politics.
A front-page commentary in today's People's Daily, the official newspaper of the governing Communist Party, said NATO's air assault in Yugoslavia was part of an American "global strategy for world hegemony." It charged that the United States was engaged in "a new form of colonialism," using pretexts like human rights to turn other countries into dependents. 
 The article called the air campaign an "aggressive war" that was "groundless in morality or law," part of a plot by the United States and its partners to destroy Yugoslavia, expand eastward and control all of Europe.
That portrayal of American intentions comes as China tellsthe student demonstrators against the United States to get back to work and urges Western companies to keep investing here. It contrasts with the more nuanced views expressed by leaders here in the last two years, before NATO began its air attacks to halt the persecution of Kosovo Albanians.
Previously, President Jiang Zemin praised President Clinton and said China was pursuing a "strategic partnership" with the United States despite disagreements over human rights, Taiwan and trade.
Even before China's embassy was attacked by mistake on the night of May 7, causing an outpouring of anti-American rage here, China strongly condemned NATO's military campaign.
NATO had bypassed the United Nations, where China has veto power -- a sign to China that its views were not respected. China also sees the bombing in Yugoslavia as a dangerous precedent for possible foreign involvement in Taiwan or Tibet.
In the last few days, China has said it hopes to continue building commercial ties with the United States despite the anti-Americanism in evidence last week as students stoned the American Embassy here. And life has returned to normal in Beijing.
But today's article and continued praise of a speech Mr. Jiang made last Thursday suggest that China may adopt a more assertive stance on international political issues.
Chinese defense experts are depicting the embassy bombing in Belgrade as the latest in a series of American steps intended to obstruct China's rise as a major power.
"The eastward expansion of NATO in Europe, the strengthening of the U.S.-Japanese military alliance in the Asian and Pacific region and the launching of the current aggression against Yugoslavia," People's Daily said, "all constitute an important step in the United States' strategy for world hegemony."
Thursday night, after eulogizing the three newspaper and news service employees killed in the Belgrade embassy as "revolutionary martyrs," Mr. Jiang made a statement that officials have since been instructed to study.
He pledged to stay on the path of economic reforms. But he also said, "The United States continues to pursue hegemonism and power politics, and wantonly interferes in the internal affairs of other countries."
Diplomats here are debating whether Mr. Jiang has had a true change of heart or is seeking to pre-empt military leaders and other hard-liners who feel that China has been too friendly with the United States. In either case, the official line on the United States has changed.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares End Mixed, With the Dow Dropping 59.85 Points

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, in large part because of an afternoon rally in technology shares. But with Federal Reserve policy makers scheduled to meet today to discuss a possible increase in interest rates, investors were reluctant to make new commitments.
"Volume was low, as it should be when you don't know what you are looking at," said Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Concern about interest rates rose significantly on Friday after the Government reported that consumer prices rose at their fastest clip in nine years during April.
The report sent stocks sharply lower on Friday, and broad-based selling continued when markets opened yesterday.
While stocks sensitive to the interest rate, like banks and financial service companies, suffered throughout the session, reports that Hewlett-Packard and Dell Computer were set to post better-than-expected quarterly earnings helped to stem the decline during the afternoon.
At the closing bell, the Dow Jones industrial average, down by 167 points at one point, stood at 10,853.47, a loss of 59.85 points, or six-tenths of a percent.
Broader indexes did better.
Bolstered by strong gains in Microsoft, America Online and Dell, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which had also been lower for much of the session, reversed course and closed up 1.69 points, or one-tenth of a percent, at 1,339.49. And the Nasdaq composite index gained 33.98 points, or 1.3 percent, to 2,561.84.
"The technology stocks really turned things around," said Michael Molnar, a managing director in retail sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney.
Despite the rally, most stocks had a tough day. Almost two stocks fell for every one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange, and 61 of the S.& P. 500's 89 industry groups declined.
On the Big Board, volume was light, at 679.7 million shares. On the Nasdaq market, 788 million shares changed hands.
Few analysts expect the Fed to raise interest rates today, but many think the central bank will signal that it is leaning toward a rate increase in the near future.
Most traders and analysts see a rate increase as an unqualified negative for the stock market. But Mr. Molnar said it could be beneficial.
"I don't think the market would necessarily view it as a negative," he said. "The selloff in the bond market has been so substantial that a surprise move by the Fed now might be seen as being preemptive. If anything, a pre-emptive move has more appeal than more waiting."
Financial services stocks, which are most sensitive to changes in interest rates, were losers yesterday. And auto stocks slumped after a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter analyst said sales might have peaked.
Citigroup fell 1, to 70. J. P. Morgan slumped 4, to 135 15/16. Bank One declined 1 3/4, to 60 5/16. And Merrill Lynch lost 1 11/16, to 79 1/16.
Ford Motor was the biggest loser in the S.& P. 500, dropping 3 1/16, to 57 11/16. And General Motors, a Dow component, declined 2 13/16, to 80 5/16.
Rumors of a strong earnings report helped to send Hewlett-Packard's stock higher. The stock rose 4 9/16, to 88 3/4. After the close, the world's second-biggest computer maker reported quarterly earnings that beat Wall Street estimates.
Dell, which is expected to report its results today, was another good performer. It rose 2 1/16, to 43 1/4.
America Online was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange, jumping 10 1/16, to 136.
Concern that the combination of U S West and Global Crossing will be closely scrutinized by regulators caused prices of both companies to fall yesterday.
U S West fell 4 1/8, to 58 1/8. Meanwhile, Global Crossing slipped 1 1/8, to 60 1/4.
Other long-distance companies gained. Qwest rose 6 1/8, to 90 7/8 and Level 3 Communications gained 3 15/16, to 88 1/2.

HEADLINE: Houses With High Ceilings;
Home Prices and Demand Soar, as 'For Sale' Signs Dwindle

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn., May 12

 BODY:
Jeri Kelley had a home buyer coming in 10 minutes. She tapped the customer's price range into the computer -- $450,000 to $480,000 -- to see what was available in this genteel town on Long Island Sound, home to Paul Newman, Martha Stewart and other luminaries.
"That's a disaster," she murmured to herself as listing after listing flashed on the screen. "That's a disaster. That's newer construction. That's a disaster." Quickly, she flipped through descriptions of seven houses, most apparently in bad condition and none fitting her client's idea of a dream house. 
 The annual spring mating dance between home buyer and seller is well under way, and the suburban real estate market is shaping up to be even more sizzling this year than last. Like the Dow Jones Industrial Average, home prices keep pushing into new territory. Brokers catch themselves describing an $825,000 house as "sweet," while reports of a $2 million-plus spread selling for hundreds of thousands of dollars above the asking price have lost their shock value.
For agents like Jeri Kelley, the combination of escalating prices and disappearing for-sale signs has made this season especially frenzied.
Many houses sell within hours of coming on the market, and there is big money to be made. Ms. Kelley, a Midwestern transplant with wintergreen eyes, sold $10 million worth of houses last year, her best ever. To celebrate, she treated herself to a BMW Z3 roadster, the zippy sports car made famous by James Bond in "Goldeneye." This year is looking even better.
The overheated atmosphere is intensified by the fact that inventory -- the industry's term for the availability of houses -- is the lowest it has been in recent memory. That situation can force a panicky buyer to pounce on a house that is not quite right. It can turn an otherwise honorable person into a dishonorable seller, one who accepts a higher offer after having agreed on a lower price. And it has made Ms. Kelley's already competitive world even more cutthroat, with realtors zealously guarding leads about new listings.
"It's a mean market -- it really is," she said.
But Ms. Kelley handles the pressure just fine. For the last two years, she has been the "top producer" among the 27 realtors affiliated with Country Living Associates in Westport. (Simply translated, she raked in the most money.) She achieved that, she says, by working six and sometimes seven days a week and keeping in touch with hundreds of former customers who often become future customers.
Many days find her in the midst of a high-wire act, like the Monday earlier this month when a $2.5 million sale hung in the balance. Twenty-four hours earlier she had shown several houses in Westport to an English couple with seven children. They were crazy about one of them, a seven-bedroom Mediterranean priced at $2.5 million.
The couple offered a respectable $2.2 million, but there were two other offers on the table, and the listing agent, the one representing the seller, told Ms. Kelley to tell her clients that they had 24 hours to come up with their "highest and best" offer. Ms. Kelley phoned the couple and suggested that they give the sellers their asking price and toss in $25,000 for good measure. The couple jumped but not quite that high. They met the list price and added an extra $10,000. They lost. "He said, 'Oh, my God,' " Ms. Kelley recalled. "They really wanted this house."
Today, Ms. Kelley had something of a breather from the bidding wars that have grown so commonplace. But she was in overdrive nonetheless, her day parsed into tight half-hour appointments. One of her less glamorous stops was the Weston Town Hall, where she darted into the tax assessor's office to make sure a house she hoped to market was in good standing.
Earlier in the day, she had been laboring at her computer in her office. One of the most powerful weapons in the real-estate business is knowledge of the market, and to that end Ms. Kelley makes notes in her computer after every listing she sees. When something comes back on the market, as it is bound to do, she can look up the address in her file to jog her memory. Over the years, she has amassed 1,395 entries for Westport alone.
The style of her notations sound like that of typical real estate ads. But often the content is unlike anything one would see in the classifieds. One entry for a $479,000 house on the market in 1996 read: "A joke at the price. Nasty rambling ranch." A notation about a current listing for $389,000 was more haikulike: "Smells, mess, not on riverside."
Next on her itinerary was an 8,900-square-foot Colonial, brand new but built to look old, with paneled wainscotting, six fieldstone fireplaces, seven full baths and an emergency generator. "I could live in the laundry room," Ms. Kelley cooed. The price: $3,995,000. She knows a couple from New Jersey who might like it, but she needed to make sure the three-acre property offered enough privacy.
She had already whisked the couple through seven houses, ranging in price from $800,000 to $2.3 million, but nothing had clicked. "The husband said, 'Find me a house that needs work, and I'll put in $2 million, or find me a house that's ready and I'll pay $3 million,"' she recalled. "It drives you crazy because there's so much you can show them."
A while later, en route to her office, Ms. Kelley passed the builder of the mansion, Michael Greenberg, whose work she describes as the best in Fairfield County. "Is it still available?" she called from her car window to his. "Barely," he said, with a slight grin. "We're negotiating."
For the last several years, the real estate market both in Manhattan and in its suburbs has grown stronger each spring, with low-interest rates and the buoyant economy receiving most of the credit. Real estate agents also cite an uptick in company transfers, a relatively mild winter and changes in the Federal tax law that benefit home sellers.
From Westchester County to Long Island, the story is the same: home sales were up in the first three months of this year, as were average sales prices, but availability was sharply down. "The inventory declined by the double digits again," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "It's at historic lows. People are not putting properties on the market fast enough to replenish what has been sold."
In Nassau County, the number of homes for sale plummeted to 3,806 in the first three months of this year from 6,003 during the same period last year, according to the Long Island Multiple Listing Service.
In Westchester, where home sales increased by 13 percent over the previous first quarter, there were 4,869 residential listings during the first three months of this year, compared with 6,598 during the same period last year and 8,641 in 1997. In Fairfield, where countywide statistics were not available, local real estate boards reported similar trends.
With so few properties on the market, realtors are in a race to get their customers on the phone after touring open houses, events that represent their weekly opportunity to scope out new listings. On Tuesday, Ms. Kelley had seen a dozen houses in four hours, and, as always, she moved fast.
"You call from the car, from your home, wherever you can, and you say to your client, 'I have a great house but you need to get out here right now and see it,' " she explained. "But 600 other brokers are doing the same thing for their clients."
Many of her clients are couples in their 20's and early 30's in search of a house in the $800,000-and-up range. The husbands typically work in the financial industry; half the wives work outside the home. What amazes Mrs. Kelley is how many young people are also looking in the $2 million price bracket.
Unlike buyers who purchased homes during the real estate boom of the 1980's, she said, couples today seem to be less concerned about the possibility that they are buying at the peak of the market.
"People are more willing to go out there and buy something they like whereas investment was more key a decade ago," she said. "I remember husbands would look at their wives and say, 'Now don't get emotional. This is just an investment.' I don't hear that now."
Applying just the right amount of pressure can be tricky. Ms. Kelley knows her customers will lose the house if they dilly-dally. She also knows they will have buyer's remorse if they act rashly.
One couple earlier this spring saw a house in Weston in the morning, made a bid on it in the afternoon and had their bid accepted a few hours later. But by nightfall, their whispering doubts about the yard were shouting, and they called Ms. Kelley to renege.
"It's like walking into Lord & Taylor and you see a dress on a mannequin and you buy it," she said. "Then you get home and you try it on and say, 'Oh, God, this is the pits.' "
This afternoon, Ms. Kelley took out a teacher from southern Westchester County who was in search of a new house that offered more land and lower taxes. A few days earlier, the woman, who asked that her name not be used, had fallen for a $439,000 Cape Cod in Norwalk, with a pool and a pond. She and her husband, a banker, had made a low bid by today's standards, meaning they did not meet the asking price. But it had been their first time house-hunting in the area, and the teacher was eager to get a better sense of the market.
After seeing five houses in the $450,000 to $480,000 range, she still liked the Cape best, and she was figuring out a way to raise their offer.
As the shadows started to lengthen, Ms. Kelley headed back to the office to check a few things before calling it a day. "I usually go home and tell my husband that he can take me out to dinner," she said.
But restaurants are not the relaxing places they once were. This spring, while Ms. Kelley and her husband were talking shop over dinner, a couple who was eavesdropping suddenly butted in. "They asked me if I knew anything about Westport," she said. "They were looking to buy something. I gave them my card. You never know."

HEADLINE: General Dynamics to Acquire Gulfstream

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The General Dynamics Corporation, a military contractor that specializes in making nuclear submarines, surface ships and tanks, announced yesterday that it would acquire the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, a maker of corporate jets, for $5.3 billion in a deal that returns General Dynamics to a business it once shed.
The Gulfstream acquisition, a one-for-one stock swap that would give General Dynamics shares to Gulfstream shareholders, would add a new and potentially cyclical business to the General Dynamics line, which is heavily laden with armaments that are steady cash generators. 
 It would also move General Dynamics back to the aerospace industry, a business it stepped away from in the early 1990's when it sold Cessna Aircraft, a maker of business jets, to Textron and when it sold its F-16 fighter jet operations to Lockheed Martin as well as its missile division to Hughes Electronics.
The deal for Gulfstream elicited a mixed reaction on Wall Street. General Dynamics tumbled nearly 10 percent, or $6.1875, to $65.25, after having traded as low as $63.25 by midday. Still, while many on Wall Street were skeptical about the deal, others said Gulfstream would add a strong cash generator to the company, even if it took General Dynamics in a new direction.
"The deal makes a lot of sense from a financial perspective," said Pierre Chao, an analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "General Dynamics is adding a company with a solid background and great cash flow, which will allow them to fuel further defense acquisitions." He said the market was forgetting that General Dynamics used to be in the aerospace business.
Nicholas D. Chabraja, General Dynamics's chief executive, said Gulfstream "is well within our core competencies and one of the strategic areas where I said we would move."
He added that the company still had executives responsible for efficiencies in aircraft "and can help Gulfstream with its internal plans."
"This company hit us right in the gut as a very nice opportunity and a very fine company," he said.
Skeptics, however, wondered why General Dynamics would consider taking on a business-jet company at what may be the top of a decadelong business expansion. But, they acknowledged that a trend in the business-jet business toward fractional ownership, or a type of corporate time-share, should protect Gulfstream from the next economic downturn. Gulfstream currently has a $4 billion backlog of orders.
"General Dynamics's business may be boring, but they make a lots of cash," said Jon Kutler, president of Quarterdeck Investment Partners, a Los Angeles-based aerospace advisory firm. "Gulfstream is a commercial business that is being acquired near the top of a business cycle. It's a lot more volatile, although less volatile since the advent of fractional ownership. This is one that investors are scratching their heads over. But I think extremely highly of the General Dynamics management team, so you are willing to give them the benefit of the doubt on this one."
Gulfstream was bought for $825 million by the New York leveraged buyout firm of Forstmann Little & Company, which took the company public in 1996 and still owns 23 percent of the stock. The firm expects to gain a total of about $3 billion in cash and General Dynamics stock from the deal, which is expected to close in 90 to 120 days, assuming it gets shareholder and regulatory approval, as expected.
The current value of the Gulfstream acquisition was based on last Friday's closing price. The final price will be based on General Dynamics share price on the day the deal closes. The deal can be canceled if General Dynamics shares fell below $63 a share in the 15 days before the deal's closing.
"General Dynamics is not a company that makes ships, it's a company that makes money, and it will diversify into those areas that add to that," said Loren Thompson, an industry analyst at the Lexington Institute, an Arlington, Va., research firm. "Gulfstream has a superior backlog of orders; it's an area where General Dynamics has a long history and a lot of current management talent and, with the anticipated expansion of Pentagon spending, General Dynamics is not buying it at the top of its own business cycle."
Earlier this year, the Government blocked an attempt by General Dynamics to buy Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. for $1.4 billion, citing antitrust grounds. Mr. Chabraja of General Dynamics said of the two deals, "They were both perking along at the same time, and we were fully prepared to do both."
General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., which earned $364 million last year, or $2.86 a share, on sales of $5 billion, said Gulfstream would increase 1999 earnings by 25 cents a share and 2000 earnings by 35 cents a share. Gulfstream, based in Savannah, Ga., earned $225.3 million in 1998 on revenue of $2.4 billion.

HEADLINE: Merger Is Set By Makers of Farm Machines

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 17

 BODY:
The deal that was struck today to combine the Case Corporation and New Holland N.V., two of the world's largest makers of farm and construction equipment, is just the latest effort to consolidate an embattled farm industry.
Although the United States economy remains robust, the sharp drop in commodity prices that began just over a year ago has jolted nearly every company in the agriculture business, and many have chosen to combine in mergers that promise to cut costs and bring renewed hope to investors. 
 The deal making, of course, has raised concerns among some farm organizations that fear the long-term effects of a highly concentrated industry in which corporate farms dominate and smaller farmers have fewer and fewer choices.
But a host of companies tied to the agriculture market -- from seed and fertilizer concerns to tractor makers and farm cooperatives -- are rethinking the way they do business and finding ways to team up.
In the last year alone, DuPont, which has been moving aggressively to establish a position in the life-sciences business, has acquired Pioneer Hi-Bred, the world's largest seed company; Cargill and Continental Grain, the two largest grain traders, agreed to merge in November. And just last week, Farmland Industries and Cenex Harvest States, two of the nation's largest food cooperatives, agreed to join forces, creating a company with $20 billion in revenue.
Today, it was Case and New Holland officials saying that new synergies and productivity gains would create an awesome combination with the kind of global heft that would make the new entity a strong rival to Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment.
Case and New Holland had been suffering, like other farm equipment makers, through what analysts say is a nearly 25 percent drop in the sales of farm equipment the last year, with little expectation that the farm economy would improve much this year. Profits are down substantially from a year ago, and the stocks of both companies had been sharply depressed in recent months.
So today's deal, one that calls for New Holland, which is 71 percent owned by Fiat of Italy, to pay about $4.3 billion, or $55 a share, for Case suggests that restructuring at a time when globalization is all the rage was simply not enough for the farm equipment makers, according to analysts. There needed to be a bigger company to restructure.
The new company, which had combined sales of nearly $12 billion in 1998, will be based in Racine, Wis., where Case is now based. Jean-Pierre Rosso, the chief executive at Case who will head the new company, said at a news conference here that he expected the company to save up to $500 million annually within the next four years. The company will sell both the Case and New Holland lines of tractors, combines and construction equipment. But administrative and other operations will be fused and financial services outfits united in a company that will soon be renamed.
"This is all about cutting costs," said Lisa Shalett, who covers the farm equipment industry for Sanford C. Bernstein. "This is a huge deal, but we won't see one of these for a while; this was the last stroke in an evolutionary consolidation of the farm equipment industry."
Wall Street analysts say that because the agriculture industry is already so highly concentrated and because the Justice Department is scrutinizing this concentration, it is unlikely there will be other such deals.
Bold moves by Monsanto, DuPont, Cargill and several meat packers, including IBP, have also raised concern among farmers in recent years.
"We have very grave concerns about this whole concentration trend because when there is that kind of concentration, those with power exert more power," said Gene Paul, president of the National Farmers Organization in Ames, Iowa. "There are that many fewer buyers that we can buy from."
Mr. Paul said that his organization is most concerned about grain companies and food processors, but that the general trend is troublesome and one that farmers organizations are pushing the Justice Department to look into.
Todd J. Duvick, a food industry analyst at Bank of America, said the deal between Case and New Holland might be seen in its broadest context as a result of a farm economy that could remain depressed for some time because of a weak outlook for commodity prices around the globe and changes related to the Freedom to Farm Act.
Low commodity prices and pressures from big retailers are squeezing farmers and middlemen, thereby reaching suppliers of farm products and equipment. And that, he said, was what led to the Case-New Holland deal, which was brokered by Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman, Sachs and Lazard Freres.
"All of this is tied together," Mr. Duvick said. "This is a new era in agriculture, one in which we've already seen a major consolidation of the industry."

HEADLINE: Winnick Weaves Single Trans-Atlantic Cable Into Communications Empire

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 17

 BODY:
Two years ago, Gary Winnick, a financier with little experience in telecommunications, undertook a project to lay an optical fiber cable across the Atlantic Ocean.
Overnight, Mr. Winnick has become the telecommunications industry's newest, and by far one of its richest superstars. 
 With its announcement today that it is merging with U S West Inc., Mr. Winnick's company, Global Crossing Ltd. has entered the ranks of the nation's major telecommunications companies.
And Mr. Winnick has parlayed his initial personal investment of $15 million in the trans-Atlantic cable into a roughly 25 percent stake in Global Crossing worth more than $6 billion. That will make Mr. Winnick, 51, the largest shareholder in the company formed by the merger.
The stunning rise of Mr. Winnick and of Global Crossing is at least partly a result of investor frenzy for anything related to the Internet. Global Crossing's stock, which was priced at a split-adjusted $9.50 when first offered to the public Aug. 14, closed today at $60.25.
But Mr. Winnick, a former aide to Michael R. Milken, has been quick to seize upon the opportunity provided by the soaring stock to build an empire through mergers, not only with U S West but also with the Frontier Corporation, a long-distance company that Global Crossing agreed to acquire in March.
"I think he'd be the first to say he didn't envision what you see today," said Lodwrick M. Cook, the co-chairman of Global Crossing with Mr. Winnick. But he added: "He saw the opportunity to build quickly. He's the driving force behind the whole thing."
Mr. Winnick, who prefers to operate behind the scenes, agreed. "Sometimes things happen," he said. "But you need to get to the plate to have things happen."
Mr. Winnick is described by those who know him as a master salesman with a quick wit. He is also driven, even conducting evening business meetings while exercising on the treadmill in his Beverly Hills office, with company executives sitting around him. While Global Crossing is supposedly based in Bermuda, its executives work in Beverly Hills in the same building used by Pacific Capital Group, Mr. Winnick's investment firm.
He has been willing to spread the instant wealth his company has generated in order to quickly do mergers and recruit experienced executives. "He's actually one of those businessmen who does go for the win-win situation," said an investment banker who has worked with him. "He's not looking for the last nickel on the trade."
Mr. Winnick grew up in Roslyn, N.Y., and earned a degree in economics from C. W. Post College in Greenvale, N.Y. He worked in New York as a bond salesman for a predecessor of Drexel Burnham Lambert, and then transferred to the company's Los Angeles office in the late 1970's to become a close aide to Mr. Milken, who pioneered the market for junk bonds.
Mr. Winnick left Drexel in 1985, several years before the firm's collapse, to start his own investment fund, Pacific Asset Management. Mr. Milken was an investor in that fund, but he is not in Mr. Winnick's current company, Pacific Capital Group. Mr. Winnick was ordered by a court to testify in Mr. Milken's case in exchange for immunity from prosecution, but Mr. Milken, charged with violating securities laws, reached an agreement with prosecutors before the testimony took place.
Until Global Crossing, Mr. Winnick was a low-profile financier with mixed results. A furniture chain and a mattress company he bought in the late 1980's both declared bankruptcy within weeks of each other in 1991. He had more success with Ornda Healthcorp, a hospital company he sold to the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, and with Optel, a company that provided cable television service to apartments and was sold to Le Groupe Videotron. Mr. Winnick also owns a 27 percent stake in Playa Vista, a real estate development in Los Angeles in which Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks SKG will be building its studio.
Mr. Winnick said he was drawn to the trans-Atlantic cable project that became the seed of Global Crossing because deregulation and new technology are opening the telecommunications industry to new players.
Pacific Capital turned to CIBC World Markets, part of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, to finance most of the $750 million needed for the project. Funds associated with CIBC now own about 94 million shares in Global Crossing, worth $5.66 billion, making the transaction "without a doubt" the most profitable investment the company has ever made, said Dean Kehler, managing director and co-head of the high-yield group at CIBC World Markets.
Most undersea cables had been installed by consortiums of big telephone companies. With less bureaucracy, Global Crossing was able to move quickly, and finished the cable in time to catch a huge spurt of demand generated by the Internet.
"There was a huge pent-up demand and there was not enough capacity to meet it," said Michael Ruddy, a fiber optic analyst with Pioneer Consulting in Cambridge, Mass. Global Crossing fashioned itself as a carrier's carrier, selling capacity to telephone companies, not to end users. With the success of that first cable, still the only one the company has in operation, Mr. Winnick decided to turn that one project into a company and to build a worldwide network of trans-oceanic and terrestrial fiber optic cables linking the world's major cities.
Its agreements to merge with Frontier and U S West move Global Crossing toward becoming a full-fledged telecommunications carrier, serving both the retail and wholesale markets. That could add risks because other carriers, now its competitors, will be more reluctant to buy transmission capacity from Global.
Mr. Winnick has positioned Global to be a major telecommunications player by hiring a team of experienced executives, all of whom have become wealthy. Mr. Winnick has given stock to everyone in the company and to others close to him, including his housekeeper. Former President George W. Bush accepted stock in lieu of an $80,000 fee for making a speech at a Global Crossing event. That stock is now worth millions of dollars.
Mr. Cook, who had retired as chief executive of the Atlantic Richfield Company, was brought on early as vice chairman. Earlier this year, Mr. Winnick recruited Robert Annunziata, who had founded and built Teleport Communications, a company acquired by AT&T for $12 billion last year.
The recruiting has made Global Crossing top heavy by conventional standards, with two chairmen, two vice chairmen, a chief executive and a separate president. Mr. Winnick has been content to let others have the titles, knowing that he is the owner. But those involved in the company say there is little doubt about who is in charge.
Indeed, Mr. Winnick will not have an executive position in the company after it merges with U S West. Mr. Annunziata and Solomon D. Trujillo, the head of U S West, will be co-chairmen and co-chief executives. Mr. Winnick would not comment on his role in the combined company, but others say he will be on the board and remain a power behind the scenes.
"I don't think he'll ever turn his back on Global," Mr. Cook said. "He will do other things, yes, but he will be involved in Global."

HEADLINE: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;
ISRAELIS CHOOSE A NEW LEADER AND REMAKE THEIR PARLIAMENT

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, May 18

 BODY:
Israelis overwhelmingly elected Ehud Barak, the Labor Party leader, as their Prime Minister on Monday, rejecting the tumultuous leadership of Benjamin Netanyahu, whose galvanizing character has dominated Israel for three years.
In a complete reshuffling of the political deck, Israelis also remade their Parliament: The right wing withered as the center grew with four new parties, changing the balance of power. 
 Because Mr. Barak can now assemble a large bloc of secular parties, he could form a Government without any ultra-Orthodox representation. The ultra-Orthodox appear to have lost their exclusive role as a swing vote between left and right; instead, Russian immigrants and other centrists may exercise that power.
By this morning, with 99.9 percent of the ballots counted, Mr. Barak had 56 percent of the vote, to Mr. Netanyahu's 43.9 percent. Today was the second time that Israel had elected a Prime Minister directly. Mr. Barak now has 45 days in which to form a Government.
A highly decorated former general, Mr. Barak, 57, is a dovish hawk in the image of his assassinated mentor, Yitzhak Rabin, and the vote is a resounding call for a revival of the languishing peace effort between Israelis and Palestinians.
"If Yitzhak is looking down on us from where he may, he knows that we together will fulfill his legacy," Mr. Barak said in his victory speech. "We need to strengthen our country's security by moving forward to peace agreements."
Mr. Barak also sounded a call for unity. "It is my intention to be everyone's Prime Minister," he said. "All of Israel is part of each of us, and we extend a courageous hand to all, to secular and religious, to those of Ashkenazi and of Sephardic background, to those who immigrated from the former Soviet Union and from Ethiopia, to the Arabs, the Bedouins and the Circassians."
Within 35 minutes of the first television exit polls, before Mr. Barak made any comment, Mr. Netanyahu not only conceded defeat, American-style, but stepped down as the leader of the conservative Likud Party.
In the West Bank and Gaza, Palestinian officials gloated over the political demise of a leader whom they considered hostile. The Israeli radio reported open celebrations in the office of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who called to congratulate the new Israeli Prime Minister.
"Netanyahu fell into the trash bin of history," Fraih Abu Meddien, the Palestinians' justice minister, said in an interview in Gaza. "He will be gone forever and good riddance. He's a racist and no other Israeli leader will ever be as bad as he was. The Palestinian people were patient for three years through his arrogance. We helped bring him down. We are the ones who made this statue fall."
Shortly before midnight in Tel Aviv, a huge celebration erupted in Yitzhak Rabin Square, the site of the Prime Minister's assassination. With mixed emotions, tens of thousands of mostly young Israelis both cheered Mr. Barak's victory and lighted candles in a release of pent-up sorrow over Mr. Rabin's death in 1995.
"Rabin, we have won!" they shouted repeatedly into the balmy evening air, crying and hugging each other.
At the Tel Aviv Hilton Hotel, a few miles away, Mr. Netanyahu, a fixture in Israeli politics for 15 years, strode off the political stage quickly, cleanly, and with cordial congratulations to his opponent. Flanked by his wife, Sarah, and by a grim Ariel Sharon, his Foreign Minister, Mr. Netanyahu addressed weeping supporters with a seemingly serene look on his face.
"The nation decided and we respect that decision," Mr. Netanyahu said, stunning his audience, which is unaccustomed to the sight of their Prime Minister conceding anything. "That is the way it has to be in a democracy."
Mr. Netanyahu possibly chose to step down as party leader before he is pushed by several rivals. His Likud Party, traditionally one of the two major parties, suffered from his collapse: In 1996 Likud held 32 seats of the 120 seats in Parliament, but won only 19 this time.
Many defectors left for Shas, the ultra-Orthodox Sephardic party. In a stunning gain, Shas seems to have garnered six new seats in Parliament, giving it about 17, making it the third largest party after Likud and Labor, which lost seats, election analysts said.
But a larger representation for Shas does not mean more power. "Shas is in for four lean years now," Shahar Ilan, a religion reporter for the newspaper Haaretz said today, "whether it is a barely wanted coalition partner or whether it remains outside."
While Shas had endorsed Mr. Netanyahu, it has swung between left and right governments before as a supporter of the peace effort.
But in these elections and probably in the new Parliament, Russian immigrants, who seem to have split their ballots between the two candidates, represented the swing vote.
"We resisted all efforts to take sides," Natan Sharansky, leader of the Russians' Yisrael Baaliyah Party, said in an interview. "We were the party of the new immigrants, but now we can be considered simply as the one real moderate force, like a bridge between secular and nonsecular, left and right."
He added, "Look, I'm sorry for Bibi, we're old friends." He said the defeat of Mr. Netanyahu was "mainly personal, not ideological."
But part of Mr. Netanyahu's defeat did appear to be a rejection of the right wing's agenda on the peace effort, which is widely perceived as obstructionist. Most Israelis not only endorse the peace effort but also accept that a Palestinian state is inevitable.
According to a beeper message from the Prime Minister's office, President Clinton sent him a message: "I appreciate the hard work you did. You're a strong man with a strong historical awareness and we all believe you will be back." Mr. Netanyahu responded, "Thank you very much, but I'm taking a long vacation."
Reporters joked that it took Mr. Netanyahu's resignation to get Mr. Clinton, whose Administration has been critical of him, to call.
The people were less restrained. Many Israelis drove through the nighttime streets beeping their horns. "As soon as Bibi said he was resigning, the champagne came out, as did the pistachios, cake and popcorn," said Lisa Feinmesser, 51, an administrative assistant in Jersualem. "We're so sick of the man."
Looking drawn and defeated, Gila Gamliel, a 24-year-old Likudnik who lost her bid for Parliament, said, "Despite the great accomplishments of the Government, everyone was against us and against the Prime Minster out of personal hatred."
Mr. Barak, a kibbutz-born Israeli who spent 35 years in the army and retired as Chief of Staff, is brainy and complex. He has a centered confidence in his own judgments, which are based, like those of any serious military strategist, as much on input as on intuition.
He has conducted his campaign like a military exercise. Building on a network of army buddies, he revitalized the Labor Party's aging infrastructure with a far more professional campaign on the ground. In the last month, "One Israel" banners and workers have been far more highly visible than those of Likud.
Mr. Barak also relied on layers of American consultants, including two top American pollsters, who field-tested every question raised by Mr. Barak about the mood of the Israeli public and the sectors within it.
He personally sought to commandeer a remake of the Labor Party, which is traditionally both leftist and elitist in a peculiarly Israeli combination, into a party of the center. He ran at the head of the One Israel coalition, forged with Meimad, a moderate Orthodox group, and the Sephardic Gesher Party of David Levy, the Moroccan-born former Foreign Minister for Mr. Netanyahu.
As a moderate at the helm of the left, Mr. Barak sees himself following the lead of Bill Clinton and Tony Blair. His political advertising has stressed his military background, which includes a string of derring-do missions that are an integral part of Israeli legend. His campaign has repeatedly broadcast images of him as his troops liberated a Sabena airplane from Palestinian terrorists in 1972, for instance.
He has said he would move quickly to kick-start the moribund Israeli-Palestinian peace effort, to plan the withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon and to reopen negotiations with Syria over Lebanon and the Golan Heights.
Before the elections, many Israelis said they considered Mr. Barak and Mr. Netanyahu to be cut from the same cloth, as Ashkenazi members of the elite who both served in the same military unit and both studied in the United States. The Israelis said they were confused about what differentiated the men's stands on peace, since both said they supported a tough peace with security.
Mr. Netanyahu's Government was dissolved in December, and the peace effort was frozen and important economic and governmental decisions were deferred.
The two men hold very different views about Israel's position:
Mr. Netanyahu believes Israel to be in a constant state of threat from its Arab neighbors, approaches them with suspicion and has refused to make concessions until concessions were given.
Mr. Barak, on the other hand, sees Israel as the strongest country in a tough neighborhood, negotiating from an advantage of greater military might, higher economic standing and a sounder, more democratic political system. He says that peace agreements must be reached before conditions are perfect.
"I want to give a new momentum to peace agreements," he said in an interview in April. "I'm not going to compromise any of our vital interest. I will definitely fight against terror: I did it all my life. But I learned during many years -- decades -- of fighting that the right way to bring about personal security to Israelis and overall security to Israel is through peace agreement with our neighbors."
Israelis cast two ballots, one for the direct election of the Prime Minister, the other for one of 31 parties running for the Parliament.
Four and a quarter million Israelis voted, almost all the adults in the country. Voter turn-out is always high here. Official statistics put it at 80 percent this time but, given that about 10 percent of the population lives abroad and there are no absentee ballots, the figure is closer to 90 percent of eligible residents.
All the passion that has been missing from the campaign poured into the streets today. Election Day is a holiday, and it was festive, like a summer block party. At every junction, children held plastic banners, and balconies across the country were strung with huge photographs of Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Barak.

HEADLINE: The Latest in Automotive Fashion Calls for Mix and Match

BYLINE: By JIM McCRAW; Jim McCraw is a freelance automotive writer based in Detroit.

 BODY:
HORTICULTURISTS have given us better-tasting tomatoes, more beautiful, hardier roses and more prolific varieties of corn by creating hybrids -- marrying the best traits of two or more strains again and again until the desired result is achieved.
But now the hybrid has come to the automotive industry. We're not talking about hybrids with diesel-electric, gasoline-electric or fuel-cell engines. These are new vehicles with regular gasoline engines, many of which are already in showrooms. 
 The first true hybrid was the American minivan, invented by Chrysler in 1984 as a combination of a front-wheel-drive car, a delivery van and a station wagon. Shorter and smaller than a delivery van and easier to load, it drove as a car did and acted in the manner of a station wagon, without the suburban-family, wood-trim baggage. Now this hybrid is as mainstream as a sedan.
Perhaps the best example of a forthcoming new-age hybrid is the Lincoln Blackwood, arriving on the market in a year or so. It has the face and the front two-thirds of a Lincoln Navigator four-door luxury sport utility vehicle. There are four leather bucket seats inside, lots of expensive and exotic wood trim and all the usual Lincoln amenities. But behind the second row of bucket seats are a solid steel wall and a rear window, a pickup-truck bed with a hydraulically operated bed cover and, at the end of the bed, a pair of Dutch doors instead of a tailgate. The Blackwood is lower than the Navigator because it has only two-wheel drive.
So it's not a sport utility and it's not a luxury sedan (even though, on the inside, it looks just like one), and it's not exactly a pickup truck that you can just throw a load of bricks into. It's somewhere in between, a luxury utilitruck.
Another recent hybrid is the Chrysler PT Cruiser, which will be offered for sale later this year. It's essentially a 2000 Plymouth Neon front-drive sedan chassis with a retro, late-1930's, four-door sedan body adapted to it. Five inches shorter in length but seven inches taller, the PT Cruiser offers almost 17 cubic feet more interior space and a flat rear hatch. It has a multifunctional interior the size and shape of a minivan's.
It's not a Neon; it's not a hot rod, and it's not a van. It's somewhere in between, a neo-van.
There are still other hybrids coming onto the market. Ford has shown its Explorer Sport Trac, a four-door sport utility with a pickup bed in place of the third seat, and Nissan has shown its S.U.T., or Sport Utility Truck, a truck/sport utility hybrid very similar in concept to the Sport Trac. Both will serve the market that wants full-size seating for four or more people, plus four-wheel-drive and storage space in back.
Too small to be called crew-cabs (large pickups with four full doors and a full bed), but packing plenty of space and utility, these are sport utilitrucks. They will be joined later this year by the Dodge Dakota four-door pickup truck.
Then there are the small, boxy sport utilities built up from front-wheel-drive passenger-car platforms. These include the Honda CR-V, the Subaru Forester and the Toyota RAV-4, which use the Civic, Legacy and Camry platforms, respectively, to make trucks out of cars.
They aren't cars, though they have passenger-car underpinnings, and they're not true sport utilities because they don't offer the extra equipment for tough going off-road. But they do have four-wheel-drive, tall bodies, roof racks and rear cargo room. They could be called sport-cutes, mini-utes or utilicars.
Isuzu, the Japanese subsidiary of General Motors, has a pair of very interesting hybrids, one on the market and one in the concept stage. The first is the 2000 VehiCross, so named because it is a cross between a three-door sport utility vehicle, a sporty coupe and a gigantic running shoe.
Driven by design rather than function, it has enormous B-pillars (the pieces of metal between the front and rear side windows), trapezoidal rear side windows and polypropylene panels all the way around the bottom half, with a big plastic grille section to match. It looks very different from the average compact sport utility. It's difficult to enter or exit the rear seat, and difficult to see through the rear window. One expert calls it "the Camaro of sport utilities."
The other, more dramatic Isuzu hybrid is the VX-O2, which was shown for the first time last month at the New York Auto Show. The VX-O2 has an upper half that looks like that of a 50's two-seat sport roadster, including streamlined headrests, and a bottom half that is a VehiCross four-wheel-drive S.U.V. It looks like a sports car, but it has only two doors, no rear hatch for cargo and no roof rack. So it's not a sport utility; it's an off-roadster, something in between a roadster and a sport utility.
AUTOMOTIVE manufacturers are interested in hybrids because they may attract new, in-between customers who are not in the market for the original or source vehicle, like the Navigator, and whose needs are better served by the hybrid. This way, manufacturers can say, "Yeah, we have that," no matter how idiosyncratic the request.
Hybrids are also relatively inexpensive to produce. The pricey engineering and development have already been done on the source vehicle, and the new parts, like the sheet metal and pickup beds, can be adapted from existing models or made cheaply. They can be built in low volumes on existing assembly lines from many existing parts, providing economies of scale and thus good profit margins.
ED MOLCHANY, the Explorer Sport Trac brand manager at Ford, the company that sells more sport utilities than any other, says of the forthcoming Sport Trac: "We're always researching what customers want, and we think we've found something, a demand that's not being met out there right now. The Sport Trac will broaden the whole S.U.V. segment. A lot of people don't want to haul dirty things inside their S.U.V.'s, or they can't carry tall things. It's a little bit different need. We're trying to focus on needs more than just demographics."
Not everyone buys this argument. Jim Hall, the vice president of AutoPacific Group, a consulting firm in Detroit, says these so-called hybrids aren't adding units to the sales total; they're just different versions of vehicles already for sale. "Ford is making the truck market far less profitable," he said, "because they're niching the truck market with variations and permutations. The more of those you add, the less profit there is per unit. Initially, they may be able to price at a premium for them, and that's fine when you're the only player, but if you start to niche the market and other manufacturers respond, you may all be fighting over 50,000 units a year."
Mr. Hall said the Ford Sport Trac and Nissan S.U.T. are just scaled-down versions of vehicles already on the market: full-size crew-cab pickups with four doors and seating for six. He says they have limited utility because their shortened pickup beds will not carry a 4-by-8-foot sheet of plywood.
"These products, while they may have some market, ultimately combine the worst characteristics of sport utilities and pickup trucks," he said. "They don't have the secure storage area of a sport utility. Everything you carry is exposed to the elements, like a pickup truck, but they have the limited load space of a compact sport utility. If you're carrying manure, they're fine. These things aren't well thought out."
Mr. Hall added: "The manufacturers are all trying to find The Next Big Thing, and The Next Big Thing has never been a cross between two ideas. It has been a unique idea that stands on its own."

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Cars

LENGTH: 3307 words

HEADLINE: CARS AND THE ENVIRONMENT;
Can Motor City Come Up With A Clean Machine?

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
WILLIAM C. FORD JR., the new 42-year-old chairman of the Ford Motor Company, became an environmentalist the way many baby boomers did. As a boy, he loved to hike, fish and go camping; he hated to revisit a spot only to find that someone else had made a mess of it. In high school, he volunteered to spend afternoons picking up trash along a nearby river. At Princeton University, he read books by radical environmentalists and stayed up late discussing how to save the earth.
Then he joined the family business as a vehicle-planning analyst in 1979, and got a shock when he tried to raise environmental concerns. "Coming to an old-line auto company, people looked at me like I was a Bolshevik for bringing it up, for even asking the questions," he said. 
 Whether the problems were air and water pollution from factories, or tailpipe emissions from the cars that came off the assembly lines, managers then had no interest in taking action, Mr. Ford said. As Ford's director of business strategy in the early 1990's, he sent out a memorandum calling a meeting on environmental policy -- only to be warned immediately by the company's lawyers that even writing the memorandum, much less holding the meeting, could be used against Ford in an environmental lawsuit.
On several occasions, Mr. Ford said, he reached the point where he told his wife that he was going to leave the company to form an environmentalist group. "My friends and my wife always convinced me that the impact I could have would be far greater if I stayed," said Mr. Ford, sitting in the same conference room where he had held his meeting on environmental policy over the lawyers' objections. "And they were right, ultimately, but they were more patient than I was."
After decades of often vociferous hostility toward the environmental movement, Ford Motor and the rest of the auto industry are beginning to show some interest in improving their records on pollution. While car makers are still capable of rousing the ire of environmentalists, notably by increasing their output of gas-guzzling but high-profit sport utility vehicles, attitudes within the industry are slowly but perceptibly changing.
A new generation of auto executives is taking charge, one that views environmental values as part of mainstream American life. Some, like Mr. Ford, are relatively young; some are older executives who have moved into the auto industry from other businesses, like detergent manufacturing, that came to terms with environmentalists long ago. While a few foreign auto makers, notably Honda, have touted their environmental records for years, domestic auto makers are just starting to see theirs as a marketing strength, giving them a financial incentive to compete on who can be greenest.
"Market survey after market survey tells us environmental issues are increasingly important to our customers," said Harry J. Pearce, the vice chairman of General Motors.
Until recently, virtually all of the auto industry's improvements were forced by Government regulation and were bitterly fought at every turn. To some extent, that is still the case; the industry fiercely opposes any tightening of fuel-economy regulations, for example, despite evidence that gasoline consumption contributes directly to global warming.
Yet now, many auto makers are also beginning to look for ways to clean up their factories and the vehicles they sell without waiting for regulators to step in. The main example so far has been Ford's decision, beginning with the 1999 model year, to make all its sport utility vehicles roughly as clean as cars, instead of continuing to exploit a loophole in Federal regulations that allows the off-road vehicles to emit several times more pollution per mile than cars do. Ford is also buying junkyards, with a plan to reuse more auto parts instead of letting them clog landfills.
Other auto makers are also taking voluntary steps. All of Honda's American-made Civics and Accords now meet California's strict emissions standard, and its Odyssey minivan and Passport sport utility vehicle have very low emissions, although the CR-V sport utility does not. DaimlerChrysler is working on a host of initiatives, like working on low-pollution synthetic diesel. And General Motors has spent hundreds of millions of dollars to develop and market an electric car, while helping the Nature Conservancy to buy and then preserve the habitats of rare species.
Perhaps most surprisingly, the auto industry did fairly little lobbying against the Clinton Administration's proposal earlier this month to require much lower tailpipe emissions, particularly from sport utility vehicles and pickups. Instead, it demanded, and got, new Federal regulations requiring oil companies to sell much cleaner gasoline -- a decision that will make it easier to produce clean-burning cars, but enraged the oil industry.
Environmentalists are divided on how much credit to give the auto makers. Some, like John DeCicco, the transportation program director at the Washington-based American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, are fairly generous. "The management of the auto industry is part of our American society, which has internalized environmental values over the last three decades," he said.
OTHERS are more dubious. One is Daniel Becker, a vocal critic of the auto industry for nearly a quarter-century, first as an aide to Ralph Nader, and now as the Sierra Club's director for energy policy and global warming. Mr. Becker said that Ford's decision to clean up its sport utility vehicles was the only significant, voluntary step that Detroit had taken in recent decades to improve the environment, and he questioned whether other steps would come soon.
The auto industry still bankrolls various groups, like the Coalition for Vehicle Choice, that criticize Federal fuel-economy rules and international efforts to limit global warming, Mr. Becker noted. Auto advertising executives continue trying to persuade Americans that relatively unregulated, high-profit sport utility vehicles are appropriate substitutes for cars, he said. Indeed, with profits on full-size sport utility vehicles running at $12,000 or more apiece, auto makers have increased production and sales in this category more than sixfold since the early 1990's. "In terms of policy decisions, in terms of product lines," Mr. Becker said, "I don't think the change has started in a dramatic way."
Auto industry leaders say they deserve more credit. John G. Smale, a marketer of soaps and detergents who became the chairman of Procter & Gamble and then of General Motors, said car makers had caught up with other businesses in understanding that environmental issues were important to consumers.
"I think G. M. was slower than P. & G., certainly in coming to that realization, but I think that's true of the rest of the industry too," said Mr. Smale, who is now chairman of the G. M. board's powerful executive committee. "I think, by and large now, the industry sees it the same way."
Nobody disputes that the sheer size of the auto industry makes it tremendously important to the environment. G. M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler are the world's three largest companies in terms of sales; their closest rivals are trading companies and retailers, which do not actually make the products they sell, followed by big oil companies. For all the attention that Internet and software companies receive, G. M. still has 11 times the sales of Microsoft and 22 times as many employees.
Without question, the most dramatic shift in environmental stance recently has been at Ford. Alexander Trotman, the company's chairman and chief executive until the end of last year, led auto industry criticisms of the efforts to limit global warming, questioning the scientific basis for environmentalists' concerns. He was also skeptical of moves to further reduce tailpipe emissions. The decision to build cleaner-burning sport utilities was led by another top Ford executive, Jacques Nasser, a 51-year-old ally of Mr. Ford's.
Mr. Trotman retired early this year, and Mr. Nasser replaced him as the company's chief executive; Mr. Ford became chairman. A great-grandson of Henry Ford's, he won the family's confidence to run the company, even though he was one of the younger members of the Fords' fourth generation. A nephew of Henry Ford 2d's, he had not grown up as heir apparent at the family-controlled company.
Mr. Ford and Mr. Nasser share a strong interest in the environment, although not necessarily the same interest in nature. The differences are apparent even in their offices. Mr. Ford's looks like a greenhouse: while one wall is a floor-to-ceiling window with a 20-mile view across metropolitan Detroit, most of the vista is obscured by potted ficus trees. More plants festoon the desk, coffee table and conference table, while the long shelf behind his desk is covered with peace lilies under special growing lights. "I need a machete," Mr. Ford quipped as he walked in.
MR. NASSER'S office next door is, by contrast, a desert. A single, small plant sits incongruously on the floor in front of a gigantic window as big as Mr. Ford's. The plant, which has coiled leaves that resemble spikes, does not look happy.
Nicknamed "Jac the Knife" because of his cost-cutting measures in Ford Motor's European operations during the early 90's, Mr. Nasser never mentioned camping or rivers or great books when asked how he became interested in the environment. Instead, he plunged into an 11-minute soliloquy on the importance of brands and how their images were formed in the public mind.
In an increasingly global economy, Mr. Nasser said, consumers increasingly turn to a few well-known brands, like Volvo's small but famous car-making division, which Ford Motor bought earlier this year. At the same time, the rise of the Internet and other forms of communications has made it possible for information about a company's activities in any city to spread quickly all over the world. So to have a popular, global brand that consumers will seek out, a company must be a good corporate citizen everywhere, Mr. Nasser concluded.
"Brands are becoming more important, and corporate image is becoming more important on a global basis," he said. "And it's very difficult, I think, in today's environment to have a global image that is substantially different from your local image."
In other words, car makers can no longer put big, polluting factories in out-of-the-way communities and hope no one will notice. Nor can they make particularly dirty vehicles and hope no one will notice. Rival auto makers estimate that Ford's cleaner sport utility vehicles are costing the company at least $100 million a year, mainly for bigger catalytic converters, an expense Ford says it is not passing on to consumers. While a few other S.U.V.'s are being cleaned up, most are not, and rival executives are criticizing Ford for taking action.
Bernard Robertson, DaimlerChrysler's senior vice president for engineering, said Ford had to do something in response to criticisms of its huge Ford Expedition sport utility vehicle and its even larger Ford Excursion, which will go on sale this autumn. The Excursion will be the world's largest S.U.V., taller than Michael Jordan and weighing as much as three Ford Escorts; with its 44-gallon gas tank and a fuel economy as low as 10 miles per gallon, it has been dubbed the "Ford Valdez" by the Sierra Club. "With the Expedition and Excursion, Ford has gone to the extremes of consumption," Mr. Robertson said.
Mr. Ford said that he understood the criticisms of the Excursion. But he maintained that some auto maker was inevitably going to build such a giant vehicle, and at least Ford was designing it to be as clean as most cars.
SUCH excuses do not satisfy Mr. Becker of the Sierra Club, who said that while he believed that Mr. Ford genuinely cared about the environment, he doubted that such views had spread widely through the company. "This is a very large ship, and he's a small rudder so far," Mr. Becker said.
Mr. Ford has also shifted his company's position on global warming, but not as much as environmentalists would like. He said there was a scientific basis for concern, but that any international agreement to limit the problem would have to include developing nations. Many environmentalists believe this to be politically impossible.
Some environmentalists also fault the auto industry for not having sold many alternatives to the gasoline-powered car. All of the big auto manufacturers are spending heavily to research alternative technologies, like electric cars, which use batteries or, more recently, fuel cells, which generate electricity by combining hydrogen and oxygen without combustion. Yet alternative-fuel cars have become a chimera that has receded ever further into the future for most of this century. Regulators in California and New York required a decade ago that electric cars be widely available by now. They retreated from that goal, however, as technological advances proved inadequate and as gasoline-powered cars became steadily cleaner.
G. M. has actually put an electric vehicle, the EV1 coupe, on the market in California and Arizona. But its limited range and small passenger compartment have made it a marketing failure, with only 289 leased in 1997 and 264 last year, many by environmentalists and image-conscious celebrities. Mr. Smale said G .M. had learned some valuable technological lessons from the EV1, including how to develop better batteries for electric cars.
Ford sells most of the alternative-fuel vehicles in the United States, but these are mainly electric and natural gas-powered pickup trucks and vans purchased by utilities and Government agencies. Honda and Toyota plan to appeal to the public soon by selling small cars powered by a combination of a gasoline engine and an electric battery.
AMERICA'S small-car market is shrinking, however, and both companies plan to ship limited numbers of their vehicles here. They will also have to sell them below the high cost of manufacturing them.
Despite lavish Federal subsidies and numerous promises by auto makers to put high-mileage cars on sale by 2004, there is little sign of continuing public interest in fuel economy. This is probably linked to the fact that gasoline is still cheaper than bottled water in most of the country, even though gas prices recently rebounded.
The 10 most fuel-efficient cars on the market now account together for less than 1 percent of sales in the United States, while auto makers no longer even bother putting fuel-economy statistics in their advertisements. They have found that such information does not draw customers.
BARRING another energy crisis, the main environmental issue in the United States is likely to remain the ever-growing fleet of gasoline-powered cars being driven ever more miles, thereby contributing to smog and global warming. Alternative-fuel vehicles are most likely to be introduced in Europe and East Asia. That's where gasoline costs $4 a gallon and up, and where people are more willing to accept small cars that are suitable for city driving but less so for the highway, said Robert C. Purcell, G. M.'s executive director of advanced technology vehicles.
G.M., in particular, used to have a grim reputation for refusing to acknowledge that environmental problems even existed. David Lewis, an automotive historian at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor who worked as a speech writer for two G. M. presidents from 1959 to 1965, said company policy then was to insist it was the oil refineries and other businesses, not cars, that caused air pollution.
"If we were accused of contributing to air pollution, we would simply say nothing had been proved," Mr. Lewis said.
Not only did G. M.'s cars pollute the air, but so did its factories. Trying to show that the river next to one of its assembly plants was clean in the early 1960's, G. M. officials dumped in live fish in front of television cameras, which filmed the fish as they swam around. The next morning, after the cameras had left, Mr. Lewis said, workers returned to scoop out the fish, which were by then floating belly up.
G. M. has recently begun improving its efforts regarding the environment, with John F. Smith Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive, joining the board of the Nature Conservancy, following the lead of Mr. Smale, a longtime member of the conservancy's board.
Having seen customers avoid detergents that included phosphates in the early 1970's, Mr. Smale came to the chairmanship of G. M. in 1992 with a strong appreciation of the risks for companies tarred as environmentally insensitive. He began lecturing G. M. managers on the importance of the issue. The company's current executives, he said, "realize that a lot of people in the country care about environmental responsibilities."
Until the last few months, some of the strongest criticisms of environmentalists have come from the former Chrysler Corporation. Robert J. Eaton, the company's chairman, and Robert A. Lutz, the vice chairman, were outspokenly skeptical of claims that global warming might be a problem. A brilliant car designer who resents any criticism of his industry, Mr. Lutz published a business-advice book last year in which he briefly compared "environmental extremists" to Communists, saying that both sought to eliminate the public's freedom to travel.
Mr. Lutz retired last year -- he now runs a car battery company; Mr. Eaton, now a co-chairman of DaimlerChrysler A.G., is expected to retire soon. Since Chrysler was acquired late last year by Daimler-Benz A.G., a leader in research on fuel cells and other environmentally sensitive technologies, the combined company has shown more enthusiasm for cleaner vehicles.
To the constant irritation of Detroit auto executives, foreign auto makers have had relatively little trouble with American environmentalists. Most top-selling foreign cars are fairly fuel-efficient because they were designed in countries where gasoline is expensive. During the 1970's, Japanese auto makers came up with cleaner engines for their small cars at a time when American auto makers were still contending that low-emissions technology was unfeasible.
But while foreign cars may be ubiquitous in coastal cities like New York and Los Angeles, they remain less common in the Midwest. G. M. still sells more cars and other family vehicles in the United States each year than every Japanese and European auto maker combined.
The harmony between foreign auto makers and American environmentalists may yet fade, as the foreign companies have begun to sell larger vehicles. Toyota, in particular, has been moving aggressively into the market for S.U.V.'s, while setting a fairly slow timetable for reducing their emissions. But after decades of hostility toward Detroit, most environmentalists still focus on auto makers based in Michigan.
The younger American auto industry executives want to change this pattern. They insist that as an older generation of leaders continues to retire, environmental progress will continue.
Mr. Ford said that during his 20-year ascent through the company ranks, he was often struck by how many other young managers were worried about the company's environmental performance. They were thwarted from doing much, Mr. Ford said, because "there were a few people in key management positions that didn't want to hear of it."
The growing number of environmentally committed people moving into positions of responsibility in the auto industry will enable further initiatives to clean up the world's air and water, Mr. Ford said.
He added, "I'm not sure, if I were chairman 10 years ago, that the world would have been ready for my views."
