HEADLINE: CARS AND THE ENVIRONMENT;
Even in Cleaner-Running Machines, Looks Will Count

BYLINE: By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI; Joseph Giovannini is an architecture critic and an architectural designer in New York.

 BODY:
The vroom is gone, or going. So is the heft of steel and the muscular body. Made of magnesium, aluminum and plastic composites, powered by sustainable-source fuels, the coming generation of pollution-conscious cars is ultraquiet and ultralight. They promise to change the rules of how a car feels, looks and operates, as well as how it affects the environment.
The transition from combustion to alternative power parallels the shift a century ago, when the carriage dropped the horse on its way to becoming an automobile. What is the next leap forward in the evolutionary chain? Will there be funky Hush Puppy designs that wear their greenness on their fenders? Streamlined designs that slip through the air like a Brancusi? Conventionalized models that reassure buyers about the new technology? 
 In July, the Museum of Modern Art will exhibit the tip of the iceberg to come in "Different Roads: Automobiles for the Next Century," a show of eight energy-efficient cars more environmentally benign than their predecessors. Christopher Mount, a curator in the museum's department of architecture and design, has selected a range of modestly priced cars already on the road, in production or in prototype.
A departure for MOMA, the exhibition does not display cars primarily as works of art, but as a preview of environmental issues relating to the potentially earth-devastating effect of the car in the next century, when developing countries develop. "What happens when everyone in China gets a car?" Mr. Mount asks.
Two forces are driving the current redesign. The first is the new, alternative fuel-source technology itself. Smaller engines mean shorter or nonexistent hoods. Improved fuel efficiency demands lighter, more compact cars, including two-seat cars designed just for commuting. Because they don't have to be cooled, electric engines require no grille. But they do need no-nonsense streamlining to reduce drag and to maximize miles between recharge.
The second force is market demand and design vision. "Folks may be interested in the environment, but they're not willing to sacrifice for it themselves," said Robert Q. Riley, a car designer who wrote "Alternative Cars in the 21st Century" (Society of Automotive Engineer, 1994). "Environment is a secondary benefit. Buyers still need to be seduced, and you don't do that by taking a conventional car and making it small and cheap. Environmentally friendly autos need to be friendly and fun in themselves; they have to be a new toy."
Gerhard Steinle, the former president of Mercedes-Benz Advance Design of North America, in Irvine, Calif., agreed. "If you take the roaring engine away, and people don't get anything besides that humming turbine sound, they'll be disappointed," said Mr. Steinle, now the president of Prisma Design International, a car design consultant in Irvine. "So you have to create something exciting to create that 'wow' effect for the neighbors."
He suggested that a compensatory kind of "entertainment" might be "an incredible audio" and telecommunications system, including a hands-free telephone, a navigation system and E-mail and Internet access integrated into the dashboard.
Mr. Steinle added: "When you create a small vehicle, you have to be careful that it doesn't look too babyish or cartoonish. It can't be a baby Benz. It has to have its own character, so that a serious businessman doesn't look like he's driving his daughter's car on Saturdays."
The surprise of this summer's MOMA show is that the eye already accepts these cars. But then, Mr. Mount said, "People aren't going to buy new technology in a wild-looking new car -- you have to put it in a shape they recognize."
Many other factors are at work conventionalizing the design of these new cars: existing safety requirements, basic human ergonomics and strong financial incentives to adapt existing bodies and off-the-shelf parts and components to the new cars.
The Ford Ka, which resembles Volkswagen's New Beetle and is already on the road in Europe, is one of the more charming cars in the show. The Ka, a very-high mileage gasoline-powered vehicle, is a persona car that changes the subject from its diminutive size to its character. Friendly, bulbous, lovable, the Ka has the appeal of a pet. But its rounded headlights and other refinements stop it from becoming an oversimplified cartoon character on wheels.
"There is a quality in the vehicle that moves you away from the idea of performance, but not toward cheapness or sacrifice," Mr. Riley said. "The New Beetle has made designers think that a dramatic shape breakthrough can excite the public."
Besides, Mr. Steinle noted, "Persona doesn't cost anything."
The Fiat Multipla, an offbeat minivan also in the show, is modest in size and charmingly awkward, designed with an upright passenger cab with lots of glass, within which seats can be removed for transporting goods. Powered by a clean-burning engine available in several forms (one can use a combination of gasoline and methane), the Multipla was conceived from the inside. It makes no visual attempt at muscle or even stealth, but shifts design rules toward the pokey end of the spectrum: it's a car with an idea -- versatility.
But then all the cars that will be parked in MOMA's garden this summer are surprisingly unassuming -- especially when compared with the sculptured studs of the 1952 MOMA show, like the Aston-Martin model D.B.2. These cars are economy cars; none are flamboyant or visually radical.
Mr. Riley warned: "If you just downsize a four-wheel car, you create a cheap car that nobody wants. The idea is to define something that in the minds of consumers is not a traditional automobile. People look at the list of features through different eyes, so they don't expect leather upholstery and electric windows. This allows you to downsize or downweight a vehicle and create a marketable car."
He thinks of them as efficiency cars as against "cheap" econobox minicars. "Think in terms of entirely new transportation products that give consumers the intangible benefits they want," he said.
Mr. Riley, who heads Robert Q. Riley Enterprises, Product Design and Development, in Scottsdale, Ariz., is himself working on the XR-3, a three-wheel suspension car akin to the Mercedes F300 Life Jet concept vehicle, and the Project 32 Slalom. All are three-wheel hybrids with the cornering dynamics of a motorcycle and the safety and comfort of a car. "When you break into a three wheel," he said, "you naturally say that this is a different kind of vehicle, which allows you to define new standards for what to put into a car."
Or on it. Mr. Steinle, for example, said that some of his design students, pursuing a more radical "Earth-shoe" approach, have proposed high-efficiency cars clad with rusting metals.
"You always have to be honest," he said. "You can't make an electric vehicle, for example, look like a muscle car." But, he said, the EV1, another car in the show, boasts a sleek dynamic shape because "that's a necessity for an electric vehicle."
Mr. Riley added: "We don't know what the technology is finally going to be, so we're not going to know for the next 10 years where design is going. We're in a state of transition. It's hard to envision the future when you're on this side of change."

HEADLINE: CARS AND THE ENVIRONMENT;
Clearing the Air In the Land of Smog

BYLINE: By BRUCE NEWMAN; Bruce Newman, who covered motor sports for Sports Illustrated, is a freelance writer living in Venice, Calif.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IN the summer of 1943, a year and a half after the attack on Pearl Harbor, people were still nervously scanning the skies here to see if anything was going to materialize above the horizon.
Something did. 
 The Japanese never came, but that summer, for the first time, the sky itself attacked. With visibility reduced to three blocks and residents reporting difficulty breathing, nausea and stinging eyes, local officials decided the mysterious cloud had resulted from a "gas attack" and blamed a nearby chemical plant. But when the plant was shut down, the cloud did not go away.
It never would.
Now when people study the skies here, it is often to measure the smog. The problem grew so much worse as the number of cars in California quadrupled over the next three decades that, in 1977, the worst year on record, smog alerts warning people with respiratory problems to stay indoors were issued on 121 days in Los Angeles.
"The air has been visible for a long time out here," said David Roe, a senior lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, a New York-based research and advocacy group.
This meant that when state officials finally declared that the sky was falling, you could see it coming down. In the mid-1970's, birds, overcome by pollution, routinely fell from the sky above the San Diego Freeway, and the state began to devise a plan to reduce emissions without disempowering its voters or its motors.
Californians hold strong views on the environment (they are in favor of it), and even stronger views on cars (anyone trying to remove them from their vehicles will have to pry the steering wheels from their cold, dead hands). "You've got a very high majority of people who want clean air, and care about it," Mr. Roe said, "and a 99 percent majority who want to stay in their cars."
This situation accounts for the polarized debate here on how to clean up car and truck emissions, the source of two-thirds of the state's air pollution. "It's very hard to run a debate when one side says you're killing our children, and the other side says you're killing the economy," said Peter Passell, an economist at the Milken Institute, a nonprofit economic research organization in Santa Monica, Calif. "People on both sides have tended to say outrageous things and then settle for whatever they could get."
The two sides seemed to fall willingly into their roles of white-hatted environmental heroes and evil polluters, hats blackened with soot. It was customary for car makers to send an expert witness to the state's hearings on environmental regulations to announce that whatever it was, auto companies were against it.
"That's usually the position you're put in," said Kelly Brown, Ford Motor Company's director of environmental and safety engineering. "Some of the early guys from Detroit said, 'If you make that a law, and I don't have a clue how to do it, you could put me out of business.' I think they believed it. So it started in kind of a contentious way. We've learned to be more artful."
When the California Air Resources Board in Sacramento adopted new low-emission vehicle regulations in 1990, the state assumed the role of technical and legislative laboratory for the nation. The Environmental Protection Agency, with plenty of other messes to clean up, voluntarily ceded a large measure of its authority to California.
"E.P.A. has historically allowed things to be tested in California, proven to be viable and then has adopted them as the law for the rest of the country," said Barry Wallerstein, the executive officer of the powerful South Coast Air Quality Management District, based in Diamond Bar, Calif.
Among the results: The catalytic converter, which is now standard equipment on all vehicles made in the United States, was required first by California in 1975, and auto makers have moved almost exclusively to fuel-injected engines because they could not meet California emissions standards using traditional carburetors.
WHILE there is a long way to go -- California still has the dirtiest air in the nation -- the initiatives have nevertheless reduced the state's air pollution to one-third its level in the mid-1950's. When cleaner-burning gasoline was required by the state in 1996, it reduced pollutants by 20 percent. Because Californians use, on average, more than 400 gallons of gas a year, this was the equivalent of taking 3.5 million cars off the road.
The switch in fuels met some initial resistance from the petroleum industry. That faded, however, when other technologies bubbling in the California laboratory -- fuel cells, gas and electric hybrids, even improved battery-powered cars -- began to threaten the market share of the century-old internal-combustion engine.
Experiments with alternative fuel technologies, though widely publicized, have met with mixed success. In the first round of low-emission vehicle regulations, auto makers were required to make 3 percent of the vehicles they sold in California zero-emitting by the end of 1998.
"The only way you could really meet that," Mr. Brown said, "unless you wanted to consider sails or rubber bands, was with an electric vehicle of some sort."
General MOTORS soon began leasing its battery-powered EV1 car through Saturn dealers in California, but the car's range was limited. With the drumbeat growing for fuel-cell cars and other hybrid-powered ultra low-emitting vehicles and super ultra low-emitting vehicles, the electric car looked like an expensive dead end.
More than a year ago, Ford and DaimlerChrysler formed a partnership to develop fuel-cell cars; recently, G. M. and Toyota formed an alliance to do the same. Ford and DaimlerChrysler have vowed to have a demonstration fleet of 30 fuel-cell cars and 15 buses on the streets by next year -- in California, naturally.
Despite this progress, there have been detours. Last year, smog in Los Angeles crept back up to levels unseen in more than a decade, and the cause was easy to identify.
With the first set of low-emission vehicle standards, California created a loophole large enough to drive millions of small trucks through, and that is precisely what happened. Sport utility vehicles were permitted to pollute at two and a half times the rate of passenger cars, just as Detroit was recognizing their potential to deliver wide profit margins. The American passion for these vehicles became the Frankenstein of the California emissions laboratory.
"The fact that you could sell them legally without very expensive control standards was certainly something the industry took advantage of," Mr. Roe said. By the time regulators woke up to what was going on in California, sport utility vehicles constituted nearly 60 percent of vehicle sales.
Last fall the state's Air Resources Board imposed new regulations treating sport utility vehicles and most pickup trucks as passenger cars. The move delighted environmental groups, who considered it overdue, and dismayed auto makers, who again insisted it would be nearly impossible to meet the new standards in five years, as required. But the board fit two Ford Expeditions with larger catalytic converters that brought them into compliance.
In fact, Ford had already improved the performance of its sport utility vehicles nationwide so that they could nearly meet today's auto emissions standards, prompting California to tighten its rules. "A lot of people in the industry say it was Ford's fault," Mr. Brown said. "It makes you the skunk at the picnic at an industry meeting."
But for all its apparent zeal, California has occupied the regulatory fast lane largely because the Clean Air Act pushed it there, while the E.P.A. has followed the state's efforts from a politically safe distance.
"One of the difficulties of moving programs along at the Federal level is that there are large parts of the country where smog is just not perceived as a threat," said Mary Nichols, an E.P.A. administrator from 1993 to 1997 and, earlier, the head of California's Air Resources Board under Gov. Jerry Brown. "There is sort of a delicate interplay in terms of how far and how fast you can actually push the industry, and in California they are willing to push harder and faster than the Feds are."
ROBERT STAVINS, a professor at the Harvard University Kennedy School of Government, said California has led not so much by example as by mistake. The first mistake, he explained, was allowing the air in its most populous cities to get so bad that it brought about the second mistake: forcing the rest of the country to scrub its air as expensively as Los Angeles.
Auto makers "were not particularly attracted by the idea of producing two kinds of cars," he added, meaning one for California, which accounts for 10 percent of the domestic car and truck market, and another for everywhere else. While the auto industry resisted regulation "as if it were essentially the Great Depression being brought to America in the 1990's," in Professor Stavins's words, once it lost those early battles, the war was effectively over. It was no longer even a question of whether it was desirable to set the same standards for Sioux Falls, S.D., as for San Francisco, but how quickly to implement them.
"The reality is that from an economic perspective, a uniform, nationwide standard doesn't make sense," Professor Stavins said, "because the damages associated with air pollution, and the costs of achieving the standards differ tremendously, depending on whether you're stuck in the Los Angeles basin or in the middle of the Great Plains. But many people are upset about the political issue of different standards. They believe that there ought to be the same standards for everyone for fundamental things like clean air."
In California, there is always something in the air; these days it is as likely to be an idea as a particulate. "When the Clean Air Act was adopted in 1970, it required huge cuts in emissions and set very tough deadlines," said Gail Ruderman Feuer, a senior lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, which is based in New York. "Everyone said it was impossible. Then lo and behold, they found catalytic converters. That was a technology-forcing act. That's how we have clean cars today."

SECTION: Section G; Page 18; Column 1; Cars 

LENGTH: 1412 words

HEADLINE: CARS AND THE ENVIRONMENT;
Muscle, Muscle Everywhere

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
TAIL FINS went, round headlights gave way to square ones, and then chrome all but disappeared. But the biggest change in cars over the last few years is not cosmetic. It is under the hood: the engine is on steroids.
Year by year, cars and light trucks have undergone a remarkable transformation, through a host of changes in engines and transmissions. The typical family vehicle of the late 1990's has turned into something that in the 1970's would have qualified as a mean street machine. And more changes are waiting in the wings that will make cars more muscular yet. 
 The Environmental Protection Agency, which has kept track since 1975, says in a draft report that for the 1998 model year, the average car had 160 horsepower, up 60 percent from 1981. Light trucks, including sport utility vehicles, which now make up almost half the market, were at 190 horsepower, also up 60 percent. A family that bought three cars in 1981 and replaced them with two new ones in 1998 would have more horsepower in the driveway now.
These days, it is not uncommon for performance cars like the Lexus GS 400 to contain more power than some heavy trucks -- 300 horsepower for the sedan to 275 for a number of Mack Truck's 18-wheelers -- and more than the engine of the typical four-seat passenger plane.
"The horsepower race is on -- it's never been off," said Thomas W. Asmus, the senior research executive for DaimlerChrysler in Auburn Hills, Mich. "With the strong economy, people are willing to spend money on all kinds of automobile features that in less good times they're not willing to spend money on. Vehicle performance has great market appeal."
But not everyone is so happy. "The traditional horsepower war certainly shows no sign of abating," said John DeCicco, the transportation program director at the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy. He, too, agreed that consumers are getting what they ask for, but, he added, "We are seeing automotive technology running amok."
For Mr. DeCicco and other environmentalists, the growth of engine efficiency is a case of the road not taken. Manufacturers have three choices when it comes to engine innovations that get more work from a gallon. They can give cars smaller, lighter engines that will maintain performance while cutting fuel consumption. Or they can increase weight while keeping performance constant. But almost without exception, they have used the gains to make cars faster -- and sometimes heavier as well.
The E.P.A. estimates that if auto makers had kept constant the car's weight and number of seconds it takes to accelerate to 60 miles per hour, but continued to add the same improvements to engines and transmissions, then 1998 cars would have averaged 33.5 miles per gallon, and trucks 25.7 miles per gallon. In both cases, this would have been about 5 miles per gallon better than the average for vehicles actually sold.
INSTEAD, the application of advanced technology to engines is driving performance ever higher, even though the other big determinant of acceleration, vehicle weight, has been rising. According to the E.P.A.'s draft report, the Light-Duty Automotive Technology and Fuel Economy Trends study, since 1981 the average vehicle has gained more than 550 pounds, reaching 3,760 pounds in 1998, from 3,201. Even with that extra heft, the time it takes a car to accelerate to 60 miles per hour from a stop, the most widely used measure of performance, has gone from 14.4 seconds in 1981 to 10.8 seconds in 1998.
Cars are only half the story, almost literally, since they accounted for about 55 percent of sales in 1998, down from 81 percent in 1975. Light trucks have shown a similar increase in performance, despite their larger size.
Acar with 100 horsepower was once a common, respectable model, but of 200 models in Consumer Reports' 1999 auto issue, only four had less than 100 horsepower.
Behind the trend in engine innovations are several refinements, most of which began in high-end cars and are working their way down to the "econobox" end of the market. A number of the new developments have made engines work better by making it easier for them to breathe.
One is the switch to four valves per cylinder from the traditional two. Valves control the flow of gases into and out of the cylinder, a space about the size of a small can of peanuts. The valves, which control openings varying in size from a quarter to a half dollar, let the fuel-air mixture in as the piston goes down, and let the exhaust gases out as the piston rises. Every bit of friction that these gases encounter, on the way in or the way out, is power that does not go to the wheels. As engine speed increases, and more gas has to be moved through the valves, adding valves lets air in and out more easily, increasing the range of speeds at which the engine can operate efficiently.
And that, in turn, has allowed engines to get slightly smaller, because a small engine operating at 6,000 r.p.m. can produce as much power as a slightly larger one operating at 5,000 r.p.m. Engines not only move weight, but they're also heavy themselves. And for every pound that engine weight is reduced, designers can cut at least another pound from the car's suspension and frame. With each pound lost, the number of horses per 100 pounds of weight rises, and the car can accelerate faster. All of this weight loss -- and more -- has been eaten up by fatter bodies.
Other engine refinements are still in their infancy, including variable valve timing, in which intake valves stay open longer and exhaust valves open sooner, depending on engine speed, and electronic controls or multiport fuel injectors, which smooth out the flow of fuel to the cylinders, to reduce friction.
Of course, there remains the question of when exactly extra horsepower is truly needed. Lexus introduced its powerful sport sedan, the GS 400, with the advertising theme "Something Wicked This Way Comes." To environmentalists, the whole trend adds up to Something Wasteful. "They advertise these things with people driving up Pike's Peak, or whatever, but 95 percent of the people who buy these things don't do that," said Ann R. Mesnikoff, an global warming specialist at the Sierra Club.
Cars ran fine 15 years ago when the average engine was 60 horsepower smaller, she said, adding, "How much performance do people need?"
 
In Valves, Timing Is Everything
SOME of the most promising engine improvements are still in the development stage -- variable valve timing, for example. Honda does this now with a mechanical system, but more flexible, capable mechanisms are on the way.
Today, almost all engine valves open and close in lock step with the turning of the crankshaft, like a cuckoo in a clock that pops out precisely when the minute hand reaches the 12. With variable timing, valves would stay open longer, or shut later, depending on engine speed.
When the engine is running fast, the fuel-air mixture flowing into the cylinders has a lot of momentum. Keep the intake valves open an extra fraction of a second, and that momentum will fill the cylinders extra-full, giving the engine more power. And if the exhaust valves open slightly early in high-speed operation, that prevents the cylinder from repressurizing in the exhaust stroke, which would cut power.
A number of companies are working on systems using valves operated hydraulically or by electric impulses through solenoids.
A related improvement would be to use the intake valves, rather than the throttle, to control the amount of fuel and air going to the cylinders. Closing the throttle increases air friction, reducing efficiency; closing a valve early to limit fuel doesn't.
Engineers have found other ways to cut friction, including electronic controls that make the car run smoothly at low engine speeds and multiport fuel injectors thateven fuel flow to the cylinders.
One step on the drawing boards is an engine with a variable compression ratio that would produce a burst of extra power by briefly allowing extra fuel and extra air into the cylinder.
If a car needed a 160-horsepower engine but could perform adequately most of the time with 150, then a manufacturer could substitute the lighter, more fuel-efficient engine. When the car needed an extra 10 horsepower -- say, for merging onto a busy expressway -- an engine with a variable compression ratio could provide it on demand.
 MATTHEW L. WALD

HEADLINE: From One Platform Many Models Grow

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
CAR buyers love choice. Car makers love low production costs.
Believe it or not, there is a way to fulfill these competing goals: build cars that share components under the skin but are as different in size as the Toyota Supra coupe and the Lexus RX300 sport utility vehicle, and in look, feel and price as the $17,000 Volkwagen New Beetle and the $40,000 Audi TT roadster. 
 The key word in this legerdemain is "platform," the term for the basic building block in car manufacturing. It includes the chassis and under-body parts like the floor pan, rails and wheel housings. All vehicles built from a single platform have the same welding points, allowing them to share a single assembly line.
Of course, the idea of saving money by using a limited number of platforms is not new: Henry Ford sold 15 million Model T's. But intense and increasingly global competition and cost pressures have led auto makers to find new ways to produce more models -- some in small volumes -- to appeal to market niches.
Some platforms serve as the bases for a whole family of vehicles. At the same time, manufacturers have grown more successful at making each one more distinctive, not just in looks, but in interior design, engines and driving character, as well as in marketing position and price. The auto makers are becoming like the home builder who uses the same basic foundation and floor plan throughout a neighborhood, but constructs houses that are a mix of contemporary, Colonial and Tudor styles, at various prices.
"The chassis is the most expensive part of the vehicle, so if you can take the basic foundation of a vehicle and spread it across more volume, you can lower the per-unit cost," said Christopher Cedergren, the owner of Nextrend, an automotive research firm in Thousand Oaks, Calif.
The savings can amount to hundreds of millions of dollars, making it easier to shift production to follow market trends. "The break-even on the next model is lower because it takes engineering time and cost out and requires no change in equipment," said Ron Harbour, president of Harbour & Associates, a manufacturing consultant in Troy, Mich.
Savings to the car companies and savings to consumers, however, are two different matters. The desire to attract a certain kind of customer seems to influence the price of an automobile as much as the actual cost of manufacturing it. The Lincoln Navigator and the Ford Expedition, for instance, share the same platform, but the Navigator sells for about $10,000 more.
Although sharing platforms is now popular, the earliest attempts by contemporary car makers failed miserably. In the 1980's, for instance, a now-famous Fortune magazine cover pictured four burgundy mid-size automobiles made by General Motors. Parked side by side, they were indistinguishable from each other. Yet G. M. sold virtually the same car as different models through Buick, Chevrolet, Oldsmobile and Pontiac dealers.
That kind of platform-sharing was derisively known as "badge engineering," because little beyond the name badges differed from vehicle to vehicle. While that still happens, especially among American manufacturers, auto makers are increasingly shifting to a more sophisticated form of platform-sharing.
To date, there have been some successes.
"Common worldwide platforms are relatively new to most car companies, and the proof is yet to be seen," said James Hossack, a senior consultant with Auto Pacific, an automotive marketing research firm in Newport Beach, Calif.
Mr. Harbour said success "depends on how creative they are in designing and engineering the platform to be adaptable to a wide range of vehicles."
Experts consistently cite Volkswagen AG, which sells cars under the Volkswagen, Audi, Seat and Skoda nameplates worldwide, as the most successful at shared platforms thus far. In 1993, Volkswagen sold vehicles built from 16 car platforms. Today, Volkswagen has four platforms, which serve as the basis for half of the company's mass-produced cars; by the end of 2001, nearly 100 percent of its vehicles will have shifted to these four platforms. Yet, while Volkswagen has reduced the number of platforms, it has increased the number of models it produces. The auto maker now sells 51 models, compared with 38 in 1996.
The same platform that spawned the phenomenally successful Volkswagen Beetle, for instance, is shared by the Volkswagen Golf and Jetta (sold as the Bora in Europe), the Audi A3, the new Audi TT sports car convertible and coupe, the Skoda Octavia and the Seat Toledo. The family of vehicles from Volkswagen's so-called A platform includes coupes, roadsters, sedans and station wagons. Similarly, the Volkswagen Passat and Audi A4 and A6, available as sedans and station wagons and with front-wheel or all-wheel drive, come from a single platform.
While some critics, including Mr. Hossack of Auto Pacific, complain that Audi and VW models still look too much alike, the company's sales are running at record levels.
Experts also praise Toyota for a commendable job in developing worldwide platforms. Its Corolla ranks as one of the best-selling vehicles of all time, and its Camry platform is among the most flexible in the industry.
The United States version of the Camry sedan, for instance, is wider than those sold overseas, though they both come from the same platform. So do the Camry Solara, the longer and roomier Avalon and the near-luxury ES300 sedan. The Toyota Sienna minivan and Lexus RX300 sport utility trace their origins to the Camry platform as well.
"The genius behind Toyota is the flexibility in its system," Mr. Harbour said.
Honda is moving in a similar direction with its Accord, which is sized differently for the United States and overseas and is the basis for Honda's wildly popular new minivan, the Odyssey, as well as Acura's TL sedan and CL coupe. Mr. Harbour said Honda had managed to make big changes in vehicles with minimal changes to components by using techniques like putting inserts into the platform to make it longer or wider.
MEANWHILE, Ford, the pioneer of the original world car, has seen mixed results with its most recent attempts.
The Ford Mondeo, developed in Europe and sold in the United States as the Ford Contour and Mercury Mystique sedans, was an extensive $6 billion program, which involved a new platform as well as new engines and transmissions. The Mondeo sold well in Europe, but its counterparts here proved too small and too expensive for American buyers. Then Ford introduced the Mondeo-based Mercury Cougar, a sporty coupe using Ford's New Edge design theme of sharp edges defining the sculptured body; it has done well in the United States and Europe. A Mondeo-based sport utility is in the works now.
An even smaller Ford platform in Europe has generated three successful and critically acclaimed vehicles, all vastly different from one another: the Fiesta economy car, the economical but innovative Ka and the sporty Puma, which ride as well as the Courier pickup sold in Brazil. Still, the platform has not been used in the United States, so it can't be called a worldwide platform.
Perhaps the greatest test for Ford will be its new worldwide platform for luxury cars. The Jaguar S-Type, which is to go on sale this month, the Lincoln LS sedans due out in the fall and the forthcoming Ford Thunderbird and Jaguar X400 will be built from the new platform.
"We haven't seen proof yet of Ford's success with the world car platform," noted Mr. Hossack of Auto Pacific.
SIMILARLY, G. M., which is developing worldwide platforms for the next century, has yet to prove its concept. Its Sigma platform, for instance, will be used as the base for Cadillac's entry-luxury Catera, its flagship Seville, its new Luxury Activity Vehicle and possibly the Evoq roadster, along with luxury cars sold in Australia.
Mr. Cedergren of Nextrend contends that the winner will be the auto maker that can offer vehicles of various sizes and different body styles from a single platform, while insuring that they have distinct brand personalities. These personalities are shaped not only by the sheet metal, but also by careful selection of engines, tuning of suspensions and choice of interior materials.
"The manufacturer must be able to dial in a distinctive brand DNA or attitude," Mr. Cedergren said. "They have to be able to have the chassis shout out, 'It's a Jag,' 'It's a Volvo,' 'It's a Beemer' or 'It's a Mercedes.' "
The auto consumers of the new generation -- primarily aging baby boomers and Generation X'ers -- increasingly base automotive-buying decisions on attitude and image, he said; the cars are viewed as extensions of their personalities and wardrobes. "They are looking for the emotional high you get when you drive it," Mr. Cedergren added.

HEADLINE: Starts of New Homes Fall To Lowest Level in a Year

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
New-home construction starts fell in April to their lowest level in a year after surging in the first quarter.
Starts fell 10.1 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.574 million houses, the Commerce Department said today. The decline came after a one-tenth of a percent drop in March and was widespread, with starts falling in all regions except the West. 
 Analysts had expected April starts to fall to a 1.744-million-unit pace.
Warm weather in January pushed starts that month to a 12-year high and "there was no way that the pace could be maintained," said Joel Naroff, chief economist of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
That helps explain why the industry remains confident this year will be one of the best on record. While April's starts were the lowest monthly level since May 1998, the pace, if it holds up for the year, would be the second strongest since 1987.
In the first four months of the year, builders started work on 515,000 homes, on an unadjusted basis, which is 9.6 percent more houses than in the corresponding period last year -- evidence that "demand for housing is still strong," said Tim McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank Ltd. in New York.
It probably will not get much better, said Marilyn Schaja, a money market economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York. The statistics show "that housing will not be a major contributor to growth during the next few months, although the industry remains at a high plateau," she said.
Also, a rise in mortgage rates means "housing won't be supercharged any longer," said David Orr, chief capital markets economist at the First Union Corporation.
The benchmark 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose last week to 7.10 percent, the highest level since mid-March. After the Labor Department reported on Friday a larger-than-expected seven-tenths of a percent rise in April consumer prices, fears of rising inflation drove market-based interest rates higher. That means higher mortgage rates, too.
By region, housing starts fell 6.8 percent in the Northeast, to an annual rate of 138,000 -- the lowest level since April 1998. They dropped 14.6 percent in the Midwest, to a rate of 328,000 units, and 14.5 percent, to 702,000 in the South, the slowest pace since April 1998. Starts rose 2 percent, to 406,000 units, in the West.
Starts of single-family homes fell 11 percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.244 million units, the lowest level since May 1998. Starts of multifamily homes fell 6.5 percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 330,000.

HEADLINE: The Fed Edges Toward Action

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's decision yesterday to leave interest rates unchanged but to warn that it was thinking of raising them in the future reaffirms how unsure the policy makers are about the state of the economy.
The Fed cut rates three times late last year when it believed that the financial panic following the Russian default would slow American growth and might bring on a world recession. In retrospect the Fed seems to have overreacted, although the cuts appeared prudent at the time. Now, with the United States' economy growing far more rapidly than expected, a world recession seemingly unlikely and with some signs of a rebirth of inflation, a modest increase in rates could easily be justified. 
 That the Fed did not dictate such an increase, but instead announced a "bias" in favor of raising rates in the future, probably reflects a continued argument within the Fed's open market committee about the extent to which inflation is a threat. Some believe that thanks to increases in productivity brought on by computers, the economy is now able to grow much faster than in the past without any appreciable threat of inflation. But it is also possible that inflation has been held down by overseas weakness that is now reversing. The Fed should be vigilant about inflation, and may rightly conclude next month that a rate increase is wise.

HEADLINE: Text of Statement by Fed

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee said it had left interest rates unchanged but had adopted a stance to raise borrowing costs in the future:
While the F.O.M.C. did not take action today to alter the stance of monetary policy, the committee was concerned about the potential for a buildup of inflationary imbalances that could undermine the favorable performance of the economy and therefore adopted a directive that is tilted toward the possibility of a firming in the stance of monetary policy. 
 Trend increases in costs and core prices have generally remained quite subdued. But domestic financial markets have recovered and foreign economic prospects have improved since the easing of monetary policy last fall.
Against the background of already-tight domestic labor markets and ongoing strength in demand in excess of productivity gains, the committee recognizes the need to be alert to developments over coming months that might indicate that financial conditions may no longer be consistent with containing inflation.

HEADLINE: U.S. Unveils Plan to Aid 68 Species in Everglades

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 18

 BODY:
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt unveiled an ambitious plan today to save more than 68 endangered and threatened species in South Florida, taking a regional approach to disappearing wildlife that the Clinton Administration hopes will become a national model.
Speaking to a forum of scientists involved in the restoration of the Florida Everglades, Mr. Babbitt called the plan "an unprecedented, pioneering effort." 
 The 2,400-page document, which looks a bit like a wildlife encyclopedia, lays out a blueprint for restoring natural habitat across 26,000 square miles in southern Florida, and saving dozens of threatened species, including the manatee, the American crocodile and plants like Small's milkpea and the deltoid splurge.
Mr. Babbitt said the Government's hope was to depart from the piecemeal approach of adopting harsh legal tactics to save each species as it nears extinction, sometimes to the detriment of other species and often at the cost of economic development.
"What we have learned is you can't do these issues one species at a time," Mr. Babbitt said. "That's the significance of this plan today."
Under the plan, Federal authorities would work with developers and local governments to reach agreements on setting aside habitats for endangered species before construction projects get under way, rather than suing those developers and governments to stop projects after they are started. In most cases, the developers would then be released from the obligation to protect endangered species on the land designated for development.
Federal wildlife officials said the idea was to shape development in a way that set aside and preserved habitats for all species, rather than fighting politically divisive battles in court over a single species of bird or fish.
"I believe we are doing it right this time," Mr. Babbitt said. "We are putting it up on the front end. We're not going to sit back and take the dog-in-the-manger stance, saying, You go and do your thing and then let us say, 'No!' "
Federal officials have tried similar tactics with considerable success in the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest and along the coastal sage lands of Southern California. But Mr. Babbitt said the Florida plan was the largest initiative of its kind ever tried, and the first to deal with a vast aquatic ecosystem like the Everglades and adjacent Florida Bay.
The health of the Everglades has been deteriorating for decades. The flood control system the Army built in the 1950's drained thousands of acres for farmland, splintered the marsh prairies with dikes and canals, and severed the wetlands in the south from Lake Okeechobee in the north, thus stopping the slow, shallow flow of water that was the lifeblood of the system.
Today's announcement comes as Congress is preparing to debate a $7.8 billion public works project this summer intended to restore the Everglades to ecological health. That project, known as the Restudy, involves building dozens of large reservoirs, both above and below ground, and revamping the canals and dikes to restore the natural flow of water to the wetlands and into Florida Bay.
Some conservationists said the public works projects going to Congress in July would be much more important to stopping the decline of threatened species than Mr. Babbitt's plan. Unless the erratic flow of water into the Everglades can be fixed, there is little hope that many of the endangered species will survive.
Charles Lee of the Florida Audubon Society, said, "If we can't put the water back in the Everglades, and we are not able to re-establish the natural flow of water, then the steps recommended in the recovery plan are not going to be sufficient."
But other ecologists said Mr. Babbitt's approach was a breakthrough in environmental policy. In the past, they said, conservationists had been forced to sue to protect a single species under the Endangered Species Act in order to save the larger ecosystem. Naturalists championed the survival of the spotted owl, for instance, to protect the old growth forests of the Northwest, and the fight over the snail darter was in reality a battle over the future of the Little Tennessee River.
It remains unclear precisely how the wildlife recovery plan will be implemented as the state and Federal governments move ahead with the larger effort to restore the Everglades. Several projects intended to restore the marshes have become bogged down for years in local political battles and disagreements among Federal agencies.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Pulp Friction

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Coke promotes its "secret formula" for achieving uniformity of taste from Tulsa to Timbuktu. Pepsi scoffs, saying its product is just plain better and boasting that its market appeal gives it a big advantage over its archrival.
Nothing new in any of that -- except that the soft-drink giants are both talking about orange juice. 
 After Pepsico bought the Tropicana juice maker from the Seagram Company last July for $3.3 billion, the spillover of the cola wars to America's breakfast tables was inevitable. The Coca-Cola Company has owned Minute Maid, the nation's No. 2 juice maker, for more than 35 years, and now the two companies have a new testing ground for their marketing arsenals.
Some analysts wonder whether the companies are indulging in overkill. Tropicana and Minute Maid are spending heavily to blast consumers with advertisements and promotions and are sniping at each other in the best Coke-Pepsi tradition. In February, Minute Maid trumpeted growing sales of its Minute Maid Premium even as "the Tropicana Season's Best line registered the largest decline in sales -- down nearly 32 percent -- of all value brands." Not to be outdone, Tropicana has issued news releases comparing the taste of juices made from concentrates unfavorably with its "natural" brands.
All this, skeptics ask, for a market that is essentially stagnant? Indeed, the juice market, at about $3 billion last year, represents only a small corner of the companies' beverage empires -- a small and highly volatile corner.
"There's very little synergy in terms of the economics," said Jennifer Solomon, a beverage analyst for Salomon Smith Barney and one of the early doubters about the wisdom of the Tropicana acquisition. "Pepsi now has to deal with refrigerated rail cars and perishable products. It's a whole level of complexity that you don't have in the soft-drink business."
Still, the Tropicana-Minute Maid clash makes for one of the more interesting side battles of the cola wars; Pepsi's purchase of Tropicana may have forced Coke to hold on to Minute Maid against its will, for example. And with orange juice, the tables are turned: Pepsi, the perennial No. 2 to Coke, has the best-selling brand for a change.
Coke and Pepsi argue that orange juice is a crucial element of their respective corporate strategies. And since both beverage giants are using the same basic techniques to sell orange juice that they use to market cola, any sudden reversals of fortune for Minute Maid or Tropicana could act as an early warning sign for the future of their other brands.
As does Coke, Minute Maid wants to convince consumers that no matter where they go, it will always give them the same familiar flavor. That is because both products are distributed as concentrate to all points of the globe.
"One of the hallmarks of a brand is consistency," said Ralph Cooper, Minute Maid's president and a former Coca-Cola president in Europe. "What we are trying to do with Minute Maid is make the taste the same everywhere. That was a conscious decision we made related to the brand building we are doing."
Minute Maid, based in Houston, adopted its concentrate-only policy in 1996 as part of an image overhaul that included the change of its name from Coca-Cola Foods. Along with a new package and a new name, the company also contended that it had come up with a formula to reproduce the taste of "biting into a fresh, ripe orange."
This was achieved, it said, through careful mixing of the orange juice, along with other "parts of the orange," that it buys from the United States, Brazil and other countries.
"It's a bit of secret formula," said Joe Scalzo, Minute Maid's marketing director, evoking the heart and soul of Coca-Cola, which still will not reveal how its cola is made. "The way we process orange juice gives us the ability to tweak the formulation such that you can naturally enhance some of the taste aspects of the product."
Taking a jab at Tropicana, Mr. Scalzo said consumers do not give a hoot how a product is made as long as it tastes good. "Our competition's approach is that they squeeze the orange juice during the season and then store it, either in tanks in Florida or frozen in big blocks," he said derisively. "We process the juice the same way, year round. They are forced to vary the process based on the season."
In essence, the reconfiguration of Minute Maid mimics the model at Coca-Cola: Make a product that can be shipped worldwide, make people aware of your brand and drive demand for it through advertising.
Tropicana, of course, says Minute Maid's strategy is all wet, or rather, not wet enough. To the Pepsico unit, it seems self-evident that consumers will prefer juice that is packaged just as it was squeezed out of the orange. And there is no longer any question that it can promote its not-from-concentrate juice as a premium brand or that consumers will pay another 10 cents a quart for it.
"Tropicana is the Michael Jordan of orange juice," said Emanuel Goldman, a global consumer-products analyst for Merrill Lynch. "That's why Pepsi bought it."
But Tropicana's real competitive advantage might be its parent company's extensive delivery networks. Pepsico plans to put Tropicana products in places they are not in right now -- like additional convenience stores, airports and food-service companies. The company just introduced a 20-ounce Tropicana container, hoping to prod higher consumption with the large single-serving package.
Essentially, Pepsico wants to weld Tropicana with the other two components of its packaged-food empire: soft drinks and Frito-Lay snack foods. Pepsi senior managers, who have begun sitting in on strategy meetings at Tropicana's Bradenton, Fla., headquarters, believe the combination of the three lines creates a marketing appeal to both consumers and retailers that it calls "the power of one."
"We believe this is Pepsico's most important strategic initiative," Ms. Solomon of Salomon Smith Barney wrote in a recent report. "In test markets, Pepsico has found that Pepsi/Frito sales aisles have resulted in 30 percent sales increases." At a recent food show in Chicago, Pepsi displayed combined soft drinks and snacks in various formats, clearly indicating this was the future.
In the first quarter of this year, Tropicana's sales grew $15 million, or about 3 percent, from a year earlier, to $499 million, and its profits rose 29 percent, to $35 million, from $27 million in 1998. "Tropicana frankly had a terrific quarter," Pepsico's chief financial officer, Michael D. White, told analysts in a conference call. "We have seen the benefit of the shift to Pure Premium and the reduction of our overhead costs."
The news at Minute Maid was even better: sales grew by 5 percent over the same period, and the company turned in the best showing of any Coca-Cola unit in a quarter when Coke's volume worldwide declined by 1 percent. Minute Maid does about $2 billion in sales annually, which includes products other than orange juice.
For all the impressive results at both companies, and for all their portrayal of their products as thirst-quenchers supreme, demand for orange juice remains lackluster. Only one in five Americans drinks it for breakfast. And both Tropicana and Minute Maid constitute tiny fractions of their parent company's total revenues: $22.3 billion at Pepsico; $18.8 billion at Coke.
"We've learned that it's in the refrigerator," Minute Maid's Mr. Scalzo said, sounding a little frustrated. "How do we get them to bring it out?"
It is not just Coke that feels his pain. Tropicana does, too. "The big challenge, is to get that segment of the population that is not starting their day with orange juice," said Brian Cornell, until recently Tropicana's senior vice president for sales and marketing and now president for Europe and Canada, "and, two, to get them to continue to drink orange juice on a regular basis."
The means to such an end, both juice makers believe, is adding more products. With its eye on young families, Minute Maid has begun packaging calcium-fortified juice in single-serving boxes for snacks and lunch boxes and is marketing new flavor mixes, also with added calcium. It has introduced an orange-passion fruit juice, Mr. Scalzo said, with "a more sophisticated taste" that is supposed to appeal particularly to older women.
Tropicana is leaning heavily on the calcium-added concept, with calcium-enhanced grapefruit juice as well as orange. There is also an orange juice with extra vitamin C, vitamin E and other additives. Marketing messages include comparisons between orange juice and bananas. "Few people recognize that a glass of orange juice has as much potassium as a banana," declares Mr. Cornell, the sales chief. And another thing: bananas may not be available in your local vending machine. Tropicana ads, with their "Perfect" slogan, are aimed at, among others, older women, whose worries about losing bone-mass because of menopause tend to be more urgent than those of other groups. Other ads focus on men and children.
Still, even if orange juice is fortified to the point that it packs all the wallop of an energy bar, consumers have dozens of other choices for a breakfast drink or midday pick-me-up, from competing juice blends to endless varieties of teas and coffees. Not to mention colas.
"You're not going to be able to sell orange juice like you sell Pepsi -- price it low and stack it high," said Kevin Murphy, the chief operating officer for Ocean Spray, which has sued Pepsi, its distribution partner, over the Tropicana acquisition.
But it is not impossible to give old products a fin de siecle spark. "Look at milk," said Bob Vosburgh, who follows the business for Supermarket News, a trade publication. "There's a whole new aura for milk with these resealable single-serve jugs that were introduced by one of the big dairies. It's helped rejuvenate the whole milk category, even though it's the same thing in a new package."
Whether orange juice can pull off the same feat is unclear. "Everyone always points to what Quaker did with Snapple," Mr. Vosburgh said, referring to the cereal giant's purchase of Snapple for $1.7 billion and subsequent, humiliating sale of the beverage maker for $300 million. "What happens with Coke and Pepsi and orange juice remains to be seen."

HEADLINE: Stocks and Speeches Fatten Wallets of Presidential Contenders

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Their bottom lines expanded by a booming stock market and lucrative speaking fees, six of the candidates for President reported assets of more than $1 million, according to financial disclosure forms filed this week.
Leading the way was Steve Forbes, the publisher, who reported assets worth more than $19 million, much of it in stocks and three properties in his hometown, Bedminster, N.J. Mr. Forbes, a Republican, also received more than $644,000 last year from 24 speeches. 
 Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who is challenging Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic nomination, reported assets of at least $5.7 million and income of more than $2.6 million last year, most of it from speaking fees.
Mr. Gore has reported assets of $1.4 million to $1.7 million.
Elizabeth Dole, the former president of the American Red Cross who is seeking the Republican nomination, reported assets of more than $6 million. Mrs. Dole received $1.6 million from speeches over the past 17 months, but gave $1.1 million of that to a charity, the Elizabeth Dole Charitable Foundation.
Lamar Alexander, the former Tennessee Governor who is also running for the Republican nomination, reported assets worth more than $6.8 million and nearly $1 million from the merger of a company he helped start in 1987 with an investment of $6,300.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and his wife, Cindy, reported assets of more than $9.7 million, which includes his investments in a Phoenix beer distributor and several other businesses in his home state. Mr. McCain also reported donating a $70,833 book advance to charity.
Four other Republican candidates, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the conservative activist Gary Bauer, former Vice President Dan Quayle and the commentator Patrick J. Buchanan have been given 45-day extensions to file their reports.
Mr. Bradley reported owning several million dollars in stocks and bonds, including more than $1 million in the BankAmerica Corporation. He received $1.6 million for 64 speeches, $171,042 for lectures at Stanford University, the University of Maryland and the University of Notre Dame, and $126,953 in pension payments from the National Basketball Association and the United States Senate.
He also received $431,250 as a consultant, mainly on international economic issues, to the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, J. P. Morgan Services and the Gartner Group of Stamford, Conn. Mr. Bradley has ended his relationship with the three companies, an aide said.
Mr. Bradley reported owning property in Athens 80 acres of unimproved land in Nova Scotia, Canada, and a house in Washington, part of which he rents.
Mr. Forbes, who is expected to self-finance much of his campaign, reported receiving $42,007 from a family farm in Bedminster and a $2.2 million salary from Forbes Family Holdings, the family's publishing company, of which Mr. Forbes is president and editor in chief. He also reported liabilities of more than $4.5 million.
Most of Mrs. Dole's assets were in stocks and bonds, including more than $1 million in a Riggs Prime Money Market Fund. Her husband, former Senator Bob Dole, reported that his consulting company, Bob Dole Enterprises, was worth more than $1 million.
Mr. Alexander reported receiving $970,000 from the merger last year of Bright Horizons Family Solutions, a Cambridge, Mass., company that provides day care services to businesses, which he helped start in 1987.
He received $420,000 from stock options he was given as a board member of the Learning Company, a company in Cambridge, Mass., that produces educational software, according to the report. And Mr. Alexander received $235,000 for serving as a director of three other companies, $88,000 in legal fees and $76,000 in speaking fees last year.
In addition to his home, he reported owning two rental properties in Knoxville and a vacation house on 35 acres in Walland, Tenn.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. in Congress to Cut Domestic Spending by $26 Billion

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress completed a plan today to cut domestic spending by tens of billions of dollars next year. Their leaders warned that it would cause "sticker shock" and political pain. The White House called it "a blueprint for political chaos."
Cutting domestic spending by 11 percent might seem strange at a time of budget surpluses and economic prosperity. But in 1997, Congress and the White House agreed to spending caps to force down Federal spending. They are now chafing under the restraints they embraced. 
 The cuts will come in spending categories covering education, job training, housing, health and human services, environmental protection, medical and technological research, diplomacy and foreign aid, among other Federal programs. These follow $53 billion in cuts in domestic spending since the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994.
"We all knew this was going to be painful," the House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, said today.
Mr. Armey said there would be "sticker shock now in realizing just how difficult it will be" to stay within the spending caps.
On Wednesday morning the House Appropriations Committee will slice up a $538 billion budget pie -- what is left of the $1.75 trillion budget after paying for mandatory programs like Medicare -- for its 13 subcommittees. Under the committee's plan, the Defense Department will receive about $270 billion, more than half the money. Every other Government agency would receive an aggregate of about $268 billion.
The committee's final spending draft for the fiscal year 2000, which will be formally approved on Wednesday, contains $26.3 billion in cuts for domestic spending, about 11 percent less than what Congress meted out for this year, and a $18.9 billion increase for the military, up about 7.5 percent, committee members said.
Members of Congress are moaning, " 'Oh, oh, oh, we can't live up to that,' " said the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi. "It's tough, but it ought to be done."
White House officials, along with some Republicans and Democrats in Congress, warned that the plan could lead to political confrontation and Presidential vetoes. Some predicted a repeat of last year's spending stalemate, which ended in a frenzied, last-minute omnibus spending bill larded with $21 billion in extras. Others remembered the standoff that led to a partial shutdown of the Government in 1995.
"The Republican budget is a blueprint for chaos," said Jacob J. Lew, the White House budget director. "These allocations are a sign of that. They would have unacceptable consequences."
Democrats say the caps have shrunk domestic nonmilitary spending to its smallest share of the national economy since 1962. They also helped create a budget surplus, but at a cost. Not all Republicans agree that they still make sense.
"There's hardly a member of Congress that doesn't realize the caps will be lifted," said Representative John Edward Porter of Illinois, a senior Republican on the Appropriations Committee.
But lifting the caps could violate promises made by Republican leaders. It could result in more spending taken from surplus Social Security funds, and it could blunt Republican plans for tax cuts, splintering two of the biggest planks in their political platform for the 2000 campaign.
Mr. Porter is one of 13 House Appropriations subcommittee chairmen -- they are called Congress's "college of cardinals" -- who will divide the $538 billion in discretionary spending on Wednesday.
Mr. Porter's subcommittee, which oversees labor, education and health programs, would receive nearly $11 billion less than last year. The subcommittee overseeing the Veterans Administration and the Department of Housing and Urban Development would take a $5.8 billion cut; the one overseeing the Commerce, State and Justice Departments, a $2.8 billion cut; the Interior Department, $2.7 billion; foreign operations, $2.4 billion.
The subcommittees must figure out how to divide their allocations and pay for their programs under the caps before the current fiscal year ends next Sept. 30.
Tonight, at least, the caps were irrelevant.
By a vote of 269 to 158, with 152 Republicans and 117 Democrats voting in favor, the House tonight passed an emergency spending bill of nearly $15 billion, twice what President Clinton requested, financing NATO's air war in Yugoslavia, relief for refugees in Kosovo and aid for disaster victims in the United States and Central America, along with billions in military projects.
About $13 billion will come from surplus Social Security funds. That money is designated as an emergency appropriation, meaning it does not count under the spending caps. Most of the rest will come from food stamp and low-income housing funds designated as surplus and unlikely to be spent this year.
The Senate will take up the bill on Thursday. The President has indicated he will sign it.

HEADLINE: Between the Feuding Rudys;
Parents Like Giuliani and Crew, but Fear for the Schools

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Like countless other New York City parents, Nancy Gasparino and her husband, Frank, a firefighter, have considered moving from their home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to the suburbs. But over the past few years, with crime falling and the economy booming, they have made their fragile peace with the city.
These days, however, the thought of fleeing New York is creeping back into her head. 
 This time around, she is not worried about making ends meet or learning that one of her four children has been mugged. Rather, she fears that the feud between Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatens the future of their education.
"I think that Mayor Giuliani has done a really commendable job in changing the city," said Mrs. Gasparino, a Parent Teacher Association president at Public School 185, as she whipped up onion dip for an expedition to the park with her brood. "That's one of the reasons we're staying in the city. I think the schools are going in the right direction. But I'm saddened by this division between the two of them. The end result is the children are the ones getting hurt."
For parents throughout the city, whether their offspring attend thriving middle-class schools in Manhattan or failing schools in the Bronx, the feud between the two Rudys is more than idle political sport or yet another municipal soap opera. For them, it is a worrisome, even ominous, sign that the public schools -- typically the strongest, most personal tie that connects parents to the city -- have once again become a political battleground. They are angry that the two leaders most responsible for the viability of the school system are fighting rather than working together to improve education. And they fear that their children will suffer.
In dozens of interviews over the past few days, parents had trouble articulating the educational agendas of either Dr. Crew or Mr. Giuliani. But most said they had a sense that the fortunes of the schools rose and fell with those of the city and that there is more reason for hope now than in many years. When Dr. Crew and Mr. Giuliani were getting along, they said, many schools could focus on what really counted, namely, teaching and learning.
Amy Schwartz, an economist, said she feels more optimistic about the schools than at any time since the oldest of her three children entered P.S. 41 in Greenwich Village six years ago. The number of small, innovative middle schools in District 2 has mushroomed, she said, and she thinks that her fifth-grade daughter has many choices that equal those available in private schools.
She is not sure, however, whether Dr. Crew deserves the credit. "As a parent, it's hard to disentangle that," she said. But she believes that the schools have flourished in part because of the stability that came from his close relationship with Mr. Giuliani.
"It worries me that Crew might leave," Ms. Schwartz said. "I think that uncertainty and change and upheaval is not good for fledgling schools. Is there somewhere out there a better chancellor? Maybe. But I personally would be happy to stay the course for another couple of years. Maybe what we need is for somebody to stay in here long enough to get past the baloney."
Few parents had patience for the larger ideological issues -- like vouchers and mayoral control of the schools -- that have dominated the dispute between the Mayor and the Chancellor. Even those who favored vouchers, for instance, saw them as largely irrelevant to their lives.
"How is it going to help the New York City public school system to take some kids out and put them in private schools?" asked Louise Russo Chin, whose three children attend school in Bayside, Queens, the city's top-scoring district in reading and math. "That's like saying, I don't want cavities, so therefore I'll take out my teeth, rather than prevent it."
Even Mr. Giuliani's strongest supporters said they would prefer that the schools not be under the direct control of City Hall. Cecilia Soranno of Bensonhurst said she had voted for Mr. Giuliani twice and would do so again if he could run for a third term. And she said she did not think much of the Board of Education. Nonetheless, she would be leery of replacing it with mayoral control.
"I'm not saying the Board of Education has done a great job," she said. "But I think it's too much for one person. He's running the Police Department. He's running this, he's running that. Maybe if you have 48 hours a day."
Parents in poor and minority neighborhoods took a more cynical view of Mr. Giuliani. Many suggested that he has an abrasive, take-no-prisoners style that makes him a poor advocate for children.
"He's a good Mayor, but he's too dictatorial," said Nancy Walker Thompson, whose son, Mark Elijah, attends first grade at P.S. 199 in Sunnyside, Queens. The Mayor's greatest strengths, she believes, involve dealing with municipal issues like garbage, traffic and crime. "They have nothing to do with children," she said. "You can't treat a child like a rapist."
While parents had strong opinions about the Mayor, their impressions of Dr. Crew were fuzzier, although they generally believed that he was committed to public education and was trying to improve the schools against considerable odds.
"I think the Chancellor is doing the best he can," said Sonia Monsalvo, the mother of a fifth-grader at P.S. 1 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Like many parents, Ms. Monsalvo suggested that Mr. Giuliani and Dr. Crew talk less to each other and more to parents.
Several parents complained that neither Dr. Crew nor Mr. Giuliani had ever visited their children's schools. One parent, Maria Ortiz, said Dr. Crew had recently visited her daughter's school, P.S. 165 on the Upper West Side, but only for a staged event at which he spoke English to a roomful of Spanish-speaking parents, most of whom did not understand what he was saying.
Parents in poor neighborhoods, whose children attend struggling schools, were more critical of Dr. Crew than those in middle-class neighborhoods with better schools.
"As an African-American, I expect him to do more," said Stephanie Porter, 27, whose son, Joshua, is a second-grader at P.S. 199 in Sunnyside. P.S. 199 is the anchor of the neighborhood, a mixture of blacks, Hispanics and immigrants from Mexico, India and Asia, where mothers stand outside in the morning after dropping off their children, drinking deli coffee and comparing notes on teachers and homework. "I feel he has gotten so caught up in his own self-image, and fighting to promote himself, he is not fighting to help the children."
If there was one almost universal complaint, it was not about what happens at City Hall or Board of Education headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, but about what happens in the classroom. Parents throughout the city complained that their children were not being sufficiently challenged. The debate over ending social promotion -- the practice of promoting children who are failing -- misses the point, they said. Instead, the Chancellor and the Mayor should insure that teachers teach effectively the first time around, whether it takes smaller classes, better trained teachers or a stronger curriculum.
"Teachers are spending too much time disciplining and not enough time teaching," said Jeanne Barnwell, whose two sons attend schools in Bayside. Mr. Giuliani and Dr. Crew "keep talking about all these changes," she said, "but they wouldn't need all these remedial programs if they had smaller class size."
Gisela Veras, a parent from Hunts Point in the Bronx, said her son, Jazz, is failing second grade, but she does not want to put him in summer school, under a plan the Mayor has advocated. When he went to summer school last year, she said, the class spent most of its time on field trips. "If my son did not learn nothing in nine months, how is he going to learn it in two months?" she asked.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Higher Rates May Not Hurt Foreign Recoveries

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A jump in interest rates in the United States -- which the Federal Reserve indicated yesterday was likely -- would raise the risks for the world's emerging markets just as they begin to recover from a financial crisis that began almost two years ago.
"The prospects for recovery in many of these countries are now going to be called into question," said Jose M. Barrionuevo, director of global market strategy at Lehman Brothers. 
 Even so, yesterday's announcement by the Fed, which said it now leans toward increasing rates to curb inflationary pressures, could prove to be more of a long-term benefit for these markets than the first headlines might suggest.
"If interest rates stay around here, it is not going to be devastating for emerging markets," said Jose Luis Daza, managing director for emerging markets at J. P. Morgan Securities. If rates rise much higher, though, emerging markets could suffer troublesome declines in exports and higher borrowing costs.
One positive sign yesterday was that both United States and emerging markets took the Fed announcement in stride. The Dow Jones industrial average initially plunged almost 150 points on the news but largely recovered, finishing the day off 16.52 points at 10,836.95. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose slightly while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.88 percent.
In Brazil, meanwhile, the Bovespa stock index initially fell but rebounded to finish up 1 percent on the day.
Investors hope the Fed's new bias toward higher rates may be the kind of pre-emptive strike that calms fears about inflation, a fear stoked on Friday with the news that the Consumer Price Index jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in April. If so, rates may not rise much more.
An interest rate increase soon could also help guide the United States economy to the "soft landing" that Fed officials would like. A soft landing means a slowing of growth here. But it avoids a sharp decline, or even a recession, which would be much more damaging for emerging-market countries, many of which depend on Americans to buy their exports.
And even if the Fed does raise its short-term interest rate target, economists are not expecting a big move, such as the one that occurred when rates rose three full percentage points in just a year starting in February 1994. The forecast among many economists and market strategists calls for a total rise of three-quarters of a percentage point in the Federal funds rate between this summer and the first half of next year.
That kind of move, said Jay Pelosky, the global emerging markets strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, "is not a sufficient condition for derailing the new investment cycle in the emerging markets."
Mr. Pelosky also argued that the Fed move is "good for emerging markets because it will provide a pause or pullback for markets that have risen rapidly." Since October, the Morgan Stanley Capital International index of emerging markets has jumped more than 60 percent in dollar terms.
The immediate reaction to big news often deceives investors about the trend for the longer term. But the emerging financial markets that were open yesterday when the Fed made its announcement did not panic -- signaling that investors had already anticipated the move, as shown by the surges recently in interest rates in the United States and in emerging markets. It may also mean that investors are not that concerned about the consequences of any future Fed move.
The spreads between interest rates offered by emerging-market nations and those for Treasuries rose modestly yesterday. But the move came early in the day and did not widen after the Fed announcement, according to indexes kept by J. P. Morgan Securities.
The Fed also seemed to express confidence in the outlook for emerging markets. Past comments by Fed policy makers suggest that they would not have taken this step if they thought it would undermine global financial markets. The economic data on Brazil -- which shrank just 1 percent in the first quarter from a year ago -- and on Mexico -- which grew 1.9 percent -- have been pleasant surprises.
While a modest move by the Fed would not devastate emerging markets, it would still curb their recoveries. Mr. Barrionuevo at Lehman Brothers noted that Mexico, which sends 80 percent of its exports to the United States, would be hurt if American demand slowed. And even moderately higher interest rates -- a move, say, to more than 6 percent for long-term rates -- would make it harder for nations like Argentina and Venezuela to borrow. Venezuela is now weighing a major global bond issue.
Plenty of uncertainty remains. Until it is clear how serious any inflation threat in the United States actually is, speculation about when the Fed will raise rates and by how much will keep emerging markets volatile.
Desmond Lachman, director of emerging-markets research for Salomon Smith Barney, summed up the outlook this way. Referring to the Fed's new bias toward higher rates, he said, "Clearly, it is not good news for emerging markets."
But, he added, "we are not expecting the Brazil rebound to be derailed."
