HEADLINE: Ernst Seeks Large Subsidy To Move to Times Sq. Tower

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Ernst & Young, one of the country's largest accounting and consulting firms, has asked state and city officials for a $65 million subsidy to move to an expensive new office tower in Times Square, according to public officials and real estate executives.
If a deal is struck, the company would move to a proposed 40-story building at the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, where the state has already granted the developer $236.4 million in property tax breaks over 20 years. The site, which is controlled by the developer, Boston Properties, is now occupied by a Walt Disney Company retail store and sits next to the New Amsterdam Theater. 
 In what has become a well-worn ritual for the city's major corporations, Ernst & Young has threatened to move some of its 4,000 employees in New York City to Jersey City if it does not get the subsidy, although real estate executives on both sides of the river doubt that the company has any such intention.
Some economists, urban planners and politicians said that the potential $301.4 million subsidy deal to develop the property for Ernst & Young would unnecessarily subsidize a profitable company and bail out a developer who may have overpaid for the land. With rents rising in Manhattan and space tight, they said the tax breaks would insure that private developers with nonsubsidized projects could not compete, because they would need higher rents.
"This number sounds excessive," said Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate. "Instead of competing in the zero-sum game of selective tax giveaways, government should invest public dollars in our poorly maintained subways, schools and housing. The risk is that government has become an A.T.M. machine for any major company that can call City Hall."
Last year, Ernst & Young hired Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate broker, to scour the city for a new location. According to real estate executives, the firm is now negotiating a lease with Boston Properties for the Times Square site.
Under the terms of the deal, the accounting firm would occupy all of the proposed 1.1 million-square-foot tower, except for retail space in the basement and ground floor. At the same time, Disney, whose retail store has the highest sales of any operation outside its theme parks, is debating whether it wants to rent space in the proposed new tower.
Boston Properties declined to discuss the deal. Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, did not return calls requesting comment.
"It is our policy not to confirm or deny potential transactions," said Robert E. Selsam, senior vice president of Boston Properties.
The location is one of four office development sites within the state's 42d Street redevelopment project, which seeded each parcel with an extraordinary level of tax breaks. Douglas Durst, the developer, is completing a 48-story tower across the street that will house Conde Nast Publications and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Another developer, William Rudin, and Reuters have begun work on a tower at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue. Boston Properties has a contract to buy control of the other two sites.
"We continue to look at a number of alternatives, both in and out of Manhattan," said Leslie C. Zuke, a spokesman for Ernst & Young. "No decision has been made at the present time."
The company's current base is at the Equitable Tower, at 787 Seventh Avenue at 52d Street, where its lease expires in 2002. It also has employees in four other buildings in Manhattan.
The firm, which expects to add up to 2,500 jobs in the coming years, has acknowledged that it would benefit financially from consolidation to a single location in Manhattan, according to city and state officials. But, they say, the company also argued that it would get tens of millions of dollars in state and local tax breaks from New Jersey if it moved part of its work force into a new tower at Newport Center in Jersey City. One official noted that Ernst & Young already has 1,200 employees at offices in Lyndhurst, N.J. "We're negotiating," a senior City Hall official said. "It's all preliminary."
But a New Jersey developer who has talked with Ernst & Young representatives in recent weeks expressed skepticism about the company's intentions. "The word is they're focusing on their New York options," the developer said.
Despite giving billions of dollars in tax breaks to communications and financial companies, the city has long had a policy against granting incentives to accountants and law firms, which they say, must be near their clients.
The Giuliani administration, however, has not been shy about giving more than one helping of tax breaks in Times Square to some of the city's most prestigious companies. In 1996, city and state officials gave Conde Nast a $10.7 million incentive package to move to 4 Times Square, a project that already had property tax breaks worth about $6 million a year. A year later, they gave Reuters up to $26 million in subsidies for a headquarters at 3 Times Square, which already had tax breaks valued at at least $36.9 million over 20 years.
Boston Properties signed a deal with Prudential more than a year ago to buy control of the last two office sites in Times Square for $330 million. Unable to find a tenant willing to pay its asking rent, Boston Properties later negotiated a discount on the deal, agreeing to pay $312.3 million and give Prudential a stake in the project. With large blocks of office space increasingly rare in midtown, Boston Properties eventually opened talks with Ernst & Young.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON AT WORK;
Insider Bemoans What He Wished For

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
As Republican national chairman, Haley Barbour designed his party's campaign to cut the growth of Medicare. Now he has taken on a new assignment. As a lobbyist for a dozen large nursing home companies, he pleads with Congress for relief from the law he helped write.
In 1995-96, Mr. Barbour told anyone who would listen that the explosive growth of Medicare threatened to bankrupt the program. He worked hand in glove with Speaker Newt Gingrich on legislation to rein in Medicare spending. Now he complains that Medicare is spending too little. 
 "Underspending by Medicare for skilled nursing homes is having serious effects in the real world," Mr. Barbour said in an interview today. "Close to 20,000 caregivers have been laid off. There's concern that nursing homes will close. It's resulting in harm to senior citizens."
People outside Washington might see some inconsistency between Mr. Barbour's earlier support for Medicare cutbacks and his work as a lobbyist now. But his advocacy raises few eyebrows in the capital, where dozens of people pass through the revolving door between government and industry every year, where politicians do battle by day but share cozy dinners in the evening, where legislators can switch their votes overnight because of public opinion.
More than any other recent chairman of the Republican National Committee, however, Mr. Barbour shaped the party's agenda, and influenced legislation, through frequent meetings with Republican leaders on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Barbour, whose four-year term as chairman ended in January 1997, said today that he was retained by his nursing home clients last month and had since discussed their problems with about 15 members of Congress, mostly Republican senators.
He said the Clinton Administration could take steps of its own to relieve the burden on nursing homes, without waiting for Congress to act. But he has not talked to Administration officials. As a rock-ribbed Republican, he said, "I'm probably not the best person for that assignment." (Vic Fazio, a California Democrat who served in the House for 20 years, said he was lobbying the Administration on behalf of the same group of nursing homes.)
Mr. Barbour has not yet filed the required forms with Congress to disclose the amount spent lobbying for nursing homes on Capitol Hill. Asked how much he was being paid, he said, "Not enough," and laughed.
He confirmed that his clients included the Sun Healthcare Group of Albuquerque, N.M.; Vencor Inc. of Louisville, Ky.; the Mariner Post-Acute Network Inc. of Atlanta; Beverly Enterprises of Fort Smith, Ark.; HCR Manor Care Inc. of Toledo, Ohio; Genesis Health Ventures of Kennett Square, Pa., and Extendicare Inc. of Markham, Ontario.
Mr. Barbour said he saw no contradiction between his old and new roles. The Medicare cuts, he said, have been much deeper than either he or Congress expected under the entirely new method of reimbursement established by the 1997 law. In the first half of the current fiscal year, he noted, Medicare actually spent less than in the first half of the prior year. In the last week, three of Mr. Barbour's clients have reported quarterly losses, due in large part, they say, to the Medicare cuts.
"What's ironic," Mr. Barbour said, "is that this Administration is spending so much less on Medicare than Congress intended when it passed the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. It's the same Administration that in 1995 and 1996 constantly clobbered Republicans" for proposing Medicare cuts that would have been less severe than those that have actually been realized.
The nursing home industry has long been a potent force in Washington and many state capitals. Alan D. Solomont, former finance chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was chief executive of the largest nursing home company in Massachusetts and just last month was host at a Democratic fund-raiser attended by President Clinton.
The industry's political action committee made campaign contributions of more than $900,000 in 1997-98, according to data filed with the Federal Election Commission and tabulated by Public Disclosure Inc., a nonpartisan research group.
Mr. Barbour, a seventh-generation Mississippian, has been in and around Washington since 1985, when he became director of the White House office of political affairs under President Ronald Reagan.
He blends his political insights with an exceptionally detailed knowledge of health care policy. Like a true policy expert, he refers to sicker people as "high acuity patients," meaning that they have acute illnesses. And he speaks knowledgeably of RUG's, the "resource utilization groups" into which patients are classified according to their medical condition and need for care.
Mr. Barbour suggests two specific ways to relieve the financial distress of nursing homes: Medicare, he says, should provide a more generous allowance for inflation, based on the market basket of goods and services used by nursing homes. In addition, he says, it should increase its payments for sicker patients.
Mr. Barbour estimated that his clients were receiving an average of $270 to $285 a day for each Medicare patient. By contrast, he said, when the budget law was signed in 1997, nursing homes had been getting $360 a day or more for each Medicare patient, and expected to get $310 to $320 a day in 1999.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, met recently with Mr. Barbour and has requested more financial data. Before rushing to bail out any companies with taxpayers' money, Mr. Grassley said, he wants to know whether they have been mismanaged, whether they grew "too large too fast" and whether they took on more debt than they could handle.
In any event, he said, they must not solve their problems by evicting patients or reducing the quality of care.

HEADLINE: Sticking to Issues Pays Off for Philadelphia Mayoral Primary Winner

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, May 19

 BODY:
In winning the Democratic primary on Tuesday to succeed Edward G. Rendell as Mayor of Philadelphia, John F. Street held tightly to his issue-oriented message in the face of personal attacks that nearly defeated him.
While other candidates in the crowded field used attack advertising in their campaigns, Mr. Street tried to ignore the barrage and emerged with a slim victory over his most aggressive opponent in the race, Marty Weinberg. 
 Mr. Street, 55, who resigned as City Council president to run for mayor, captured 100,902 votes, 35.4 percent of the total, to 89,041 votes, or 31.2 percent, for Mr. Weinberg, an aide to former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo who was making his first run for elective office.
John White Jr., a former head of the city housing agency and the state welfare department, finished third with 61,816 votes for 21.7 percent. Happy Fernandez, a former City Council member and the first woman to run a credible race for mayor of Philadelphia, won 17,952 votes, 6.3 percent. Dwight Evans, a state legislator, had 13,290, 4.6 percent, and Queena R. Bass, a community organizer, had less than 1 percent.
Fewer then 30 percent of the city's 980,000 registered voters turned out, about the average level of participation for a primary in Philadelphia, a city of 1.47 million people, about 40 percent black.
"I am enormously pleased about the way I conducted my campaign," Mr. Street said today at a victory lunch with Mr. Rendell and other city leaders. "But as the winning candidate, I now have to do what I can to bring the party together, not just for me but for the city of Philadelphia."
Much of Mr. Street's success on Tuesday flowed from his smooth working relationship with Mr. Rendell, a popular Democrat who is barred from seeking a third consecutive four-year term. Over the years, they worked together closely, pulling the city back from a fiscal abyss in the early 1990's with programs of economic austerity that led to budget surpluses and urban renewal throughout many parts of the city.
It came as no surprise that Mr. Rendell gave Mr. Street, one of four black candidates in the primary, a hearty endorsement. But in the November general election, Mr. Street will face a Republican opponent who also played a major role in the city's turnaround, Sam Katz, who ran unopposed on Tuesday. As an expert in municipal finance, Mr. Katz, 49, was one of the first consultants Mr. Rendell sought out to stabilize the city's finances.
Mr. Katz ran unsuccessfully for mayor in 1991 and for governor of Pennsylvania in 1994, and in a city where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by almost 4 to 1, it might appear that he has a difficult task ahead.
But aides said his campaign strategy for the general election would be to attract Republicans and the considerable number of Democrats who did not vote for Mr. Street in the primary, including many black voters. It is a calculation that strategists for Mr. Katz helped bring about through the unusual decision to inject him into the Democratic advertising wars. Mr. Katz ran commercials that attacked the two Democrats he least wanted to face in the fall, Mr. Weinberg and Mr. White.
In effect, the aides said, Mr. Katz preferred a showdown with Mr. Street, whose political fervor through years as a black community leader most sharply contrasted with his own. To bolster Mr. Street's chances in the primary, Mr. Katz ran advertisements that questioned Mr. Weinberg's and Mr. White's credibility and management skills.
In addition, Mr. Katz said in an interview, Mr. Street's close relationship with Mr. Rendell provided him an opening to portray Mr. Street as a status quo candidate who is resistant to bolder solutions to the city's most intractable problems. As examples, Mr. Katz said, he favors school vouchers to offer children alternatives to troubled public schools and a faster reduction of the city wage tax as a means to stimulate economic development. Mr. Street opposes vouchers and favors a slower reduction of the wage tax.
Yet to make his case that more drastic measures are necessary, Mr. Katz pointed out that for all the progress in the Rendell-Street years, the city had lost 150,000 residents and 40,000 jobs since 1991.
Mr. Weinberg, meanwhile, focused most of his attacks on Mr. Street, the campaign front-runner who won glowing endorsements from the city's three leading newspapers: The Inquirer, The Daily News and The Tribune, which has a mostly black readership.
Playing largely to the same middle-class and working-class white voters who supported Mayor Rizzo, Mr. Weinberg used television commercials that showed 18-year-old images of Mr. Street shoving a reporter and throwing water in the face of a City Council staff member, Mr. Weinberg's way of suggesting to voters that Mr. Street might be too unstable to lead the city government.
Other Weinberg advertisements cited financial problems Mr. Street once had, including the two times he filed for personal bankruptcy.
For his part, Mr. Street did not respond in his commercials until late in the campaign and then only to admonish Mr. Weinberg for attacking him and injecting an element of race in the campaign.
Rather, Mr. Street focused on issues like seeking more state revenue to improve public schools and expanding economic development as a way to aid some of Philadelphia's neighborhoods, where residents are suffering from substandard housing, joblessness and high crime rates.
"Out of working together, Philadelphia has become a can-do city, and it's important for us to continue that work," said Mr. Street, who would become the city's second black mayor, after W. Wilson Goode, who preceded Mr. Rendell.
"The first step is to make sure we heal the wounds of the primary. I'm sure all the candidates will do their fair share to bring the party and the city back together."

HEADLINE: Some Abandon Water Cooler For Internet Stock Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
In Florida, a young dentist tracks stocks between patients, sometimes even between an X-ray and a filling. In Washington State, a freight-company manager logs on to a financial Web site for four to six hours of his workday. A designer at a California architectural firm gets so absorbed in the market that his productivity falls 25 percent.
The long bull market and cascading advances in technology have combined to drive capitalism's main numbers game into the heart of the American workplace, with millions of wage earners, managers and entrepreneurs obsessing about Wall Street. Their obsession, in fact, far eclipses the speculative 1920's, when elevator operators and bootblacks were a chief source of what passed for information. 
"Two years ago I would have never thought I'd be into doing this," said the dentist, Norma Victores, 30, of Hialeah, Fla., who follows the market on the Internet and has bought part of her portfolio of 21 stocks and mutual funds on line. "I used to think it was just for the big-timers."
While much of the early concern about workday Internet abuse focused on pornography, the lure of the stock market has overtaken it, some specialists said. The Internet is making a lot of information available to small investors that was once accessible only to professionals.
"That's where employees are really wasting their time," said Jonathan Penn, an analyst at Giga Information Group, a firm that advises companies on information technology. "I'd definitely put that first," he added, ahead of sports, personal E-mail, chat rooms and pornography.
The flick-of-the-finger ease with which office workers and others can research, monitor and trade stocks -- often able to return instantly to their assigned tasks -- is a growing concern for employers.
Most of the people willing to discuss the issue were self-employed or worked for small companies where Internet abuses could be dealt with amicably. Larger corporations, while acknowledging the potential for abuse, generally denied that employees were using company time to trade stocks. Some devotees in the workplace said the activity could be addictive, but most simply found it a practical method for earning extra income.
So far, the Government has not been able to measure any economic effect. Michael Harper, the acting associate commissioner for productivity and technology at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, suggested that the time spent by workers on the stock market was not unlike water-cooler discussion of football or movies and might even be a partial substitute for it.
"We don't know whether they would be working or doing something else" if there was less absorption in the market, Mr. Harper said.
But according to Media Metrix Inc., a New York company that meters Internet use much the way Nielsen Media Research does television, 22.8 million Americans used Web sites on company time in March. Some 8.2 million people visited Yahoo Finance, CBS Marketwatch, Schwab, E*Trade and other financial sites at work, up from 6 million just three months earlier, the company said.
About 25 percent of all corporate Internet traffic, much of it surreptitious, is considered unrelated to work.
The stock market "is becoming a huge distraction," said Victor Woodward, a vice president at Content Technologies, which develops programs to help companies create and enforce policies for Internet use. He said corporate demand for help in curbing stock-related Web use had quadrupled in the last year. And companies face growing competition for the attention of their employees: Internet gateways like Yahoo, Go and Excite, eager to attract advertisers, use their home pages to tempt Web browsers to check stock quotes.
On-line trades account for as much as 30 percent of all buying and selling by individual investors, surveys show.
"I can't imagine that this is not a problem in the workplace," said Jill Munden, who oversees Silicon Investor Inc., the biggest financial discussion forum. She said 50 percent of Silicon Investor site visits, which averaged 20 minutes each, came during regular working hours and that "you have to believe most people don't divulge trades and research to their boss or co-workers."
The Web site for Charles Schwab, the broker accounting for more than a quarter of Internet transactions, now averages 33 million visits a day, up from 24 million in the fourth quarter of 1998, according to Daniel Hubbard, a spokesman. And actual transactions, which take only a couple of minutes, are outnumbered 26 to 1 by typically longer sessions for researching companies or mutual funds or to review portfolios.
Schwab's busiest periods, Mr. Hubbard found, coincide with the opening and closing hours of the New York Stock Exchange -- from 9:30 to 11:30 A.M. and 3:30 to 4 P.M., which falls during the workday for most people on the East Coast.
Take the case of Dean Hatfield, 36, the designer, for whom earning between $5,000 and $15,000 a month from on-line trading for much of last year began to threaten his day job.
"Instead of billing, say, 37 hours during the week, as I should have, I was billing perhaps 28," said Mr. Hatfield, who works at KRJ Design in Burlingame, Calif. "It became an issue because the revenue just wasn't coming in." Mr. Hatfield's superiors took away his Internet access, so now if he wants to go on line he must walk to another terminal, his activities easily visible. He likens it to "getting your hands caught in the cookie jar." Now, he says, "I do it on the phone or from home -- but it's not day trading anymore."
At American Fast Freight, a company in Kent, Wash., that bundles shipments into bigger units and then arranges for overseas transport, the official in charge of computers, Jeff LePage, is still struggling to find a way to "put the kibosh" on a manager who is routinely logged onto a financial site for most of the day.
"I hadn't really focused on this until it became chronic," said Mr. LePage, who has noticed a gradual decline in the unit's performance for which he blames the employee, a peer he is reluctant to confront.
Mr. LePage has switched off the employee's financial site, but the employee appears to be logging on to other people's computers. "The battle goes on," Mr. LePage said.
Then there is John Alexandrou, a 43-year-old salesman in Foster City, Calif., who said that for the last three years he has spent 30 minutes to an hour of working time a day on the market. "The adrenaline of trading options, that's got me completely hooked," Mr. Alexandrou said, adding that the fraternity of on-the-job market devotees is very large, especially in Silicon Valley. "You're not going to find very many people in this Valley who are not distracted by the stock market," he said. He insisted, however, that despite his on-the-job trading, he never failed to make his business quotas.
On-the-job Internet stock activity has been a particularly visible problem in the high-technology community on the West Coast, where much of employees' pay is in stock options and it is common for even those of low rank to have an equity stake.
None of this necessarily means that investors pay less attention to their jobs. Ross Brown, vice president of MSI Consulting, a Seattle-based management and marketing adviser to high-technology companies, says he often spends less time tending to his portfolio -- worth in the mid-six figures -- than when he used to phone orders to a broker, a process he said can mean "you've chewed up an hour of your day."
Still, the market is seen as an increasingly serious time eater by many employers, who have only recently begun to monitor Internet activity in earnest. A survey by the Society for Human Resource Management in Alexandria, Va., found 76 percent of members not bothering to monitor activity as recently as 1997.
Moreover, employees seem to have little trouble avoiding detection from casual observation.
"One second I was in E*Trade," said Mr. Hatfield, the California designer, who for a time was making more money trading than in salary. "And the next second I was doing design in Autocad," a tool of his trade.
"I could hide the day trading quite easily," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Large Settlement Expected In Vitamin Price-Fixing Case
The Justice Department is expected to announce as early as today that at least two of the world's largest drug and chemical companies have agreed to pay as much as $700 million to settle charges that they participated in a global conspiracy to fix prices in the sale of vitamins, people close to the talks said.
In what would be the largest settlement ever in a Federal antitrust case, Roche Holding of Switzerland is expected to pay as much as $500 million and BASF of Germany is expected to pay about $200 million. Page A1. 

U.S. Case Against Brokers Falters
The Federal Government's case against a group of stockbrokers charged with illegal trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange has run into a snag. Prosecutors said they could not prove how much the defendants profited from the suspected scheme. C2.
 
Tyco Agrees to Acquire Raychem
Tyco International, the maker of electronic components, agreed to buy Raychem, which makes wiring and tubing for industrial electrical products. Tyco will pay $1.4 billion in cash, issue 16.1 million shares and assume $400 million in debt for Raychem, making the deal worth $3.27 billion. Shares of Raychem soared $5.125, to $36.25. C11.
 
When Work Becomes a Trading Pit
While much of the early concern about Internet abuse at the workplace focused on pornography, the lure of the stock market has overtaken it, some specialists said. A1.
 
Fund Proposal Meets Opposition
The Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's lobbying arm in Washington, is encountering opposition to a recent proposal that would make it easier for brokerage firms to buy and sell securities with their own mutual funds without first seeking regulatory approval, as they must do now. Market Place. C12.
 
Long-Term Treasury Rates Decline
Rates on long-term Treasury securities fell sharply as investors seemed to send a vote of confidence to the Federal Reserve that it would keep inflation at bay. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.80 percent from 5.88 percent on Tuesday. C11.
 
Stock prices rose on Fed-related optimism. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 50.44 points, to 10,887.39; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 10.91 points, to 1,344.23, and Nasdaq composite index climbed 19.04 points, to 2,577.40. C11.
 
Seeds of Uncertainty in China
Despite the anti-American demonstrations that erupted in Chinese cities 10 days ago after the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia, the effect on American business in China has been moderate. Chinese officials like Shanghai Mayor Xu Kuangdi met with foreign investors to ease concerns, but there also signals of slower reforms and greater uncertainty. C10.
 
Car-Hauling Strike Is Threatened
The teamsters' union is threatening a strike by drivers against the trucking companies that carry new cars to dealers. Such a move would likely limit the selection of available vehicles but would not affect the economy as much as a strike at an auto factory. C2.
 
Soft Drink Distributor Settles Suit
B. K. Miller, a soft drink distributor, has agreed to settle its suit against Coca-Cola Enterprises for an undisclosed amount. C2.
 
Lawyer Fined in Cendant Case
A Federal judge fined a lawyer $1,000 after finding he had improperly disclosed confidential aspects of bidding by law firms seeking the lead role in a suit against Cendant. C2.

HEADLINE: Rights Groups Say Logbook Lists Executions by Guatemalan Army

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON and MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, May 19

 BODY:
Lucrecia Vasquez wavers from one day to the next about whether her brother is dead or alive.
The last time she saw him was in April 1984, a few months before he was to have finished medical school. The telephone rang, she recalled, and a moment later the brother, Omar Dario Vasquez, was rushing out the door. He yelled something about a medical emergency and said he would be back soon. But Mr. Vasquez, 23, was never seen again. 
 This week, his sister received what may be the first real evidence about his fate. A logbook that human rights officials said was taken from secret Guatemalan military files explains that Mr. Vasquez was "captured on 7th Avenue, in front of the Hotel Dorado Americana" here.
Nine days later, on May 6, the book said, Mr. Vasquez was killed. His death, human rights investigators said, is noted on the document in military code, using the overseas shorthand that transposes months and days, "06-05-84: 300."
The logbook is to be released on Thursday by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, as well as the National Security Archives, an organization that works to declassify Government papers, and Human Rights Watch and the Washington Office on Latin America, human rights groups. Investigators from the agencies, who have been studying the document for two months, said they had concluded that it describes the activities of a secret unit that kidnapped, tortured, and executed Guatemalans in the early 80's in a violent army campaign against leftists suspected of subversion here.
The deaths and disappearances occurred at a time when the country of 11 million people was being ravaged by civil war between a right-wing military government, supported by the United States, and leftist guerrillas. The war, which ended three years ago, was the longest and bloodiest in Central America. About 200,000 people were killed. Human rights advocates in Guatemala and the United States said the logbook of detainees bound in a tattered plastic binder was the most detailed document about military abuses ever obtained from Guatemalan army sources. Human rights investigators who participated in an independent truth commission, formally the Historical Clarification Commission, had unsuccessfully asked the military for such documents in its 16-month investigation.
Government officials who reviewed the book said although it could be a genuine military intelligence document, it was not something that could be found in the official military archives.
Human rights officials disagreed, saying it proved that similar documents had to exist. "It is about the best evidence we have ever gotten about the cold-blooded, deliberate, calculated strategy that the military used to pick people up one by one," said Kate Doyle, a Guatemala expert for the National Security Archives who led an inquiry on the document. "There must be more documents like this. And now we can press harder for the Guatemalan Government to release them."
Ms. Doyle refused to divulge the source of the document. She said only that human rights agencies had bought it for $2,000 from a former "low-ranking" military officer.
Although almost the entire book is typed in dry shorthand, with no signatures nor military seals, the investigators said they were confident it was genuine.
Dozens of those listed had been reported missing in human rights records and press accounts from the period, Ms. Doyle said, and the dates and detention details about many prisoners also match human rights reports from the period.
After having briefly reviewed the document, Government officials said they could not dispute that contention without conducting their own investigation. A spokesman for President Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen suggested that the logbook be turned over to Guatemalan courts that have been established to investigate allegations of abuse against the military.
The spokesman said that the Government had never tried to keep documents about military abuses hidden but that such documents were not part of "official" military archives.
Defense Minister Hector M. Barrios refused to comment on the book, saying he had not had an opportunity to study it. He noted, however, that "apocryphal documents" had circulated in the past.
General Barrios insisted that the military had turned over "all the information possible" to the truth commission. "We cooperated in everything we could," he said. "But somebody always thinks that there is a great vault with documents. Such a thing does not exist."
Former members of the Historical Clarification Commission said the logbook confirmed their suspicions that the military had kept detailed records of people who were detained, tortured and executed outside the law. The panel found that the military was responsible for 93 percent of all documented human rights violations in the war.
"We asked them for reports on specific cases of people who had disappeared or who were killed on the street, and they told us that such documents did not exist," said Otilia Lux de Coti, a former commissioner and a leading spokeswoman for the Indians here. "That was always their argument. But we knew that an institution like the military that takes such pride in its history had to have more than what they were giving to us."
Ms. Lux de Coti scanned the document and said: "We asked them if they had lists of people who disappeared, and they told us, 'No.' This shows that they did not tell us the truth."
Separated into four main parts, the document has surveillance studies on reportedly subversive organizations, lists subversive safe houses that had been raided with the contents of each house and lists organizations described as "facades for the service of subversion," including the Association of University Students, the Democratic Front Against Repression and Amnesty International.
The most chilling section is the chronological log of detainees. Numbered 1 through 183, each entry lists a prisoner's name and reported pseudonyms, date and location of capture, affiliations with suspected subversive groups and any suspicious activities, including travel to Cuba, meetings in their houses and participation in demonstrations.
Glued beside each entry is a wallet-size photograph of the detainee. Some relatives recognized the photos as coming from Government-issued ID cards. At the end of each entry is a line that describes the prisoner's fate. A few dozen of those on the list were released, some on the condition that they serve as informants for the military unit and help turn in their associates.
More than 100 people on the list were executed, the investigators said. Their deaths were described by the code "300" or the phrase, "He was taken away by Pancho."
Although codified and at times ungrammatical, the book is suspenseful reading. Its entries, some a few lines long and others a half-page each, tell of doctors and shoemakers, labor leaders and students, mechanics and economists who were suspected of participating in efforts to overthrow the military government of Brig. Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, according to the investigators.
They were abducted in shopping areas, restaurants, movie theaters, on the way to work or in their houses. Sometimes they resisted, the document said, they were shot, and "300."
One entry tells about an attempt to capture Edwin Rogelio Rivas Rivas here.
"When they wanted to take " the book said, "he tried to flee on a motorcycle, which made the necessity to shoot, falling gravely wounded. It was tried to revive him on the H.M., but it was impossible. 300. And he was left on the side of the road."
Many of those detained, the book said, were members or supporters of suspected subversive groups like the Guatemalan Workers Party, the Guerrilla Army of the Poor and the Revolutionary Organization of People in Arms.
Rather than criminal charges, the book listed only suspicious activities.
Prisoner No. 1, Teresa Graciela Samayoa Morales, the book said, "traveled to Cuba." No. 17, Orencio Sosa Calderon "is in charge of taking foreign journalists to film different guerrilla fronts," another listing said. And No. 52, Prudencio de Jesus Carrera Camey, 15, an entry said, was a member of the Guatemalan Workers Party "apparatus responsible for painting cars."
For the families of "the disappeared," the dry shorthand provides information denied over 15 or more years. In interviews with relatives of two men and a woman listed as dead, family members said they had ached to know what happened to their children and siblings and, if killed, to be told where to look for the remains.
Only when they are able to mourn and bury their dead, the family members agreed, would prosecutions of those responsible for the killings be a concern.
"First I want to know if he died and where to find him," Ms. Vasquez, 36, a lawyer, said. "Then I want to know who did this? Why?"
She broke down in sobs as she talked in the office of the Group of Mutual Support, an organization of families of the disappeared that has more than 25,000 cases in its files.
"There's no worse thing than uncertainty," she said. "You imagine that he went through the worst. My father thinks he is in another country. He always talks in the present. 'Omar must have kids by now,' he says. My mom is more realistic. She sometimes thinks he was killed."
The relatives confirmed dates of disappearances and other information in the book. Ms. Vasquez confirmed that her brother had belonged to both the Revolutionary Movement of the People and the Revolutionary Organization of People in Arms, a main guerrilla group. The information appeared on the log sheet next to his name, along with "doctor and surgeon."
"He'd tell me: 'Let's fix the world,' Ms. Vasquez recalled. "I'd reply, 'Let's fix it.' "
Shown a page that read "06-05-84: 300" under a photograph of Lesbia Lucrecia Garcia Escobar, her father, Efrain Garcia, 66, made a quick calculation. If she disappeared on April 17, 1984, Mr. Garcia said, that meant that she had been kept alive for 20 days.
"During that time they were torturing her and getting stuff from her," he said without a trace of doubt.
The book said Ms. Garcia Escobar had shared a house with a guerrilla where weapons, grenades and "propaganda" were found. Mr. Garcia, a retired doorman at the Health Ministry, said his daughter, then 29, had been abducted after a man walked into the restaurant where she was dining with a girlfriend and told her that her boyfriend was waiting outside. When she walked out, the girlfriend later told Mr. Garcia, two men pushed her into a waiting car.
A witness gave Mr. Garcia the number of the license plate of a motorcycle that he was told escorted the car, a number that he continues to carry on a scrap of paper. He said he went to the police with it, but was told that the plate did not exist. After that, he recounted, two men began following him, leading him to abandon his search, stay indoors for three months and eventually move.
Ms. Vasquez said she started searching for her brother only after the peace accords of 1996 because family feared that if she pressed for information she would risk danger.
But others, like Jesus "Chusita" Palencia, 70, who is looking for the oldest of her 10 children, have pressed and pushed the whole time. Ms. Palencia said that for 15 years she has sent telegrams to the National Palace, looked at hundreds of bodies in morgues and joined in protests, occupations of public buildings and other demonstrations by human rights groups.
Since the disappearance of the son, Alfonso Alvarado Palencia, a former labor leader shown in the logbook as dead by March 1984, she has also asked the Roman Catholic priest at her parish several times to hold a Mass for her son's return.
"I told the priest to pray for my son's reappearance, but he always says Mass as if my son were dead," Ms. Palencia said.
"It gets worse and worse as the years go by," she said of the Government's silence. "Just a few months ago, I dreamed that someone had knocked on the door, and it was him, dressed in a white shirt. I ran to tell the others, 'Look, children, here is your brother.' And then I woke up.
"If my son is dead, I want at least his little bones."

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
An Upstart Unveils Rival to the Game Boy

BYLINE: By Michel Marriott 

 BODY:
With millions of Game Boys sold worldwide, Nintendo has practically owned the handheld computer amusement market for a decade. At the recent Electronics Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles, SNK, a game maker best known for its presence in video arcades, unveiled its effort to end Game Boy's reign.
Called the Neo Geo Pocket Color, the 16-bit, processor-based game machine is smaller, lighter and faster than Game Boy players, SNK said, and it can display "nearly three times as many colors as Nintendo's Game Boy Color." The Neo Geo system, housed in a sleek horizontal case (Game Boy's case is vertical), is capable of rendering 146 colors simultaneously on its 2.6-inch display screen, compared with Game Boy's slightly smaller display, which can show 52 colors at the same time. The Neo Geo Pocket Color machines also have a thumb-friendly, built-in joystick, rather than the four-point directional game controller that Nintendo uses on its portable and console machines. 
 Neo Geo Pocket Color machines will cost $69.95, $10 less than a Game Boy Color. Beginning on June 1, they will be sold on line through the company's Web site at www.snkusa .com and later in the year in stores. Ten Neo Geo games are available, with 10 more expected later this summer, Ms. Sujishi said. At last count, Game Boy Color can play 450 original titles, including those made for black-and-white Game Boys.
But Jeremy Schwartz, a senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., is skeptical of any newcomer's chances of dislodging Game Boy as a favorite among players.
"Game Boy is so entrenched at this point, with so many people making so many well-known game properties for it, these guys are going to have a very hard time getting any widespread consumer acceptance of it," said Mr. Schwartz, an expert on games. He said there was a long trail of other gaming machines crushed by Game Boys. "They're the master," he said.

HEADLINE: China Trade Group Ready for Business

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 19

 BODY:
China may be angry at the United States after the bombing of its embassy in Belgrade, but it is still open for business.
That was the message carried by the first Chinese trade delegation to visit the United States since NATO's accidental bombing earlier this month set off a diplomatic dispute.
A delegation of about 150 business and government leaders from Jiangsu province, one of China's fastest-growing regions, sounded an upbeat note on economic ties despite a no-show by the province's Governor and his deputy.
"The Governor, Lieutenant Governor and myself have been very dismayed at the incident committed by U.S.-led NATO," said Ye Jian, director general of Jiangsu's Economic Relations and Foreign Trade Commission.
"But I deal with the economy and trade, so I must come," Mr. Ye told a news briefing in Los Angeles on the second day of his 12-day visit.
"Our arrival signals that our policy of opening up to the outside world has not changed," Mr. Ye said. "We want to develop friendly cooperation with American entrepreneurs and people, and develop more trade and investment. This has not changed."
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said today that trade talks aimed at getting Beijing into the World Trade Organization would resume soon. "I do think negotiations will resume," Ms. Barshefsky said in an interview with CNBC. "We are in contact with the Chinese and will soon be setting a date for resumption."

HEADLINE: A Guaranteed Job

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While your look at Project New Hope, the Milwaukee experiment with guaranteed jobs for low-income people, offered a reminder that there is no single remedy for inner-city poverty, it understated the effectiveness of New Hope's job guarantee for those otherwise unable to find work (front page, May 15). 
 Among those not already working full time, New Hope cut the rate of persistent joblessness to 12 percent from 22 percent during participants' first year in the program. The proportion who were not employed over the course of their first two years fell by more than half: to just 6 percent from 13 percent. If we achieved similar success nationally, finding or creating jobs for roughly half of the 1.2 million adults who are unemployed for an entire year because they cannot find work, I don't think we would consider this progress to be modest.
 
CLIFFORD M. JOHNSON
Washington, May 18, 1999
 
The writer is a senior fellow, Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.

HEADLINE: A Guaranteed Job;
Living-Wage Ordinances

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Ralph Nader's criticisms of the increase in corporate tax subsidies and his ideas to use Federal and local legislation to stem their expansion are exactly on target, but may be a long time coming (Op-Ed, May 15). In the meantime, local activists have been applying a useful tool to counteract the increase in corporate welfare: living-wage ordinances. 
 In 35 cities, including Boston, Detroit, Los Angeles and Minneapolis-St. Paul, companies that receive tax abatements from the city must pay their workers at least a living wage. These wage levels are set by local ordinance, and are usually in the neighborhood of $7 to $10 an hour. That's not the most glamorous neighborhood, but it's enough to lift full-time working families above the poverty line.
 
CHAUNA BROCHT
Washington, May 17, 1999
 
The writer is a policy analyst at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
WASHINGTON MUTUAL TO BUY CALIFORNIA MORTGAGE LENDER

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Washington Mutual, a financial services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Long Beach Financial Corporation, a California mortgage lender, for $350.4 million, or $15.50 a share, expanding its presence in the residential mortgage market. Washington Mutual, based in Seattle, has 2,000 offices and assets of $174 billion. Long Beach Financial, known as a subprime lender, makes mortgage loans to customers with spotty credit records, usually at high interest rates, then packages its loans and sells them to institutional investors. Shares of Long Beach jumped 16.8 percent, gaining $2.0625, to $14.375. Shares of Washington Mutual climbed 75 cents, to $39.75.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 5; Circuits 

LENGTH: 2657 words

HEADLINE: A World Of Choices To Plug In To the Net

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
CONSIDER the Internet service provider. Depending on your on-line habits, it can be the home of your familial interactions, the envelope for your business memorandums, the conduit of your deepest desires. It can get about as much intimate use as the lenses of your glasses or the pages of a journal. It is the choice of a way to view Web pages and to send E-mail, and as such it should not be approached without proper introspection and circumspection.
Or should it? For many Internet users, new and seasoned, that choice depends on what start-up disk appears in a mailbox or cereal box on any given day, which provider an employer chooses or which program for an Internet service provider, commonly called an I.S.P., shows up on a new desktop computer. 
 "Based on the correspondence we've received, and its emotional content, choosing an I.S.P. seems to rank somewhere between selecting a long-distance phone service and choosing a caterer for a bar mitzvah," Dr. Dawn McGatney, a Maryland pediatrician and Webmaster, said via E-mail. Dr. McGatney runs a site called Compleat Guide to an I.S.P. You'll Enjoy Using (dogwolf.seagull .net/isp.html). "But we hear from many folks who are now on their fifth or higher I.S.P.," she added. "Once you switch one to two times, it's obviously easier. There is a bit of fear of the unknown here."
Millions of people have decided they would rather switch providers than fight suboptimal service. As of January, 36.7 percent of home Internet users had changed their I.S.P.'s at some point and lived to tell about it, according to the Strategis Group, a Washington-based research company that studies patterns in telecommunications use. It's not an easy decision, but taking that step can be liberating, people who love their new Internet services say.
The scope of the choice is formidable, with 4,500 Internet services available across the country. According to Forrester Research, America Online has 39.4 percent of all home accounts (with Compuserve, which AOL owns, the total is 41.9 percent); AOL's 17 million subscribers worldwide are a group larger than the combined daily circulation of the top 20 daily newspapers. Other large services, like AT&T, Earthlink, MSN and Prodigy, collectively share 15.3 percent of the market, while small I.S.P.'s -- those with less than 2 percent of the market, like Sprint, Erols and the local Bell telephone companies -- serve 41.3 percent.
Internet services compete fiercely for new Internet users and for people who have been on line for years.
AOL is the 800-pound gorilla in the middle of the information superhighway and the new user's magnet. Its simple-to-install software and ubiquitous distribution are the keys to its success. Andrew Shepherd, a Forrester Research analyst, said that as of January, AOL had captured 54 percent of all users who had been on line for less than six months and half of all users who had been on line for less than a year. It has also garnered its share of criticism, as have other large and small I.S.P.'s, for slow service, busy signals, the prevalence of spam and concerns about members' privacy. But Kathy McKiernan, an AOL spokeswoman, said that the company was experiencing its fastest growth and lowest turnover rate ever.
Another service provider, Earthlink Network, based in Pasadena, Calif., is competing for customers by, among other things, marketing its Get Out of AOL Free plan and offering promotions like a free month of service or free setup. Earthlink can transfer Favorite Places Web sites from AOL to a new browser and will send E-mail to everyone in a new customer's electronic address book to notify them of the change of address.
Taking cues from AOL, Earthlink has created easy-to-use software that features a friendly on-screen guide, named Lisa. "She'll say: 'Hi, welcome to Earthlink. I'll walk you through step by step. Click here,' but you can also shut her up," said a company spokeswoman, Kirsten Kappos.
Other Internet providers, particularly smaller ones, win new subscribers in more personal ways. Paul Budlong of Seattle, for example, chose his small I.S.P., based in Seattle, after receiving E-mail from someone who used it.
"I liked the name," he said of Drizzle.com, and found it appropriate to local weather conditions. He switched from a provider in Portland, Ore., to Drizzle, which serves the Puget Sound region. He was frustrated by his old service's busy signals (it could take up to 20 attempts to get through) and "complete technomorons at tech support who were incapable of speaking plain English." He found the smaller local provider to be more helpful.
"They E-mail back, they call back, they explain things in simple terms, they're friendly, on the ball and very patient," said Mr. Budlong, who has an old 386 computer with software that could best be described as quaint. The support staff even downloaded a huge program for him that would have taken him hours to do on line. "I went downtown, knocked on the door, and they didn't even charge me for the disks," he said. "It was very cool."
But the smaller I.S.P.'s are particularly vulnerable to mergers and acquisitions, so they are less likely to remain stable.
People who find an I.S.P. they like might hesitate to rave about it because that might encourage others to join, leading to busy signals all over again.
"I had a friend who wouldn't tell anybody when he'd find an I.S.P. he liked," said David Cassel, editor of the AOL Watch newsletter, which is distributed to an E-mail list of 42,000 readers. "You really want a small service no one has ever heard about."
The search for the perfect fit can be traumatic. While any other company that hung up on customers several times a day could expect a quick pink slip, an I.S.P. is harder to dump. Switching providers could mean forfeiting prepaid Internet service, spending hours rejiggering modem strings and software interfaces, losing old E-mail messages and printing new business cards and resumes with the new E-mail address.
"The No. 1 reason that folks stick with an I.S.P. that they hate -- and they can get truly emotional on the subject -- is that they've prepaid a year or two in advance and stand to lose hundreds of dollars by leaving," Dr. McGatney said. "The trick here is always to read the I.S.P.'s terms of service before subscribing. Be sure that the I.S.P. offers a prorated refund for those who cancel early. The No. 2 reason would be the pain of notifying all your friends that you have a new E-mail address, though many I.S.P.'s will forward your E-mail forever at no charge." Mail sent to a closed AOL account, she said, bounces back with a note that the mail could not be delivered.
Jason Catlett, president of the Junkbusters Corporation, an on-line privacy advocacy group in Green Brook, N.J., said switching often required reconfiguring the user's computer. "That's probably a traumatic experience for many people," he said.
Chris Sherman, a Web search guide at the Mining Company site, said some Internet patterns were hard to break. His parents started out with AOL and resisted a move to Mindspring, he said. "Even though Mindspring is so easy, they were comfortable with AOL," he said. "It's an inertia issue more than a branding issue."
When choosing a provider, a computer user should decide whether one goal is to get broad-bandwidth Internet access, which allows Internet connections at speeds faster than the current standard consumer maximum, 56 kilobits per second on a conventional telephone line. These faster access routes to the Internet have many advantages: they can be open as long as the computer is on, there is no waiting for dial tones, and there is little waiting for Web sites to load.
Internet service through a cable TV provider, which is available in some places, can typically download one megabyte of data in less than 8 seconds, compared with digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L. lines, at 15 seconds or a fast telephone modem, operating at 56K, at two and a half minutes. (Actual speeds can vary.)
Cable Internet service connects a house through cable television wires, with, in most cases, the cable company acting as the Internet provider. D.S.L. connects a computer to the Net through existing phone lines but the computer must be within limited a distance -- a few miles -- of a phone company switching center.
"You can pretty much count on the fact that the larger I.S.P.'s are in heavy-duty competition to roll out high-speed access," Mr. Sherman said. "The question is just when."
Cable companies can now reach only about 23 million households. Their Internet service costs about $40 per month, said David Eiswert at the Strategis Group. D.S.L. lines are available to about six million households for about $50 a month, compared with a cost of about $20 a month for traditional dial-up services.
"That's in some ways going to be one of the things that allows dial-up I.S.P.'s to really fight off cable in the short term," said Mr. Shepherd, of Forrester Research. "They're providing service at half the cost."
Some people decide not to pay for any I.S.P. and rely on free Web services instead.
"People can take half-steps -- get a Geocities Web page and Juno E-mail account and access the Web through a machine at work or the local public library if they don't want dial-up service," said Mr. Cassel, of AOL Watch. Juno, Hotmail and Alta Vista mail are examples of free E-mail services that a user can log onto from a computer at a public library or Internet cafe. Free Web pages are available at sites like Geocities and Tripod.
Many Web surfers, however, want Web access from home. Some choose their I.S.P.'s based on particular needs -- a frequent traveler might want to have access to the Internet service while overseas, for example, or a biology buff might need a large space on the Web to post a special page on the naked mole rat. Other customers choose a service like AOL because it provides something like a roped-off section of the larger Internet for children.
There can be advantages in switching providers. "Changing your E-mail address periodically and auto-notifying the sender to the old address with a message is a great way to get off of every spam list in the world," Dr. McGatney said. "Each time we've moved, our junk mail dropped to zero for the next several months."
 
Choices and Defaults
 
Don Ho
Entertainer (through his Internet director, Christopher Soares).
"We picked a local service provider based on price, service, tech support, dial-ups and personalized service, not necessarily in that order, mind you. We were with a local company. One of the partners, whom we started with, split and formed his own I.S.P. called Maikai.net (www.maikai.net). So now we're with them. Because I know the service will remain excellent! We've found that the larger I.S.P.'s are of little or no help when they're done setting you up with a D.N.S."
 
Linus Torvalds
Creator of the Linux operating system.
"I've never had to choose; I've always gotten a free Internet connection through my work (or my studies back when I was at the university)."
 
Jason Catlett
President of Junkbusters, an on-line privacy advocacy group.
"At the time I started using ISDN, Eclipse Internet was the only I.S.P. with ISDN-capable modems in my local calling area. Now many others do, but I haven't bothered to shop around. Also, I like the fact that they're comparatively small because of the rumors that some of the big national I.S.P.'s are considering deals where they sell details of their customers' surfing activities to advertisers."
 
Isabel Wang
Co-founder of I.S.P.-Check, which helps users find Internet service providers and Web page hosts.
"I was with Bell Atlantic for a long time. They claim they support 56K, but I was always connecting at 28, and there were busy signals on weekends and evenings. I'd get kicked off every five minutes. I switched to Starpower, which is good. It was really easy. Most I.S.P.'s can set you up the same day or the same minute when they have you on the phone."
 
Pattiann Rogers
Poet, whose ninth book, "The Dream of the Marsh Wren, Writing as Reciprocal Creation," will be out in June.
"There was an article in a computer magazine that gave Mindspring a very high rating. I couldn't always make connections reliably on Compuserve so I switched to Mindspring because of its rating and because I wanted service for a Web site. I've been with Mindspring several years now and am satisfied."
 
Talking Points
Questions to Ask Before Buying Internet Service
 
Whether you are finding your very first Internet service provider or looking for the perfect one after seven false starts, choosing an I.S.P. is challenging. Here are some questions to ask when shopping around:
 
HOW COMMITTED DO I HAVE TO BE? -- Extra points go to providers offering trial memberships. Beware of those that tie you down to years of service if you want a good rate. Find out if you can get money back if you switch later.
 
CAN I GET CONNECTED? -- Try dialing the phone numbers of a prospective I.S.P. during peak times and make sure you hear a modem screech (good) instead of a busy signal (very bad). Ask about the service's user-to-modem ratio, and find out if there are any guarantees about how easy it will be to connect to the Web.
 
WILL MY I.S.P. KEEP UP WITH TECHNOLOGY? -- Find out if your prospective provider plans to offer broad-band technology like D.S.L. for speedier access to the Internet. If you are particularly fond of playing games, shopping or trading stock on line, make sure that the service has sufficient bandwidth to accommodate those activities easily. Talk to customer service or sales representatives to see if the provider has partners for D.S.L. service in your area or plans such partnerships. Or find out whether you could continue with the provider if you got a cable Internet connection; some I.S.P.'s offer discounts for people gaining access to the Net through cable modems.
 
IS THE PRICE RIGHT? -- If you don't choose unlimited access, make sure you can afford the often-steep hourly rates if you exceed your monthly minimum. You should find out if the provider has hefty setup fees.
 
IS THERE FREE, 24-HOUR TECH SUPPORT? -- You will most likely need it. To check out customer satisfaction with a provider, talk to other people who use it. If you can't find someone off line, try searching newsgroups on line for comments from the Web world at large.
 
IS ACCESS AVAILABLE ON THE ROAD? -- If you need access while traveling, your provider should have a wide range of local numbers in the areas you tend to visit or offer 800 numbers. If you decide on cable or D.S.L. service, make sure that you can connect in other cities through your provider when you are limited to a phone line on the road. With Web TV, you need a box unit to get on line from the road.
 
WILL I HAVE PRIVACY ON THIS I.S.P.? -- You should ask if the I.S.P. will sell your name to marketers or bombard you with spam. It is also wise to find out if you can post what you want on your Web page, including commercial material, if applicable.
They say that breaking up is hard to do, but there are ways to soften the separation anxiety when changing I.S.P.'s. "Don't get wedded to your I.S.P.," said Jason Catlett, president of the Junkbusters Corporation, an advocate of on-line privacy. "They should be a commodity service, and you should be able to switch easily if they raise prices or start invading your privacy." Mr. Catlett noted that E-mail tended to tie people to their I.S.P.'s. He suggested breaking that link by using an E-mail forwarding service (like Pobox.com, Ziplink or a college alumni group that offers lifetime E-mail addresses). That way you can keep one E-mail address, regardless of how many times you change providers. TINA KELLEY

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section E; PT1; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 475 words

HEADLINE: Acting Is in Their Blood, Blood Is in Their Eyes

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
Quentin Tarantino has already blasted himself a niche in cinema history, but his full impact on the gross national product may not be measurable until the last of his filmmaking disciples has exorcised the demon that impels them to imitate ''Pulp Fiction.''
 The latest of these bloody black comedies is ''Frogs for Snakes,'' written and directed by Amos Poe. It tells the story of a group of lower Manhattan lowlifes circulating in the malign milieu of a corpulent loan shark who also happens to be a bit of a theatrical impresario. And all of his associates, lovers, ex-lovers, children and their friends yearn seriously to act. 
 So here's the joke that is repeated throughout the film: for all of these people, killing or maiming is simply business. What really stirs their blood is the thought that someone else in this circle might get a part they covet or have the gall to choose a monologue in an audition or acting class that they regard as theirs. These are people who would literally kill for a role.
 Mr. Poe has assembled a fine cast, led by Barbara Hershey as Eva, and including people like John Leguizamo, Robbie Coltrane, Justin Theroux, Ron Perlman, Harry Hamlin, Debi Mazar and Lisa Marie. But in the end, after the oral sex monologue and the bouncing shotgunned head and the gallons of blood and the diner that have their ''Pulp Fiction'' counterparts, ''Frogs for Snakes'' remains derivative.
 Although surely not for delicate sensibilities, the film nonetheless maintains a consistent sense of macabre humor and delivers vivid performances. Ms. Hershey as the ex-wife of Al (Mr. Coltrane), the mother of their little boy, a sometime hit woman and occasional waitress, is the best actor of the lot but eager to escape to a better life. ''I don't kill people,'' she says to one of her targets. ''I maim them.''
 Her determination is intensified after her lover, Zip (Mr. Leguizamo), is gunned down by Al's wheel man, U. B. (David Deblinger), whose zeal is heightened by his desire for a role in Al's next production, David Mamet's ''American Buffalo.''
 ''Frogs for Snakes'' begins intriguingly, but thereafter it is mostly recycled ''Pulp.''
 ''Frogs for Snakes'' is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It contains bloody violence, coarse language and simulated sex.

FROGS FOR SNAKES
Written and directed by Amos Poe; director of photography, Enrique Chediak; edited by Jeff Kushner; music by Lazy Boy; production designer, Michael Shaw; produced by Phyllis Freed Kaufman; released by The Shooting Gallery. Running time: 92 minutes. This film is rated R.

WITH: Barbara Hershey (Eva), Robbie Coltrane (Al), Harry Hamlin (Klench), Ian Hart (Quint), John Leguizamo (Zip), Lisa Marie (Myrna), Debi Mazar (Simone), Ron Perlman (Gascone), Justin Theroux (Flav), David Deblinger (U. B.) and Clarence Williams 3d (Huck).
