SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 27; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 4253 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Cosmopolitan Makeover for a Tidewater Backwater

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va.

 BODY:
Hampton Roads, the natural harbor where the James River and several lesser streams meet Chesapeake Bay, has had a balcony seat for history.
It was into these waters that Capt. John Smith and his companions sailed in 1607 after their first landfall at Cape Henry, on their way to establish Jamestown. It was near here that the French admiral Francois de Grasse turned back a British relief fleet in 1781, sealing the fate of Lord Cornwallis at Yorktown. 
 Here Commodore Perry set sail for his voyage to Japan in 1853, here the Monitor fought the Merrimac, heralding the age of the ironclad that revolutionized naval warfare, here the American invasion force set out for North Africa during World War II. Here American warships have been built and the powerful Atlantic Fleet has long been based.
But until recently, much of Tidewater, as the locals call the region, was a backwater. The writer William Styron grew up in Tidewater, and in his early novel "Lie Down in Darkness" (1951), he wrote feelingly of "the low, sorrowful beauty of tideland streams winding through marshes full of small, darting, frightened noises and glistening and dead silent at noon, except for a whistle, far off, and a distant rumble on the rails."
You still find such places. One is the little county seat of Surry, across the river from Jamestown, where a Confederate memorial bears the bittersweet inscription, "Our Heroes." Life there is lived legato.
They are no longer typical, though. Hampton Roads -- composed, for our purposes, of the cities of Norfolk, Portsmouth, Virginia Beach, Hampton and Newport News, plus the towns of Jamestown, Yorktown and Williamsburg -- has long since overtaken Richmond as a metropolitan area. Its population now exceeds 1.5 million, roughly a quarter of the state's total, and Virginia Beach, of all unlikely places, is the Old Dominion's largest city, with 393,000 people.
On a long weekend here recently, my wife, Betsey, and I were flabbergasted by the transformation. As a schoolgirl 40 years ago, she used to take the train to Buckroe Beach in Hampton on swimming outings, and as a draftee 40 years ago I was based at sleepy Fort Monroe, nearby, writing speeches for Gen. Bruce C. Clarke, one of the lions of the Battle of the Bulge, and sometimes for Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, a D-Day hero.
What happened? I asked my brother-in-law St. George Pinckney, a Richmond man through and through. Simple, he said: "The foreigners and the come-heres" did it.
"In the last 25 years, Europeans at the NATO headquarters in Norfolk, people at the military bases, civilians from all over the country whose companies moved them into the area, all helped break through the crust of insularity," he said. "In Richmond, that never happened."
The benign climate helped. This may not exactly be the Sun Belt, but snow is about as common in these parts as Russian submarines.
 
The Fleet's Really In
The military remains the economic prime mover, despite a lot of recent diversification. People here work in a Ford assembly plant and a Budweiser brewery, for the mail-order queen Lillian Vernon and Pat Robertson's Christian Broadcasting Network.
But one in every four workers in Hampton Roads -- like Los Angeles County, it is politically subdivided but economically united -- takes home a paycheck from Uncle Sam, and total defense spending here in 1997 totaled $6.92 billion. In terms of active-duty personnel, seven of the nation's 60 largest military installations are located in Hampton Roads.
The Army has Fort Eustis, its transportation center, and Fort Monroe, the only moated installation still in active use, where Jefferson Davis was imprisoned after the Civil War. The Air Force has Langley Air Force Base, the oldest active air base in the country. Near that is NASA's big Langley Research Center, established in 1917, where the astronauts learned the Right Stuff for the pioneering Mercury and Apollo space shots.
Norfolk, of course, is a Navy town par excellence. All along its western flank rise the fearsome gray superstructures of aircraft carriers, cruisers and other vessels -- fighting machines catching their breath between missions. The Norfolk Naval Base is the largest in the world, home to more than 100 major ships and 27 squadrons of aircraft. More than 75,000 people work there. More than 25,000 other people work at the Little Creek amphibious base and the Oceana Naval Air Station, both in Virginia Beach.
But Norfolk is no longer the brawling liberty town of World War II. It was once as disorderly and disreputable a place as you could find on the East Coast, and Main Street, a young man we met there told us, "used to be nothing but bars, cathouses, tattoo parlors, and more bars." Now it is lined with gleaming modern buildings, including hotels, a world trade center and bank towers, as well as Nauticus, a Disneyesque maritime museum.
Norfolk has yet to attract a big-league sports franchise; this must be one of the largest metropolitan areas in the nation without one. But the New York Mets' Triple-A farm team, the Norfolk Tides, play their home games in Harbor Park, a spiffy stadium close to the waterfront.
Most surprisingly, perhaps, Norfolk's metamorphosis has included its emergence as a cultural center of note, with the Chrysler Museum of Art and Virginia Opera in the vanguard. Both rank among the outstanding institutions of their size in the South and, for that matter, the nation.
It was Walter P. Chrysler Jr., son of the founder of the Chrysler Corporation, who enabled Norfolk to join the late 20th-century revolution in which museums have helped to power the revival of struggling cities. Married to a Norfolk native, he lifted a provincial collection into the top rank in 1971 with the gift of 30,000 objects that "any museum in the world would kill for," as John Russell wrote on one occasion in The New York Times.
In 1989, the museum was deftly enlarged, modernized and reorganized by the Washington architects George Hartman and Warren Cox.
A series of rooms just to the right of the main entrance contains two of the museum's treasures. A collection of Art Nouveau furniture by Majorelle and Colonna, accompanied by Tiffany and Galle accessories, fills the first. Then comes a feast of glass, unmatched on this continent except in the glass-making towns of Toledo, Ohio, and Corning, N.Y.: room after room of Favrile vases and Tiffany lamps, dozens of major pieces of Lalique, Steuben and Wiener Werkstette glass, Sandwich glass, Amberina, Murano glass.
Upstairs, in the picture galleries, my eye was caught by a precise profile portrait of a man in a red turban, attributed to Domenico Veneziano, Piero della Francesca's teacher, whose surviving works are exceedingly rare; Georges de la Tour's pensive St. Philip; a brassy, recumbent blonde, "Mlle. Monna Lils," by the Dutch modernist Kees van Dongen, and a mural by Thomas Hart Benton, painted for the original Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, which vividly embodies the breakneck pace of modern life.
An elaborate parcel-gilt silver cup in the shape of a pineapple, made in London in 1610, testifies to the civilization the Jamestown settlers left behind three years earlier for a rude life in the wilderness.
Until fall, in the largest of the Chrysler's galleries, a giant, golden Dale Chihuly glass sculpture, "Laguna Murano Chandelier," has joined Venetian masterpieces of another era by Veronese and Tintoretto. At the far end of the room, Bernini's great, wide-eyed "Bust of the Savior," which the Baroque master originally intended for Queen Christina of Sweden, "finally has something to stare at," as a curator irreverently remarked to us.
More Chihulys, some of them so dazzling they made me weak in the knees, are on show for three months at the Contemporary Art Center of Virginia in Virginia Beach, magnificently installed and brilliantly lit.

The Music Man
The Virginia Opera has had but one general director in its quarter-century existence, a Brooklyn-born violist named Peter Mark. He has put it on the musical map in not one but three locations. The company's principal residence is the Harrison Theater in Norfolk, a smashing post-modern conversion (by the Boston architect Graham Gund) of a seedy former U.S.O. theater and wrestling arena. Completed in 1993 on a budget of under $10 million, it eschews frou-frou to focus on comfort and capacity (1,600 seats).
Next season Virginia Opera will stage 46 performances of five operas, including a Handel rarity, "Rodelinda," here and in Richmond and northern Virginia. In addition, it will take its shows on the road, performing in various guises before a quarter-million Virginia schoolchildren, an unmatched educational touring program.
Mr. Mark, who also conducts, has given important early breaks to singers as important as Renee Fleming. Two dozen of his alumni are on the current roster at the Metropolitan Opera. The company has done "Don Pasquale" as a spaghetti western, no less, and it has presented acclaimed premieres of several works by Mr. Mark's wife, the Scottish composer Thea Musgrave, most recently her eighth opera, "Simon Bolivar," in January 1995.
"It was like picking up a live wire," Mr. Mark said of his arrival here. "In New York and L.A., people take things for granted. Here, people who want something better for their children realize they have to roll up their sleeves and create it."
The 75-year-old Virginia Symphony Orchestra, which plays for the opera's performances, has begun to burnish its reputation under its young conductor, JoAnn Faletta. This spring, the orchestra was featured during the wide-ranging third annual Virginia Waterfront International Arts Festival. The thoroughly professional Virginia Stage Company plays in the handsome old Wells Theater downtown.
Norfolk is a very old city, of course, and quite a few handprints of history have survived the free-swinging wrecker's ball of recent decades. Among the most notable are three grouped close together downtown: St. Paul's Episcopal Church (1739), shaded by towering magnolias, which has a Revolutionary cannonball lodged in its south wall; the Federal-style Moses Myers House, built in 1793 by the city's first Jewish family, who brought with them from New York portraits by Gilbert Stuart and Thomas Sully, which still hang in the house, and the gray-and-white Old Norfolk Academy (1840), designed in a rigorous Greek Revival style by Thomas U. Walter, who added the House and Senate wings and the cast-iron dome to the United States Capitol.

A General's Tomb
Another of Walter's local buildings, the domed Old City Hall, has been turned into a Napoleonic mausoleum for Gen. Douglas MacArthur, a tomb almost as grandiose as his ego. No fan of his, I gave it a pass and instead visited the Scope Arena, a soaring, saucerlike dome of interlocking concrete triangles, supported only by a system of massive buttresses outside. The work of the Italian Pier Luigi Nervi, this is engineering become art.
You have to climb into the car to see the three 17th-century brick buildings that lie beyond the city's perimeter. So far as I know, they are the only survivors of their kind in the country: the simple, story-and-a-half Adam Thoroughgood House in Virginia Beach (circa 1680), named for a man who came to Virginia as an indentured servant and made a fortune in tobacco, an early example of American upward mobility; Bacon's Castle (1665), near Surry, a two-story Jacobean manor house with a pair of triple chimneys and curvilinear gables, and the wonderful, cherry-pink St. Luke's Church (1632), near Smithfield, probably the only truly Gothic (as against Gothic Revival) structure remaining in America, with the stone buttresses, pediment, crockets and finials of the old-country models faithfully copied in brick.
If you come to Hampton Roads in springtime, you will encounter an intoxicating array of flowering shrubs and trees along most streets -- Bradford pears, wisteria, camelias, magnolias and azaleas. The very best show is at the excellent Norfolk Botanical Gardens, created by the W.P.A.

A Rolling Excursion
A 10-minute trip across the Hampton Roads Bridge-Tunnel will take you to Hampton, the oldest continuous English-speaking community in America. Fort Monroe, once known as "the Gibraltar of the Chesapeake," stands at its edge. Burned twice, in the War of 1812 and the Civil War, the old town has little to show for its long history, with the notable exceptions of Hampton University, founded in 1868 as Hampton Institute to educate freed slaves, and St. John's Church, the oldest Anglican parish in the Western Hemisphere, dating from 1610. The present church dates "only" from 1728, but its lovely silver communion plate, made in England in 1618, is still in use weekly.
Newport News, which lies to the west of Hampton, is more of a 19th-century phenomenon. Collis P. Huntington, the railroad baron, chose it as the eastern terminus of his new Chesapeake & Ohio Railroad, with which he linked his Western lines to the Atlantic. He also established the gigantic Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, still the nation's biggest.
It was Collis's son, Archer, who contributed to the city the institution you're most likely to visit there, the Mariners' Museum. It has fabulous collections of ship models, from six inches to six feet long; ship's figureheads, including a 3,200-pound eagle from the U.S.S. Lancaster, built in 1881, and artifacts associated with the ill-fated liner Titanic.
Farther up the Virginia Peninsula, as the tongue of land between the James and York rivers is known, two towns a few miles apart witnessed the beginning and the end of Britain's colonial experience in America.
Yorktown is not nearly as interesting a battlefield as Gettysburg or Antietam, frankly, and the recreated Jamestown Settlement, despite impressive museums, has something of the theme park about it. The site of the original village, administered by the Colonial National Historical Park, includes the broken tower of the settlers' fourth church, finished in 1647, which stands amid lacy dogwoods -- "God's perfect trees," Betsey calls them.
But somehow neither the tower nor the reproduction huts at the Settlement proved as evocative for us as other features of the historic park, like the pitch swamp where the settlers struggled to survive, now inhabited most visibly by herons, or the simple list of the 104 settlers who stayed in 1607, and the 50 among them who died within six months.
It was fascinating, too, to put some flesh on the cardboard figure of John Smith, the colony's gutsy, imperious leader. Long before he reached the American wilderness, it turns out, he had fought in Hungary, been taken in captivity to Turkey, been sold into slavery in Russia, killed his master, escaped and made his way home to Britain. I guess he must have sailed for Virginia to inject some excitement into a humdrum life.

The Lure of Williamsburg
I have saved for last the area's premier attraction for tourists, Colonial Williamsburg, the reconstituted capital of Patrick Henry and George Washington, willed back into existence by the millions of the philanthropist John D. Rockefeller Jr.
There is no more need to describe it than to describe the Statue of Liberty. Suffice it to say that I went there as a kid, visited it often when I was at Fort Monroe and took my stepchildren there. I have never tired of it, especially the restored Governor's Palace, with its formal gardens, and the George Wythe House, which belonged to Jefferson's law teacher. This time, Betsey and I especially enjoyed a 10-minute midday prayer service at Bruton Parish Church, sitting in a box pew that belonged to St. George Tucker, whose descendant, another St. George Tucker, christened her. Fond of continuity, these Virginians.
Of course, it's the ensemble that counts in Williamsburg -- shops and taverns, houses and gardens -- plus two amazing museums. One houses Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's pioneering collection of American folk art; a special show of Edward Hicks landscapes has been mounted there this year. The other, designed by Kevin Roche and named for DeWitt Wallace, a co-founder of The Reader's Digest, houses a world-class decorative arts collection.
And more, always more: just down the road stands Carter's Grove, the Georgian plantation often described as "the most beautiful house in America," and all over Williamsburg there are daily re-enactments of turning points in colonial history, designed to involve vistors in the past.
These last were part of the recipe for Williamsburg's rebound after an attendance slump in the late 80's and early 90's, caused partly by theme parks and science centers.
"We felt we had to create a more compelling environment to tell the story of our country's ideals and values," explained Robert C. Wilburn, Williamsburg's outgoing president. "We needed more than antiques and gardens. This is no longer your mother's Colonial Williamsburg, and we're back to the busiest we've ever been."
 
A Region of Shipshape Hotels, Savory Marine Chow and Colonial History
Here is information about visiting the Hampton Roads area around Norfolk, Va.:
 
Where to Stay
 
COLONIAL HOUSES, 302 East Francis Street, Williamsburg, (757) 565-8440. This is Williamsburg's best-kept secret. It's hard to imagine a more charming place to spend a night or a weekend than one of the 18th-century houses or taverns in the colonial capital, with authentically creaking floors, fetchingly time-worn antiques, working fireplaces and modern plumbing. Ours, once occupied by Cary Grant, came with a quartet of well-mannered sheep across the street. Double room: $99 to $200 a night.
 
MARRIOTT WATERSIDE, 235 East Main Street, Norfolk, (757) 627-4200. An unusually well-managed chain hotel, Norfolk's best, with fascinating views over the ship-filled harbor from rooms on the upper stories. Right in the middle of the downtown area, near Waterside Marketplace, yet close to freeways. The 405 rooms are bright and immaculate if not luxurious. The good-humored clerks and bellmen act as if they enjoy what they do. Double room: $159 to $179 a night.
 
PAGE HOUSE INN, 313 Fairfax Avenue, Norfolk, (757) 625-5033. Four rooms, two suites, in a superbly refurbished Georgian Revival brick mansion, built in 1898, with the leafy streets of the Ghent district on the doorstep. This urban, urbane bed-and-breakfast is so close to the Chrysler Museum of Art that you could come back at midday to rest your feet for an hour or so if need be. Up-to-date gear, including cable TV, modems and in-room fridges. Double room: $116 to $185 a night.
 
WILLIAMSBURG INN, Francis Street, Williamsburg, (757) 229-1000. The region's premier establishment, owned by Colonial Williamsburg, is sedate and agreeably old-fashioned. The decor is pure 1930's, with quilted sateen bedspreads, swag curtains and flowered wallpaper, but the bathrooms and air-conditioning are 1990's and the sheets and towels are to die for. The staff is remarkably friendly and accommodating. Killer breakfasts. Double room: $365 a night.
 
What to Eat
 
FORD'S COLONY, 240 Ford's Colony Drive, Williamsburg, (757) 258-4100. Among his peers, David Everett is considered one of the South's standout chefs. No wonder. In a formal dining room overlooking a suburban golf course, he serves delicious, technically accomplished dishes like a four-story tower of tomatoes, blackened and spiced crabmeat and chopped cured salmon. The wines are superb; the service, alas, is a little pompous.
 
LUCKY STAR, 1608 Pleasure House Road, Virginia Beach, (757) 363-8410. Decorated with 1940's flea-market finds, this congenial spot is tucked into a strip mall halfway between downtown Norfolk and the beach. Butch Butt, once a fisherman, knows where to find the best local, seasonal raw materials, and his partner, Amy Brandt, cooks them simply and skillfully -- prime soft-shell crabs, from the Atlantic, not the Bay; wild rockfish, cherrystone clams from their place of origin, Cherrystone Creek on the Eastern Shore.
 
PIERCE'S PITT BAR-B-QUE, 137 Rochambeau Drive, Lightfoot, (757) 565-2955. You won't miss it on the highway near Williamsburg, not with its orange and red Day-Glo paint job. Pierce's is expanding again. But the pitmaster sticks to tradition: succulent ribs and pork shoulder, slow-cooked over oak and hickory logs. Pitt? A sign-painter's mistake that stuck.
 
SURREY HOUSE, Route 31, Surry, (757) 294-3389. A 50's roadhouse in a little courthouse town near the James River ferry, serving authentic, unadorned regional food: peanut soup, proper crab cakes, dynamite country ham cured by S. Wallace Edwards & Sons, just down the road, and lemon chess pie with a featherweight crust. Wanda, the waitress, has the sweetest smile and softest voice this side of heaven.
 
TODD JURICH'S BISTRO, 210 West York Street, Norfolk, (757) 622-3210. Norfolk's standout, an unpretentious room with paper tablecloths. Mr. Jurich is a wizard with Eastern Shore shellfish; try his mouthwateringly plump, juicy fried oysters or the irresistible oyster stew, flavored with slivers of country bacon. Some dishes have too many ingredients, but the wine list is exemplary and the prices are minuscule (no starter above $8).
 
TRELLIS, 403 Duke of Gloucester Street, Williamsburg, (757) 229-8610. Marcel Desaulniers is a noted cookbook author who specializes in salads (spicy shrimp with shaved parmesan and celery, marinated tuna with arugula) and satanically rich chocolate desserts. The main courses taste better than they read, especially the pan-fried chicken. More than a dozen Virginia wines, plus plenty of others; the wait staff is overstretched.
 
Attractions
 
CHRYSLER MUSEUM OF ART, 245 West Olney Road, Norfolk, (757) 664-6200. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission: $6; $5, the elderly and students; 12 and under, free.
 
ST. PAUL'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH, 201 St. Paul's Boulevard, Norfolk, (757) 627-4353. Mondays through Fridays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; services on Sunday at 8 and 10:30 A.M.
 
MOSES MYERS HOUSE, 331 Bank Street, Norfolk, (757) 664-6200. Open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission: $4; children 12 through college, those in active military duty, teachers and the elderly, $2.50; children under 12 are free.
 
OLD NORFOLK ACADEMY (HAMPTON ROADS CHAMBER OF COMMERCE), 420 Bank Street, Norfolk, (757) 622-2312, ext. 4. Hours: 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.
 
MacARTHUR MEMORIAL, MacArthur Square, Norfolk, (757) 441-2965. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free.
 
NORFOLK BOTANICAL GARDENS, Azalea Garden Road, Norfolk, (757) 441-5830. Open daily, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Admission: $4; $3, the elderly; $2, children 6 to 18.
 
MARINERS' MUSEUM, 100 Museum Drive, Newport News, (757) 596-2222. Open daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; $3, for students; free for children 6 and under.
 
JAMESTOWN SETTLEMENT, Route 31 South, (757) 229-1607. Open daily, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $10.25; $5, children 6 to 12.
 
JAMESTOWN SITE, Colonial Parkway, (757) 229-1733. Open daily, 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; children under 16, free.
 
COLONIAL WILLIAMSBURG, 100 Visitors Center Drive, Williamsburg, (757) 229-1000. Open daily, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: Patriot Pass (year-round entry to all buildings, free parking and special walking tours) is $35 or $20 for children 6 to 12; two-day pass is $31 or $18; one-day pass is $27 or $16. Children under 6, free.
 
ADAM THOROUGHGOOD HOUSE, 1636 Parish Road, Virginia Beach, (757) 460-0007. Hours: Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission: $4; $2.50, the elderly and students over 12; under 12, free.
 
BACON'S CASTLE, Route 617, near Surry, (757) 357-5976. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 4 P.M. Admission: $6; $3, children 6 to 18 and college students; $4, the elderly.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 34; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1155 words

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Irish Style: A 'Stepson' Gains Favor

BYLINE: By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
Ireland seems to be entering a golden age. There is the promise of peace. The country is in the midst of a boom: the so-called Celtic Tiger's economy is growing at a faster rate than Europe's. Many computer companies have large operations there, and Dublin has a new International Financial Services Center, where banks like Chase are congregating.
The new prosperity is fueling the market for houses, especially grand old mansions in the countryside, and the Irish art and antiques to fill them. All of which has been great news for auction houses and dealers in Irish antiques on both sides of the Atlantic. 
 "The property market in Ireland is red hot," said Graham Child, a furniture specialist at Sotheby's, which is holding an "Irish Sale" today in London. "A lot of the old, decaying houses are being pulled back. The economy has led to the creation of wealth and a desire to spend the wealth on national things."
The 405-lot Irish sale has some large 18th- and 19th-century mahogany dining tables, chairs and sideboards; a rare pair of oval mirrors with borders decorated with facet-cut studs of blue and clear glass (expected to sell for $8,000 to $11,200); a circa 1755 architect's table and a graceful mid-18th-century mahogany card table with a drawer and a typically Irish carved shell on the front (estimate: $3,200 to $4,000).
"A lot of Irish furniture and pictures are going back to Ireland," said Hugo Swire of Sotheby's London. "The people who are restoring the big Irish houses have limitless budgets. The problem is there's not an enormous amount of supply."
The golden age of Irish furniture-making began about 1720, when mahogany from the West Indies and South America reached Ireland, and ended about 1840. The most popular pieces are 18th-century Irish Georgian antiques. They can be distinguished by their weathered patina, dense grain, quirky dimensions and deep carvings of masks and hairy paw feet. Sometimes the furniture was blackened with polish to match the very dark bog oak, native to Ireland, that was commonly used in 17th-century furniture.
"Irish furniture is often considered the slightly crazed stepson of English furniture," said Clinton Howell, a Manhattan dealer with a shop at 19 East 74th Street. "I have Irish clients who fly over here every year looking for Irish antiques. Right now I have only one piece left."
It is a George II mahogany console table with a breche violette marble top. The apron has elegant gadroon molding and a carved acanthus; the cabriole legs have carved knees. Its price tag, $87,500, is hefty, but only last January Christie's New York sold an Irish George II mahogany side table, circa 1740, with a large lion mask for $96,000, against an estimate of $40,000 to $60,000.
"Almost all our Irish furniture is gone," said John Snead, of John and Patricia Snead, private dealers in McLean, Va., who specialize in Irish long-case clocks. "I recently sold a fine Dublin clock to an American collector for about $15,000."
But the surge in demand for Irish antiques is fairly recent.
"You couldn't sell Irish furniture for large sums five years ago," said Desmond Guinness, an Irish author and connoisseur of houses and antiques. "Now it's being avidly collected." In 1958 Mr. Guinness co-founded the Irish Georgian Society with his fellow Irishman Desmond FitzGerald, the 29th Knight of Glin, to rescue decaying Irish houses.
Last Monday Mr. Guinness gave a party for Kindel Furniture of Grand Rapids, Mich., at Leixlip Castle, his home in County Kildare. A passionate patron of all things Irish, Mr. Guinness agreed to let Kindel sell its reproductions of 22 fine Irish antiques in his Gothic gate lodge as a way for his organization to raise money to restore other Irish houses.
Chantal O'Sullivan, an Irish dealer with galleries in New York, Dublin and Kenmare, said: "For a long time no one wanted Irish antiques, and they were really collectible. When Irish things became more fashionable, they became harder and harder to find."
She is partly responsible for that. An American magazine recently photographed David Mlinaric, a top British decorator, at her gallery.
The Irish Government gives tax breaks to artists of all kinds: musicians, filmmakers, artists and writers. Ronnie Wood of the Rolling Stones, members of the band Simple Minds and actors like Jeremy Irons, Mia Farrow, Anjelica Huston, Daniel Day-Lewis, Liam Neeson and Miranda Richardson all have houses in Ireland now.
Ms. O'Sullivan, who has dined with President and Mrs. Clinton in Dublin and Washington, sells mostly through New York designers like Thierry Despont, Bunny Williams, Thomas Jayne, Mario Buatta, Scott Salvator, Glenn Gissler and David Anthony Easton. She currently has for sale an Irish mantelpiece made of Italian marble ($95,000), a 14-foot-by-5-foot mahogany library table (also $95,000) and an Irish Georgian mahogany blanket chest with carved shells and its original brasses, circa 1770 ($22,000).
Several of her tables have carved shells or masks. "The masks were carved in the likeness of the absent landlords of the house," Ms. O'Sullivan said. "That's why some have hairy faces. It meant the owner had thick whiskers. If he were mean, the face would be ugly, too."
A prominent Paris dealer, Ariane Dandois, said: "Everyone is interested in Irish furniture now. It's English furniture with fantasy. The shapes are extravagant. It's more macho than English furniture."
Mrs. Dandois offers a rare set of eight Irish Regency giltwood armchairs made in Dublin about 1820. The arched crest-rails are carved with lions drinking from a fountain. The armrests have eagle-head supports. She has attributed the chairs to a furniture-maker from Italy, James Del Vecchio Sr., who immigrated to Dublin in the 1790's.
When Mrs. Dandois, who normally sells 18th-century palace furniture to the richest clients on earth, starts selling Irish antiques, it is a clear sign that Irish furniture has joined the top ranks.
Dillingham in San Francisco and two New York dealers, the Newel Art Galleries and Philip Colleck, also sell Irish furniture.
There are two unrelated indications of Irish chic. On May 7, the actress Julia Roberts was one of about 250 people at a book party at Christie's to celebrate "West of Ireland Summers: Recipes and Memories from an Irish Childhood" (Roberts Rinehart, Boulder, Colo.), a new book by Tamasin Day-Lewis, sister of the actor. Ms. Roberts had such a good time with the Irish guests that she was an hour late for dinner with a major fashion magazine editor.
Clue No. 2: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum in Manhattan is adding an Irish immigrant family apartment to its Jewish and Italian ones. And this just six months after President Clinton declared the museum's tenement building a National Historic Site. Maybe he knew that the White House was designed in 1792 by an Irish immigrant, James Hoban.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 21; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2224 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AFTER LIFE," starring Arata, Taketoshi Naito and Erika Oda. Written, directed and edited by Hirokazu Kore-eda (not rated, 118 minutes). Much of this transcendently compassionate, gently humorous Japanese film is set in a drab office building where courteous caseworkers welcome the week's new clients. The place turns out not to be a social service agency but a metaphysical way station where the newcomers are people of all ages and types who have just died and have three days to select one memory to take with them into eternity. Before they depart, those memories will be filmed. As they tell their stories and make their choices (those who can't choose remain at the processing center as caseworkers), the movie becomes a profound meditation on life's meaning and value and the relationship of movies, memories and dreams (Stephen Holden). 

* "COOKIE'S FORTUNE," starring Charles S. Dutton, Glenn Close, Patricia Neal, Julianne Moore and Liv Tyler. Directed by Robert Altman (PG-13, 118 minutes). What a treat. The sweet assurance and guerrilla wit of Mr. Altman's vintage ensemble films make a copacetic return with a Southern small-town black comedy. Seamlessly made and completely enveloping, it tells of the machinations set off when a wealthy old woman (Ms. Neal) outrages her diabolically genteel niece (Ms. Close) by committing suicide. As the old woman's dearest friend and the niece's unwitting nemesis, Mr. Dutton is rock solid and appealing. The entire cast works on a single wavelength as Mr. Altman makes the most of a well-woven screenplay by Anne Rapp (Janet Maslin).
 
* "THE DREAMLIFE OF ANGELS," starring Elodie Bouchez and Natacha Regnier. Directed by Erick Zonca (R, 113 minutes; in French with English subtitles). In this very special French film about two freewheeling young women, their turbulent friendship is frayed by sexual passion and economic realities. The weaker and more head-turning of the women (Ms. Regnier) falls for the advances of a rich nightclub owner, while her fiery friend, played with unforgettable immediacy by Ms. Bouchez, rages against what she views as imminent disaster. In the process, Mr. Zonca shows astonishing acuity in observing how the women's diverging values affect every aspect of their lives. A rare and wrenching drama (Maslin).
 
* "EDGE OF 17," starring Chris Stafford and Tina Holmes. Directed by David Moreton (not rated, 100 minutes). It's 1984 in Sandusky, Ohio, and Eric (Chris Stafford), a skinny, fresh-faced high school student who worships the Eurythmics and Culture Club, has his first homosexual experiences. This is not boy-meets-boy (Romeo meets Romeo and they fall madly in love) but boy is used and confused and tries to go straight by sleeping with his former girlfriend. The teen-age coming-out story is realistic but warmhearted, the best among the recent gay coming-out films (Holden).
 
* "ELECTION," starring Matthew Broderick and Reese Witherspoon. Directed by Alexander Payne (R, 105 minutes). From the acerbically funny director of "Citizen Ruth" comes this caustic satire of the American electoral process in a high school setting. Its leading candidate, Tracy Flick, played tartly by Ms. Witherspoon, has a mother who sought tactical advice for Tracy from Connie Chung and Elizabeth Dole. Mr. Broderick plays the hapless good-guy teacher who thinks this wicked little front-runner needs to be stopped. And the hunky newcomer Chris Klein plays Tracy's reluctant opponent in a style best described as early Keanu. With a lovely ear for hypocritical conversation, the screenplay specializes in keeping all the characters a few beats off what they actually mean (Maslin).
 
"ENTRAPMENT," starring Sean Connery and Catherine Zeta-Jones. Directed by Jon Amiel (PG-13, 105 minutes). This glossy caper summons the days when being a thief was the profession of choice among debonair movie heroes. And heroines: as the great-looking insurance investigator who is supposedly investigating Mr. Connery's glamorous super-burglar, Ms. Zeta-Jones makes a smashing gymnast and heist expert in her own right. No need to believe the outlandish details of the story; there's enough verve and charisma to the stars to make the escapade easy on the eyes. The action sequence, in which the stars hang off the side of the world's largest skyscraper, is a vertiginous show stopper. And here's a nice bonus: nobody gets killed (Maslin).
 
* "LEILA," starring Leila Hatami, Ali Mosaffa and Jamileh Sheikhi. Directed by Dariush Mehrjui (not rated, 129 minutes). The devastating drama of a happy marriage destroyed by a monstrous mother-in-law is the latest cinematic gem from Iran. Think of it as a contemporary Islamic "Now Voyager" skimmed of suds, in which the tyrannical matriarch gets her way. On learning that Leila (Ms. Hatami), the wife of her only son, Reza (Mr. Mosaffa), is infertile, Leila's mother-in-law (Ms. Sheikhi) embarks on a campaign of intimidation to convince her daughter-in-law to let Reza take a second wife who might bear him a child. Although Reza claims not to want a child, the mother-in-law shames Leila into being her collaborator in the scheme. Minutely observed, beautifully acted, relentless (Holden).
 
"THE MATRIX," starring Keanu Reeves, Laurence Fishburne and Carrie-Anne Moss. Directed by Andy and Larry Wachowski (R, 120 minutes). The time-traveling story steeped in virtual reality will be all but incomprehensible to anyone but techno freaks. And the film borrows unapologetically from other sci-fi extravaganzas, with a big debt to "The X-Files" in the paranoia department. But the storytelling is intricately bizarre and the special effects are indeed special, notably when it comes to midair martial arts with a gravity-defying gusto. And Mr. Reeves shows that you can look like a Prada model while behaving like an action hero. One of the main stars here is Bill Pope, an inventive cinematographer. He and the Wachowskis provide a couch-potato epiphany: while the characters seem to be performing marvelous feats, they're often lying stock-still in the grip of virtual reality (Maslin).
 
"A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM," starring Kevin Kline, Rupert Everett, Michelle Pfeiffer and Calista Flockhart. Directed by Michael Hoffman (PG-13, 115 minutes). This is potluck Shakespeare, with a wildly uneven range of performances and no clear style holding them together. Rather than wonder why the actors are wrestling with bicycles in 19th-century Tuscany (a setting used much less enchantingly than it might have been), it's best to focus on the most comfortably Shakespearean performances and not wonder what Ms. Flockhart is doing here. Mr. Kline makes a perfect Bottom, Mr. Everett slinks seductively through Oberon's role and Ms. Pfeiffer makes an appropriately gorgeous fairy queen. The younger cast members are largely used as window dressing for the Leo-Does-Romeo set (Maslin).
 
"THE MUMMY," starring Brendan Fraser Rachel Weisz, Arnold Vosloo and John Hannah. Directed by Stephen Sommers (PG-13, 134 minutes). More like a video game than a movie, this incoherent spoof (very loosely based on the 1932 Boris Karloff horror classic), overloaded with cheesy special effects, suggests an unwieldy hybrid of "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and "Abbott and Costello Meet the Mummy" via "Night of the Living Dead." The intrepid adventurers who disturb an ancient Egyptian crypt that carries a fearful curse are Mr. Fraser (playing a swashbuckling American in the Foreign Legion), Ms. Weisz (as a plucky, wide-eyed English librarian) and John Hannah (as her twitty older brother). It's all played for laughs. The only scary moments involve swarming scarabs who burrow under the skin and do awful "Alien"-like things (Holden).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE" (the Oscar winner for best film, best original screenplay, best art direction, best costumes and best comedy score). Starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow (the best-actress winner) and Judi Dench (best supporting actress). Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile, this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
* "STAR WARS: EPISODE I -- THE PHANTOM MENACE," starring Liam Neeson, Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman and Jake Lloyd. Directed by George Lucas (PG-13, 132 minutes). Stripped of hype and breathless expectations, Mr. Lucas's first installment offers a happy surprise: it's up to snuff. It sustains the gee-whiz spirit of the series and offers a swashbuckling extra-galactic getaway, creating illusions that are even more plausible than the kitchen-raiding raptors of "Jurassic Park." While the human stars here are indeed reduced to playing action figures, they are upstaged by amazing backdrops and hordes of crazily lifelike space beings as the Lewis Carroll in Mr. Lucas is given free rein. The "Star Wars" franchise was funnier and scrappier when it was new. But it simply wasn't capable of this (Maslin).
 
"TEA WITH MUSSOLINI," starring Cher, Judi Dench, Joan Plowright, Maggie Smith and Lily Tomlin. Directed by Franco Zeffirelli (PG, 117 minutes). The screen divas (especially Maggie Smith) who give "Tea With Mussolini" a patina of class obviously relish chewing the scenery in this sudsy historical drama (adapted from a chapter of Mr. Zeffirelli's autobiography) about a circle of English expatriate women living in Florence on the eve of World War II. Ms. Smith, a quintessential British snob, is the leader of the pack, nicknamed the Scorpioni, whose comfortable lives are shattered when the Fascists rise to power and they find themselves carted off to another city where they are held under house arrest. Cher is her usual likable self as a free-spending, free-loving wealthy American heiress and art collector who befriends the group (Holden).
 
"THIS IS MY FATHER," starring Aidan Quinn, Moya Farrelly and James Caan. Directed by Paul Quinn (R, 120 minutes). Made with obvious sincerity, this story of a glum Chicago schoolteacher (Mr. Caan) in search of his more interesting Irish forebears (Mr. Quinn) involves a third Quinn brother as well. And Declan Quinn's cinematography adds warmth to an atmospheric, sentimental tale featuring stellar Irish actors (Stephen Rea, Brendan Gleeson, Colm Meaney) in cameo roles. Aidan Quinn's sturdy performance, as a lonely farmer in love with a fiery young lass from a prosperous family, does a lot to help the film override its hackneyed elements and keep it moving (Maslin).
 
* "THE WINSLOW BOY," starring Nigel Hawthorne, Rebecca Pidgeon and Jeremy Northam. Written and directed by David Mamet (G, 110 minutes). Terence Rattigan's play about the 1910 schoolboy's trial that created a furor in England has been artfully pared down to its essentials in this stately and deliberate adaptation. Played with unusually effective restraint by a fine, meticulous cast, it works as a precisely calibrated war of nerves in which the family of a cadet accused of theft is quietly staggered by the consequences of that accusation. Benoit Delhomme's cinematography is beautifully lucid and painterly. Ms. Pidgeon's defiantly arch acting style sets the film's tone and gives her suffragist character a sharp edge (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"ALFRED HITCHCOCK." Alfred Hitchcock's birthday doesn't arrive until Aug. 13, but that isn't stopping anyone from celebrating the centennial of the master of suspense (1899-1980). The tributes are already in progress. At the Museum of Modern Art "Alfred Hitchcock," with more than 50 features, shorts and documentaries, as well as an exhibition of posters, photographs and papers, is trumpeted as the most comprehensive Hitchcock film retrospective ever mounted in the United States. At 2:30 P.M. today and 5:45 P.M. tomorrow, the attraction is "Notorious" (1946), with a cast including Ingrid Bergman, Cary Grant and Claude Rains. Francois Truffaut said, "In my opinion, 'Notorious' is the very quintessence of Hitchcock." Continuing through June 15 at the museum, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, the series is free with museum admission: $9.50 for adults, $6.50 for students and the elderly; free for those under 16 accompanied by an adult. Pay-what-you-wish on Fridays from 4:30 to 8:30 P.M. Information: (212) 708-9400 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 41; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 967 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Forks Through Windows And Other Grotesqueries

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

TOUGH, TOUGH TOYS FOR TOUGH, TOUGH BOYS
By Will Self
244 pages. Grove Press. $23.
There has never been any question whether the flamboyant British writer Will Self had talent. The question was whether he would squander his manic imagination and tactile, hyperventilated prose on self-consciously nasty exercises in sophomoric humor ("Cock & Bull," "Great Apes") or create fictions commensurate with his copious gifts ("My Idea of Fun"). 
 Mr. Self's latest book, "Tough, Tough Toys for Tough, Tough Boys" represents his most disciplined storytelling yet. The tales in this collection demonstrate a new control and polish, without sacrificing anything in terms of inventiveness or plain weirdness. Like his 1994 novel, "My Idea of Fun," it attests to Mr. Self's ability to render even the most bizarre, "Twilight Zone"-like events with convincing verisimilitude while enthralling -- and often horrifying -- the reader with his scathing, Swiftean humor.
"Tough, Tough Toys" comes with an epigraph from Oscar Wilde -- "Life is a dream that keeps me from sleeping" -- and most of the characters in these stories realize that their lives have come to resemble a nightmare or hallucination. In "Flytopia," a Hitchcockian thriller that slowly morphs into a William Burroughsesque fantasy, a mild-mannered clerk enters into a strange pact with the insects infesting his house. In "The Rock of Crack as Big as the Ritz," a drug dealer named Danny discovers that there's a huge vein of crack cocaine running beneath the basement of his house. And in "A Story for Europe," a 2-year-old English child and a German businessman appear to exchange personalities.
The last of those stories, of course, is meant as a wacky commentary on the new, unified, economically interdependent Europe, and its sardonic humor recalls "My Idea of Fun," which satirized the go-go years of the 1980's by depicting yuppie greed as a Faustian pact with the Devil. An even more pronounced version of this sort of social satire can be found in the story "Caring, Sharing," which depicts a therapy-obssessed America in which people mate not with lovers but with "emotos" -- that is, giant manifestations of their own inner children. "The whole messy business of sexual and emotional entanglement" has been written off by these narcissistic Americans; what they want more than anything is "the absolute reassurance that an emoto would provide them with."
Though the remaining tales in "Tough, Tough Toys" are ostensibly more realistic, their characters fall prey to drug- and hormone-fueled fantasies that infect their day-to-day lives, undermining their sense of self and throwing into question their most basic assumptions about the world. The narrator of "Dave Too" -- arguably, the weakest story in this volume -- sees everyone around him turning into someone named Dave. The hero of the title story, a former psychiatrist named Bill, finds himself forced by a chance encounter with a hitchhiker to re-evaluate his entire self-indulgent existence. And Danny, the drug-addicted hero of "The Nonce Prize," discovers an unlikely new vocation as a writer, while serving time in prison for a horrific rape and murder he didn't commit.
Using his eye for detail to flesh out his oddest imaginings, Mr. Self does a nimble job of evoking the addled states of mind of these characters. The Dave man looks at his psychiatrist's window and thinks it looks like an egg: "If a fork like a prop for a Magritte painting were to be plunged through the window of Dr. Klagfarten's office," he tells himself, "a gush of yellow neurosis would undoubtedly ooze out."
During long drives, Bill the ex-shrink likes to imagine himself merging with his car, becoming part of the big machine as he cruises the long, twisty roads between London and the Orkneys. While he drives, he allows his mind to wander, musing that the landscape beyond his windshield is "a terrain in which a few triceratops and pterodactyl wouldn't have looked altogether out of place." His favorite fantasy involves a seraglio made up of all the women he hashad sex with: a Felliniesque dream sequence in which the younger women handle the bulk of the domestic work and the older ones spend their days in "idle conversation and hobby-style activities."
As for Danny, the former crack addict turned short story writer, he suffers from visitations of menacing spirits he calls "the Fates" -- "tall, wispy, indeterminate figures" who metamorphose, much like the ghostly special effects in "Raiders of the Lost Ark," into terrifying djinnlike creatures, "bearded, turbaned, wearing long gray-and-black robes, and carrying mutant, nine-foot-long Kalashnikovs."
In both this story and "Tough, Tough Toys," Mr. Self expertly orchestrates suspense: in the former by turning a simple drive home from a country house into a harrowing adventure in which every attempt to pass another car on the twisting road feels like a life and death confrontation; in the latter, by conjuring up a particularly gruesome crime -- the sexual torture and murder of a 6-year-old boy -- and the almost equally terrifying subculture of sex criminals in a prison.
Although the other stories in this volume may not be as thrilling as this pair of tales, they, too, attest to Mr. Self's ease and authority as a storyteller. His tendency displayed in previous books to force his tales into predictable shapes with obvious, italicized morals, has given way in these pages to masterfully shaped narratives that are both complex and unexpected, just as his earlier, adolescent preoccupation with sex has evolved into a more deeply felt interest in the mysteries of identity and emotional (dis)connection. Along with "My Idea of Fun," "Tough, Tough Toys" stands as Mr. Self's most powerful work yet.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
MTV Is Buying TwoServices From TCI Music

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
Just weeks before it is to unveil a new on-line music venture, MTV Networks announced yesterday that it was acquiring music services on the Internet and on cable television.
MTV, a division of Viacom, will acquire Sonicnet, one of the first Internet sites dedicated to music, and the Box, a pay-per-view cable television music service. In exchange, MTV will give a 10 percent stake in its on-line service to the owner of the two properties, TCI Music, a company based in New York that provides audio and video music through cable, satellite and the Internet. 
 Tom Freston, chairman of MTV Networks, said the on-line music division would be spun off as a separate publicly traded company in the next 9 to 15 months.
TCI Music, a division of Liberty Media Group of Englewood, Colo., also announced that it would change its name to Liberty Digital. Liberty Media, a cable television programming distributor, is part of the huge cable company TCI, which was bought by the AT&T Corporation, although Liberty Media continues to operate independently.
In a phone interview, Mr. Freston called the on-line music business "ripe for consolidation" as the major music labels seek ways to distribute music on the Internet.
On-line commerce will be an important piece of MTV Networks' new on-line music venture, which is to be started next month. In addition, Mr. Freston said there were plans to create an interactive television channel selling tickets, music and other merchandise.
"Our strategy is anyone who can drive traffic is going to be in a position to sell a lot of merchandise, a lot of tickets," he said.
MTV's flagship music channel is available on television in 300 million homes around the world, and Mr. Freston said an expanded on-line presence was a logical next step. He spoke by telephone from Singapore, where MTV will start a Web site for the Asian market today.
Industry analysts said traditional media companies were realizing the power television has to send viewers to the on-line medium, as well as the power of the Internet to extend what they can offer viewers in the finite time permitted by television.
"On line can support strategies in ways broadcast can't," said Mark Hardie, a senior analyst for Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass. "You don't have the air time for all you're trying to air." An on-line presence allows television programmers to direct viewers to their computers for additional services, particularly electronic commerce and eventually, as higher-speed connections become more widely available, music videos.

HEADLINE: Fed Policy Makers Voted 11-0 In March to Hold Rates Steady

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in deciding not to change the overnight bank lending rate at their March 30 meeting and continued to take a wait-and-see attitude on what to do about rates in the future, minutes of the session showed today.
The Federal Open Market Committee voted 11 to 0 to leave the Federal funds target unchanged at 4.75 percent. 
 "The incoming data and prospects for sustained favorable economic performance did not support" a rollback in last year's three successive reductions in the overnight bank rate, the minutes said. The committee decided it "was in a position to wait for developments to unfold, especially given the absence of any evidence of an impending acceleration of underlying inflation."
The committee announced after its most recent meeting on Tuesday that it was leaning toward higher interest rates in the future, the first time the panel has immediately announced a change in its stance. At the March meeting, however, central bankers maintained a neutral bias -- suggesting that it was equally likely to raise or lower rates -- after dropping a stance toward lower rates at their meeting on Nov. 17.
"With little evidence of rising pressures on prices at early stages of production or on nominal wages, inflation should remain contained for some time," the minutes said.
The members indicated, however, that their patience would be limited once the first signs of accelerating inflation appeared. "Many of the members emphasized that in such circumstances the committee might need to act promptly to forestall a buildup of inflationary forces that could destabilize the expansion," the minutes said.
The March minutes showed that many committee members "believed that the next policy move would likely be in the direction of some tightening." At the same time, the minutes said, "the timing of the next policy action was highly uncertain." That uncertainty "argued for a cautious approach to any policy change, especially in light of an economic performance that had not conformed to historical patterns in recent years," the minutes said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Barclays to Cut 10% of Jobs in Britain

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 20

 BODY:
Struggling against bloated costs and increased competition, Britain's second-largest bank, Barclays P.L.C., announced today that it would cut almost 10 percent of its 65,000-member British work force this year.
The reduction, aimed at saving an annual $320 million, was one of the biggest reductions of jobs in British banking. 
 Coming after months of uncertainty and seesawing stock prices, today's announcement lifted the price of Barclays shares nearly 4 percent, to 18.87, or $30.33, carrying other banking stocks with them.
In a statement, Barclays said it would record an accounting charge of $646 million this year to reflect the cost of reducing its staff, mainly in retail financial services, which employ 55,000 people, and in corporate banking, with about 10,000.
The cuts, which will be made through attrition, voluntary retirements and layoffs, follow staff reductions at the bank's Barclaycard credit card division and at Barclays Capital, the investment arm that had heavy losses in the Russian debt crisis.
While the job reductions announced today were limited to Barclays in Britain, executives did not rule out further cuts in the bank's widespread overseas operations.
"The announcement is very sad, but on a business level this is absolutely essential," said Sir Peter Middleton, the Barclays chairman and acting chief executive. "This is to produce a simpler structure for people to bank with us and reduce costs."
Sir Peter has been running the bank since the last full-time chief executive, Martin Taylor, quit last November in a board-room row over the losses at Barclays Capital. His American replacement, Michael O'Neill, a former Bank of America executive, quit because of a heart problem on the day he was supposed to start work in London in mid-April. His replacement has not been announced.
Coupled with the bank's emerging-markets losses and rising costs, Mr. O'Neill's withdrawal from the top job contributed to a sense among some market analysts that the bank was drifting and was ripe for a takeover. Others, however, say that Barclays and its management remain essentially sound.
"With or without a C.E.O., this is still a major bank with a major market share and it's going to remain a major player," said Alan Reid, a credit-rating analyst with Moody's Investors Service. "There's more to an organization than a single person, and that's very much illustrated by what the bank announced today."
Nonetheless, Barclays has acknowledged that its costs were spiraling and promised to contain them.
"In terms of costs, this has been a bit of an Achilles' heel year after year," said Nick Collier, an analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "This announcement provides more tangible evidence that they are a little bit more determined on costs."
Michael Trippett, an analyst at Schroders Investment, said the saving would bring Barclays closer into line with the most cost-efficient British banks. But, he said, the balance-sheet benefits would not show until 2001.
Essentially, the problems of Barclays stem from its slow response to a revolution in British retail banking over a decade that has seen 150,000 jobs disappear as some 4,000 bank and savings and loan branches closed.
The transformation of traditional mortgage companies into full-fledged banks, and a rush into the retail financial services market by supermarkets and other nonbanking concerns, has magnified the competition.
At the same time, technological advances -- first in automated teller machines, then in telephone, computer and Internet banking -- have forced banks to devise ways to reduce costs without losing customers.

He was sentenced to 10 years in prison, but the court gave him credit for time served on similar charges in the Soviet Union, where he spent 13 years in a Siberian labor camp. (AP)

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Rises Faster Than Forecast

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit reached another record in March, the Commerce Department reported today, providing fresh evidence that the American economy continues to absorb imports at a prodigious rate.
The deficit for March totaled $19.7 billion, the department said, up from a revised $19.1 billion in February and well above the $18.5 billion predicted by economists. It was the third consecutive month in which the deficit was at a new high. 
 Exports totaled $77.5 billion, up $700 million from February, the first increase in five months and a sign of possible recovery in key foreign markets for American goods such as Asia. But imports grew even faster, up $1.3 billion, to $97.2 billion, also a record.
The increase in import revenue was propelled in part by the higher cost of crude oil, which jumped in recent months after being depressed for a year or so.
But imports surged in other categories as well -- notably steel, autos and auto parts, as foreign producers looked to the United States as the vibrant market for their products at a time much of the rest of the world was in the economic doldrums.
Analysts expect the deficit to continue creeping higher in coming months, although probably at a slower pace than over the last several months. They said the deficit would not begin contracting until Western Europe, Japan and the developing nations of Asia begin enjoying a more marked rebound than they have had so far.
"The bottom line is that until the pace of economic growth in the U.S. slows and the rest of the world picks up, the deficit will continue to grow," said G. David Orr, chief economist at First Union Capital Markets.
Asked about the trade deficit during a Congressional hearing today, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said it should not be a problem in the short run because the dollar has been reasonably stable in value and others have been happy to invest the dollars they earn through trade back into the United States.
"There is no evidence that there is any immediate problem coming because of the fact that we are, as an economy, growing far faster than the rest of the world," Mr. Greenspan told the House Banking Committee.
But he said the deficit could become disturbing in the long run if it continued to grow, "creating a significant rise in debt or claims against us by foreigners, which could essentially destabilize our system."
Moreover, the trade deficit is often as much a political and diplomatic problem as an economic one. The United States' deficit with Japan, long a source of friction between the two countries, surged to $6.5 billion in March from $5.3 billion a month earlier, largely because of a sharp jump in imports. Washington has been pressing the Japanese, with mixed success, to do more to stimulate a moribund economy.
The deficit with China dropped to $4.1 billion from $4.6 billion. China has been the focus of the Clinton Administration's trade policy in recent months, as Washington and Beijing spar over the terms on which the Chinese should be admitted to the World Trade Organization.
The best news in today's report was the increase in exports. For years, the Administration was able to point to growing exports as evidence that its policy of opening markets to American goods was paying off in the form of domestic jobs and profits. But since the Asian financial and economic crisis began in mid-1997, the demand for American products in many foreign markets has been weak, hurting farmers and manufacturers.
The increase in exports in March was modest, and it still left the export level 1.8 percent below where it was a year earlier. But it reflected improved sales abroad of a variety of products as diverse as telecommunications equipment, generators, soybeans and chemicals.
Despite the growing deficit, the Administration has given no indication of abandoning its policy of keeping the dollar strong, a strategy that makes exports from the United States relatively more expensive but helps hold down domestic inflation by making imports less expensive.
Indeed, while the surge in imports could ultimately prove troublesome, it has benefited consumers by creating competition and forcing American producers to keep prices down. The announcement by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday that it would tilt in the future toward higher interest rates could lead to a further strengthening of the dollar.
The trade deficit is one of the few tangible ways in which the American economy has been affected by recent global economic turmoil. In part because the United States has weathered the problems well, policy makers here have urged caution in moves to change the world financial system.
Today, Mr. Greenspan and Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin repeated the message that tough monetary and fiscal policy choices, rather than a new financial architecture, were the most effective ways to avert problems in the international economy.
Appearing side by side before the banking committee, they outlined steps the United States has taken to reduce the likelihood of another global financial crisis, including encouraging nations to share more economic data with investors and to keep their currencies realistically valued.
As a way of insuring that developing nations are able to weather financial crises, Mr. Greenspan suggested that they keep enough foreign-currency reserves on hand to allow them to pay all their debts for one year without any additional borrowing. He said developing countries should not take on too much short-term debt and should keep the average maturity of their foreign debt at no less than three years so they do not find themselves squeezed by rapid-repayment demands.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
West Side Tower to Have Park Views

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Sales began last week for the 53 apartments at the Park Laurel, a 40-story tower at 15 West 63d Street that was conceived more than a decade ago. Preliminary site work is under way and the developer expects the building to be ready for occupancy in 2001.
So far contracts have been signed on 11 of the two- to five-bedroom units, including one two-story penthouse. Prices, which in the last week were raised an average of 5 percent, are $725,000 to $10.5 million, according to the Sunshine Group, the project's sales agent. Apartments range from 1,309 to 4,782 square feet. 
 While sales are proceeding, a legal challenge that has swirled around the project continues. Three community groups that oppose the project -- they contend that it will make a dense neighborhood denser -- are appealing a March ruling by the State Supreme Court in favor of the development. Though the court granted a temporary stay to stop construction, it was ultimately lifted.
The tower will replace the five-story building of the former McBurney School and will cantilever over part of the westerly portion of the adjacent 14-story Y.M.C.A. at 5 West 63d Street. The former school's interior has been demolished, though its landmarked Italian Romanesque facade is being preserved and will be incorporated into the new building. Last February, the Y.M.C.A., which owns the old school and has been pursuing plans to develop the site since 1986, sold the air rights over it to make way for the new tower.
It is being developed by the Vornado Realty Trust, a large real estate investment trust based in Saddle Brook, N.J. The project marks Vornado's first foray into Manhattan's luxury residential market.
"We opportunistically came in and took over a project that was waylaid by the real estate recession of the late 1980's because we think it is the single best site in Manhattan," said Steve Roth, Vornado's chairman.
The company secured a building permit from the city in March and at the same time had its offering plan accepted by the State Attorney General's office, which is the first step needed to start sales.
The 1986 plan to develop the site had also provoked a lawsuit, which was resolved in favor of the development. That plan was ultimately sidelined by the real-estate recession.
In 1997, with Manhattan's housing market robust, the Y.M.C.A. resurrected its plan to develop the site and after 18 months of negotiations sold the air rights to Vornado. The Y.M.C.A. received $9.3 million in cash and ownership of the 13 lower stories of the new building, valued at $10 million.
It will use those floors for its programs and for 65 rentals for low- and moderate-income tenants, said Rowena Daly, its director of community relations. The cash proceeds, she said, will be used to improve the existing Y.M.C.A. building.
The 14th through 40th floors of the new tower will contain the luxury condominium apartments, most of which will have Central Park views. The views distinguish the building from the crop of condominiums catering to prosperous buyers now being built, industry professionals say.
Yale Robbins Inc., a Manhattan-based publisher of real estate data, reports that six such buildings, totaling 337 large apartments, are taking shape above 59th Street. Meanwhile, prices continue to rise.
"Nothing is outrageous given the lack of new product to meet demand for large luxury apartments," said Henry Robbins, senior vice president of Yale Robbins.
On the Upper West Side, the average sales price per square foot for condominiums -- both new construction and resales -- is just over $800 for three-bedroom units and $1,050 for those with four bedrooms. These prices represent increases of 33 percent and 10 percent, respectively, from the end of 1998, according to Douglas Elliman, the Manhattan brokerage.
But the new luxury condominiums are pushing the market's upper limits. The average sales price per square foot at the Park Laurel is $1,320, which is expected to rise to $1,500 by the time all the units are sold, said Louise Sunshine, president of the Sunshine Group. She attributes $200 of that price to what she called the "park factor."
"Everyone wants a park view," she said.
Layouts of the apartments, designed by Costas Kondylis, a Manhattan architect, feature nine-foot-high ceilings and large windows to enhance park views.
The building's exterior was designed by Beyer Blinder Belle of Manhattan, an architectural firm, to complement the historic facade of the former school.
Planned amenities include a fitness center and a children's playroom. Monthly common charges will range from $989 to $3,164. Because of a 10-year tax abatement, real estate taxes are to range from $65 to $922 a month, eventually rising to $608 to $8,683.
On the legal front, the West 64th Street Block Association, One Lincoln Plaza condominium association and Landmark West, a preservation group, have filed a notice to appeal the State Supreme Court's March ruling. A hearing is expected in September.
Their lawsuit contends that the approval for the project, which was issued in 1989 and lacks an expiration date, should be invalidated because the city began putting four-year limits on such permits in 1995. It also said the project's environmental impact statement should be updated because buildings constructed in the intervening decade have made the neighborhood more congested, said Charles E. Knapp, a Manhattan lawyer representing the groups.
"Though the court agreed with our analysis that the lapse provision applied to the permit, it inconsistently allowed the city not to apply the law here," he said. "We are not antidevelopment, but we are concerned in trying to maintain a livable neighborhood."
Vornado views things differently. In a statement, it countered, "If the appeal is heard, it won't be for several months and in the meantime Vornado is going ahead with the building." The company said it would start construction on the new tower in July.

HEADLINE: Legislature Of Nebraska Votes Pause In Executions

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 20

 BODY:
Responding to concerns that the death penalty was being applied unfairly, the Nebraska Legislature voted today to impose a two-year moratorium on executions.
Although other states have considered such a suspension, Nebraska, where three prisoners have been executed in the last five years, is the first to send the proposal to the governor. The purpose of the moratorium would be to allow time for a study on whether the race or economic status of the defendant, or any other issue unrelated to the crime, plays a role in death sentencing. 
 But the legislation faces the likelihood of a veto by Gov. Mike Johanns, a first-term Republican who supports capital punishment and has expressed opposition to the moratorium. Still, the Governor said today that he would take a serious look at the measure, which he has five days to sign or veto. After that, it becomes law without his approval.
The vote in the one-house Legislature was 27 to 21, two more votes in favor than were needed for passage but three fewer than would be required to override Mr. Johanns's veto. And while the Governor could allow the bill to become law without his signature, he suggested today that he would not choose that path.
"I think I'm here to make difficult decisions," The Associated Press quoted him as saying.
A co-author of the measure, State Senator Kermit A. Brashear of Omaha, a Republican in a legislature that is officially nonpartisan, said he did not oppose the death penalty but was unconvinced that it was being applied fairly.
"If you love the law and you love justice, you must be committed to fairness," Mr. Brashear said. "And when I see 165 murderers in Nebraska prisons and only 10 are on death row, I want to know, Why are some of these people treated differently?"
Mr. Brashear said that while he did not believe that Nebraska itself practiced racism in its use of capital punishment, "there is clearly a racial component and a socioeconomic component nationwide" in death sentencing. Although accounting for only 13 percent of the country's population, blacks are 42 percent of the 3,600 or so prisoners on its death rows. In Nebraska, 3 of the 10 death-row prisoners are black or Indian.
Whatever the fate of the bill, opponents of the death penalty said, the vote today sends a heartening message.
Steven Hawkins, executive director of the National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty, based in Washington, said Nebraska, a mostly conservative state, was not a place where such deep-seated reservations about executions might have been expected.
"There's a change in the public attitude on the death penalty," Mr. Hawkins said. "We're very encouraged by what we're hearing in the heartland. It says something about where Middle America stands."
Mr. Hawkins and other foes of capital punishment attributed that change to a variety of factors. One was Pope John Paul II's strenuous opposition to executions. Another was the concern over mistaken convictions that has been stoked by a series of cases in Illinois. In the last 12 years, a dozen men on death row there have been exonerated, one of whom, Anthony Porter, came within two days of being put to death last fall.
While Nebraska's legislators are the first to approve a moratorium, lawmakers in other states as well have begun taking a second look at the death penalty laws. In Pennsylvania, a bill has been introduced that calls for a moratorium on executions there. A resolution calling for a six-month moratorium was approved by the Illinois House in March, although the measure failed in the State Senate. Legislation recently enacted in Montana bars the execution of anyone who was a juvenile when arrested for the capital offense. Texas, which puts to death more prisoners than any other state, is considering a measure that would prohibit executing anyone mentally retarded.
That kind of activity in state legislatures, Mr. Hawkins noted, is the opposite of a trend that prevailed only three years ago, when politicians were looking for ways to give the death penalty broader reach.
Yet even as the states assess the use of capital punishment, the number of executions is soaring.
Forty-four prisoners around the country have been executed so far in 1999, said Mr. Hawkins, who predicted that perhaps 100 would be put to death by the end of the year. That would be a record for any year since 1976, when the Supreme Court allowed capital punishment to be resumed. Nebraska has executed three prisoners in the post-1976 period.

HEADLINE: City's Unemployment Rate Stays at Its Lowest, Reassuring Wary Economists

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
New York City businesses continued to add new jobs at a rapid pace in April and the unemployment rate remained near its lowest level in a decade, reassuring some economists who had feared that it would rebound after its sharp drop in March.
After adjustment for seasonal factors, the unemployment rate in the five boroughs edged up to 6.5 percent in April from 6.4 percent in March, according to data released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. Both figures are sharply lower than February's unemployment rate of 7.6 percent; a year ago, unemployment in the city was 8 percent. 
 "I'm glad to see it's down, I'm glad it didn't bounce back up," said Jim Brown, an analyst for the agency. Unemployment figures, which are extrapolated from a sampling of households, are traditionally volatile, he said.
Nevertheless, he noted, the underlying trend in the city has been for unemployment to decline for several years. In June 1997 the rate, which is the percentage of people seeking work as a percentage of all the people working or looking, was close to 10 percent.
The number of new jobs in the city rose in April by 14,000, according to state figures, which are derived from a survey different from the unemployment data. The gains were largest in construction, retailing and services to businesses and individuals. But while the number of jobs in the city rose, the number of city residents with jobs fell by about 29,000, according to state data. The unemployment rate stayed low because the number of people looking for jobs also fell, by almost 9,000.
Mr. Brown cautioned against assuming that the difference between the rising number of jobs and falling employment is caused by people commuting into the city to work, noting that many city residents also work outside the city.
Some economists suggest that the underlying data may be flawed in some way but it is not clear exactly how. In March, the number of people with jobs plunged by 50,900 and the number of city residents looking for work fell by 44,400, according to the city comptroller's office, which adjusted the numbers for seasonal factors. Both declines are unusually large for a single month.
A statement from the Comptroller's office expressed concern about the figures, which "suggest that even though there has been a steady increase in jobs, there has been a decline in the number of city residents working or looking for work."
Within the city, the lowest unemployment rate was in Staten Island, at 5.1 percent. In Manhattan, the rate was 5.4 percent; in Queens, 5.8 percent; in the Bronx, 7.5 percent, and in Brooklyn, 7.6 percent. None of these figures is seasonally adjusted.
Though it has come down sharply, the city's unadjusted unemployment rate of 6.4 percent remains sharply higher than the rate for the state over all of 4.9 percent and than the national rate of 4.1 percent.
