HEADLINE: U.S. Aide Due in North Korea With Deal to Lift Sanctions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
President Clinton is sending an envoy to North Korea next week with a proposal that the 50-year-old economic embargo against the country be lifted gradually in exchange for a series of major concessions, including an agreement that the North will end its long-range missile program, officials said.
Several current and former Administration officials expressed doubts that North Korea would accept the limits on military programs in the proposal, though an end to the sanctions would allow the famine-scarred nation to trade with the West. North Korea's sales of missiles in the Middle East and to Pakistan have constituted its only lucrative export in recent years. And any agreement to lift some of the sanctions would be subject to Congressional approval, which would be an uphill battle. 
 Still, the diplomatic overture represents the biggest change in Washington's approach to North Korea since the Korean War ended in 1953. Since that conflict ended in stalemate -- no formal peace treaty has ever been signed -- the United States has prohibited virtually all trade, investment and travel, and most communication with the Communist nation.
This is the first time that the United States has made a comprehensive proposal to lift those sanctions or offer the prospect of full diplomatic recognition, a matter of prestige for the isolated country that officials say the envoy, former Defense Secretary William J. Perry, will raise during his visit.
Administration officials have declined to detail the contents of the proposed deal that Mr. Perry hopes to present in person to North Korea's reclusive leader, Kim Jong Il.
Mr. Perry's trip is the first time a Presidential envoy has been dispatched to North Korea, although former President Jimmy Carter went there on his own to defuse a nuclear crisis in 1994. That trip ultimately led to an agreement by North Korea to freeze its nuclear weapons program, though American intelligence agencies believed that before the accord North Korea had extracted enough plutonium to produce one or two crude nuclear weapons.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced Mr. Perry's visit today in Congressional testimony, confirming reports that had circulated in Washington for several days. But she said nothing about the offer to lift sanctions in return for concessions by President Kim, who has ruled North Korea since the death of his father, Kim Il Sung, weeks after Mr. Carter's visit in 1994.
Mr. Perry's visit culminates a six-month review of North Korea policy that he began, at Mr. Clinton's request, after several years of what even some Administration insiders volunteer was a dangerous neglect of the country. The timing of Mr. Perry's trip was also closely linked to the start yesterday of the first American inspection of a huge, mysterious construction project under a North Korean mountain that American intelligence agencies feared was originally intended to house a secret nuclear processing plant.
It is unclear whether Mr. Perry, who is carrying a letter from Mr. Clinton, will meet with President Kim, which he had suggested earlier would be a precondition for a visit. "We certainly hope to meet with Kim Jong Il," a senior Administration official said today, suggesting that the North Koreans had provided winks and nods that such a meeting is being arranged.
But even if Mr. Perry convinces Mr. Kim that it is in North Korea's interest to give up the weapons program and curb its behavior, it is unclear that he can convince Congress that lifting sanctions is in America's interest.
Conservatives on Capital Hill have already charged that the Administration is pursuing a policy of appeasement. On Tuesday, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of New York Republican, introduced a bill he called the North Korea Threat Reduction Act that would prohibit Mr. Clinton from lifting the sanctions -- some of which are imposed at the discretion of the President, others by Congressional mandate -- and will make it difficult to provide food aid to North Korea.
Mr. Perry has met with a number of members of Congress, and gave a classified briefing today to members of the Senate. He has also traveled repeatedly in recent months to Japan, South Korea and China, seeking their support for a new American approach.
The reaction has been mixed: South Korea's President, Kim Dae Jung, has pursued what he has called a "Sunshine Policy" of fuller engagement with the North and urged the United States to do the same. Japan has been far more cautious, especially after North Korea shot a three-stage missile over Japan on Aug. 31, a test that appeared intended to demonstrate that North Korea could hit any Japanese city and the tens of thousands of American troops based in Japan.
What Administration officials have declined to discuss is what advisers around Mr. Perry call Plan B: How to respond if North Korea decides not to trade its missile program for a gradual relaxation of the American economic embargo.
"This has been the hardest part, and I think it is the issue that has delayed the Perry report for so long," said Donald Gregg, the former American ambassador to South Korea, and a Central Intelligence Agency operative in the region during the cold war. "To be credible, this plan has to have a plan about how to deal with the North if they turn this down. For a while it looked like the recommendation would be benign neglect."
"But it is clear," said Mr. Gregg, who now heads the Korea Society in New York, "that if we leave them alone, they go back to building nuclear weapons and missiles."
In his few public comments while he has been putting together recommendations for a new policy, Mr. Perry has said that he thought it was important to "test the proposition that North Korea wants a more positive relationship" with the United States, but to be prepared to respond if it continued on its current path.
That path has been erratic. In 1993 and 1994 the United States and North Korea appeared veering toward a dangerous confrontation that Mr. Perry, the defense secretary in those years, has since said could have led to war. North Korea had taken steps that led American officials to believe it was about to harvest a load of plutonium at its nuclear facility at Yongbyon, north of Pyongyang, the capital. Washington was prepared to seek sanctions at the United Nations, a move North Korea had hinted could lead to military reprisals.
Mr. Clinton was within hours of ordering additional troops to South Korea when Mr. Carter visited Kim Il Sung, the country's founder and its leader during the Korean War. Mr. Carter made the breakthrough that ultimately led to a freeze on production at North Korea's Yongbyon nuclear reprocessing facility. Kim Il Sung died the next month, but the accord went ahead.
In return for the freeze, Japan and South Korea agreed to build two light-water reactors in North Korea for electricity production, and Washington agreed to provide fuel oil to help North Korea through its long winters. But Congress slowed those fuel shipments, and the construction of the plants has moved very slowly; financing is just now coming together.
So last year North Korea returned to some classic provocations. First there was the huge underground construction site. The Administration said little about it to Congress, and the revelations about its existence in mid-August led to Congressional protests against Ms. Albright, who some members charged had misled them. That was followed by the missile test over Japan. However, North Korea appears to have abided by the production freeze, which is under constant international monitoring.

HEADLINE: Easy Credit Demands Tough Laws

 BODY:

To the Editor: 
 I agree with Representative Henry J. Hyde (Op-Ed, May 18) that our bankruptcy laws need to be humane, and suggest that Congress stop allowing such usurious rates on consumer credit. I recently received a notice of revised terms to my credit card, and the interest on cash advances and outstanding balances if not paid on time was 26.99 percent. No wonder bankruptcies have increased so dramatically. Until our lawmakers put an end to such unconscionable greed, bankruptcies and credit problems will continue to plague the middle and lower classes.
 
S. BRAD ARINGTON
Mountain View, Calif., May 18, 1999

HEADLINE: Met Opera Association Names President

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
Paul M. Montrone was elected president and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Opera Association at its annual meeting yesterday. The association oversees the company's financial affairs, and although it has no direct artistic input, it is responsible for hiring both the general manager and the artistic director. The term of office is one year, with no term limit.
Mr. Montrone, 58, succeeds Bruce Crawford, 70, who was elected honorary chairman. Mr. Crawford was president of the association in 1984 and 1985 and general manager of the Met from 1985 to 1989. He has been president since he was re-elected to that post in 1991. During his tenure the company appointed Joseph Volpe as its general manager and installed Met Titles, a system that provides English translations on seat-back screens. 
 "The real strength of the Met today is a combination of artistic achievement and financial wherewithal, and today we're standing strong in both areas," Mr. Montrone said yesterday. "My job will be to maintain that momentum. None of this happens by itself.
"We have a budget of $170 million, of which we raise about $70 million in contributions, with almost nothing from the government. So we have a large job to be done each year, and to do it, we have an active board that is a mosaic of people from various fields."
Mr. Montrone joined the Met's advisory board in 1986 and its managing board in 1991. He has been a member of the executive committee since 1992. He is the president and chief executive officer of Fisher Scientific International Inc., which supplies products and services to research and clinical laboratories.
A native of Scranton, Pa., he graduated from the University of Scranton in 1962 and later earned a doctorate in economics and finance from Columbia University. He began his career as a systems analyst in the office of Robert S. McNamara when he was Defense Secretary.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: May 22, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the election of Paul M. Montrone as president and chief executive of the Metropolitan Opera Association referred imprecisely to the association's role in hiring. The association is responsible for hiring the Met's general manager. It is the general manager, not the association, who hires the artistic director.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Two Views of the Commuter's Curse;
Isn't It Obvious? Cutting Taxes Helps the Economy

BYLINE: By George E. Pataki; George E. Pataki is the Governor of New York.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Higher taxes mean fewer jobs, lower taxes mean more jobs. That is why I am going to sign the bill that eliminates the tax on the state's commuters to New York City. Our rate of job growth now matches the national rate, thanks in part to our tax cuts. And in New York City, state tax and economic policy has helped the city regain all of the 350,000 jobs it had lost during the 1990-92 recession.
Getting rid of the commuter tax is part of a pattern. We've cut the income tax, the corporate franchise tax, the estate and gift tax, school property taxes, taxes on electricity and motor fuel, taxes on small business, taxes on real estate transactions, taxes on Internet commerce, and more. 
 Repealing the commuter tax will help the 450,000 New Yorkers who commute to the city and contribute to its economy in so many ways -- shopping, dining, visiting museums and theaters, investing on Wall Street and so on. Commuters spend plenty of money in the city. Cutting their taxes by $210 million will give them more to spend as they wish. That's good for the city economy and budget.
When I proposed large income tax cuts in 1995, there were those who said tax cuts would decimate the state's finances. But tax cuts have strengthened our economy, which has led to four consecutive large budget surpluses. That means more money for education and the environment.
New York has suffered for too long under a culture that said high taxes were a given and could never be reduced, a culture that responds to every tax cut idea by reflexively shouting, "You can't do that!" This culture believes tax revenues are the sole property not of the person who pays the tax but of government. In this environment, tax policy becomes a debate over how much a tax cut will "cost" government -- as if it were the government's money to begin with -- and not about wage earners' rights to their money.
This wrongheaded thinking made New York State and New York City the tax-raising, big-government capitals of America in the 1980's and early 1990's. Taxes in New York City were raised by more than $3 billion in the early part of this decade, directly contributing to the loss of nearly 350,000 private-sector jobs.
Across New York, we're changing this culture. Fiscal debates now center on cutting taxes, not raising them. In Albany, we've cut taxes 36 times. And we are fighting for even more tax cuts today.
This attitudinal shift has helped push New York back in the right direction, where jobs are growing, personal income is rising and our economy is improving. In Albany, we have more than reversed the $3 billion in tax increases on city residents and businesses by cutting many taxes. These initiatives included cutting the state income tax and using state money to require a 10 percent cut in the troublesome city income tax.
So why the commuter tax and why now? Given the city's $2 billion surplus, shouldn't some other tax be cut instead? The answer is, If there are other taxes people want to cut in the city, let's cut them, too. But the opportunity to repeal the commuter tax has arisen, and it must be seized. Both houses of the Legislature, including an Assembly Speaker who is from Manhattan, have passed a bill I can sign. It's clear that tax cuts work for all New Yorkers. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Computer SharesFall; Investors Shift to Small Companies

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, led by computer-related shares such as the Microsoft Corporation, as investors shifted from large companies that gained the most in recent years to laggards, including small stocks and utilities.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index slumped 22.09 points, to 2,520.14. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 37.46 points, to 10,829.28, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 8.54 points, to 1,330.29. 
 The Russell 2000 Index of smaller stocks rose 1.12 points, to 449.14, its fourth consecutive gain.
"A lot of people continue to take money from large-cap growth names, and are putting it into smaller names that look cheap," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners L.L.C., which oversees $820 million.
While the average company in the Nasdaq 100 index trades at 54 times its estimated earnings per share for this year, Russell 2000 stocks trade at 23. The industrial equipment rental company Rental Service, with a market value of $578 million, gained 1 1/2, to 23 13/16 , while the stainless-steel maker Armco Inc., which has a market capitalization of $706 million, gained 7/8, to 6 1/2.
Six computer-guided buy programs and six sell programs had the net effect of adding 4.25 points to the Dow average, according to Birinyi Associates Inc., a research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
Concern is growing among some investors that price competition in the personal computer industry will slash profits in coming years. Already machines costing less than $1,000 are flooding the market.
Dell Computer, the direct seller of personal computers, slumped 15/16 , to 37 5/16 , and Compaq Computer fell 7/16 , to 25 1/16 . Dell, one of the top-performing stocks this decade, has returned just 2 percent this year, while Compaq is down 40 percent. International Business Machines , the world's biggest computer maker, fell 2 1/2, to 230 3/8.
The Dow Jones utilities average gained more than half a point, to 325.15, its third consecutive record, as investors sought shares that carry relatively high dividends. "It's safe-haven buying," said Wayne Nordberg, vice chairman of KBW Asset Management Inc., which manages $400 million. Reliant Energy gained 11/16 , to 30 7/8, and Consolidated Edison rose 5/8, to 48 1/16 .
Eastman Kodak fell 2 9/16 , to 73, after an analyst, B. Alex Henderson at Prudential Securities, said the photography company might face a second-quarter profit squeeze as its rival, Fuji Photo Film, cuts United States film prices heading into the busy summer season. That raised concern that Kodak would respond with price cuts of its own. The analyst said Kodak might continue to lose market share to Fuji, the No. 2 photo company.
General Motors and its Delphi Automotive Systems, the auto-parts maker, rose after Delphi was added to the Standard & Poor's 500 index. G.M., which still owns 82.3 percent of Delphi shares, will distribute about 0.7 share of Delphi for each G.M. common share outstanding next Friday. It is spinning off Delphi to let the parts company compete more effectively for business with other auto makers. G.M. rose 3 3/16 , to 83 5/16 . Delphi rose 13/16 , to 21 5/16 . Companies' shares typically rise when they join the S.& P. 500 because mutual funds that try to imitate the performance of the index must buy them. About $700 billion is invested in portfolios that try to match the index, S.& P. said.
Oil stocks gained, limiting losses in the Dow industrial average and the S.& P. 500 as crude oil for July delivery rose 34 cents, to $17.41 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange on reports oil exports would be delayed from Iraq, which accounts for about 2.5 percent of the world's oil.
Exxon gained 2 3/4, to 82 3/4; Mobil rose 3 3/4, to 103 1/8, and Texaco climbed 1 3/4, to 66 1/8.
Iraq has told shippers that sales would be delayed by at least a week starting Tuesday, when a new six-month round of exports in a United Nations program was scheduled to begin, news services said. The United Nations has yet to vote on renewing the oil sales agreement.
"Oil companies have done well in the last few months, mainly on the strength of oil prices," said Bob Christian, senior vice president of the Wilmington Trust Corporation, which oversees $27 billion. "Economic growth is picking up abroad and these are the companies that can benefit from faster economic growth in Europe and Asia."
Oil service companies also gained. Smith International Inc. rose 4 1/8. to 47 7/8; Cooper Cameron climbed 2 13/16 , to 39 5/16 , and Weatherford International gained 1 7/8, to 34 13/16.

HEADLINE: Goodyear May Shut Plant

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, May 21

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will close a 600-employee plant in southeast Ohio next fall if it cannot find a buyer. The plant in Logan, Ohio, will close by October if a buyer is not found, it said today. The plant, about 40 miles southeast of Columbus, makes instrument panel pads for the auto industry. Its biggest customer, the Ford Motor Company, decided to make its own equipment and the plant has not been able to replace the business, its manager said.

LENGTH: 449 words

HEADLINE: Vallone Sees Layoff Threat After a Tax Is Eliminated

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, warned yesterday that the loss of up to $360 million a year in commuter tax revenue could force the city to lay off workers at some point in the next few years.
Speaking to a group of labor leaders, Mr. Vallone said the State Legislature's decision last week to abolish the income tax paid by nonresidents who work in the city had created a "perpetual hole" in the city's $35 billion budget. The impact could be more serious in future years, he said, when the economy might be weaker and the city might not have a surplus. 
 "The quickest way of saving money is not to hire," Mr. Vallone, a Democrat, told about 50 labor leaders, who had invited City Council members to a luncheon to discuss concerns about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's spending plan. "And who gets hurt first? The little person gets hurt first."
After his speech, Mr. Vallone told reporters that the repeal of the commuter tax -- which was 0.45 percent of taxable income for most wage earners -- had forced the Mayor and the Council to reconsider their spending priorities as they figure out how to make up for the anticipated loss of revenue.
"Everything is back on the table," Mr. Vallone said, adding that Council members would discuss spending priorities today in a special meeting at City Hall. "We were able to get through the worst of times without laying people off, but we were never faced with this situation."
Later in the day, aides to both Mr. Vallone and Mr. Giuliani said layoffs in the coming fiscal year were highly unlikely, because the city had a record $2.1 billion surplus. A more likely strategy for dealing with the lost commuter tax revenue would be to abandon some of the tax cuts that the Mayor and the Speaker had proposed, the aides said. Mr. Giuliani has proposed $405 million in tax cuts, while Mr. Vallone has called for more than $800 million in cuts.
"This year there is a surplus, so we're just going to have to make some choices regarding the tax cuts," said Carolyn Daly, a spokeswoman for Mr. Vallone. "But in years where there is no surplus, those are the years where you will start considering layoffs."
Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said Mr. Vallone was justified in worrying about the long-term effects of the commuter tax repeal, because the city anticipates sizable budget deficits in the next few years. The Giuliani administration is predicting a $1.6 billion budget gap in the 2001 fiscal year, and a $1.7 billion gap in 2002.
"Given the size of our out-year gaps, layoffs are an option," Mr. Lhota said. "It's one of the many things we will consider as we move forward to close the budget gaps."

HEADLINE: U.N. Lets Iraq Sell Oil for 6 Months; Sanctions to Remain

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 21

 BODY:
The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the United Nations relief program for Iraq for six months amid calls to lift gulf war sanctions entirely.
The resolution allows Iraq to sell $5.26 billion worth of oil every six months to purchase food, medicine and other necessities for its people under crippling United Nations sanctions since Baghdad's troops invaded Kuwait in August 1990. 
 Benon Sevan, the United Nations Under Secretary General in charge of the program, expects difficulties in obtaining Iraq's agreement. "We have noted a certain increase in the stridency of statements regarding the future of the program, which may signal difficulties ahead," he told the Council.
During the last six months, Iraq sold about $3.8 billion worth of oil, about $900 million more than its previous high because of recovering oil prices and its ability to export an average of about two million barrels per day. If oil prices are sustained, Iraq could exceed the $5.26 billion in oil sales before Oct. 20.
Consequently, today's resolution promises to review the $5.26 billion limit on oil export revenues if Iraq reaches the ceiling before Nov. 20.
About two-thirds of the oil revenues go toward the purchase of relief supplies. The remainder is for costs of the program and to compensate victims of Iraq's 1990 occupation of Kuwait before United States-led troops expelled them in the 1991 gulf war.
The extension of the oil-for-food program came as Council members were considering proposals to ease or lift sanctions entirely. France had wanted some improvements to the relief plan in today's resolution, such as eliminating the ceiling on oil exports entirely.
But the United States, which made an identical proposal in January, only endorsed the possibility of raising the cap in meetings with diplomats.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

30-Year Treasury Yields Decline to 5.75 Percent
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond declined this week from a 1999 high of 5.92 percent on May 14. It closed yesterday at 5.75 percent. Treasury bond prices held onto strong gains as jitters about emerging markets caused a flight-to-quality buying while the expiration of June options increased purchases of bond futures. 
 On Tuesday, Federal Reserve policy makers said that they were leaning toward raising interest rates to slow economic growth and curb inflation. Although they did not raise their interest rate target, which is now 4.75 percent, the warning is now official. Page C4.
 
Japanese Banks Report Big Losses
Japan's eight largest banks have reported steep fiscal-year losses. The poor performance largely reflected efforts by the banks to clean their books by writing off bad loans. The losses, however, were still larger than expected. The main reason is that the banks must follow stricter rules for evaluating bad loans and creating a deeper cushion of money in the event that good loans go bad. C2.
 
Microsoft Continues Its Depositions
The chairman of America Online, Stephen M. Case, gave a deposition as part of Microsoft's preparations for the rebuttal phase of the antitrust trial against it, which is scheduled to resume June 1 after a three-month recess. C3.
 
F.C.C. Is Ordered to Review a Ruling
The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ordered the F.C.C. to review part of a 1997 decision that resulted in lower long-distance phone bills for millions of Americans. C4.
 
Computer Issues Lead Stocks Down
Stocks fell, led by computer-related shares as investors shifted from large companies that gained the most in recent years to laggards, including small stocks and utilities. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index slumped 22.09 points, to 2,520.14. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 37.46 points, to 10,829.28, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 8.54 points, to 1,330.29. C4.
 
Historian Signs New Book Contract
The historian Simon Schama has signed a deal to publish his next work of nonfiction with Talk Miramax Books, a division of Talk Media, which is owned by Miramax Films. The book, titled "Brittania," will be a history of Britain from the time before the Roman invasion to the year 2000, and it will accompany a 12-part BBC series, directed by Mr. Schama, that ABC will broadcast in the fall of 2000. C15.
 
Senate Passes Satellite-TV Bill
The Senate has approved legislation aimed at helping satellite-television companies compete more effectively against cable-TV providers by carrying local TV channels. The House has already approved a different measure. C15.
 
Financial Group Opposes Audit Plan
The nation's largest group of corporate financial officers is lobbying against parts of a plan from an S.E.C.-appointed committee on how companies calculate their profits. C3.
 
U.S. Joins Lawsuit Against Vencor
The Federal Government has joined a whistle-blower suit against Vencor that accuses the struggling hospital and nursing home company of overbilling Medicare. C15.
 
 
AK Steel to Acquire Rest of Armco
AK Steel, the owner of the flat-rolled steel plants originally built by Armco Steel, agreed to acquire the rest of the company, now called Armco, for $842 million in stock. C4.
 
Credit Suisse Apologizes to Japan
Credit Suisse Group apologized to Japanese regulators for obstructing an investigation that threatens to stunt its growth there. C2.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Flags of Inconvenience;
Union Campaigns Against Some Foreign Ship Registry

BYLINE: By RUSSELL WORKING 

DATELINE: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia, May 17

 BODY:
The Lakhta is a rusting hulk that usually hauls scrap metal to Japan, but since February the vessel has sat idle here in the largest port in the Russian Far East, her superstructure painted in Russian and English: "WE ARE ON STRIKE. WE WANT OUR MONEY!"
So when the Global Mariner sailed into Vladivostok's Golden Horn Bay recently, its crew pitched in $720 for the sailors on the Lakhta. The Global Mariner is a 13,000-ton freighter owned by the International Transport Workers' Federation, a union of sailors, truckers, longshoremen and others. Outfitted as a form of seagoing protest, the British ship is undertaking a round-the-world voyage to fight the registration of ships under "flags of convenience" -- countries other than the place of ownership. 
 Flying the flag of countries like Belize or Liberia allows them to avoid heavy taxes and hire crews from low-wage countries, cutting the cost of transportation. But the union says such vessels have poor safety records, frequently do not pay employees, and sometimes abandon sailors in distant ports when aging ships get too expensive to run. The Lakhta, the union said, represents everything it is fighting.
Once owned by the Far Eastern Shipping Company, the largest transportation fleet in the Russian Pacific, the ship was sold and reflagged in Belize. The sailors are a year behind in their wages, and the owners no longer provide food or water and once even tried to evict the crew at gunpoint. The ship is caked in rust, and even her basic seaworthiness is in question. The hatch covers over the cargo holds do not fully close, a problem that could swamp the ship in high seas, said Ulrich Jurgens, the Global Mariner's captain and a union inspector, after touring the Lakhta.
"If you have open hatch covers, it is basically a death sentence," he said. "This is one of the worst cases I have ever seen. What we're seeing here is inhumane. It shows less than no respect for the lives of the seafarers."
Of the world's 85,500 self-propelled cargo vessels of 100 gross tons or greater, some 16,000 are registered in the 27 countries that the union lists as flags of convenience. The practice of registering abroad began in earnest with Prohibition, when rumrunners hauled their cargoes under the Panamanian flag. But the practice has grown in recent years as shipping companies try to save money. In the eight years since the fall of Communism, 10 percent of Russia's fleet has been reflagged abroad to avoid the country's onerous taxes.
Costly regulations and high-wage workers in North America, Japan and northern Europe often make it profitable for shipping companies to reflag. For example, the United States levies a 50 percent duty on any repairs to American-flagged ships in overseas ports, said Rod Vulovic, vice president of Sea-Land Service Inc., a Charlotte, N.C., unit of the CSX Corporation.
Twenty-eight of Sea-Land's 63 ships are flagged overseas, saving up to $3.5 million a vessel each year, Mr. Vulovic said.
Mr. Vulovic rejects the union's charges that shipowners are cavalier toward workers and safety when their vessels sail under foreign flags. "You can have companies such as Mobil Oil that do a good job and are responsible citizens of the world," he said, "and they're put in the same bag as those who don't pay mariners and abandon ships."
But critics say foreign registries effectively allow countries to pick and choose which regulations to follow. Flag-of-convenience countries, taken as a whole, have a worse safety record than registries of ships based within a country, said Paul Lane, director of the Seafarers' Research Center of the University of Cardiff in Wales. Even more troubling, he said, is that sailors at sea are subject to the laws of the nations under which they are flagged, and maritime ministries do not effectively monitor working conditions. How well can states like Liberia or Cambodia, torn by civil strife for decades, oversee their national ships?
The International Transport Workers' Federation has fought reflagging since 1948. And last year, on the 50th anniversary of its campaign, it took its show on the road. The union bought an old freighter for $3 million. (It hopes to recoup this cost by selling the ship when her voyage ends early next year). The union spent an added $1.8 million refurbishing the ship as a floating museum. Workers decorated the Global Mariner's enormous holds with flags from "convenience" countries.
They covered the bare steel walls with billboard-sized pictures depicting what it says are the legacies of such fleets: abandoned or unpaid sailors, increased shipwrecks, maimed seamen, cockroach-covered food in a ship's galley. ("A seafarers menu," the caption states). In one hold, a film shows real footage from shipwrecks on flag-of-convenience vessels. Sirens blare as rescuers pull passengers' corpses from the sea. A man grabs a child by the hair and hauls him into the boat like a drowned seal pup.
The Global Mariner set out last summer on an 18-month voyage to take its message to the world. Its campaign will cost an estimated $9 million, money that comes from fees that shipping companies pay for union members, Captain Jurgens said.
The show has drawn crowds in ports ranging from Reykjavik, Iceland, to Vladivostok, with more than 300,000 visitors coming on board so far. In Vladivostok alone, 14,983 people came aboard during a four-day stay. (The Global Mariner belly-flopped, however, in New York in October: Only 100 visitors came aboard.)
The images of sailors sharing food with cockroaches can be particularly poignant in a port city like Vladivostok, where thousands of unpaid sailors work and scores of families have relatives who are stranded on vessels abroad. Maxim Pechevisty and Konstantin Strokin, both 21, are students at the Marine Academy, and they went through the Global Mariner's display twice, transfixed by the grim images of life at sea.
"This shows the real conditions aboard the ships under flags of convenience," Mr. Pechevisty said. "We have come across such problems ourselves."
Several crew members have sailed on Greenpeace vessels in the past, and the Global Mariner has employed similar tactics. The ship uses a high-powered projector to beam slogans onto ships run by owners it criticizes. In Louisiana the crew hung a 20-by-40-foot banner criticizing the United States Navy because of a union dispute at a shipyard in New Orleans.
But while shaming the Navy may cheer union members on the Mississippi Delta, Russia, with its crippled economy and fathomless corruption, is not so easily moved by the appearance of a union ship armed with a high-beam projector.
In the case of the Lakhta, the crew has not been able to figure out just who owes them the wages. After it docked in February, the seafarers tried to sue the Dellner Shipping Company of Vladivostok, which chartered the Lakhta from the Seattle-based Caribbean Maritime, for $82,423 in back wages.
Dellner, which took over the vessel in December, says it has paid its share -- 40 days' worth -- and the previous charter operator owes the rest.
When the dispute went to court, a judge threw out the sailors' case. On March 16, the court, at Dellner's request, sent a bailiff accompanied by 13 gunmen in black masks marching on board. Snipers scaled the masts, and the gunmen threatened the crew with Kalashnikov rifles, said a cook, Marina Popova, 36, and other crew members who were there. A Lakhta sailor managed to throw a matchbox onto the ship next door with a note begging for help.
After a lawyer and a television crew showed up, the gunmen left.
The union's Vladivostok inspector is representing the crew, and the Global Mariner donated boxes of food and invited the Lakhta seafarers over for dinner. (Ms. Popova declined the invitation; she was ashamed that the Lakhta was too poor to return the hospitality for the foreign seafarers.) When Russian border guards refused the foreigners access to the boat, the Global Mariner crew hopped a fence to check on their comrades.
The crew of the Lakhta was hoping the arrival of the Global Mariner would change their situation by drawing attention to their plight. But then the British ship sailed from port on May 3, and the Lakhta crew watched her go from their mooring in front of a heap of scrap metal on a pier in the commercial seaport.
Captain Jurgens, the Global Mariner's skipper, said he expected the Lakhta to eventually sink at its anchorage. But Mikhail Plyushchakov, Dellner's general director, remained optimistic that the Lakhta would again ply the Sea of Japan under the flag of Belize.
"We'll get a new crew on board," he said. "We'll fix all the problems port inspectors tell us to fix. And we will sail again."

LENGTH: 3328 words

HEADLINE: WAITING FOR RICHES: A special report.;
Living Off the Daily Dream Of Winning a Lottery Prize

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY

DATELINE: ORANGE, N.J., May 21

 BODY:
Inside Home Dairy, a sliver of a store that sells candy, cigarettes and newspapers here, people mill around all day searching for phantom riches: writing down numbers and scratching tickets in a nonstop frenzy that amounts to $14,400 in average weekly lottery sales.
Despite the store's name, only a few cartons of milk are sold each day. More customers come looking for "dream books," which sell for $3 to $5 and offer advice on what lottery numbers should be associated with a dream or daily occurrence. If a person dreams about a cat, one book advises, the number to play is 114. If the cat is black, the number is 244. And if a person buys a hat, the book recommends 815 or 816. 
 Standing in the store one evening, Dennis Dutton, a 36-year-old custodian who bets on numbers every day, explained how important a lottery jackpot was to his financial planning. Throughout the month, Mr. Dutton said, he intended to bet $15 each day on the number 898. At the time, his telephone was disconnected and he was hoping that hitting the number -- for winnings of about $2,750 -- would help pay his bills.
"I wish that 898 would come out," he said, "because it would solve all my problems." (It did not.)
In this working-class neighborhood, 18 miles west of Manhattan, as in similar areas across the country, the state-sponsored daily lottery is becoming so deeply woven into so many lives that it is a part of the social fabric. It is a pastime more popular than baseball, a ritual as routine as watching the nightly news, a practice far more common than voting.
With lottery machines as prevalent as cash registers in the 38 states with lotteries, instant-win tickets hanging behind store counters everywhere, and $35 billion bet each year across the country, the most prevalent purveyor of betting games in America is no longer the street corner sports bookmaker or the Las Vegas casino operator.
Instead, it is the state governments -- the same entities that for years outlawed gambling -- that are now leading the way in building widespread acceptance of gambling across the country. The impact that state lotteries are having on communities around the country has also been a focus of the National Gambling Impact Study Commission, appointed in 1996 by President Clinton and Congress to examine the social and economic consequences of legalized gambling in the United States.
The commission, which in June is scheduled to release a report of its two-year study, is expected to recommend that state lotteries curtail their advertising in economically distressed communities and that they be required to contribute some of their revenues to research and treatment for problem gambling.
It is in communities like Orange where the lottery is a dominant force and many poor and modest-income residents are devoted to an endless search for winning numbers and an unswerving belief that a jackpot waits for them.
 
The Players
The Best Customers Can Least Afford It
A close look at Orange and a computer analysis of lottery playing in New Jersey by The New York Times provide a compelling picture of just how vital the people who live and work in cities like this one are to the lottery business.
Far more than previously known, modest-wage earners, the poor and less educated people spend a greater percentage of their income on the lottery than do wealthier New Jersey residents, the Times analysis found.
Using 1998 New Jersey State Lottery data, the analysis found that in the ZIP codes where people with the lowest incomes live, the amount spent per $10,000 of income on lottery tickets was more than five times the amount spent on tickets by people who live in wealthier ZIP codes. The analysis was calculated from information on 48,875 lottery winners and estimates based on census data.
It found that for a chance to cash in on an instant-win scratch ticket, people living in the 100 lowest average-income ZIP codes in New Jersey spent $53 per $10,000 of their earnings. But in the 100 ZIP codes with the highest-average income, spending on instant-win tickets was just $12 per $10,000.
And for the Pick 4 game, which can pay as much as $2,788 for a 50-cent bet on the correct four numbers and which is one of the state's most popular games, people in the 100 lowest-income ZIP codes spent $29 per $10,000 income, compared with $5 per $10,000 income in the 100 highest-income ZIP codes.
In New Jersey, people who are less educated also spend far more money playing the lottery. In the ZIP codes with the lowest percentage of people with college educations, people spent more than five times as much per $10,000 of income than those in areas with the highest proportion of college-educated population.
The analysis is consistent with those in other states that have shown that as a percentage of household income, poorer people in cities and rural areas alike, spend much more on the lottery than do people in high-income brackets. Living from paycheck to paycheck, they are easily captured by the notion that the lottery can fulfill their basic financial goals.
And while these customers put far more money into the lottery, there is little evidence that they get more back.
The spread of lotteries nationally was propelled largely by the politically palatable promise to use the proceeds to help finance education. People might lose their money, the reasoning went, but they can feel all right about it knowing that it is going to a good cause.
In New Jersey, as in many other states, however, the proceeds from the lottery go to the state treasurer. Although those lottery dollars are indeed used to augment educational spending, studies have shown that lotteries have not increased the net amount spent on education but have only given the states a larger pool from which to allocate those funds. And areas of the state where large percentages of lottery revenues are generated do not receive a proportional amount of state aid in return.
"With all the money we spend on the lottery," Orange's Mayor, Mimms Hackett Jr. said, "I think we would be in much better shape if it was equated with the amount we get from the state."
Mary Lou Murphy, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Department of Taxation, said that although the games might take a larger proportion of income from poorer people, playing was voluntary.
"The state does not usurp rights and privileges based on economic status," Ms. Murphy said. "Their chances of winning may not be very good, but it's an exciting thing."
 
The Numbers
So Many Chances, So Many Ways
The statistics come to life here in Orange, where up and down Main Street and all along the thoroughfares that intersect the city's thriving business district, the state lottery's familiar green and yellow four-leaf-clover logo is pasted on windows.
On some days, a local storefront psychic adviser hangs a sign out offering "lucky numbers." And each day inside a check-cashing store, customers line up in front of one teller to cash their payroll and Social Security checks, and then move a few steps to another teller to buy instant scratch tickets and daily lottery numbers.
With its ubiquitous advertisements and tickets on sale all around them, the lottery is always right there -- whispering in their ears, reminding them that it only takes one lucky drawing to finance their retirement, cover college expenses for their children, or buy the house they have always wanted.
"You notice in urban areas, there are a lot of people who have not made it to the top by a certain age," Mayor Hackett said. "The lottery becomes the only outlet for that dream. Success for a lot of people is predicated on hitting the number."
The numbers underscore the significant role that the lottery plays in Orange. New Jersey, where the median household income is $55,209, has 8.1 million residents and 6,000 lottery outlets -- about 1 lottery machine for every 1,350 residents.
But Orange, where the median household income is $37,529, has 30,000 residents and 33 stores selling lottery tickets, or about 1 machine for every 909 residents. And while weekly per capita lottery sales are $3.92 statewide, they are $6.87 in Orange.
With a population that is 70 percent black, 20 percent white and 10 percent Hispanic, the City of Orange Township, as this urban-suburban municipality is formally named, has homes that range from old, well-kept mansions to aging two-family frame houses and daunting public housing complexes. Bus drivers, office workers, nurses, police officers and janitors are among those who regularly line up for lottery tickets here.
In addition to the daily three-digit and four-digit drawings, residents buy tickets for a five-digit drawing that is held three days a week, a six-digit drawing held twice a week and a once-weekly matching game with 21 sets of four numbers.
Even more popular are the dozens of types of colorful instant lottery tickets, which sell so briskly that lottery officials have begun putting them in automatic vending machines and marketing them as special-occasion gifts -- with decorative envelopes and names like "Happy Birthday" and "Merry Money."
At the Majestic Barber Shop, where haircuts cost $10, all three barbers play the numbers every day. Between customers, one barber, Hilliard Kelly, runs to the corner deli to buy instant tickets. Mr. Kelly buys about four tickets a day at $1 to $2 each and spends about $10 on the daily number.
"I come out behind," he said, sitting in his barber chair, using a coin to scratch a ticket called 50 Grand. (It was a loser.) "But I keep going back. Once you get used to playing those rub-offs, it's hard to walk in a store with money in your pocket and not buy one."
 
The Players
A Way of Life For One Couple
Among the many people who play every day are Emmett and Mary Newsome. A full-time local bus driver by night, Mrs. Newsome spends her days operating the Top Chef restaurant, serving takeout soul food like pork chops smothered in gravy, collard greens, peach cobbler and sweet potato pie.
Mrs. Newsome has played the lottery for more than 20 years, spending about $12 a day each week to play numbers that correspond with family birthdays, home addresses or whatever might catch her attention.
"We play the lottery all the time," she said, standing behind the counter of the sparsely decorated restaurant.
Although she has never tallied her total losses against her winnings, she said she believed she had come out ahead.
"There's nothing like the lottery," she said. "You can always make a little money from that."
Mrs. Newsome is now seeking something that she is certain will increase her business: a lottery machine. She has applied to the state to become a ticket agent, and her application is pending. Agents receive 5 percent of their ticket sales.
Mr. Newsome, who works at a nearby powder-coating plant, applying protective coatings to metal products, has developed his own system of tracking past winning numbers to determine patterns.
In a ritual that is performed in the family's house each morning, Mr. Newsome rises at 4:30 A.M., puts on his robe and walks downstairs to the kitchen. After turning on a pot of water for his coffee, he sits at the table and in front of him he places several memo pads and worn file cards that have hundreds of three-digit numbers written on them.
Painstakingly, Mr. Newsome creates charts based on factors like which hostess on television picks the numbers on which day of the week. (New Jersey holds a lottery drawing every day except Christmas.)
Although the drawing is random, Mr. Newsome is convinced that there is a pattern.
"I see here that 994 has come out three times on Sunday," he said as he sat down to make his selections one recent Sunday morning. Lighting a cigarette and scooping four heaping tablespoons of sugar into a large mug of coffee, he predicted, "I think that 994 is going to come back today." (It did not.)
Based on the information he compiles each morning, he writes down his 20 favorite numbers for the day, and leaves a copy on the table for his wife. She decides which ones she will play.
It is hard to tally how much the Newsomes spend or win, because in addition to the game itself, there is a little gamesmanship between the two. A couple of months ago, Mrs. Newsome played one of the numbers her husband had suggested and she won more than $300. When Mr. Newsome asked her whether she had played it, she said no.
"I know he's hitting a lot of times and ain't saying nothing to me," she said.
Last June, according to Mr. Newsome's day planner, the couple won on four consecutive days, for a total of more than $1,000. "That was a good week," Mr. Newsome said. But throughout most of two months early this year, the Newsomes were playing every day and were not having any luck.
By the middle of one month, Mr. Newsome was growing anxious.
"We could sure use the money," he said one evening as he walked up to the counter at Home Dairy and played 172, 578, 198, and 574. (They were all losers; the winning three-digit number that evening was 416.)
 
The Suspicions
Black Winners, White Winners
Despite their devotion to the lottery, many players in Orange say they believe that the state lottery is rigged. While they have no proof, they constantly complain that most winners of big Pick 6 Lotto jackpots come from areas that are predominantly white.
"Most of the time when I win on rub-offs," said Mr. Kelly, the barber, "I bought my ticket from a white neighborhood."
Virginia E. Haines, executive director of the New Jersey state lottery, sighs with frustration when she hears of such suspicions. Everywhere Ms. Haines goes in the state, she said in an interview at her Trenton office, people complain that the big winners never come from their own region.
In fact, statistics show that the number of big winners from a particular region is commensurate with the number of tickets sold in that region. For example, Essex and Hudson Counties are among the those with the highest amount of lottery sales in the state. And since 1996, those two counties are tied for the most Pick 6 Lotto winners, at 14 each.
Furthermore, Ms. Haines said, the Lotto numbers are selected randomly, and the instant tickets are dispersed in a manner assuring that the winning tickets are randomly distributed. Still, even among the most experienced lottery players, the criticism persists.
"They don't put the Lotto winners in the black areas and they can't convince me otherwise," Myra Russell asserted, speaking of the "quick picks," in which a player lets a computer select the numbers.
Nevertheless, Ms. Russell, who lives in Orange, has played the New Jersey lottery since it became computerized in 1975. Back then, she worked at an Orange liquor store, operating the lottery machine every day.
"I started with them and I know," she said as she bought her daily tickets inside a local check-cashing store. "To me, the New Jersey lottery is a big joke," she snapped -- all the while stuffing her tickets into her pocket.
Although modern-day lotteries have been legal in New Jersey for just 29 years, people in and around Orange were betting on illegal lotteries long before that. As in many other poor and working-class cities around the country, the illegal numbers, which were known as policy, had flourished for decades. People could play for pennies, and the daily three-digit number was determined by the total amount of money bet at a specified horse race track that day.
Until whites began moving out in the 1970's, Orange was largely populated by working-class people of Italian and Irish descent, and John J. Kunz, an Orange native and general manager of Town Check Cashing, said, "Everybody played the number."
Mary Lou Williams, who operates the lottery machine at Town Check Cashing and who formerly owned Home Dairy, said many of her customers had been buying lottery tickets from her for more than two decades.
"We used to have a lot of fun selling tickets," Ms. Williams said. "Now it's much more serious. People are determined they're going to win."
Ms. Williams does not make as much money from lottery sales as she once did because more ticket outlets are in the area.
"Nowadays I'm like a spider in a web," she said. "There's one on every corner."
 
The Jackpot
One City Awaits A Big Winner
While there may be plenty of places to play the lottery in this city, finding someone who has actually won a big jackpot is not as easy. When asked whether they could provide any big winners from Orange, lottery officials said they had winners in surrounding areas, but none who had actually bought their tickets in Orange.
Photocopies of winning tickets are prominently displayed above the counter at Home Dairy, but based on the serial numbers on the winning tickets, they were sold at stores elsewhere in the state.
One recent evening, Stanley Micheaux, 69, who uses part of his twice-monthly disability payments to play the numbers each day, gazed skeptically at the winners pasted up inside Home Dairy.
"I mean, how long have those things been up there?" Mr. Micheaux asked. "They make us think we're going to win, but we ain't going to win a lot of money."
Mr. Micheaux's wife, Margaret, who is 59, retired and also a daily player, is more sanguine. "I play because I think I'm going to win," she said.
By 7:55 P.M. that day, Mr. Micheaux, who has lived in Orange for more than 25 years, was in front of the television set just as he is every day at the same time.
"Stan, turn to Channel 23!" his wife yelled into the living room, reminding him that it was time for the daily lottery drawing.
While at Home Dairy, Mr. Micheaux had bought a "Happy Birthday" instant ticket (it was a loser) and bet $1 on 059 -- adding a zero to his home address just as he does each day -- and $1 on 5723. (Both were losers.)
 
The Hopes
A Possible Jackpot Is Always Present
When Emmett Newsome pulls his number-covered file cards from his wallet, the first thing a person notices is the dirt on the cards, and then his hands. The skin is dry and cracked, his fingertips are covered with a greasy film.
They are the hands of a man who labors for a living, and Mr. Newsome, who is 54, hopes that one day he will win a big lottery jackpot and be able to wash his hands of the more than 20 years he has worked at metal-coating plants.
Raised in the tough Howard Street area of Newark, he has been involved in the daily numbers since he was a boy working as a "runner," picking up betting slips for his "Uncle Soldier," who ran an illegal numbers racket.
Mrs. Newsome, 51, has been a bus driver for New Jersey Transit for 20 years, and whether the couple win a big lottery prize or not, she plans for them eventually to retire from their jobs, sell the restaurant and move to her native South Carolina. Her only misgiving about returning to South Carolina is that the state has no lottery.
"It's a shame they don't have a lottery because people need to have some way to try to make a little extra money," she said.
On April 7, however, legislation in South Carolina moved a step closer to allowing voters to decide in 2000 on whether to establish a lottery.
The couple's 15-year-old daughter, Monique, struggles to understand her parents' obsession with the lottery.
"I mean, I know that sometimes you win, but you also lose," she said.
She thinks that her parents play the lottery too much.
"My father, if he has a little money left over, he plays his Pick-Its," she said. "And I tell my mother not to play, and then after she loses she says, 'Oh, I should've listened to you.' "
On a Saturday, Mr. Newsome followed his regular routine. Among the numbers that he bet on that day was a family favorite, 703, a combination of the home address. It was also the winning number that evening, paying Mr. Newsome $262.50 -- enough to keep him playing for another month.

Chart: "Spending on the Lottery in New Jersey"
 
An analysis by The New York Times of lottery spending in New Jersey found that people who live in the state's lowest-income ZIP code areas spend more than five times as much of their income on lottery tickets as do people who live in the highest-income ZIP code areas. For example, in the 100 lowest-income ZIP code areas, spending on the lottery game known as Pick 4 was $29 per $10,000 of annual income. But in the 100 highest-income ZIP code areas, the amount spent on Pick 4 was less than $5 per $10,000 of annual income. And for instant-win scratch-off tickets, the amount spent in the 100 lowest-income ZIP codes was $46 per $10,000 of annual income, compared to $10 per $10,000 of annual income in the 100 highest-income ZIP codes.
 The Times also found that when lottery revenue is analyzed along with other tax revenues that the state receives, low-income people -- through their lottery spending -- close the tax burden gap between themselves and wealthy people. For example, for every $10,000 of annual income earned in lower income areas, $108 is spent on income taxes, while $111 is spent on the lottery. But in wealthier areas, for every $10,000 of annual income earned, $319 goes to income taxes, while just $25 goes to lottery spending. FORD FESSENDEN
 
Low-income areas pay less than high-income areas in property taxes and income taxes per $10,000 of income. But when it comes to the lottery, New Jersey's fourth-largest source of revenue, the trend is reversed: lower-income areas spend more.
 
There are nearly twice as many outlets selling lottery tickets in the lowest-income areas than in the highest-income areas.
 
HOW THE ANALYSIS WAS DONE
The New York Times study of lottery spending was based on data derived from 48,875 people who won at least $600 in 1998 playing one of five games: Pick 4, Jersey Cash 5, Pick 6 Lotto, Lotzee, and Instant-Win. Data on people who won less than $600 on any of the games is not available because those winners are not required to provide personal information such as name and address. A sixth game, known as Pick 3, is one of the lottery's most popular games -- especially in low-income areas -- according to lottery experts. But data for Pick 3 are not included because most winners receive less than $600.
 In the analysis, each winner indicates a certain amount of money spent on the games. For instance, each person who won the Pick 6 Lotto in 1998 represent 2/3ed $45,000 in betting. Because winners should be a random sample of players, The Times was able to estimate the amount of play in each ZIP code.
 
Graph highlights lotto spending trends related to per-$10,000 worth of income, property taxes, income taxes, and lotto outlets per 10,000 people. (pg. B6)

LENGTH: 945 words

HEADLINE: Halt in Pay For Legislators Ruled Invalid

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 21

 BODY:
A Brooklyn judge ruled today that a new law withholding state legislators' pay until a budget is passed is unconstitutional. His decision dealt a blow to an attempt to speed the state's notoriously lethargic budget process.
Gov. George E. Pataki and Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said they would appeal the ruling. Both camps in the case have agreed that the ruling will not take effect while an appeal is pending, so the legislators may not see new paychecks for months. 
 The 211 members of the Assembly and the Senate have not been paid since March 31, the last day of the old fiscal year, and some say they are beginning to have financial trouble. "Let's just say that my landlord is happy at the thought of my getting paid again," said Senator Thomas K. Duane of Manhattan, one of 14 legislators, all Democrats, who sued to challenge the law.
The plaintiffs took heart from the strongly worded decision by Justice Richard D. Huttner of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. He found that the law gives the Governor a coercive power over the Legislature that curbs its power and independence, in violation of the State Constitution.
"When even one legislator, by dint of economic circumstance, is coerced into passing a budget that may require him or her to sacrifice conscientiously held beliefs, then the entire process is tainted," Justice Huttner wrote.
As a sideshow, the question of withholding pay has threatened to drown out the main attraction. The state budget is 51 days overdue, there are no serious negotiations under way, and the Republicans who control the Senate and the Democrats who run the Assembly are blaming each other for the lack of progress. Republicans say Democrats have dawdled, pinning their hopes on the court case, while Democrats have accused the Governor of waiting for them to crumble under the pressure of working unpaid for months.
In the icy atmosphere of the Capitol, where even civil talk among the powers has become rare, the dispute has deepened the animosity between Mr. Pataki, who continues to collect his pay, and the Assembly Democrats, including the Speaker, Sheldon Silver. It has heightened tensions between Mr. Silver, who did not take part in the suit but looked favorably on it, and the Senate's Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who proposed the law withholding pay.
Mr. Pataki has proposed a $72.7 billion budget, while the Assembly Democrats want to spend $2 billion to $4 billion more, and the Senate Republicans' plan falls between the other two proposals.
Cases turning on constitutional issues can sometimes be appealed directly to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, bypassing the Appellate Division, but it is unclear whether that will happen in this case.
Justice Huttner ruled that the withholding law, known as Chapter 635, violated both the separation of legislative and executive powers implicit in the State Constitution, and an explicit provision barring any change in a legislator's pay during a two-year term.
"Chapter 635 flies in the face of that prohibition," he wrote. "By enacting Chapter 635, those legislators who voted in favor improvidently and unconstitutionally incapacitated the Legislature from performing its duty as a representative body. The natural and intended consequence of Chapter 635 is to coerce passage of a timely budget by the infliction of personal financial hardship upon some legislators."
Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried of Manhattan, who has taken the lead in the suit, said: "The court's analysis is quite plain, and doesn't leave much room for argument. I know we're not going to get paid, but I'm very pleased."
Mr. Silver could not be reached by telephone because he was observing the Jewish holiday of Shabuoth.
Mr. Bruno issued a statement saying: "This entire issue can be easily resolved by passing a budget. It is long past time that the Assembly join with the Senate and the Governor in adopting a prudent, responsible budget."
Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's communications director, expressed confidence that the law would be upheld. The plaintiffs' pursuit of the case, she said, "proves that they're not interested in doing the people's business, only in getting paid."
The withholding law was rooted in the legislators' desire for a pay raise, which Mr. Pataki had opposed for years. In December, he relented and signed a bill increasing state elected officials' salaries by 38 percent. Legislators now earn $79,500 a year, plus stipends for leadership and committee positions that raise the average close to $90,000. The Governor earns $179,500. But Mr. Pataki insisted that a withholding law be part of the price the Legislature would pay for his agreement to the raise.
Last month, 11 Assembly and Senate Democrats who had voted against the law, and 3 who first took office in January, after it was enacted, sued to overturn it. Many Republican legislators are sympathetic to their cause but have not spoken out, unwilling to risk the ire of Mr. Bruno, Mr. Pataki or the public. And some lawmakers in both parties voted for the law, believing that it would be struck down in court.
The paychecks are being held in a safe. They can be released only by agreement of the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, and the State Department of Taxation and Finance, controlled by the Governor.
In light of today's ruling and the fact that no appeal has yet been filed, Mr. McCall authorized release of the checks. Mr. Silver's office sent the Pataki administration a request for their release, which aides to the Speaker conceded was an empty exercise. Ms. Mucha said the checks would remain in the safe.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BURLINGTON NORTHERN IS MAKING MOVES TO CUT COSTS

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation, the second- largest United States railroad, said yesterday that it was slashing a total of 1,400 jobs, cutting capital spending and naming a new president as part of a plan to improve profits. The railroad said the moves were aimed at cutting costs because revenues are slipping below levels a year ago. Some 400, or about 7 percent, of the railroad's salaried positions are scheduled for elimination by the end of the second quarter, and 1,000 hourly union positions will be eliminated by the end of 1999. The Fort Worth-based Burlington Northern has about 39,000 hourly union employees. Shares of Burlington Northern fell $1.4375, to $33.50.

HEADLINE: Vacation Spots in New York Suddenly Appeal to Clintons

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
President Clinton, as he is fond of reminding everyone from time to time, cannot run again for re-election, which frees him from certain political calculations. One of these, you would think, would be where to spend his summer vacation, a decision that in the past has been so fraught with image-conscious polling that he twice went off to Wyoming just to please environmentalists when he really wanted to go back to Martha's Vineyard.
Now, with his wife edging closer to running for the Senate from New York, the summer vacation is still in the balance. And although Administration officials caution that a final decision may be dozens of permutations away, one thing seems likely: It will be in New York. 
 The First Couple for the first time in their lives, these officials say, are exploring the recreational options across the state. The choices have apparently narrowed, they say, to the Adirondacks or Shelter Island, although Marsha Berry, the First Lady's spokeswoman, was noncommittal.
"I don't know that you can narrow it down to two, or rule out Martha's Vineyard," Ms. Berry said. She noted that the Clintons were planning a five-day Florida vacation next week, where Mrs. Clinton will focus on deciding whether to run for the Senate. "That's as far as they're planning, in terms of vacation," Ms. Berry said. The annual vacation decision, she said, "is one of the hardest things to pin them down on."
Other officials say the Adirondacks and Shelter Island are under close study. Both spots, at different ends of the state, make two entirely different political statements, and have their own drawbacks.
The rustic Adirondacks, spread across six million acres in northern New York, make a nice setting for the outdoorsy look. But the area is remote and short on the kind of socializing that the Clintons favor.
It may be telling that when one Administration official was asked whether the Clintons might pick the Adirondacks, his first response was: "How far is that from New York City?"
Answer: Too far for dinner.
Shelter Island, tucked between Long Island's North and South Forks, is quaint -- it has no traffic lights -- while still easily accessible to the Hamptons and its trunks of campaign cash. But constant shuttling to Steven Spielberg's estate could suggest a certain elitism that Mrs. Clinton, if she runs for the Senate, would probably want to avoid.
Dick Morris, the former White House consultant, in the past has steered the Clintons toward places that have an appeal to middle-class families -- i.e., the suburban swing voters who frequently decide elections.
It was Mr. Morris who convinced the Clintons in 1995 and 1996 to drop Martha's Vineyard and head for Jackson Hole, Wyo.
As he writes in his memoir, "Behind the Oval Office," (Random House, 1997) Mr. Morris, with the help of pollster Mark Penn and an elaborately refined polling grid, found out that people whose votes are up for grabs tend to like baseball, hiking, camping and technology.
"I urged that he take a mountain vacation, that he hike and camp out in a tent" and publicize the high-tech gear he was using, Mr. Morris wrote, admitting that he was carrying his belief in polling to "a mindless extreme."
"Clinton was not happy," Mr. Morris continued, asking him whether, for example, if he wore a baseball cap he could still go golfing. "What if I hike, set up my campsite and go fishing but I don't catch anything?" an irked President pestered the consultant.
Despite his irritation, the President and First Lady went to Wyoming, and they did camp and hike. But then, after the President's re-election, they returned to Martha's Vineyard in 1997 and 1998 -- ever nomadic in the summer, having no family retreat like a Kennebunkport or Hyde Park to call home.
Mr. Morris, now widely loathed within the Administration, laughed today when informed of the New York options.
"That's ridiculous," he said, branding their sudden interest in a New York vacation "totally and completely phony." He said that the Adirondacks were "derivative of my advice to go to the Rockies" and that Shelter Island was "derivative of Martha's Vineyard, which is where they really want to go."
On reflection, he thought the Adirondacks would be a better choice than Shelter Island. "Swing voters like camping, hiking and fishing," he said.
While a visit to the woods may have broad appeal, it is unclear whether it would help with the Adirondack locals, who tend to vote heavily Republican. Gerald B. H. Solomon, who represented the Adirondacks in Congress for 20 years before retiring last year, said in an interview today, "The natives would welcome them, but they certainly wouldn't vote for them."
Mr. Solomon said that Mrs. Clinton's advocacy of gun control would be particularly troubling. He received much attention for his forceful denunciation of a gun-control measure in 1996, when he said his wife, who lived alone in Glens Falls while he was in Washington, needed her rifles for protection.
But he also acknowledged that the seasonal Adirondack economy could use a boost from the money a Presidential visit would bring in. "Their entourage would be most welcome," he said.
Wherever the Clintons wind up, they are not likely to bump into Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mrs. Clinton's likely competitor in a Senate race. The Mayor makes a point of not taking vacations.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ANOTHER WORLD, by Pat Barker. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) Old hatreds, wounds and guilt, simmering from World War I and beyond, haunt a family in a novel set in modern Newcastle.
 
A DANGEROUS FRIEND, by Ward Just. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $23.) As its well-meaning civilian hero attempts to find an American officer captured in Vietnam, this novel emerges as an allegory for our country's place in the increasingly deranged world of the mid-1960's.
 
ENGLAND, ENGLAND, by Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $23.) This satirical novel suggests that while there may always be an England, its immediate future looks more like a theme park than an empire.
 
FOR THE RELIEF OF UNBearable Urges, by Nathan Englander. (Knopf, $22.) Ambitious short stories by a 29-year-old former yeshiva student from New York, now living in secular Israel; his characters are able to flourish in a borderland between the author's old world and that new one.
 
FREDY NEPTUNE, by Les Murray. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) This verse novel follows an itinerant Everyman from Australia afflicted with an unusual power as he travels through the horrors of the 20th century.
 
LORDS OF THE HORIZONS: A History of the Ottoman Empire, by Jason Goodwin. (John Macrae/Holt, $32.50.) A journalist and travel writer illuminates the history and culture of a former seat of imperial splendor, from its humble origins to glittering eminence to lumbering decline.
 
NANSEN: The Explorer as Hero, by Roland Huntford. (Barnes & Noble, paper, $19.95.) A biography, 12 years in the making, of the Norwegian explorer, diplomat and Nobel laureate who became the mentor to a generation of adventurers and whose life seemed to come from an Ibsen play.
 
THE PITY OF WAR, by Niall Ferguson. (Basic Books, $30.) The traditional views on the causes of World War I are called into question, and the author suggests that had England stayed at home, the world might be a different place today.
 
A PRIVATE LIFE OF HENRY JAMES: Two Women and His Art, by Lyndall Gordon. (Norton, $30.) A biography that pierces the myth the novelist built around his life by delving into the lives of Minny Temple and Constance Fenimore Woolson, two women who inspired him and became the models for some of his heroines.
 
TURN OF THE CENTURY, by Kurt Andersen. (Random House, $24.95.) A novel about a "yoga-practicing Jew" and a "lapsed Unitarian" who are married and competing in the silicon rat race of the new millennium, where life is only slightly more crazy than the old one.
