HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99;
Greenback Blues

BYLINE: By Jason Goodwin; Jason Goodwin is the author of "Lords of the Horizon: A History of the Ottoman Empire." He is working on a history of the United States dollar.

 BODY:
I was in Ahmadabad, India, when I was 17, listening to a railway clerk explain that I could stay there forever for all he cared. So I squeezed a dollar bill into the filthy bundle of rupees I was toying with. Without missing a beat, the clerk heaved open a ledger and began combing it for late cancellations.
Returning from China, Marco Polo had to produce a hoard of gems before his relatives recognized him. But since the Bretton Woods conference of 1944, travelers like me could get that same instant recognition with U.S. dollars. They have achieved unparalleled consumer awareness all around the world; with more greenbacks in circulation than even gospels, they may be the most popular man-made product of all time. 
 Yet now, following in the benighted footsteps of that other global product, Coke, the United States has started monkeying with its successful formula. Over the last four years, the Treasury has rolled out new versions of the $100, the $50 and the $20 bills. And on May 4, in a ceremony beamed live across the internet, Hillary Rodham Clinton unveiled the plans for a new dollar coin. It is meant to be handy for vending machines and what the Mint politely calls "gratuities," and it shows the Shoshone Sacajawea carrying her papoose as she guides Lewis and Clark's 1804 expedition out into Indian territory.
Most of us felt that the new bills looked weird, but we were told the change was necessary to foil counterfeiters. And perhaps it was. But this latest design change, however tasteful and charming at first glance, risks undermining America's compact with the world to define what money ought to be.
For centuries, there has been nothing so properly American as paper money. Colonial Massachusetts invented the stuff in 1690, and it was the paper dollar that made the new country. It was uniquely suited to finance American opportunity: easy money, with which anyone might realize his ambitions -- the very opposite of the gold-backed and class-bound economies of the Old World. "Do you think that I will load my constituents with taxes," asked a representative at the first Continental Congress in 1775, "when we can send to our printer and get a wagon-load of money?"
Which they did. Five years later it was being sewn together into paper suits, but it had paid for the war, and later paper money rolled out the frontier. Local banks started printing their own versions (13,000 different ones -- a third of them counterfeit -- were in circulation by the start of the Civil War); the Union Government effectively consolidated production by issuing greenbacks, the patriarch of the bills in your wallet.
The new bills didn't just facilitate America's ambitions; they seemed to embody them. Compared with the other currencies of the world, which shift and shrink and update themselves perpetually, piling color upon color and one bloodless symbol upon another, the dollar is staggeringly august and changeless -- basically unaltered since 1928, shortly before Wall Street proved that America's health was the world's concern.
Foreign money gets bigger and brassier as it climbs the scale -- it bows to a hierarchy of wealth -- but American democracy is nobly expressed in the identical size of all its bills. The pauper's roll is as impressive as the millionaire's, and the hundred, or the ten, at a glance, is indistinguishable from the one. I feel bad for the Ahmadabad clerk, but there it is: the price of democracy is eternal vigilance.
And so, the 20th century's wars and booms were financed with symbols of the simple morals of the Republic: faith in democracy, belief in God and the perfectibility of man. Novus Ordo Seclorum, it says, A New Order of the Ages. And as the global economy becomes increasingly unstable, the dollar, more than ever before, has emerged as the currency of last resort. Indeed, when Washington announced plans to redesign the $100 bill, the news nearly toppled Russia's underground economy; this month, Argentina floated the possibility of abandoning its own currency in favor of America's.
Yet just at this moment when Asia and Russia and Latin America teeter, when gold has sunk and even Coca- Cola has stumbled, America -- alone among all the nations of the world -- is making a symbolic retrest from the paper dollar that built it and that now represents it.
Compared to all that (and in light of the Susan B. Anthony dollar's utter failure) what does the Sacajawea dollar have to offer? Despite its golden color, it's not likely to cut any ice on an Indian railway station or in a Moscow taxicab. Even its imagery, meant to be nice to Native Americans and women, is fraught with tension. Sacajawea's persevering loyalty to Lewis and Clark helped facilitate American expansion but thereby doomed her own people. The other side of her coin bears a bald eagle swooping through the sky, as dictated by monetary law -- a bit queasily, in this case.
For all Sacajawea's charm, her gentle gaze is wildly misplaced, signaling a relationship with the currency that is essentially false. After all, she's going to fetch up in some pretty unsavory places. As a father, I'd want to keep an eye on that papoose; as an earner and a spender, I'd worry about Sacajawea's anxious backward glance. (In 1787, one-cent coins bore the motto "Fugio"; we know it to be true, but do we really want our money nodding us goodbye?) What's so gentle about this, I'll be tempted to ask Sacajawea, when I feed her and her baby into the cold slot on the parking meter or exchange her for a paper full of Balkan horrors? For my part, I still prefer my money stern and grim -- more a primer in republican values than a token of America's sentimental dialogue with its past.

Enjoying the dual advantage of having once been an actual living person and having recently been featured in two major books about Lewis and Clark, Sacagewea prevailed.
 
* The unsuccessful Susan B. Anthony coin, the Treasury's last attempt at a dollar coin, was last minted in 1980. It cost about four cents to produce. The Sacagewea coins will cost approximately twice that.
 
* Opinion polls indicate that at least 70 percent of Americans prefer paper dollars to metal.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99: Questions for Joan Chen;
The Revolution of Little Girls

BYLINE: By Melanie Rehak 

 BODY:
Q: Your new film, "Xiu Xiu: The Sent Down Girl," focuses on the plight of children during the Chinese Cultural Revolution in China. What was life like for you during those years?
The Cultural Revolution started in 1966, when I was 5, and from 1967 to 1977, more than 10 million children were "sent down" to remote areas like Tibet and Mongolia to help build socialism. Later on, we all learned that it was to relieve the city of unemployment, and stories came back about how horrible it was. It involved everybody's child -- everyone. So it was better if you volunteered. Otherwise they dragged you out. 
 How did you avoid that fate?
In my first year of high school, I was picked to go to the film studio, which was very, very rare. Mao's wife planned to do three movies about the Long March, and she had to personally approve all the cast. I was proud to be doing propaganda, to be of use to the Communist cause.
Movie star - that's a very unusual exemption. Was the kind of celebrity that you eventually achieved difficult for a believer in the group cause?
I was very young and pure, and I didn't enjoy fame. I would be on a street in any city, and there would be thousands of people falling down hurting themselves, crowding me, their bicycles all trampled, and I wouldn't be able to get out. That scared me. Really, I wanted to be a parachuter.
A parachuter? Why did that appeal to you?
The uniforms looked so handsome, and the female uniform actually had a waistline. Ordinarily we weren't allowed to have a waistline. In school, our outfits didn't show our shapes. When you have no physical appearance of being a woman, you seem to have less vulnerability. And we were taught that we shouldn't behave any differently than the boys.
But clearly, you also learned how to act in a way that's not boyish at all.
I had to learn a whole new set of things after I came to America and got parts in "Tai-Pai" and "The Last Emperor." I knew there was one version of Chineseness that America wanted from me: exotic, slant-eyed, long-haired, sexy, vulnerable China doll. I was eager to adapt and conform. I regret that.
Your screen-siren femininity got you places, though. Was it a greater source of strength than the androgyny you were taught back in China?
I've learned that I could combine these two things. When I was directing this movie, I had to command a crew of 60 that consisted mostly of men. So I tried to see what was most effective: should I be straightforward or should I be coy? Sometimes batting your lashes works. I had to recognize feminine power; now it's good because I have both faces.
What about the other, more ideological aspects of your Chinese upbringing? What lessons have they given you for your current life in America?
It instilled in me an appetite for something intangible, spiritual and grander outside of the practical pursuit of self-interest. That's what drives me to make films. I'm actually extremely comfortable materially. I feel very rich; I don't need any more. It's the other side of me that's hungry. From getting an idea to completing this film to talking with you was obstacle after obstacle after obstacle. I think without that drive, that spiritual need to tell a meaningful story, I would not have been able to do it.
Do you think that whatever keeps you from losing yourself to materialism will also keep China from losing itself in American capitalism?
It seems to spread so easily in China. They're quite brand-oriented, more so than America. The younger generation saves up for a month to buy Chanel lipsticks and cosmetics. I'm grateful that my Communist upbringing has taught me how to enjoy myself in a less materialistic way. But the new generation seems to embrace materialism quite easily.
But for all your patriotism, you were denied a permit to film in China. You ended up filming it illegally. Did you know it would be that hard?
I didn't think that far. I just wanted to pay tribute to a land and a culture that I came from. But my fame hurt me, in a way. If I was caught, I'd be punished a little more strictly -- just to show, because I'm a known figure.
Are such painful homecomings a familiar part of your cross-cultural life?
There are times when I feel like a bastard everywhere I go. Every time there's tension between China and the U.S. I get scared that I won't be trusted by either. But most times I feel fortunate that I could be in both places and learn both cultures. I do miss the real texture of China, but it's good to have something to miss. Melanie Rehak

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99: Economics Of: Unemployment;
Labor Pains

BYLINE: By Paul Krugman; Paul Krugman is an economics professor at M.I.T. and the author, most recently, of "The Return of Depression Economics."

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan doesn't think you should get a raise. And he doesn't want you to feel too secure in your job, because otherwise you might demand that raise.
I'm not putting words in his mouth. A few weeks ago, addressing an audience of bankers, the usually Delphic chairman of the Federal Reserve Board was uncharacteristically clear, warning that the United States economy is "steadily depleting the pool of available workers" -- that is, giving jobs to the previously unemployed. As a result, "labor market conditions can become so tight that the rise in nominal wages will start increasingly outpacing the gains in labor productivity" -- that is, workers who know that jobs are plentiful will get big raises. And that, Greenspan implied, would be a very bad thing. He didn't say what he would do about it, but markets got the hint: bond prices immediately plunged, on fears that the Fed would soon raise interest rates. 
 Now to a man from Mars -- or for that matter to a normal human being -- Greenspan's concerns might sound very peculiar. After all, what's wrong with giving jobs to the jobless and higher wages to the employed? But Greenspan is probably right to be worried. What is less clear is whether it was a good idea for him to be so explicit.
Think of it this way. Once upon a time (say, back in the mid-70's, when Gerald Ford was President and Alan Greenspan was his chief economist), the U.S. economy was like a trendy restaurant -- one of those places where the tables are set close together and the ceiling seems custom-designed to maximize the din. What happens in that kind of environment is that everyone tries to talk above the background noise so as to be heard by his or her companions. But by talking louder, you yourself raise the noise level, forcing everyone else to talk louder, raising the noise level still further, and eventually everyone is shouting themselves hoarse. Substitute wage and price increases for speaking volume and inflation for the overall noise level, and you have a capsule analysis of the kind of inflationary spiral that the U.S. faced in the 1970's. And the only way that the noise level (inflation) could be kept under control was to keep a substantial number of tables vacant -- that is, by maintaining a large reserve army of unemployed.
Today, of course, the situation is vastly improved. The economy is flourishing, with unemployment at a 25-year low. (The restaurant is full again.) Yet so far inflation is quiescent. (The noise level is tolerable.) This is partly because exceptional productivity gains have made it possible for companies to pay higher wages without raising prices. (A sound-absorbing ceiling?) But it is also because, for reasons that nobody fully understands, workers have been remarkably diffident about demanding higher wages, even in the face of labor shortages. (Diners have mysteriously become more polite?) Everyone is happy. But will the very exuberance of the diners bring the bad old days back?
That's what Greenspan is worried about. What he said to the bankers was, in effect, that no matter how good the acoustics, no matter how well behaved the customers, if the restaurant gets sufficiently crowded there will be a shouting match. And if that happens -- well, he'll just have to limit the number of patrons. It's not that he is mean-spirited or a tool of capitalist oppression; he's just doing his job. But you still have to wonder whether it was a good idea to describe that job so explicitly and so honestly.
For there is, when you come down to it, always something slightly unsavory about the business of central banking. A market economy -- even the Goldilocks economy of America in the 90's -- requires that a certain number of people who want to work be unable to find jobs so that their example will discipline the wage demands of those who are already employed. Even liberal economists like myself grudgingly accept the conclusion that a responsible Fed must sometimes raise interest rates in order to limit the number of jobs and maintain a suitably high rate of unemployment. But the scene remains an ugly one: when the Fed acts to cool off an overheated economy, what that literally means is that a group of comfortable men and women in suits are deliberately acting to limit the job prospects of some of their worst-off fellow citizens.
How is one supposed to explain that scene to the general public? Many of Greenspan's counterparts deal with the ugliness by denying that it exists -- by denying that they have any influence over employment at all. Greenspan, to his credit, tells the truth about what he does, but until now, he has done it in a way that only the cognoscenti can understand. Well, now he has said it clearly. But is America ready to hear it?

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Two Plays Illuminate Each Other and Their Author

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
THE British playwright David Hare, now at the Booth Theater in "Via Dolorosa," his own one-man play about the Arab-Israeli stalemate, reports with some amused chagrin Dame Judi Dench's response to his performance, which marks his debut as a professional actor. A few blocks away, Dame Judi, a longtime pro and a legitimate Dame, is starring in Mr. Hare's "Amy's View" at the Ethel Barrymore. Though both productions were hits in London earlier, Dame Judi apparently hadn't had a chance to catch "Via Dolorosa" until she came to New York.
"She's been saying to me for some time now," Mr. Hare told James Barron of The New York Times, "that I must write a play in which we can act" together. Though after seeing "Via Dolorosa," he said, she seemed to have cooled on the idea. 
 "Mmm," Mr. Hare quoted her as having said, "I don't think I want to be in a play with you. You don't act. There's not a single choice you make in the course of an evening that any professional actor would make. It's moving, but I don't feel that what I do and what you do have any professional kinship."
This sounds very much like good-natured ribbing from an admiring star who may have received a certain amount of constructive criticism from the playwright during rehearsals, possibly through Richard Eyre, the director.
Yet it also calls attention to Mr. Hare's approach to theater and, indeed, to the vast differences between "Via Dolorosa" and to virtually every other Hare play American audiences have had the opportunity to see. That would recently include not only "Amy's View," but also "The Judas Kiss," a consideration of the fate of Oscar Wilde, which opened in New York just a year ago, and, to a somewhat lesser extent, "The Blue Room." This is the playwright's chilly, sardonic variation on "La Ronde," the Schnitzler classic, in which a discreetly nude Nicole Kidman helped to sell out a limited Broadway engagement earlier this season.
Seldom has the latest work of an established playwright been available in such quantity on Broadway within such a short period of time. For many of us, it has been a learning experience of the sort that only repertory theaters can offer. It is as if Mr. Hare had decided to supplement three more or less conventional plays ("Amy's View," "The Blue Room" and "The Judas Kiss") with a fascinating, extended career footnote ("Via Dolorosa"). For the first time, he allows us free entry into the mind -- the playwright's hidden storage vault -- where he keeps the raw material that later goes into his plays.
In fact, of course, "Via Dolorosa" is no footnote. It is a major work in its own right: not fiction but reportage, being Mr. Hare's first-person account of his three fact-finding trips to Israel and the West Bank when he was pondering the writing of a play to illustrate the problems there. Somewhere along the way, however, he decided that what he calls "theater of fiction" would not be adequate to the task.
Instead, he wrote a 90-minute monologue in which he, as himself, an uncommitted, skeptical outsider, a native of a land where passion has become theoretical, reports on the religious, ethnic, social and economic contradictions that have led to this most passionate of stalemates.
Dame Judi is right. Mr. Hare doesn't portray himself with the skill and nuances that a pro might bring to the role, which is all to the good. There is nothing seductive about his performance that might distance the audience from the full import of what he is saying. Yet he brings to intense, dramatic life the dozens of remarkable characters he meets en route, all the while keeping up a running commentary of his own thoughts, which issue from a mind infinitely curious and committed only to common sense and justice. Such are the luxuries, he acknowledges, available to the outsider passing through.
Now, New Yorkers have the luxury of seeing "Amy's View" and "Via Dolorosa" back to back in such a way that each serves to illuminate the other. You have to make your plans quickly, though: "Via Dolorosa," which is directed by Stephen Daldry, closes on June 13.
In "Amy's View," Mr. Hare has created fictional characters into which, like a ventriloquist, he throws his disguised voice to make points that are often dramatic but not always consistent with the characters who express them. On the other hand, there is never any doubt in "Via Dolorosa" about the validity of the characters or about the playwright's reactions to them. Writing in the first person, he is a superb reporter with a gift for locating the vivid detail.
"Amy's View" is an updated version of the kind of star vehicle I associate with the pre-World War II American theater. That was when actresses on the order of Katherine Cornell, Tallulah Bankhead and Ina Claire wouldn't be caught dead onstage at the curtain's rise, but would make great, sweeping dramatic entrances intended to provoke adoring applause.
Dame Judi's entrance in "Amy's View" is not quite so self-conscious, but the buildup for it is perfectly timed and the response to it warm. The performance that follows is big, showy and, I suspect, infinitely satisfying to American audiences. They are ready to salute the star who played Queen Victoria in "Mrs. Brown" (for which she should have received the Oscar last year) and this year's Oscar-winning best-supporting actress for "Shakespeare in Love," in which she plays Queen Elizabeth I.
Dame Judi doesn't disappoint. Mr. Hare has written a rich role for her in "Amy's View": Esme Allen, a great, dedicated star of the London theater whose daughter, Amy, falls fatally in love with a young man named Dominic who represents everything crass in contemporary culture. In the 16 years covered by the play, Dominic, a part-time correspondent for tabloid journals, hustles his way first to celebrity as a television arts critic and then to financial and critical success as a director of movies that are described as if they might be Quentin Tarantino spinoffs.
"Amy's View" is actually about more things than can easily be absorbed in one viewing, though it reads more coherently than it plays. Among other things, it's about Esme's abiding faith in the theater as opposed to Dominic's commitment to getting ahead in the more popular arts. Theater is mind and conscience. Movies and television are pure sensation.
At the same time, Mr. Hare explores Esme's horror that Amy should marry Dominic in full acceptance of the fact that he can never love her to the degree that she loves him, which is a brief replay of the theme spelled out at somewhat greater length in "The Judas Kiss." Rapacious capitalism, as exemplified by Lloyd's of London, also figures prominently in a plot that seems to wander from one would-be big emotional scene to another until the end. At that point, magically, Mr. Hare delivers a coda that helps to make all that has gone before seem worthwhile.
Dame Judi is splendid and great fun to watch as an actress who is most actressy and out of touch in real life, whether dealing with those she loves or even with a bankruptcy that might send a more ordinary woman into a permanent nervous breakdown. Only at the end of "Amy's View," when she is about to go onstage in a hit play that has arrived late in her career, is the essence of the woman revealed. The scene is a stunner and is, I suspect, the reason that people come away from "Amy's View" with such fond feelings.
Except for Esme, none of the characters in the play has the startling authenticity of those recalled by Mr. Hare, acting David Hare, in "Via Dolorosa." Like so many characters in earlier Hare plays, those in "Amy's View" tend to sound like mouthpieces. Yet "Via Dolorosa" is so good that it invites us to attend to all his other work with greater care. It reveals the playwright to be a man of piercing wit, understanding and intelligence. "Amy's View" has the manner of a play that has been laboriously built and furnished, not out of creative urgency but out of a need to provide temporary shelter for the author's colleagues and himself.
It will be interesting to see if the critical success of "Via Dolorosa" has any effect on the direction Mr. Hare's work takes in the future. Most encouraging is the fact that he is still taking chances, still in the process of growing, still exploring new ways of expression. He is alive and well and restless.
 
'The Lonesome West'
I hope New York audiences don't fail "The Lonesome West," now at the Lyceum Theater. If anything, this third play in Martin McDonagh's Irish trilogy set in Leenane is more satisfying and less tricky than the initial installment, "The Beauty Queen of Leenane," which closed not long ago, having won Tonys for three of its actors and its director last season.
That Mr. McDonagh is still a young playwright (he is 29) is apparent in "The Lonesome West," which replays the manners and, to a certain extent, even the central situation of "Beauty Queen." However, the denouement of "The Lonesome West" does not depend on something as lame as an undelivered letter.
The setting is another dreary Godforsaken farmhouse in County Galway in the west of Ireland, inhabited this time by two aging bachelors, Coleman Connor (Maeliosa Stafford), a brutish lout, and his brother, Valene (Brian F. O'Byrne), a fussy fellow who collects plaster figurines of saints as his passport to heaven. The two deeply loathe each other but, at the start of the play, they have become forever locked together.
They have just buried their not so dear old dad, who died suddenly when Coleman, in a rage, shot him at point-blank range. In return for Valene's testimony that it was simply an unfortunate household accident, Coleman has deeded his brother his share of their father's money and is now dependent on the stingy Valene not only for his freedom, but also for food, drink and the clothes on his back.
Surveying all, aware of everything, but himself unable to cope with a parish where murder and other antisocial activities are endemic, is Father Welsh (David Ganly). He is a young man who, in a more shapely play, might have been its central figure. Welsh is not a comic character. He is a sweet-natured fellow who has gone into the church as a last resort. It's there, and it provides a living in a land not bursting with opportunity.
Father Welsh hangs around Coleman and Valene because they are free with their booze, and because he genuinely likes them. As the rest of the parish goes about its dark business, the priest drinks with Coleman and Valene and tries to save them from their mutual hatred. The only thing that frightens the priest more than the Leenane bloodshed is the adoring, openly available presence of Girleen Kelleher (Dawn Bradfield). She is a pretty young thing who, knowing Welsh's squeamishness about sex, can't resist talking dirty to him.
Though most of "The Lonesome West" is devoted to the furious sparring of Coleman and Valene, it is the ineffectual, alcoholic Father Welsh, a nascent independent thinker, who dominates the play. His gradual awakening to the hell he inhabits is the backbone of "The Lonesome West," providing a subtext for a work that otherwise would be merely the Irish equivalent to the kind of hillbilly cartoons Esquire used to run.
Garry Hynes, who staged "Beauty Queen," is also the director of "The Lonesome West," which is beautifully acted by Mr. Stafford, Mr. O'Byrne, Ms. Bradfield and, particularly, Mr. Ganly. Still to come: the second play in the Leenane Trilogy, "A Skull in Connemara."
In one way and another, Mr. McDonagh is out to destroy the old Hollywood vision that rural Ireland is a land of jolly, avuncular Barry Fitzgeralds. Mr. McDonagh's message: let your daughters run free, but lock up your firearms and all instruments blunt and sharp.
 
AMY'S VIEW (and VIA DOLOROSA)
Dame Judi Dench doesn't disappoint in a rich role, but David Hare's star vehicle creaks and does, unlike his own excellent solo show.
 
THE LONESOME WEST
A beautifully acted and satisfying return to the blackly comic Leenane Trilogy.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
A Multiplex of a Museum Turns On the Lights

BYLINE: By ANN WILSON LLOYD; Ann Wilson Lloyd's most recent article for Arts and Leisure was on the artist Teresita Fernandez.

DATELINE: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.

 BODY:
THE Visavox was a proto-television device developed here in the 1920's by the electronics wizard Frank Sprague, founder of the Sprague Electric Company. The appliance was more accurately a personal cinema, synchronizing sound and image for the first time, but awkwardly requiring you to stick your head up inside a box. Among Sprague's more successful products before the plant closed in 1986 were capacitors that enable radio, television and other appliances to spring to life at the flip of a switch.
This electronic trivia is relevant for the way it meshes with a new installation to be introduced here next Sunday by the video artist Tony Oursler. Titled "Optics" and aimed at investigating the origins of sound and light media, Mr. Oursler's new work was commissioned by the Williams College Museum of Art in nearby Williamstown and the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, called colloquially Mass MOCA, which is what the sprawling, former Sprague plant has become. 
 Mr. Oursler's work will have its premiere as part of Mass MOCA's long awaited opening, also next Sunday. After more than a decade of honing a workable formula, the institution -- five huge, 19th-century mill buildings out of 27 available at the site -- will become the Northeast's newest, and the nation's largest, contemporary museum and high-tech performance center. It will have a black-box theater that seats 650, an outdoor cinema and courtyards filled with artists' installations and sound works. Joseph Thompson, Mass MOCA's director, calls the place a cultural laboratory. His ambitious, multifaceted concept would probably do Frank Sprague proud.
It was serendipitous timing that Mr. Oursler was chosen to help inaugurate Mass MOCA, said Deborah Rothschild, the curator of the Williams College Museum, where Mr. Oursler's midcareer traveling survey is on view though Oct. 24. "We were looking for a way to collaborate with Mass MOCA and also for a way to allow Tony to make new work," Ms. Rothschild said. "His work is appealing on many levels; it's lively and actively involves the audience. We thought it would fit Mass MOCA's combined purposes well."
Mr. Oursler calls "Optics" his audiovisual treatise on a spectrum of phenomena -- mythology, the origins of science, early distrust of theatrical entertainments and the mysteries of sound and light. "All these came together for me in this installation," he said. "I wanted to create a loose chain of optics, mimicking, for instance, how TV takes light and turns it into electricity, and then into a coded signal, which is then represented to the viewer who decodes it again culturally."
Though not finished as of this writing, Mr. Oursler's new work promises to be a departure from what his audience knows best: projections of hectoring, neurotic characters onto puppets and rag dolls; whining, talking heads and disembodied blinking eyeballs that simulate a psycho ward of sadly funny misfits. About two dozen of these characteristic pieces are on view at the Williams College Museum exhibition, where some of his earliest television installations have also been reconstructed, revealing, in their haphazard quirkiness, the roots of Mr. Oursler's obsessions.
If Mr. Oursler has pulled back from television specifically, and from examining our complicities with the electronic personas that demonically invade our lives, his refocus on proto-media has flushed devils out of the historical details. Part of his installation at Mass MOCA will feature small glass Lucifers lurking around various lighting devices and drawing attention to the odd behavior of light. One little devil appears to be crawling into a utility lamp, mischievously leading one's eye into the glare. Viewed indirectly, the light seems to pop out the tip of his tail.
Devils cropped up everywhere when Mr. Oursler researched early sound and light experiments, he said. Part of his installation will include a homemade camera obscura with a hand-ground lens. Through it, people are rendered as small, fuzzy, moving figures that, apart from being upside down, are akin to early television figures. The history of the camera obscura, traceable to the 13th century, depicts engravings of cavorting devils in the imagery, Mr. Oursler said: "Somehow they connected devils with the lens transparency. To me, that connects to Lucifer as light, and the battle we've had with media that goes on to this day."
Inspired by early films in which moral dilemmas are often portrayed by devils wrestling angels, he is shooting a video of two costumed friends battling it out amid puffs of smoke and other primitive theatrics. Other segments of Mr. Oursler's installation will include a new video projection in which a camera interacts with aberrant light that causes auras or coronas around figures, effects that filmmakers try to eliminate. Mr. Oursler plans to remove the figures and keep the mystical-looking flares. A digitally animated video of morphing imagery, to be projected on arranged objects, is also under development. "It will be a frieze based on a kind of meta-history of technology, almost a W.P.A. mural based on sensory research," he said.
The video was made in collaboration with the digital-animation firm Kleiser-Walczak Construction Company, one of Mass MOCA's newly installed commercial tenants, and another reason the Williams College Museum wanted Mr. Oursler to be able to develop new work at Mass MOCA. Kleiser-Walczak, formerly based in California, produced the special effects for the 3-D opera "Monsters of Grace," by Philip Glass and Robert Wilson, which will be presented at Mass MOCA on July 17. (The full summer programming is available on the Internet at www.massmoca.org.)
Down the vast hallways from Mr. Oursler's new piece are newly installed monumental works, few of them ever likely to fit into conventional museums. Robert Rauschenberg's marathon painting, "1/4 Mile or 2 Furlong Piece" (1984-1999), lent by the artist, has its own gallery the length of a football field. Large, rarely seen works by John Chamberlain, Joseph Beuys, Bruce Nauman, James Rosenquist, Mario Merz, Dan Flavin and Carl Andre, are also on loan for various tenures from several institutions.
These galleries represent what remains of Mass MOCA's original plan to be a home for oversize contemporary art that Thomas Krens envisioned here back in 1985. Mr. Krens, who became director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, headed the Williams College Museum of Art at the time. As Mass MOCA's mission evolved over the years, the Guggenheim's role gradually diminished. It is now simply one of several lenders of large artworks, said Mr. Thompson, who is also an alumnus of the Williams College Museum.
These rooms, large enough to swallow up art leviathans, are themselves a grand spectacle finessed back from near ruin by the architectural firm Bruner/Cott & Associates of Cambridge, Mass. Practicing minimal intervention, their efforts, in one vast gallery, include a center row of old wooden support posts chopped into stubs left hanging from the ceiling like a spine. These are spanned by interlacing steel cables creating a graceful trussed ceiling. Throughout, a century-old patina of paint and fugitive markings denote former rooms, floor levels, doors and windows that bear elegant witness to the past. If romance can be mined from America's industrial age, the mother lode is here.
Around 100,000 square feet of space will eventually be leased to compatible commercial tenants, like Kleiser-Walczak, generating up to $1.2 million a year, Mr. Thompson said, to offset operating costs. Revenues from the performances will help, though the cultural economy here is seasonal, and Mass MOCA's avant-garde programming unproven as a draw.
Additional visual art that Mr. Thompson has commissioned for Mass MOCA is, like Mr. Oursler's, in keeping with the museum's revised mission as a place for experimental new media and cross-disciplinary investigations. "Ghost Catching," a video installation of images of the dancer Bill T. Jones digitally multiplied into an ensemble is a prime example. Others are off site and temporary, like billboards by Sue Coe, Gary Simmons and Leon Golub, placed along nearby highways; some will become part of Mass MOCA's somewhat ephemeral collection.
These include two sound pieces from previous exhibitions that already exist and a new work, "Music for a Quarry," by Walter Fahndrich, in an abandoned marble works outside town. Others are "The Visitations," an installation by Ron Kuivila in an unrenovated building that was left with dropped tools and rusting equipment still in place, and "Tree Logic," a large outdoor piece by Natalie Jeremijenko sure to make arborists cringe. Six trees have been strung up in high rigging, roots skyward in containers, where they are expected to pit gravity against phototropic forces.
Back up in Mr. Oursler's galleries, he tells the tale of the so-called "lightning room" during Sprague's occupation of the site. It was where electronic components were jolted by thunderbolts to see how they stood up. Residents of North Adams recall seeing flashes through the lightning room's glass-block wall as they drove past, invoking a mad-scientist scenario that the artist relishes. "This was a room I couldn't refuse," Mr. Oursler says.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 992 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The Andrew Freedman Home;
A Retirement Home Built for the Formerly Wealthy

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
IT is the Grand Concourse's grandest building, a broad limestone palazzo set back behind a wide grassy lawn between 166th and McClellan Streets in the Bronx. But the building, paid for by the somewhat mysterious Andrew Freedman, is not a mansion or a museum. It is a home for the elderly, and it has an unusual history. The 1924 building, the Andrew Freedman Home, operated by the Mid-Bronx Senior Citizens Council, has its own signs of age, and of rejuvenation.
 By the turn of the century Andrew Freedman was a millionaire, but it wasn't clear just how he became one. He had been involved in real estate and subway financing, owned the New York Giants baseball team and was a close associate of the Tammany Hall boss Richard Croker. But Freedman's entry in the authoritative Dictionary of American Biography ventures only that "by ways that are no longer traceable he achieved a conspicuous success." 
 Freedman died in 1915 in his private apartment at Sherry's, a restaurant-hotel at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, unmarried and without children. His will left the bulk of his $7 million estate to establish a retirement home not for the poor, but for those who had been wealthy but had suffered reverses. His sister, Isabella, explained to The New York Times that Freedman believed that "worthy habits and traditions of affluence and refinement deserve recognition and respect."
His will was drawn up in 1907, and some accounts say that the financial panic of that year damaged Freedman's finances and made him contemplate how easily he could have been reduced to poverty.
The trustees of what became known as the Andrew Freedman Home retained the architects Joseph H. Freedlander and Harry Allan Jacobs to design a broad four-story-plus-basement structure set on an elevated platform. The main floor contained a card room, library, parlor, dining room and related rooms, the interior designed by L. Alavoine & Company, a French decorating concern. The entertaining rooms were as grand as many private clubs of the period, and the guest rooms upstairs compared favorably with the scale and finishes of Park Avenue apartment houses of the time.
Finished in 1924, the Andrew Freedman Home accepted only 14 of the first 84 applications. Two wings were added in 1931, designed in matching style by the architect David Levy.
In a 1933 article in The New Yorker, Geoffrey Hellman noted that servants made the beds of the residents, dusted the furniture and cooked the meals. He noted that the residents included a stockbroker who had made $160,000 a year, but that most were doctors, lawyers and ministers who enjoyed "sofas that couldn't be more overstuffed if they were in the Union League Club."
"Ceilings are high," Hellman wrote, "carpets deep, and it seems incongruous to look out the windows and see, across the lawn, the nondescript traffic of the Grand Concourse. Somehow you expect to see limousines." There were 50 employees for the 129 residents, paid for out of the Freedman Home's endowment income of $150,000 a year.
In the 1960's operating costs exceeded income, and by the 1970's the Home started charging for its accommodations. In 1974 the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the building over the trustees' objections, but the designation was overturned by the Board of Estimate.
IN 1984 the Mid-Bronx Senior Citizens Council purchased the building, and now it offers the elderly -- whether or not they were formerly wealthy -- lodging on the second floor and the use of the main rooms on the main floor. The council also agreed to landmark designation in 1992. The third and fourth floors are unoccupied, but the council has renovated the basement -- which is open at the rear because of the slope of the site -- with a commercial mortgage and $600,000 in state grants.
Now it rents the basement to a Head Start program and a family preservation program, using the combined rent to pay the mortgage interest. "There is nothing left over," said Zenon Arribalzaga, deputy director of the council.
The council has also worked with Thomas Navin, an architect and garden designer, to redo the entire front lawn and the planting beds, with a $188,000 Urban Resources Partnership grant.
Mr. Navin relocated plantings away from the base of the steps -- where they were distant from the sidewalk and could not be seen from inside the home -- out to the property line. "I was thinking of the winter, when people who couldn't come out could look out the window," he said.
He also cleared out later growth from the center of the front lawn -- where it blocked the view of the building -- and established curved walkways and seating areas. The Head Start children come up to the garden to learn about the different plants over the course of the year.
MR. NAVIN'S work is implemented by Mark Hill, a horticulturalist hired by the council with the grant. Mr. Hill maintains the garden and invites the public to visit. The gate is open during daylight hours and Mr. Hill offers tours to anyone who calls the home at (718) 293-8100.
Part of the council's goal was to have year-round planting. The colors of the irises and lilac now in bloom will be succeeded by hydrangeas, lilies and liriope in the summer, mums and peonies in the fall and witch hazel, yellow twig dogwood and cherry in the winter.
The garden is flourishing, but the terrace masonry is cracking, the wooden windows are rotting and the upper sections of the building show signs of water penetration. Mr. Arribalzaga said that returning the Andrew Freedman Home to good repair is an uphill battle.
The Mid-Bronx Senior Citizens Council would like to open up the top two floors for additional community programs, but doing so would require a new elevator -- at a cost of at least $100,000, Mr. Arribalzaga said, plus the costs associated with refitting the floors. The Andrew Freedman Home grows older and older, with no retirement in sight.

LENGTH: 1510 words

HEADLINE: Making the Best of a Congested Bridge

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
IF the thought of being in Friday afternoon or Sunday evening summer traffic heading across the Tappan Zee Bridge makes you shudder, here is some advice from the experts:
*Get an E-Z Pass. 
 *Get a good pair of sunglasses.
*Get an E-Z Pass.
*Avoid traveling in prime time.
*Consider alternative Hudson River crossings.
*Get an E-Z Pass.
The Tappan Zee Bridge, opened in 1955, draws about 47 million vehicles each year, with average daily traffic of 130,000. On holidays and summer weekends, expect more, much more.
On Friday afternoons in the summer, said Nancy K. Finger of Elmsford, who lives near Interstate 287, an approach to the bridge, "Get yourself a good book if you're trying to go across the bridge."
Officially the Gov. Malcolm Wilson Tappan Zee Bridge -- almost no one calls it that -- the 3.03-mile-long span, seven lanes wide, is the only bridge that crosses the Hudson River between Westchester County, where it connects with the Cross Westchester Expressway (I-287), and Rockland County.
High volume on the Cross Westchester, the only east-west highway that traverses the county, has a strong impact on bridge traffic. The expressway splits the eastbound and westbound sides of Westchester Avenue, called the Platinum Mile because of its many large corporations. Even when employees do not cross the bridge -- for example, they might be going to or from White Plains or one of the county's other parkways that link with the expressway -- they collectively clog the roads that lead to the bridge.
Add an accident or bad weather and traffic can be at a turtle's pace on the road's six lanes (three in each direction).
An added contributor to bridge congestion this year is the new Palisades Mall in Nyack in Rockland County, attracting customers to stores not present in Westchester.
Laurie A. Smith of Elmsford regularly goes to the Jersey Shore in the summer. "It's a question of do we want to creep across the Tappan Zee or chance the G.W.," she said, referring to the George Washington Bridge. "I usually will take the Tappan Zee and literally crawl across it, or try to leave before noon on Friday."
She added: "You plan your whole return trip around what time you think you will be going across the bridge. On Sundays we try to come back by 11 A.M., or even come back Saturday nights."
Roberta A. Klumpp of Greenburgh said that as a "reverse commuter" who heads toward Rockland when the mass of traffic is Westchester-bound, she has encountered few major delays on the bridge getting to her teaching job in Nanuet. "But when I look in the other direction and see the backup, I say, 'Thank God, I'm not going that way,' " she said.
Last year, on Thursday, July 2, the start of the Fourth of July holiday, 79,000 vehicles crossed the bridge in each direction (for a total of almost 160,000). On Labor Day weekend last year, between noon and 3 P.M., 16,499 crossed the bridge northbound, compared with 14,104 during a similar time on Friday, April 17, a nonholiday weekend.
Even on nonholiday summer weekends traffic can build up, particularly southbound (toward Westchester), where the toll is collected; 82,563 crossed the bridge from Rockland last July 24, a Friday; 77,316 on the following Sunday.
"The traffic gets quite bad on summer weekends, particularly Friday evenings and Sunday evenings," said Mark Kulewicz, the director of traffic engineering and safety for the Automobile Club of New York. "That's from the crush of people who are headed on vacations or holiday weekends."
But, he observed, what is bad news for summer vacationers can be good news for regular commuters. "The regular traffic congestion for commuters in the morning and evenings tends to lighten up a bit," he said.
Jim Volpe, owner of the Wedge Service Station in Tarrytown, on Route 119 near the bridge, agreed. "The morning and evening commutes Monday through Thursday are easier in the summer," he said. "There is no waiting."
Mr. Volpe, who for four years until recently commuted to his station from Rockland, added: "Unless there is an accident. Then my service station gets swamped because a lot of people coming from Rockland get off the expressway, to take a short cut near my station and stop for soda or gas."
Officials of the State Thruway Authority, which owns and operates the bridge, say that a continuing $28 million project to rehabilitate the bridge should not have much impact on bridge users because lane restrictions will occur during off-peak hours only and closings will not be permitted during commuter or holiday travel times. Most of the work, to resurface the bridge, will take place at night and require lane closings in the evening.
A number of people interviewed said that there was actually less congestion on the Tappan Zee Bridge these days than there was a few years ago because of the growing use of E-Z Pass and the reversible lane median barriers. Also helpful are additional toll stations. There are 13 toll stations, 6 of them tandem, meaning they can serve two vehicles at a time. Three tandems were added in the late 80's and the other three in the early 90's.
"Our delays have been less; they never reach the other side of the bridge" except when there is an accident, said Mary Ann Meola, a former toll taker who is now the toll division manager for the Thruway Authority. "I would say our maximum delay is 30 minutes to get across the bridge, and that's very unusual. We're able to push vehicles through much faster than ever."
Users of E-Z Pass prepay their tolls and are given a small electronic gadget, which is taped or held inside the front windshield near the rear-view mirror. As they pass through the tollbooth at 5 miles an hour, their account is debited. "I wouldn't go across any bridge without an E-Z Pass," said Barbara A. Policastro of Pleasantville, adding that she uses her E-Z Pass on other bridges.
At the Tappan Zee Bridge, about three-quarters of all vehicles use E-Z Pass during peak commuter hours. But the number is half that during summer weekend and vacation getaway times -- something the Thruway Authority would like to change. "We are aggressively marketing E-Z Pass," said Howard E. Steinberg, the former chairman of the Thruway Authority. "It makes a tremendous difference."
Frequent bridge crossers get another benefit: 17 trips a month for $17, instead of $3 each trip. For further information or an application for E-Z Pass, call(800) 222-8655 or go to the Authority's Web site (www.thruway.state.ny.us/ezpass/ index.html).
The reversible lane median barrier on the bridge "has been a blessing," Mr. Kulewicz of the Automobile Club said. Twice a day since 1993, transfer machines move a 3-mile chain of barriers 12 feet across the bridge. This changes the traffic direction for the center lane, so that a fourth lane can be added in the direction that most traffic is headed (toward Westchester in the morning rush period, toward Rockland in the evening rush). The transfer machines travel at 3.5 miles an hour and make the 12-foot transfer of the seven million pounds of concrete barrier in about 60 minutes, according to Barrier Systems Inc., the company that installed it.
Mrs. Finger, the Elmsford resident, said that traffic actually slows down while the changeover is under way.
It is people's inability to see that causes some other bridge slowdowns, Mr. Kulewicz said. "Sun glare is a tremendous problem," he said, observing that it affects those going toward Westchester in the morning and those leaving the county in the afternoon. "Get a good pair of sunglasses," he advised.
Other advice he offered was consideration of alternatives to the Tappan Zee Bridge. "It depends on where you're going," he said. "You can use the Taconic Parkway to go south. There are a number of other Hudson River crossings. You can cross on I-84 at the Newburgh-Beacon Bridge, or take the Bear Mountain Bridge or cross at Rhinebeck."
And what of the future? Jessica Astrof, the New York project coordinator for the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, an alliance of public interest, transit advocacy, planning and environmental groups, said: "There is an obvious need to solve the problem of congestion on the bridge. It's hurting the region's economy as well as its environment."
The alliance supports a multipronged approach, she said, a cornerstone of which is "congestion relief pricing" -- charging vehicles different toll amounts, more in prime time, less in off-peak hours. "This is a very cost-effective strategy, and the revenues could then finance more public transportation," she said, adding that the Thruway Authority is soon expected to complete a yearlong study of this option.
Mr. Kulewicz of the Automobile Club rejected this idea, however, saying: "We oppose any increase in tolls. Congestion pricing is unproven."
Past suggestions, for a new bridge or for I-287 to be widened to accommodate a high-occupancy-vehicle lane, are off the drawing board because of intense local and political opposition, the Thruway Authority said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Providing Modest-Income Assisted-Living Units

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH its ballooning population of residents 60 years of age and older, New Jersey has become fertile ground for all types of housing for the elderly, especially assisted-living residences, which offer apartment living with meals, social services and personal care.
As of January, 9,671 such units in 113 projects have been or are being built. Some 28,908 more units in 326 projects are planned, according to the state's Department of Health and Senior Service, which began licensing assisted-living developments four years ago. 
 Most of the projects, where the average age of tenants is 75, are being built for affluent residents. Now a small group of developers, with financial assistance from the state, are putting up projects in which at least 20 percent of the residences are reserved for people with annual incomes of 50 to 80 percent of an area's median income.
The financial help is coming primarily from two semi-autonomous state agencies -- the Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency and the Economic Development Authority. The agencies, using money raised through the sale of taxable and tax-exempt bonds, provide construction and/or permanent loans at or below market interest rates to developers.
"We are striving to insure older New Jerseyans have the opportunity to age in place and access to a residential setting with the services needed to maintain an independent lifestyle that is within their means, " said Deborah De Santis, executive director of the housing finance agency.
In the three years since both agencies began offering such loans they have provided $270 million in financing for nearly 2,000 units in 20 projects either built or under way. At least 20 percent of the units will be for those with incomes below an area's median.
Some of the projects offer assisted-living residences with wings for residents with Alzheimer's disease or with independent-living units as well. Developers who accept Medicaid-eligible residents into their projects can also apply to the state for Medicaid vouchers for qualified residents -- those 65 or over with a monthly income of no more than $1,500. The vouchers, valued at $40 to $60 a day, help write down costs of services. The state has allocated 350 of the available 1,500 vouchers.
"The problem has been getting developers to accept the vouchers since the the state's first developers of assisted-living projects have been reaching out for the middle- to high-income elderly," said Andrew P. Aronson, director of longterm care licensing and certification at the state's Department of Health. "The challenge is to spread the housing to people of all economic levels."
To that end a bill was recently introduced that would require developers of licensed assisted-living residences to set aside 10 percent of their units for Medicaid-eligible residents. The measure is now in committees in both houses of the Legislature.
At the same time, the New Jersey Association of Health Care Facilities in Trenton, which along with other groups is concerned about overbuilding in the state, is advocating more government oversight. The aim, said Rick Abrams, president of the association, is to devise a system that makes sure that the growth of the assisted-living industry is both "orderly and meets the demographic, geographic and economic needs of the state's elderly residents."
One way to address those concerns, he said , would be to revise the state's way of reviewing assisted-living projects. The current 90-day review process primarily looks at a developer's record in running such properties.
A state commission has been formed to study the current review process and come up with recommendations in 10 months on whether to retain or modify it. Meanwhile, the housing finance agency, also worried that supply may be outpacing demand, is considering ways to direct the financing that it and other state agencies provide to avoid saturating areas, yet still encourage construction of assisted-living units affordable to people with modest incomes.
DEVELOPERS building such units believe they will fill a niche in the market. Yet, even with state assistance, getting the economics to work is difficult and often involves piecing together several different financing sources.
That is the case at the Clare Estate in Bordentown in Burlington County, where renovation and new construction are to get under way next month. The complex will have 105 assisted-living units, including 50 for people with Alzheimer's disease, in a restored 1885 monastery.
There will also be 36 independent-living units in nine buildings to be built on the grounds of the former nine-acre campus of the Sisters of Poor Clare, a Roman Catholic order of cloistered nuns. The complex is in the downtown, a designated historic district of the one-square-mile city.
Forty-six of the units will be affordable to residents whose incomes are 50 to 80 percent of the area's median income. The area's median income for a one-person household is $38,920 and $44,480 for a two-person household.
The state's housing finance agency provided $14.2 million in low-interest loans for the $16-million project, which also received $1.2 million in Federal tax credits for rehabilitation of historic structures. The rest came from private sources and the developer's own equity. The city also granted the project a 30-year real estate tax abatement, tying taxes to profits, rather than the value of the property.
"Nobody is paying attention to the affordable assisted-living market," said Christiana Foglio, president of Community Investment Strategies, of New Brunswick, the developer. "We came up with a strategy that will produce low- and moderate-income units and keep the price of the market-rate units reasonable."
The key, she said, is to use public financing to create the housing, allowing the market-rate units to, in effect, help subsidize the modest-income units.
Services also vary for the subsidized and unsubsidized units. While residents of both receive a general package, including three meals a day, help with bathing and dressing and transportation, those in the market-rate units get more medical-related assistance and weekly housekeeping.
The 55 units in the monastery, eight for low-income tenants, will range in size from 350 square feet for the private units to 450 square feet for shared ones. Monthly rents, including meals and services, are $463 for the modest-income units and $2,200 to $2,800 for the market-rate ones. The fees for the Alzheimer units will be $3,400 a month and include all services.
All of the independent-living units, with 600 square feet each, will be for modest-income residents and rent for $495 to $590 a month. Meals and services will be offered to residents for a yet to be determined fee, said Ms. Foglio.
She said she hoped to repeat the formula for other projects her company has planned in the state. One with 130 units, 61 of them for modest-income people, is in Cherry Hill.
In Edison, work is winding down on the Heritage at Clara Barton on 4.2 acres on Amboy Avenue, just west of Route 1. It has 27 independent-living units and 84 assisted-living units. Twenty percent of the latter are for residents earning no more than 50 percent of the area's median income, or $26,850 for a single person and $30,700 for a two-person household. All of the units will be in a renovated three-story former school built in the 20's and an interconnected new building of the same size.
The $17.6-million project is being developed by Pennrose Properties of Philadelphia using $12.2 million in financing from the state's Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. Edison also provided a low-interest $500,000 loan and granted the project a tax abatement also tied to profits as opposed to property value.
"The market is totally untapped for these units," said Charles M. Lewis, assistant vice president at Pennrose, referring to subsidized apartments. "But without the public financing we wouldn't be able to do it." The financing also helped lower rents on the market-rate units, he added.
The 84 assisted-living units, with 450 to 840 square feet, will be in the old school and the two upper floor of the new building. Residents will receive three meals a day, transportation, housekeeping and personal care. Rents for the modest-income units, including all services, will be $1,700 to $1,821. Some of those units will be made available to Medicaid-eligible people, said Mr. Lewis. Monthly rents for the market-rate units will be $2,400 to $3,400.
The fees for the 27 uniform-size independent-living units will be $765 to $984, he said, adding that the services would be available as options to those residents. Occupancy is to begin next month.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property /Trinity Real Estate;
Longtime Landlord Ponders Becoming a Developer

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
AS the subsidiary of an institution that is 302 years old, Trinity Real Estate tends to take the long view of things. For the last decade and a half it has been transforming most of the 5.5 million square feet of industrial buildings it acquired -- unwillingly -- during the 1930's into office space.
Now it is about to take the next step: development. Executives of the unit of the Parish of Trinity Church have selected four properties that can be demolished or totally remodeled into 2 million square feet of new offices. 
 Not that anyone is getting carried away. These projects are not likely to be built on speculation. Tenants, in most cases, will have to sign leases for a substantial share of each building before a spade goes into the ground.
"We are not risk takers," said Joseph T. Palombi, executive vice president of real estate for Trinity Church. "The only way we are going ahead with these projects is if we have tenants for 60 percent or more of the space."
Nevertheless, he said, the time is ripe for development by a company that owns its building sites, does not need zoning changes and is in an area that has proven attractive to the computer- and Internet-related companies that have been multiplying in recent years.
Handling architects' renderings of new buildings is an unusual sensation for managers of a portfolio of former lofts and factories clustered near the Holland Tunnel that until the early 1990's mostly housed printing companies. The buildings are a lingering legacy of a gift of 215 acres of land by England's Queen Anne in 1705 that is now generally thought of as the west side of lower Manhattan.
Most of the royally deeded land was sold or given away over the intervening centuries to found churches, hospitals and an educational institution now known as Columbia University. As New York industrialized in the early part of the 1900's, the church allowed developers to build sturdy factory buildings, most of them occupied by printing companies eager to be close to their financial industry clients on Wall Street.
Trinity retained ownership of the land and simply collected the ground rent until the Depression of the 1930's. The collapse of the economy left tenants unable to make mortgage and tax payments and the church was forced to take title to the properties to avoid losing them to lenders or the city. The debt it assumed was not retired until the 1960's.
By the mid-1980's, Trinity's real estate managers decided they did not want to be in a printing business that was clearly in longterm decline with the advent of electronic communications. They began remodeling the industrial buildings to attract office tenants, particularly the new-media and other computer-related companies that were springing up in the city.
Companies like these were not interested in the supposed prestige and high cost of midtown Manhattan. They installed open space layouts and strung the multitude of wires needed for connections in overhead racks and got to work.
That conversion process is still under way.
Trinity is renovating a triangular, 1.1 million square foot building bounded by Canal, Varick and Watts Streets for office use by enlarging the lobby, replacing elevators, bringing in additional electrical power and telecommunications and installing new windows to shut out the din of traffic at the Holland Tunnel.
Once known as 75 Varick Street, the building has been renamed 1 Hudson Square as part of an effort to put a brand name on the Trinity portfolio.
The proposed development projects include one large building that would occupy the entire block bounded by Hudson, Varick, Spring and Vandam Streets and three more modest undertakings.
Mr. Palombi said the low vacancy rates and the dearth of new construction in the city has convinced Trinity's leaders that there will be tenants eager to occupy brand new space. And because the church owns the land, it can charge lower rents than are possible in situations where a third party landowner is part of the equation.
"We figure that we have a $15 to $20 a square foot advantage over comparable space in midtown," he said, referring to projected annual rents. "That adds up to a big number over a period of years."
HE said that a 1.2 million square foot building could be erected on the site, which is currently occupied with smaller, Trinity-owned structures, without the need for a change in zoning. Because the building, to be designated 4 Hudson Square, would cost from $260 million to $300 million to build, the church will not proceed without a lease, and possibly financial participation, from a tenant whose solid credit will enable economical borrowing.
"Our fantasy is that a company like AT&T or I.B.M. will take the entire building," said Stephen D. Heyman, the director of commercial leasing for Trinity.
Mr. Palombi said that while Trinity will be the owner of the building, the church will hire a developer to supervise the detailed planning and construction.
One of the buildings on the site, 304 Hudson Street, which is 85 percent occupied, largely by information technology tenants, may be incorporated in the larger structure, but smaller buildings facing Varick Street are likely to be demolished, he said.
If a suitable tenant can be found soon, the building could be ready for occupancy by early 2003.
The remaining 800,000 square feet of potential development is divided among three projects. One is at 330 Hudson, to be designated 6 Hudson Square, which occupies the western half of the block bounded by Hudson, Varick, Vandam and Charlton Streets. The building is occupied by a document storage company, but Trinity officials said there is an opportunity to terminate the lease in about a year.
The plan here would be to strip the building down to its steel frame, use an alley in back to install a modern core and add four floors to the top, expanding it to 425,000 square feet. Once again, Trinity officials say they can make the alterations within existing zoning, a situation that is called "as of right" in the industry.
Because no foundation work will be involved, Trinity officials say they will be able to deliver what will amount to a new building quicker and cheaper, possibly by the end of 2002. "We may do this one without a tenant," said Mr. Palombi, who noted that the building would offer new space at a rental rate in the mid-30's per square foot annually compared to $45 a square foot and above for older space in midtown.
A small parking lot and garage to the east of the building at 345 Hudson Street, now known as 555 Greenwich Street, would be replaced with a slender building that has been designated 7 Hudson Square. The building could rise as much as 15 stories with 220,000 square feet of space. The building is being designed so that its floors match up with the Trinity-owned 345 Hudson, so that tenants in the Hudson Street building could expand via connections with the new structure.
An unused automobile service station adjacent to a Trinity property at 100 Avenue of the Americas would be converted into a six-story office building with 23,000 square feet of office space that could be connected to the larger structure.
In addition to the new building, Trinity officials said there is an opportunity to add 50,000 square feet of penthouse space to the building at 350 Hudson Street.
Trinity officials say the benefits of the new buildings will be greater than the rents they can collect on the added space. New, Class A buildings, they say, will enhance the entire portfolio by enhancing the image of the neighborhood.
"Our interest in developing these building goes beyond any individual project," Mr. Heyman said. "These developments will raise the value of the other space in the area."
He said the area began its transformation from light manufacturing to office when the Saatchi & Saatchi advertising agency moved into a new building at 375 Hudson Street in the mid-1980's. Although Trinity does not own the building, which was built by Tishman Speyer Properties, the company that controls Rockefeller Center, the church benefits from more than the changed image the building brought to the area.
"We," Mr. Palombi said, "own the land.".

HEADLINE: For Temporary Workers, A Full-Time Quandary

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Temporarily Yours" (Preludes, April 18) noted the boom in temporary work but not the sobering fact that a large number of temps are trapped in these precarious work arrangements, and in most cases without job security and employee benefits. 
 The column did not mention that many of these so-called nomads have resorted to temporary employment only because they have not been able to secure permanent, full-time jobs.
Under the guise of flexibility and independence, temporary status is quite seductive. But for most, temporary work means lower wages, no health insurance or pension coverage and little if any economic security.
Most alarming is that the temporary-work industry is expanding as employers turn to these work arrangements to cut costs and raise revenues because they can exclude employees from benefit plans and deny them protection under labor laws.
That is creating a new working underclass and is lowering our national living standard.
I will soon be introducing legislation in Congress to prohibit employers from evading their legal and moral responsibilities to their employees. For those of us who care about working families, a legislative solution to this expanding problem has been a long time coming.
 
LANE EVANS
Member of Congress
17th District, Illinois
Washington, April 28

HEADLINE: Local Wineries Developing a Following

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
AS wine-making knowledge grows apace, the production of pleasurable, expressive, technically sound wines in areas once deemed inhospitable to the grape has become commonplace. In the trade, this movement is called wine regionalism, and it is as natural as the culinary world's late-20th-century emphasis on the delights and utility of local bounty.
Yet, oddly, owing in part to snobbery, the reputations of local wines in minor wine appellations lag behind other fare. 
 Which informed Hudson Valley residents would not return often to such products as Hudson Valley Foie Gras? To Hudson Valley Draft Cider? To Coach Farm goat cheese?
Three long-established wineries constituting the Dutchess Wine Trail, on the east side of the Hudson River Valley, often generate excellent white and red wines. They are John and Kathe Dyson's Millbrook in, of course, Millbrook; Ben and Phyllis Feder's Clinton Vineyards, in Clinton Corners, and Bill and Margaret Wetmore's Cascade Mountain, in Amenia.
The wines of these estates, delivering distinctive local character, can be splendid mealtime and party fare.
The wines of Clinton and Cascade Mountain can be read as the equivalent of France's vins de pays, outstanding country wines, the kind that American visitors relish, say, in the Midi but declare nostalgically "never travel well." (In fact, they do, splendidly.)
Because of the ambitions and financial assets of Mr. Dyson -- Rudolph W. Giuliani's former Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and former Agriculture, Commerce and State Power Authority official under Gov. Hugh L. Carey -- many of his wines occupy a different category: the so-called world-class arena in which chardonnays, cabernet sauvignons and pinot noirs compete for attention and approbation.
Millbrook's current offerings in the tasting room consist of 1993, 1995 and 1996 reserve chardonnays; 1994, 1995 and 1997 regular chardonnays; 1993 and 1994 reserve cabernet sauvignons and 1992 and 1996 regular cabernet sauvignons; 1995 reserve cabernet franc (a grape that is a cousin of the cabernet sauvignon) and regular 1992, 1993 and 1996 cabernet francs; 1993 and 1997 reserve pinot noirs; 1991 and 1994 merlots and a 1997 gamay noir (the grape of Beaujolais), and 1998 Tocai Friulano (an Italian grape).
This array enables customers to buy several bottles and compare differences in style, vintage and outcome from the agricultural variables that influence fruit farming.
(Mr. Dyson also sells 14 wines from his holdings on the coast of central California, but he does not sell any from Williams and Selyem, the outstanding pinot noir property in Sonoma's Russian River Valley, which he bought in 1998, and from his Villa Pillo estate in Tuscany.)
Clinton Vineyards currently offers customers the 1997 "Anniversary Reserve" seyval blanc (marking the house's 20th year); the nonvintage Seyval Naturel, a sparkling wine, and Romance, a half-bottle nonvintage fortified sweet Seyval dessert wine. It will soon be releasing the 1998 seyval "Proprietor's Reserve."
In addition, Clinton sells Peach Gala, which is the Seyval Naturel with peach flavoring, and is introducing Embrace, a fortified dessert wine in half bottles made from Dutchess raspberries.
Ben Feder, the founder of Clinton Vineyards, was a Hudson Valley pioneer. He planted seyval blanc and after more than 21 vintages has so mastered the hybrid grape, a Northeastern specialty, that his crisp, fresh, fruity wine can sometimes be confused with chardonnay.
For many years, the Hudson River Club, a fancy restaurant in the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan, has kept Clinton's methode champenoise Seyval Naturel and its still-wine counterpart on its wine list.
The White House bought the Feders' Victory White, and when Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin held a summit conference at the Franklin D. Roosevelt estate in Hyde Park in 1995, Clinton wines were poured for the press.
Cascade Mountain Winery was founded in the early 1970's by Bill Wetmore, who likes to call himself a "novelist turned grapeist." A big attraction is its rustic indoor-outdoor restaurant where students and graduates from the Culinary Institute of America, in nearby Hyde Park, have been present. Ever the wordsmith, Mr. Wetmore, an easygoing fellow who likes to talk with customers, has given his wines names that sell. Though no longer made, Le Hamburger Red lingers fondly in residents' memories.
Customers can find the following grape-based wines: the 1997 seyval blanc, a dry, fruity white; 1996 Private Reserve White, an oak-aged blend of chardonnay and seyval blanc; Summertide, a nonvintage, picnic-oriented semidry white blend made of seyval, aurora and Cayuga white; a 1997 Coeur de Lion, a Beaujolais-style red blend, which is typically composed of Marechal Foch and cabernet sauvignon; the 1997 Private Reserve Red, a full-bodied blend of Foch and cabernet sauvignon; nonvintage Harvest Rose, a light wine made from the Chancellor grape, and 1997 Vignoles, a golden-colored sweet dessert wine.
The three Trail members all lie in a dreamy rural part of Dutchess County. The vistas -- pheasants rising, trout streams, orchards, woods, meadows, gentle hills, valleys, distant Catskill Mountains -- inspired Hudson River School paintings in the 19th century. On late 20th-century weekends, they calm frazzled Manhattan dwellers.
"We hibernate there -- and play hard," said Cathy Morrell, the wife of Peter Morrell, whose Madison Avenue wine shop in Manhattan (soon to move to Rockefeller Center) and wine auctions lure the cognoscenti.
The Dutchess Wine Trail lies within the Hudson River region that the Federal Government designated an American Viticultural Area in 1982 and which is one of the oldest wine-growing areas in the United States.
Overall, the area is home to 20 wineries, 16 of them widely dispersed on the river's west side. (For example, the Brotherhood Winery in Washingtonville -- which is on the west bank and not part of the trail -- is the oldest continuously operated winery in America, having been founded in 1839.) All are within easy driving distance of Westchester.
But that is another story.
 
Where to Find the 3 Wineries
Here is information about the Dutchess Wine Trail:
Cascade Mountain Winery and Restaurant, Flint Hill Road, Amenia, 12501; 373-9021. Open daily 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. all year. (The restaurant, which is open all year except in March, is closed Wednesdays.)
Clinton Vineyards, Schultzville Road, Clinton Corners, 12514; 266-5372. Open Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. and by appointment. A new "Vintner's Lunch Basket" program is to run Saturdays and Sundays from June through October.
Millbrook Winery, Wing and Shunpike Roads, Rural Route 1, Box 167D, Wing Road, Millbrook, 12545; 677-8383; (800) 662-9463. Daily noon to 5 P.M. From June through October food is to be served Saturdays and Sundays by Xe Sogni, an Italian restaurant in Amenia, at the Vineyard Grill, on the grounds. Web site: www.millbrookwine.com.
All three wineries will take part in the Hudson Valley Food and Wine Festival on June 19 and 20 at Montgomery Place, an 1804 estate in Annandale-on-Hudson.
