HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Seaford, N.Y.;
A Certain Chemistry on the South Shore

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
LAST fall Seaford High School's football team topped off a winning season with a 23-to-12 victory over Babylon to take the Long Island Class 4 championship.
The victory, said head coach Rich Schaub, "left an indelible imprint on all of us."
"The team had great chemistry and a never-give-up attitude," he added, "and that reflects the people in this community." 
 The hamlet's chemistry, said Mr. Schaub and others, combines good schools, involved parents, family-centered living and a choice coastal setting.
"The parents here are so very involved in the schools," said Edward P. Mavragis, the Seaford Schools Superintendent. "The booster club is always raising money. We don't even have to ask."
An area of single-family houses -- many of the more expensive ones bordering canals, waterways and wetlands -- Seaford is situated on Nassau County's South Shore.
Representative Peter T. King, the Republican incumbent in Long Island's Third Congressional District, moved to Seaford from Queens in 1967 and sent two children through Seaford schools.
"We've lived in the same house for 28 years and never had a bad moment," Mr. King said. "It's a very solid place, very family-oriented, very safe, good schools, good community spirit."
Mr. King said that while there were some complaints about higher school taxes than in some nearby districts, even this had an upside. "It's because we have no industry," he said. "And in a place like Seaford, if the trade-off for lower taxes is more industry, I'd rather see no industry."
As recently as the 40's, Seaford, linked historically to the adjoining hamlet of Wantagh -- with which is once shared the name Jerusalem -- was a marsh and farm area with few houses. The 1940 census put the population at 2,216. By 1960, after Long Island's postwar building boom, the census recorded 14,718 residents, just about 1,000 fewer than today.
Water has always been central to Seaford. Houses along canals with backyard docks or along Seamans Creek, Seaford Creek or the James River are considered waterfront and cost more than houses on the inland, or north side, of the hamlet.
The southside canals lead past salt marsh islands into South Oyster Bay, part of Great South Bay. "The closer you get to the bay, the more expensive your house gets," said Donna Pasquale, office manager at Cruse Real Estate and Development in Seaford.
Mrs. Pasquale said home prices in Seaford ranged from $130,000 "for something that needs total renovation" up to $600,000 on the water.
At times, lower-priced waterfront homes appear on the market. Barbara Shane, the broker and owner of Shane's Anchor Realty in Seaford, said a two-bedroom, one-bath riverfront Swiss chalet was in contract for $225,000.
Housing styles in Seaford include summer bungalows converted to year-round dwellings, ranches, colonials, Cape Cods, eclectics and contemporaries. Most were built in the 50's and 60's.
There is some new construction. Crescent Cove, a 57-home development planned at the former Marina Del Mar, will include three- or four-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath, two-story colonials and traditional-style, single-family homes starting at $459,000.
PRICES will be about $100,000 higher for homes on the water, said Barbara Adamo, vice president and director of sales and marketing for Realty Group Marketing of Smithtown. She said 22 homes had been reserved from blueprints and are now under contract. The development is expected to be completed by next spring.
Seaford's rental market is very limited. Two-bedroom apartments rent for about $1,200 when available. There are also rentals in a few small buildings, the largest with 25 units, and in a few two-family houses. Other rentals are illegal ones in single-family homes.
There are about 200 co-op apartments, including 71 for the elderly citizens at the Cedar Cove co-op. Average prices are $150,000 for two-bedrooms and $120,000 for a one-bedroom. One-bedroom units for the elderly are about $90,000. Buyers of these units must be at least 62 years of age and have an annual income of no more than $35,000. Mrs. Shane said there were no condominiums in Seaford.
Seaford has no beaches or public boat ramps. But there are a number of private marinas and Jones Beach State Park is about seven miles away.
The 77-acre Seamans Neck Park, a Town of Hempstead park, has three playgrounds, six playing fields and courts for basketball, tennis, volley ball, handball and paddleball.
Cedar Creek Park, a 265-acre Nassau County park, has five playing fields and courts for handball and tennis plus picnic areas, a roller rink and hills for sledding. The county's 84-acre Tackapausha Preserve is a five-mile nature trail popular with birdwatchers.
Local shopping is along Merrick Road, the main east-to-west thoroughfare. The 1.2-million-square-foot Sunrise Mall is less than five miles away.
At Seaford High School, 72 percent of the 143 graduates in the class of 1998 earned Regents diplomas. The state average was 43 percent. About 90 percent went on to higher education. Average S.A.T. scores last year were 516 in verbal and 526 in math. State averages were 495 in verbal and 503 in math; national scores were 505 and 512, respectively.
The Seaford High School Marching Band performs in the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade in Manhattan, and performed in events in Phoenix and Los Angeles last year.
A Regents tutorial program in the high school spans the academic year and continues in summer sessions. In the elementary and middle school, many students enroll in special reading and math programs to meet tougher state standards.
There are four computer labs in the high school, one in the middle school and one in each of the two elementary schools. Every classroom in the district has at least one computer. All computers are connected to the Internet and each student has an e-mail address.
Pupils in the first three grades are placed together in what the school refers to as learning communities, where they are encouraged to advance to the limits of their abilities, regardless of age.
A school-to-career program exposes elementary and middle-school students to future career choices at an early age. And high school students are eligible for internship programs at local businesses.
The high school offers advanced placement classes and participates in a Syracuse University program in which students can earn college credits in economics and history. A districtwide inclusion model integrates special education students into regular classes.
District elementary schools are for grades K through 5 and the middle school is for grades 6 through 8. The district has 2,534 students.
A former schoolhouse closed in 1921 and, for a time, headquarters of the Seaford Fire Department is now a Hempstead landmark, housing the Seaford Historical Museum, where memorabilia from the hamlet's maritime and farming past is on display. The museum is open by appointment only. Call (516) 826-1150.
Joshua Soren, president of the Seaford Historical Society and the museum, said that many an older home had been torn down to make way for two or three new houses on the property. Each year, he said, there is less to show schoolchildren he takes on historic tours. "It's more like this was there than this is there," he explained.
AMONG English settlers of Hempstead in the 1640's was Capt. John Seaman, who built a home in what came to be known as Jerusalem, now Seaford and Wantagh. One legend is that the captain, who died in 1695, was from Seaford, England. But another maintains that it got its name because a horse stolen in the 1860's was found in Seaford, Del.
Mr. Soren said that Seaford was variously known as Jerusalem South, Hempstead South, Atlanticville and Verity Town -- after a large local family -- until the name Seaford was finally adopted in 1868.
By then the area had a post office, a schoolhouse and a Methodist church. The Long Island Rail Road arrived that same year, but Seaford didn't get a station until 1899. By 1909 the population was 850, up from 350 in 1888. By 1926, when the Seaford National Bank opened, there were 1,200 residents. Then came the transformation following World War II, when home construction soared and city residents, many from Brooklyn, flocked in.
In 1967, residents managed to get the name of the just opened Wantagh-Oyster Bay Expressway changed to the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway, arguing that the southern terminus was really in Seaford. The expressway links Seaford to the Long Island Expressway and to the Northern and Southern State Parkways.
Mrs. Shane said long-term residency was the rule in Seaford. "Most people who come here stay here until they die," she said.

SEAFORD SKIFF: From its beginnings, Seaford has been a place for duck hunting and fishing. In the 1920's, Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig were among visiting sportsmen. And Seaford baymen, now few in number, once plied local waters for shellfish. A favored boat for such expeditions was the Seaford Skiff, a flat-bottomed vessel made to navigate shallow bay waters where the best shellfishing was found. The skiff, which had a mast and oars, was also used by duck hunters, doubling as a duck blind. An original locally designed skiff is on display at the Seaford Historical Museum. Joshua Soren, the museum president, said officials from Mystic Seaport in Mystic, Conn., came to the museum two years ago to measure and document the 14-foot vessel and build a replica.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
A Ruling on Co-ops and Disability

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
THE New York City Commission on Human Rights has issued a wake-up call of sorts to property owners -- including co-op and condominium boards as well as landlords -- about discriminating against tenants with disabilities.
In a decision in a case involving a wheelchair-bound shareholder and a co-op on Central Park West, the commission ordered the co-op to construct a ramp for the shareholder to use to enter the building, to install automatic door openers on elevators and in the building's lobby, and to pay the shareholder $15,000 in compensation for the mental anguish caused by the co-op's failure to provide "reasonable accommodations" when the shareholder requested them. The $15,000 award was $5,000 more than a recommendation in a report by an administrative law judge that formed the basis for the commission's decision. 
"The commission's decision and order puts co-ops and their boards in the five boroughs on notice that disability-based discrimination is absolutely illegal under the city's Human Rights Law, and that violators will be called to account by the Commission on Human Rights," the commission chairwoman, Marta B. Varela, said in a press release issued with the decision on March 8.
Randolph E. Wills, the deputy commissioner in charge of the commission's Law Enforcement Bureau, said that the Human Rights Law requires property owners to make reasonable accommodations so that residents with disabilities can enjoy the same rights as those without disabilities. And, Mr. Wills said, in the case in question, that included the right of a shareholder who used a wheelchair "to leave her building without fear of having to beg a car service driver or other stranger for assistance."
John Herrion, assistant program counsel for the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association in Jackson Heights, Queens, said that the shareholder, Ronnie Ellen Raymond, who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1990, had experienced increasing difficulty with balance and negotiating stairs. Mr. Herrion, who represented Ms. Raymond in the case against the co-op at 325 Central Park West, at 92d Street, said that despite the fact that the shareholder offered to pay for installation of a sidewalk ramp at the building's entrance stairs, the co-op board rejected her offer.
Instead, Mr. Herrion said, the board decided to install an exterior lift that could transport a person in a wheelchair from street level down into a "moat" that ran along the front of the building. Once in the moat, the person in the wheelchair would then be able to enter the building through a basement door and from there gain access to the elevator. That arrangement, Mr. Herrion said, was not acceptable to Ms. Raymond and did not satisfy the "reasonable accommodation" provision of the law.
"The board was essentially saying to the shareholder, 'You can use the back door,' " he said. "But the Human Rights Commission agreed that our request for the ramp was a reasonable one." Mara B. Levin, the co-op's lawyer, declined comment on the decision or on whether the board will appeal.
Real estate lawyers say the decision puts all property owners on notice that they must take seriously any request for special accommodations made by a disabled resident. "I've been dealing with several cases like this myself," said C. Jaye Berger, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. "But the problem with the Human Rights Law is that there are no clear parameters to guide you."
Ms. Berger said that while the law clearly requires property owners to make "reasonable accommodations" for disabled residents, it is impossible to define that term in the abstract. "A decision like this is extremely scary for a co-op," she said. "There's a huge potential for a building to have serious claims. And the Human Rights Commission wields such broad authority to decide what is appropriate, you have to take every request by a disabled tenant quite seriously and engage in a lot of creative thinking."
Bruce Cholst, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that the recent decision -- along with an apparent increase in the number of elderly residents who choose to remain in their apartments as they grow older -- makes it necessary for boards to prepare for requests for reasonable accommodations in any number of different situations. "This is a slow-motion time-bomb in the early stages of exploding," Mr. Cholst said, adding that there are two distinct aspects of what may be required to provide a reasonable accommodation for a disabled tenant or shareholder. "One is whether to make physical changes to the building," he said, "and the other is whether to suspend or change rules already in place."
For example, he said, an older tenant would not have to be disabled -- in the traditional sense of the word -- to have difficulty opening heavy lobby or elevator doors. Nonetheless, Mr. Cholst said, it would probably be appropriate in such a case for a property owner to choose to install automatic doors like the ones ordered by the commission in the Raymond case. On the other hand, he said, a board being asked to make a reasonable accommodation for a person who has a need for a pet for companionship might have to contemplate rule changes if there is a no-pet rule in the building.
At the same time, Mr. Cholst said, it may also be possible for a property owner to provide a reasonable accommodation for an older or disabled tenant without having to resort to changing the rules or the physical layout of the building, if all parties strive to remain reasonable.
"What is usually at issue is not whether something needs to be done, but how to do it," he said. "If you have a disabled person in a wheelchair, it might be possible for a neutral person -- maybe even a paid mediator -- to assure the resident that having a building staff person always available to help them up a short flight of stairs would be a reasonable alternative to constructing a ramp." Indeed, Mr. Cholst said, one of the elements of "reasonableness" is whether a proposed solution to a problem is economically feasible and practically achievable.
"A reasonable accommodation is one that does not impose undue hardship on the property owner," he said.
Dennis Greenstein, another Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that property owners -- particularly co-op and condominium associations in which tenants are owners -- must also prepare for the inevitable increase in the number of building residents who will have special needs as they grow older. "Most boards are pretty good at dealing with financial planning and capital improvement planning," he said. "But now they have to start thinking about people planning, too."
In fact, Mr. Greenstein said, the best way to address a request for help from a disabled or aging resident is to do so as quickly as possible.
"I'm seeing more and more people come to boards saying they need better accommodations, better access to the building," Mr. Greenstein said. "And in many cases, even though the board is making a good-faith attempt to help the tenant, they may seem to be a little slow in responding." When that happens, he said, the resident may perceive the slow response as an indication that the board does not sincerely wish to cooperate.
"And once a complaint gets filed," Mr. Greenstein said, "it's much more difficult to keep the discussion on a friendly basis."

HEADLINE: Troubled Co-ops Outside Manhattan Are on the Rebound

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
BEYOND the plusher precincts of Manhattan, New York City's co-op and condominium market has been steadily gaining strength, bringing welcome financial news and a palpable sense of relief to many apartment owners.
The market had been dormant, if not on life support, for the first half of this decade. 
 Those were the bad old days: a time when promises went unkept, renters balked at paying for neglected apartments, shareholders withheld their maintenance checks; a time when sponsors defaulted and sometimes disappeared -- some after pocketing co-op funds -- when banks filed foreclosure petitions, buildings struggled to devise financial workout plans and a few even deconverted, leaving residents owing loans and owning nothing.
It is not as though the co-op and condominium market in the boroughs outside of Manhattan, as well as above 96th Street, has roared back. But signs of vitality are evident almost everywhere.
"We're seeing a dramatic shift in the reason people come to New York," said Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. "Because of the fall in the crime rate, there's a significant increase in empty-nesters moving from the suburbs into the city instead of going South; young families electing to stay in the city rather than moving to the suburbs."
"And I don't mean just Manhattan," Mr. Saft said, "but also the outer boroughs."
Typical of the swing in fortunes is a 122-unit postwar six-story, red-brick building in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, that -- as it flirted with foreclosure -- did not see a single sale between 1992 and 1995. Since then, 23 apartments in the co-op have been sold, including six this year. "It was like cancer back then," said Jules Reich, who took over as sponsor of the building at 302 96th Street in 1994, after the original sponsor defaulted and left the resident shareholders holding the bag -- mortgage and tax arrears totaling $4.6 million.
"You couldn't give apartments away," Mr. Reich said.
At Hampton Court, a four-building co-op complex of 316 apartments on Park Lane South in Kew Gardens, Queens, where occupied apartments sold for as little as $10,000 during an auction in 1992, one-bedrooms currently go for $85,000 and two-bedrooms for $149,000 -- with 17 sold so far this year. "It's been a bumpy ride, but we've landed on our feet," said Frank Daliendo, the board president.
A nine-story, 76-unit building at 250 Cabrini Boulevard in Manhattan's Washington Heights, where there were no sales in 1992, 1993 and 1994, has since seen 40 apartments sold, 10 so far this year. At the nadir of the market nose-dive, a one-bedroom in the building sold for $13,000. Currently, they are going for $150,000.
"It's a wonderful turnaround that people can now sell for the original prices or more," said Annice Alt, the board treasurer, "compared to when four shareholders lost their apartments after defaulting on their mortgages."
Not every nook in New York's co-op-condominium supply closet -- an estimated 10,000 buildings containing 700,000 units have been converted or constructed in the city since 1980 -- is basking in the financial glow. In many buildings, while sales have picked up, prices have not yet rebounded to where they were at the time of conversion. And in some buildings, strength has been felt only in the level of rents for sublets -- a precursor, some say, to a resurgence in sales.
At Regents Park Gardens on Jewel Avenue in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, two-bedroom apartments in the 138-unit garden-apartment condominium complex were offered to outsiders for $145,000 at the time of conversion in 1986. They now sell for $125,000.
But at Barnes Gardens, a 96-unit co-op at 2080-90 Barnes Avenue in the Pelham section of the Bronx, Howard Lazarus, the sponsor, said, "We have a dramatically improved rental market, which has led to reduced availability of apartments, and at higher rents."
"This means," Mr. Lazarus said, "that given the still moderate prices of co-ops in the Bronx it is now significantly cheaper to own than to rent." At Barnes Gardens, a one-bedroom renting for $800 a month can be bought for $35,000, he said, with total monthly costs of under $700 (maintenance of $450 and $250 in debt service on a loan of $30,000). "People have started calling our office, asking about buying," Mr. Barnes said. "This is new, compared to last year."
All of which -- in a citywide market where the level of demand continues to outstrip a supply long constricted by limited construction -- indicates that the seemingly inexorable rise in market-rate rents is making those still moderately priced co-ops and condominiums increasingly desirable.
Edithe Deshauteurs, a leather-accessories designer who recently sold her one-bedroom in Manhattan's Gramercy Park area, needed more space and, at first, she said, wanted to move downtown, "somewhere in the Village, or lower."
She will soon move into a one-bedroom in Forest Hills, Queens.
"More than a year ago," Ms. Deshauteurs said, "I started looking around Manhattan; then I looked at the prices. For what I wanted, it was at least $200,000, and I just didn't want to spend all my money on a mortgage."
Some friends had already "moved out to Brooklyn -- the Heights, Cobble Hill," she said. But Ms. Deshauteurs, a native of Haiti who grew up in Richmond Hill, Queens, said she "really can't relate to Brooklyn; as beautiful and trendy as it is, it's foreign territory to me."
So when she looked at what was available in Essex House, a six-story prewar building on 75th Avenue in Forest Hills, "I thought the sizes were great, the apartment charming."
"I'll have an eat-in kitchen, windows in every room," she said. "The eat-in kitchen was a big thing; I had a little kitchenette in Gramercy Park."
Ms. Deshauteurs did not want to state the precise price of her new apartment, "but a one-bedroom in the building is $90,000, $100,000," she said. "I looked at two-bedrooms in the area, and some were about $100,000. You also have those luxury apartments with a doorman and all the trappings, and those, I'd say, could be $130,000 to over $200,000."
She also did not want to disclose the price she got for her Manhattan co-op, which she bought 12 years ago for about $100,000, except to say, "Some apartments in the building went for a quarter of a million, so I'm making some profit." Another one-bedroom in the building was "on the market less than a week and went for more than $250,000," Ms. Deshauteurs said. "I was shocked."
Manhattan prices have been shocking many buyers for several years, and, more recently, prompting them to expand their horizons.
"It's one of the main topics on people's minds," said Sylvia Shapiro, a lawyer, president of the board of her Greenwich Village building and author of "The Co-op Bible" (St. Martin's Griffin, 1998), an "everything-you-need-to-know" book. "I can tell you stories about friends who were priced out of Manhattan and headed to the boroughs."
In particular, what people want to know these days, Ms. Shapiro said, "is what to do given the dizzying heights of both rental and sales prices: 'Do I take the plunge now?' "
Manhattan rents, she said, "are so exorbitant that people face a Hobson's choice -- between throwing away thousands a month in rent or plunking down a king's ransom to buy a little piece of Manhattan."
AMONG those scratching their heads are insiders who chose not to purchase at the time of conversion. Some even hope to buy now at the old insider price. In one court case, Adiel v. Lincoln Plaza Associates, a tenant who passed up the chance when the building converted to a condominium in 1983 filed suit 13 years later, claiming the insider price remained in effect because the offering plan inaccurately described the number of rooms in her apartment. She lost.
Ms. Shapiro said that in her building, Randall House at 65 East Ninth Street, prices are "literally triple" what they were at conversion in 1991. "One-bedrooms are now in excess of $300,000," she said, "two-bedrooms, $450,000 to $500,000."
And she told of a friend who paid $400,000 for a two-bedroom in the Village two years ago, "a price which, at the time, seemed like a stretch."
"But now she's thanking her lucky stars," Ms. Shapiro said. "Today that same apartment is selling for $600,000, and who knows if she could afford it?"
William Lie Zeckendorf, co-chairman of the Brown Harris Stevens brokerage company, tried to place the Manhattan market's trajectory in longterm perspective. Based on surveys of several market levels, not just the luxury sector in which his firm specializes, Mr. Zeckendorf said sales volume plummeted by at least 50 percent between 1990 and 1993, while prices dropped 25 to 30 percent. It was only in 1996, after nine years of slippage, that the first significant price increases were recorded, he said.
Mr. Zeckendorf called 1997 "a great year," with prices rising 28 percent, followed by a leveling off in 1998, when -- despite foreign economic tremors and a Wall Street swoon -- prices rose a still appreciable 15 percent.
"People ask: 'How much longer can this market keep going? Am I buying at the top?' " Mr. Zeckendorf said. "But if you look at this over a 10-, 12-year period, relative to inflation, we're only 19 percent higher than in '88." By comparison, Mr. Zeckendorf pointed out that the Dow stood at 2,168 at the end of 1988, and at 9,181 at the end of '98. "That's 323 percent," he said. "For now, I think the market has behaved efficiently."
But buyers take a more immediate view -- wondering whether they will find what they need now; whether they will automatically eat up the profit from the sale of their old apartment when they plunk down the money for the new one; and, for some, whether to venture across a river.
And they worry whether there will ever be another debacle like that of the early 90's.
There is no central registry of all the buildings -- and, more pointedly, all the people -- whose financial health was shaken when the bottom dropped out of much of the co-op market after the boom of the 80's. In the early 90's, said Gary Connor, chief of enforcement in the real estate financing bureau of the New York State Attorney General's Office, about 10 percent of the 13,400 co-ops and condominiums created in the state after 1980 found themselves in some sort of financial difficulty -- 900 to 1,000 of them in the city.
"I can tell you that the number of buildings that have financial problems is greatly diminished," Mr. Connor said. "We still have longterm problems at some buildings, but it's nowhere near what it used to be."
DURING the depths of the troubles, he said, the Attorney General's Office filed about 100 civil actions to bar sponsors from further activity in the real estate securities business, with "a high percentage of those" eventually enjoined. About 10 sponsors were brought up on criminal charges, with "several of them" convicted, he said.
"We had one sponsor who from day one just outright took the reserve funds, didn't pay maintenance and sold apartments without disclosing this," Mr. Connor said. "He went to jail."
There were 25 to 30 buildings in the city, Mr. Connor said, that were ultimately foreclosed upon and deconverted. "But the vast majority of troubled buildings were eventually worked out," he said. "And now we're down to 15 or 20 that remain with some kind of financial problem."
Beyond the greed and mendacity of a few sponsors, there were two spikes that popped the late-80's co-op-condominium bubble -- a market already bloated by overvalued properties purchased with huge underlying mortgages that had been granted to speculating sponsors by high-risk-taking lenders. One spike was the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which eliminated incentives for outside investors to buy apartments; the other was the confidence-chilling stock market slide of 1987.
Many conversions back then had less to do with the real value of buildings than with the sponsor's prediction of the maximum value of the apartments after they were all sold. Many sponsors, in their conversion plans, added wraparound mortgages to the underlying mortgage, creating additional capital for themselves and more debt for the resident shareholders. Tenants often did not raise objections to the wraparound because they were more interested in buying apartments at low insider prices and selling for quick profit.
"Typically, the co-ops that had the greatest difficulty were those with less than 50 percent of their units sold when the music stopped in 1989," said Susan Hewitt, president of the Cheshire Group, one of a handful of companies dubbed "white knights" for their work in rescuing troubled buildings -- in exchange for a significant share of future sales.
"The distressed situations," Ms. Hewitt said, "were those with the fewest owner occupants and the largest number of regulated tenants, whose rents were less than the maintenance, so the sponsors fell behind and defaulted. And they tended to have disproportionately large underlying mortgages -- everybody got carried away back then. That's the universe of buildings that white knights were working with."
Before 1986, a sponsor could expect to sell blocks of his unsold apartments to other investors -- a syndicate of doctors, for example -- who saw short-term tax benefits and longterm value in eventual sales to outsiders. But the 1986 Tax Reform Act eliminated most of those deductions, and a significant portion of the market. The following year, the stock market drop forced thousands of layoffs in the financial district; not just the big-money traders, but support staff -- the people who buy apartments in Brooklyn and Queens.
Sponsors started applying for, and getting, end loans (the individual apartment loans) against the value of their unsold apartments. Often, the sponsor got a loan based on an estimate of one-third of what the apartment's price would be when it someday sold to an outsider, even though the apartment was occupied by a rent-regulated tenant. The rent would be significantly less than the maintenance and debt service the sponsor had to pay. They began to default.
Gila Khabbaza, president of the board of Sanford Plaza, a 180-unit, four-building co-op complex on Sanford Avenue in Flushing, Queens, remembers those nightmarish times.
"When I joined the board in '87, I realized the numbers didn't add up," said Ms. Khabbaza. One number, she recalled, was $180,000 for asbestos removal, "and we didn't have any removal."
In a not entirely unusual pattern for the time, Ms. Khabbaza said: "The sponsor owned the management company. The vendors doing work were mostly owned by him. The bank doing the end loans was owned by a business partner. It was very incestuous." The sponsor hadn't paid maintenance for several months, she said, "but we didn't know because he owned the management company and he controlled the board."
It took pressure from the Attorney General's Office and Queens Borough President Claire Shulman, who set up a task force to deal with troubled co-ops, before a settlement was hammered out with the sponsor "so that we would take over everything and he would just get lost," Ms. Khabbaza said.
During the turmoil and before a financial workout could be reached between the board and the banks -- reducing the underlying mortgage from $7.1 million to its current $2.7 million -- some shareholders were forced into bankruptcy.
"We had 10 people who just walked away," Ms. Khabbaza said. The foreclosure price for those apartments was $25,000 for a one-bedroom. Currently, one-bedrooms sell for up to $70,000.
Ms. Hewitt said the typical "white knight" strategy was to negotiate a reduction of the underlying mortgage in exchange for an interest in the unsold shares. "We would buy the underlying," Ms. Hewitt said, "reduce it to where the co-op could afford the shortfall on the unsold shares and then split the proceeds from any new sales with the co-op; usually we'd get 75 percent, the co-op got 25 percent. In most cases, the sponsor was history."
MOST of the troubled buildings are now three or four years into their recovery, and Mr. Saft of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums believes they have come out stronger than if they had not gone through the wringer. "They are stronger," he said, "because when we did the workouts we attempted to not only resolve the obvious financial problems, but also to predict future problems -- an overall solution rather than a Band-Aid."
Assessing himself as "usually pessimistic" about the co-op and condominium market, Mr. Saft said he was "very bullish" these days. "Of course, this will be tested in the next recession, but I don't believe we'll see the kind of collapse we witnessed in the early 1990's."
Arthur Margon, an economist and director of academic affairs at the New York University Real Estate Institute, concurred. "Things are different this cycle because the financial institutions and the co-op buildings themselves are both on firmer financial footing," he said. "This is because the workouts addressed the longterm financial responsibilities of the buildings."
But even more important, Professor Margon said, is that "there hasn't been enormous production of new units or newly converted units, and that means it's unlikely that any economic downturn will coincide with substantial oversupply."
Pointing out that "we didn't start absorbing the oversupply in Manhattan until '94, and outside of Manhattan until the last two years," Professor Margon said: "Now, apartments in even more recently gentrifying neighborhoods and middle-class neighborhoods -- Prospect Heights, Windsor Terrace in Brooklyn, Rego Park and Ridgewood in Queens -- are selling quickly."
None too quickly for Ms. Khabbaza, the board president at Sanford Plaza in Flushing, and for many others who lived with uncertainty for so long. "It was like not being able to breathe, like holding our breath," Ms. Khabbaza said. "And now it's like being given oxygen."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Meredith Shin, Jonathan Rozoff

 BODY:
Meredith Suejung Shin and Jonathan Mark Rozoff were married yesterday at Blantyre, an inn in Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Donald Pollock officiated; a Korean cultural wedding celebration was held earlier in the day.
Mrs. Rozoff, 27, is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree from the University of Pennsylvania. She graduated from the University of California at Berkeley. She is a daughter of Dr. Sookja Shin and Dr. Dongsoo Shin of Santa Ana, Calif. Her mother is an anesthesiologist at Queen of Angels-Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center in Hollywood, Calif., and her father is a general surgeon in Los Angeles. 
 Mr. Rozoff, 35, is a vice president and the manager of the Washington office of Cornerstone Research, a finance and economics consulting firm. He graduated from Brown University and received an M.B.A. degree from Penn. He is the son of Jane and Herbert Rozoff of Highland Park, Ill. His father owns a public relations firm in Northbrook, Ill., bearing his name.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Rites of Survivorship

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT was fitting that this financial revelation came in church.
During a recent service, our minister honored the people who have been members of the congregation for at least 50 years. As he called their names, they stood at their pews, some with the aid of canes. Almost all of them were women. 
 I looked at my wife, Christine, sitting next to me, and I suddenly realized that she could be among the honorees someday and that I would not likely be standing next to her. The odds are that Christine, a television reporter, will outlive me by a good stretch.
I leaned over and whispered my thoughts to her, and we spent the rest of the service holding hands. I was sitting in that church trying to figure out how we were going to save for our children's college education -- and still have enough for Christine when she's going to church solo.
Not a very romantic notion, but a prospect that financial experts say baby boomers must consider. After all, the Census Bureau says that in 1997, some 46 percent of all women 65 and older were widows, while only 16 percent of men that age were widowers. And if wives indeed outlive their husbands, the family's assets must outlive the husbands, too.
HAVING a sound financial strategy is an obvious first step. Like many other financial planners, Elaine Bedel of Indianapolis recommends conventional investments first, with life insurance a possible supplement. If couples think that their assets will not last long enough to provide for a surviving wife, they can buy insurance to cover the shortfall. She favors level term policies that can offer hundreds of thousands of dollars in coverage at the same, or level, premium, for as long as 30 years.
Insurance agents often recommend whole life insurance and variable annuities, which offer both investment returns and death benefits. But financial planners, citing the fees and tax complications, say many people would be better off buying cheaper term life insurance while using their other funds for conventional investments.
Even a solid financial plan can weaken if one partner is not a participant, though. Often, one spouse takes charge, and even in the 1990's, it's usually the husband.
Keith Phelps, 53, a vice president of employee benefit sales at Conseco Risk Management in Carmel, Ind., had always managed his family's assets. He had the expertise and his wife lacked the interest. His father had died young, so he knew the importance of planning ahead. Recently, Mr. Phelps asked his wife, Kay, to accompany him to visit Ms. Bedel.
"While I still had time to do something about it, I wanted to make sure we had our finances on track," he said. "I wanted my wife to be more involved. I was concerned that if something happened to me, she wouldn't know where to start financially."
Ms. Phelps, 53, an administrator of a scholarship program for the Independent Colleges of Indiana in Indianapolis, found the meeting useful, but still counts on her husband. "He's so conscientious, and such a good husband and parent," she said. "I guess I have always had so much confidence in his love and caring for me that I knew everything would be taken care of."
Mr. Phelps now carries about $1.25 million of life insurance, mostly term insurance. He plans to cut back, sharply though not entirely, as he nears a retirement he intends to finance with his investments. "I've been in the insurance industry for 30 years and have a loyalty to the product, so I am reluctant to give it up," he said.
But how much money will a widow need? The more men think about it, the thriftier they might become today to provide their wives with more security tomorrow. Assuming continued low inflation, Ms. Bedel said that if a man who is 45 today lives to 65, and his wife outlives him by 10 years, she will need $750,000, assuming living expenses of $50,000 a year. If she outlives him by 20 years, the total rises to $1.2 million.
To reach those totals, a Mr. Wonderful must immediately start saving $1,250 or $2,000, respectively, a month or invest $150,000 or $250,000 now and get an 8 percent return until he dies.
So get busy, guys.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 10; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 499 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ELMHURST -- UPDATE;
Multiplex Choice Question: Who's on First?

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR 

 BODY:
For the past year, homeowners living near the Queens Center Mall have been fighting plans for two multiplexes within five blocks of each other. While one of those projects seems to have fallen through, residents are now keeping their eyes on yet another developer's plan, this one for a 3,200-seat theater atop a nearby Stern's department store.
Word that the developer, Forest City Ratner, had entered the race to put up the first multiplex in the area further stoked the anger of local residents. "Why do we need more movie theaters shoved down our throats when the community is screaming we don't want them?" said Maura Mullen, a member of Community Board 4 who serves on its zoning and land use committee and on a borough task force studying the potential impact of various proposed projects, including expansion of the mall. 
 At a community board committee meeting Tuesday, the executive vice president and general counsel of the city's Economic Development Corporation, Michael Carey, said research by the city and the theater industry showed a shortage of movie screens in Queens. But apparently not enough to support more than one multiplex, he said. "That's why there's such a rush," Mr. Carey said.
Until recently, the Mattone Group of College Point and Proto Industries of Elmhurst were both vying to put up a theater. Mattone is collaborating with Loews Cineplex Entertainment, which is owned by Sony, to build an 18-screen theater on a municipal parking lot between 59th Avenue and the Long Island Expressway, near the mall. The project, which needs city approval, is under official review. As part of it, Mattone would demolish the four-screen Elmwood Theater, off Queens Boulevard, and Loews would give the property to St. John's Queens Hospital.
Proto Industries and AMC Entertainment, meanwhile, had planned a 30-screen theater on a parking lot behind the Georgia Diner on Queens Boulevard and 55th Avenue. The diner's owner, Dimitrios Kaloidis, is an investor in Proto Industries. But on Wednesday, a spokesman for AMC, Sonny Stuffle, said the company was "not interested in that site anymore."
In March, a lawyer representing Forest City Ratner announced that the developer wanted to build a theater above Stern's, directly across 55th Avenue from the Georgia Diner. The lawyer, Jesse Masyr, said the project did not need city approval. On Wednesday, he said Forest City was also planning to build a shopping plaza on the lot behind the diner.
But a spokeswoman for Forest City Ratner, Joyce Baumgarten, said later that the retail plans for the lot behind the Georgia Diner were "on hold." On Thursday, she said that plans for the Stern's store would include a shopping center "with movies as a possibility."
Mr. Carey, who sits on the borough task force and whose agency is negotiating the sale of the city land to the Mattone Group, said the shifting plans were "a little bit like a slippery eel -- it's hard to get our hands around." RICHARD WEIR

LENGTH: 2913 words

HEADLINE: Wedding or Wipe-Out?

BYLINE: BySTEPHANIE STROM and KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
A CANDID version of the advice that the Ford Motor Company might offer its competitor, Renault S.A., on making an investment in a Japanese car company would probably be something like this: Get ready for a long, hard trek, because the payoff won't come quickly.
Ford's 20-year, $624 million odyssey with a Japanese car maker, the Mazda Motor Corporation, has so far produced a lot of headaches. But since Renault has already plunked down $5.4 billion to buy a 36.8 percent stake in the sputtering Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, avoiding the potential potholes is no longer an option. 
 So what lessons has Ford learned that might be useful to Renault? Grasp authority and hang onto it for dear life. Expect nasty surprises. Hand responsibility for a turnaround to your partner and its employees. Respect the sacred cows, but don't kowtow to them.
And read the life story of Mother Teresa, for hers is the sort of tenacity and forbearance that you will need.
These principles have led to what industry executives regard as the beginning of a turnaround at Mazda's headquarters and sprawling factories in Hiroshima. The company has gained market share in Japan despite slipping sales and an extremely weak domestic car market; in the fiscal year ended March 31, it posted its first overall profit, including the performance of subsidiaries, in six years. Operating profits doubled, and, thanks to a more than $2 billion reduction in costs, the break-even point for Mazda alone, exclusive of subsidiaries, has plummeted almost 40 percent.
All of this has been accomplished without the cultural clashes that many people expected when Ford took control of Mazda in 1996 after 17 years as a major stockholder. After all, international auto mergers have a history of ending badly, with the two best-known examples involving Renault: the managerial chaos at the American Motors Corporation, which Renault controlled through most of the 1980's and sold to Chrysler in 1987, and Renault's failed merger with Volvo of Sweden in 1993.
Not surprisingly, Renault and Nissan executives have been trying to understand why Ford and Mazda have gotten along so much better. "That relationship between Ford and Mazda is very good, and that is one example of two cultures working," Yoshikazu Hanawa, the chief executive of Nissan, said in an interview.
Indeed, it is clear that the French are trying to follow Ford's blueprint. Ford increased its stake in Mazda in 1996 by giving it cash for new shares, and Mazda spent the cash to reduce debt, bankroll vehicle-development programs and meet other urgent financial needs. Now Nissan has issued new shares to Renault and has plans for a similar kinds of spending.
Also following Ford's lead, Renault is trying to combine its product lineups with its Japanese partner's to eliminate duplication, but without sending lots of managers to Japan. "It is not about merging corporate structures; it is about working together to develop and sell cars, which is not quite the same thing," said Louis Schweitzer, chairman of Renault.
Still, the rapport between Ford and Mazda obscures an awkward fact that can only trouble Renault's shareholders: Ford has made little money on its Japanese investment and is unlikely to make much anytime soon. Rather, Ford has behaved to some extent as an indulgent sugar daddy, willing to bail out its Japanese partner and providing gentle nudges rather than risking blunt action that might upset managers at Mazda's headquarters.
Ford, eight times the size of Mazda, is the world's second-largest company in sales, after General Motors, so it can afford to make generously financed, long-term bets on the Japanese market. Renault does not have that luxury. It is slightly smaller than Nissan in sales and less than one-third the size of Ford. Nissan's problems are bigger than Mazda's ever were, mainly because Nissan has continued to bleed financially as the Japanese auto market has crumbled over the last three years, while Ford has taken some steps to stanch Mazda's losses.
Nonetheless, Mr. Schweitzer, delighted at the scope of his deal, declared soon after the ink was dry in March that it would offer a "shortcut to the world growth status we were looking for." If Ford's experience is any guide, however, the road ahead of Renault may be more of a meandering detour.
 
Grab the Wheel
For a long time, Ford's investment in Mazda, starting in 1979 with the purchase of a 25 percent stake for $140 million, amounted to little more than an expensive visitor's pass for Detroit engineers and managers to tour Japanese factories. One of Ford's goals was to figure out why Japanese auto makers seemed able to build more reliable and affordable cars than American auto makers, and it did pick up valuable tips on quality and efficiency. But it had little success in influencing Mazda's overall strategy -- failing, for example, to persuade Mazda not to produce cars that competed directly with Ford models.
Through the first 17 years of the partnership, in fact, Mazda executives largely ignored their American partners. Indeed, in the early 90's, Mazda went on a panicked spending spree, building a modern factory for the equivalent of several hundred million dollars and opening three new sales divisions while the Japanese economy tumbled into its worst recession since World War II.
Senior Mazda executives appointed by Ford, meanwhile, were not even invited to key meetings and did not always receive full information about Mazda's activities, said Henry D. G. Wallace, a career Ford executive who served as Mazda's executive vice president in the mid-1990's.
The situation changed in 1996, when Ford spent $484 million to raise its holdings to 33.4 percent after Mazda found itself losing money and struggling to meet its debt payments. By itself, such a stake usually does not confer control in Japan. But Ford imposed a crucial condition on its investment: that it have the right to appoint Mazda's president.
Mr. Wallace got the job, becoming the first foreigner to oversee a Japanese auto maker. And he was no figurehead. At Mazda, as in most large Japanese companies, whoever is president is virtually an absolute monarch; his wishes rarely go unfulfilled, no matter how unreasonable, unprofitable or ill-conceived. No longer, Mr. Wallace said, was he outside the loop. He was the loop.
Ford also had a powerful ally in Sumitomo bank, Mazda's main lender. Sumitomo and Ford had a close, longstanding relationship; it was Sumitomo officials, for example, not Mazda executives, who convinced Ford to make its initial investment in Mazda, and it was Sumitomo officials who put Ford on a white horse to rescue Mazda in 1996.
"What Ford wanted to see was that the relationship with Mazda would go smoothly, and when it was necessary, we did talk to Mazda to insure its cooperation," said Sotoo Tatsumi, the retired Sumitomo chairman who first approached Ford in the early 70's, when he was a general manager. "Until a few years ago, not all the people at Mazda welcomed Ford."
The former Ford managers who are now Mazda executives consider the Sumitomo relationship crucial to their success. "It's not just Ford and Mazda at work here," James E. Miller, Mr. Wallace's successor as Mazda's president, often says. "It's Ford, Mazda and Sumitomo."
Though Renault's 36.8 percent stake in Nissan is slightly larger than Ford's holdings in Mazda, Renault does not appear likely to wield as much control. Renault will be installing Carlos Ghosn, one of its best executives, at Nissan this summer, but he will be the chief operating officer, and while Nissan's executive vice presidents will report to him, he will report to Mr. Hanawa.
 
Confront the Unexpected
Ask top American or European auto executives about their Japanese rivals these days, and they are likely to repeat dark rumors about how much debt the Japanese companies have -- and how much of it lurks in hidden business partnerships.
The extent of Nissan's liabilities off the balance sheet apparently had a lot to do with a decision by DaimlerChrysler A.G. not to invest in the company. But Renault says it has not been scared by what it has found in poring over Nissan's books.
There are many stories in the auto industry about how much debt Ford might have discovered at Mazda after taking control, mostly at dealerships that were owned by Mazda. Kaoru Kurata, an auto analyst at Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd., estimates that Mazda's dealership-related debts may be as high as $3.66 billion.
Ford executives say their full year of research before taking control adequately documented these debts. But Gary K. Hexter, a Ford manager who is now Mazda's chief financial officer, acknowledged that there had been some surprises elsewhere. "Yes, we've found some liabilities that hadn't been adequately identified, both at Mazda and at the subsidiary companies," he said. "It's inevitable."
William C. Ford Jr., chairman of Ford Motor, said there had not been any major shocks. "We have a very firm idea of where Mazda is," he added.
To prevent any future shocks, however, Mr. Hexter has the thankless task of trying to bring order to Mazda's books, pulling together figures on roughly 180 affiliates and subsidiaries. He has established borrowing limits; he also requires pre-approval of major new spending and reviews new business proposals.
"We have made a lot of progress, but it has been slower in the domestic subsidiaries and dealerships," he said. "There's such a huge range of businesses, which makes it difficult to manage them centrally."
 
Set Goals That Stick
Ford executives have long believed that there is nothing like tangible success to help win friends and allies. So the Ford managers dispatched to Mazda have made a practice of setting all sorts of targets and then making it clear that they expect them to be met.
That is a big change for Mazda, said Kei Kado, a director in charge of product development planning and international business planning. "Most Japanese workers would feel that a target is a sort of challenge," Mr. Kado said. "But the people from Ford regard it as a commitment -- and in Japan, if you don't meet your commitments, you put a knife in your stomach."
One of his tasks was to achieve a 40 percent reduction in the variable costs of car production -- the expenses left after subtracting things like profit margins, fixed costs, advertising and the price of logistics from the price of a car. He accomplished that, and now Mr. Miller is asking him to save 30 percent to 40 percent more.
Mazda's dealers and directors were shocked when he began pushing a plan that consolidated back-office dealership operations regionally, eliminated unprofitable shops and pared the number of dealer chains from five to three. All of Mazda's Japanese directors opposed the plan, but Mr. Miller persisted. Then the results came in. "Our monthly expenses went down by nearly 100 million yen," exclaimed Yoichi Suzuki, president of the consolidated dealership operation in Saitama prefecture, still somewhat in awe of the results.
"Their approach is brilliant in terms of business," Mr. Suzuki said of the Ford officials. "They are energetic, speedy and clear about what they want. The Japanese style is more ambiguous, dependent on mood and human relationships."
By now, though, Mazda's Japanese managers have become accustomed to once-startling changes. Among other things, Mazda has eliminated the time-honored Japanese practice of shuffling unneeded white-collar workers off to affiliates for two-year job stints, rather than laying them off. Instead, it now dispatches them to its own assembly line, where staffing is relatively lean.
 
Be Sensitive; Show Spine
In the United States, Ford has been criticized for not moving faster at Mazda to reduce capacity, cut jobs and use other tools favored by American companies overhauling their operations. In Japan, however, it has been praised for the same cautious approach. "I did not give them any specific advice," Sumitomo's Mr. Tatsumi said, "but I knew Ford understood it would need a soft touch."
Although Mazda has eliminated about 6,000 jobs, it has winnowed its ranks through attrition, early retirement and leaner hiring practices, softening the effects on the Hiroshima area, where the company is crucial to the economy.
But Ford's genius has been in differentiating the truly sacred cows from the merely privileged ones. Consider taxicabs. In 1995, Mazda was producing cars for sale to taxicab companies, a business dominated by Toyota and Nissan, and it wasn't making money on the operation. Mr. Wallace's suggestion that Mazda exit the cab business met with protest from Japanese executives. But the cries were quickly silenced when he asked whether they wanted to be riding in Mazda taxis after the company went bankrupt.
At the insistence of managers sent from Ford, Mazda also slowed research into rotary engines, a product for which the company was famous but which had limited usefulness. "That was painful, because a lot of people felt it was the heart and soul of the company," said Mr. Wallace, now group vice president for Asia-Pacific operations and affiliations at Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich.
To soften this sort of pain, Ford's executives have tried to adopt local customs whenever possible. Mr. Miller has stunned his Japanese colleagues with his whole-hearted embrace of the after-hours carousing that is an integral part of Japanese business. His stamina in keeping up with the parties that migrate from restaurant to bar to bar has astonished Mazda employees. And like Japanese executives, Mr. Miller often takes to the public-address system to rally the troops, reading haltingly in Japanese to make announcements, issue exhortations and pay compliments for jobs well done.
His cosmopolitan ways reflect one of Ford's biggest assets at Mazda -- its unusually large corps of globe-trotting executives. Mr. Miller is an American, but his curriculum vitae reads like that of the most seasoned international executive: president of Ford New Zealand from 1989 to 1993; head of Eastern Europe and exports at Ford Europe to 1994; president of Ford's South African subsidiary until 1997, when he joined Mazda.
Four of the six group vice presidents at Ford grew up outside the United States, including Mr. Wallace, a Scot. So did Jacques Nasser, the new chief executive and president, who was raised in Lebanon and Australia and speaks fluent Arabic, French, Spanish and Portuguese, in addition to English.
Mr. Ghosn, the top Renault executive going to Nissan, was born in Brazil, and the company has long had a large and successful business in South America. But Renault's leaders are clearly worried that they may be short of top managers with international experience. "Probably we would look outwards for a few new talents at Renault," said Mr. Schweitzer, the chairman.
 
Get Ready to Wait
While it appears that Ford has pulled off at least the beginnings of a turnaround at Mazda, the true benefits of its investment remain to be seen. "While we've climbed mountains," Mr. Miller said, "there are higher mountains in the range to climb."
The first synergies will not appear until the end of next year, when the two companies are expected to begin producing sport utility vehicles with common suspensions, engines, transmissions and other components.
In the meantime, its Mazda stake gives Ford a foothold in the Japanese market, which can only prove valuable whenever car sales rebound there. Ford officials hope to sell Mazdas in other Asian markets, as well, though they have not developed a strategy since the recent economic turmoil.
With these benefits hard to measure in dollars and cents, it is difficult to make a case for the wisdom of Ford's investment. The company got a bargain in 1979 by securing a quarter interest in Mazda for the equivalent of $318 million in today's dollars; that is a pittance compared with the $6.5 billion that Ford paid in March for Volvo's car-making operations, a smaller but more consistently profitable business than Mazda. And Ford has also collected $100 million in dividends from Mazda over the years.
Yet if Ford had invested the money it sank into Mazda in 1979 in its own stock instead, the shares would now be worth $8.4 billion, a 6,000 percent return. And for $8.4 billion, Ford could buy controlling stakes in several Mazda-sized companies today.
Still, many auto executives are betting that the industry will eventually consolidate into five or six big companies. Each of these leviathans will need sizable operations in Japan. And given the impossibility of starting from scratch there, American and European auto makers are going to be in business with the Japanese one way or another.
By that reasoning, Ford's years of losses at Mazda might someday not seem like such a waste of money. And Renault, in taking an even bigger gamble than Ford, can only hope to have as much success.
Mr. Schweitzer, conscious of his company's failures in the past, said he is determined to form a close partnership with Nissan. His Japanese partner may not be a beauty now, but he nonetheless uses the language of love to describe his plans for the courtship.
"To build a good relationship," he said, "you should not look at each other but do things together and look in the same direction."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1389 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Yes, Investors Panicked. But Brazil Didn't.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
PRESIDENT FERNANDO HENRIQUE CARDOSO traveled to the United States early this month and everywhere he went, the same people who just four months before were worrying about an Asian-style meltdown of Brazil's economy praised him for his astute leadership. At the White House, President Clinton led the chorus, expressing relief at "the substantial progress" Brazil has made in recovering from the fiscal crisis, which led to a 40 percent devaluation of its currency in January.
During his tour Mr. Cardoso also stopped in New York, where he was peppered with questions about Brazil's implementation of a $41.5 billion economic rescue package backed by the International Monetary Fund. Left unaddressed, however, was a more fundamental issue: To what extent did the crisis reflect genuine deficiencies in the Brazilian economy and to what degree was it a self-fulfilling prophecy, brought on by panic and myopia in the global capital market itself?
At this juncture, no one denies that Brazil's currency, the real, had become overvalued against the dollar and needed to be adjusted. Throughout his first term, Mr. Cardoso's main policy goal had been to bring inflation, traditionally the country's biggest bugaboo, under control; that made him eager to avoid any sharp and sudden devaluation and the surge of higher prices that would follow it. 
 But Brazilians, from Government officials to the average citizen, are increasingly convinced that a series of "simplistic comparisons" and "undue generalizations," as Minister of Finance Pedro Malan put it in a recent interview, made the situation last January worse than it might have been and overlooked the country's underlying strengths.
Now that the world's eighth largest economy has begun to right itself, for example, all the talk about "global contagion" seems particularly exaggerated. Except in the estimation of some traders abroad, Brazil was never really comparable to Indonesia, where a family dynasty enriched itself at the country's expense. Nor was it equivalent to Russia, where the collapse of a Communist state has allowed a mafia to seize control of the economy, or even Mexico, where one corrupt and ossified political party has wielded power for 70 years.
"Wall Street needs a geography lesson," Marcus Vinicius Pratini de Moraes, a former Cabinet minister who is now president of the Brazilian Association of Exporters, said recently. "A bank goes bust in Moscow and they sell their Brazilian shares? They should go back to school."
Too late for Brazil and its 165 million people, who have had to endure lost jobs and recession since January, stock markets around the world seemed to recognize that error this month.
Granted, speculative pressure on Argentina and its currency last week generated some turbulence here and in other Latin American countries. But Boris Yeltsin's dismissal of Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov in Russia caused barely a ripple. Indeed, as the announcement was being made in Moscow, the Sao Paulo stock market rose to an 18-month high, fueled largely by the return of foreign money, and the Brazilian Government was able to announce the sixth cut in interest rates in the past two months.
Other measures of Brazil's strengths are, if anything, more revealing. In contrast to the traumas that have wracked Russia and the Asian tigers recently, Latin America's largest country has in just 15 years successfully made the transition, without violence or social trauma, from military dictatorship to democracy. Its democracy is often raucous, as is demonstrated by a current Congressional investigation into insider trading that took place at the time of January's devaluation. But even though Mr. Cardoso has to work within a system of checks and balances more restrictive than the systems facing his Asian, Russian and Mexican counterparts, he has time and again delivered on promises to restructure the Brazilian state and economy.
After the agreement with the I.M.F. was signed last November, investors and officials abroad immediately began to view a reduction of Brazil's often-generous social security benefits as a test of Mr. Cardoso's resolve. Though the Brazilian Congress dithered for two months, it eventually passed the legislation, which requires a constitutional amendment. As political leaders here have noted, none of the countries that have been hectoring Brazil on this matter -- not Germany, not France, not Italy, and certainly not the United States -- have themselves begun to come to grips with the issue at home.
In reality, the steps Brazil had taken to modernize its economy even before the January crisis were substantial, more than what many other countries have done in decades. When he took office in 1995, Mr. Cardoso inherited a highly protectionist economy. But he quickly lowered tariffs, allowing trade and competition to surge, and sold off one inefficient state-run monopoly after another: ports, electricity, mining, telecommunications, railways, banks and more.
Mr. Cardoso maintained that course, showing unusual political courage, even when a harsh recession set in after the eruption of the Asian crisis in 1997, threatening both his re-election and efforts to stabilize both prices and the real. And Brazilian voters were mature enough to resist opposition blandishments of short-term relief in favor of what they saw as the long-term payoff that would make their country an economic power: stability and growth.
The late Carroll Quigley, the Georgetown University professor whom Mr. Clinton has cited as his most influential teacher, used to define capitalism as "a system of accounting that ignores social costs." Judging from Brazil's recent experience, the converse is also true: market-driven philosophies are unwilling to grant credit for social gains that cannot immediately be measured.
TO Riordan Roett, an expert on the Western Hemisphere at Johns Hopkins University, Mr. Cardoso's most significant achievement may be that during his first term "more Brazilians were lifted from poverty than in the past 50 years." That feat, a result of the same inflation control and currency stabilization program that came under speculative pressure in January, has turned millions of poor Brazilians into consumers and makes the country more attractive to foreign investors hunting for new markets.
At the height of the crisis, a new study appeared here showing that between 1994 and 1998, high school enrollments in Brazil increased 37 percent, as parents realized that they no longer needed to yank their children out of classes and send them to work. "These are extraordinary numbers for so short a period," a "gigantic leap," Claudio de Moura Castro, an economist who is the co-author of the study, wrote in the news magazine Veja. In the long term, of course, they also represent a social investment that will benefit foreign companies in the form of better-educated workers who will, as a consequence, earn higher salaries and be able to spend more money.
A generation ago, Charles de Gaulle visited here and rendered a verdict on Brazilian society so stinging that it is still frequently recalled, always with chagrin. "This is not a serious country," the French leader said. Brazil in 1999 may still be associated primarily with soccer and samba, but in a perverse way the January crisis was a yardstick of how far the country has come: Thirty-five years ago, even an economic collapse here would have had little impact elsewhere. Today, for better or worse, Brazil matters.
At a conference in Chicago earlier this month, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, cautioned that Brazil is "not quite out of the woods," a warning that a suddenly euphoric market now seems prepared to discount. Investors snapped up more than $2 billion in Brazilian bonds issued last month, and so much foreign investment is flowing back into the country that the Government has had to adjust its estimate upward to as high as $20 billion for the year.
Mr. Cardoso himself, however, ever the realist, appears to be as unmoved by the sudden recovery of confidence in Brazil as he was by its January jitters. "The Brazilian situation was never as bad as it was presented then, and it is not as good as it is presented now," he said in a recent interview. So let the market beware.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 821 words

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Rates Are Rising. Are the Bears Near?

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IS Goldilocks dead, choking on her porridge, or merely suffering indigestion?
People have long wondered just how long the "not too hot, not too cold" environment that has amazed economists and nourished financial markets for years could last. Recent events suggest we may be in the introductory phase of a very different story. 
 The consumer price report for April, which showed an increase of 0.7 percent, hit on May 14. Then, last week, the Federal Reserve Board, for the first time in more than two years, said it was more inclined to raise interest rates than to lower them.
One could argue that inflation is entitled to one bad month every now and then. And since 1996, the Fed has adopted a bias toward tighter monetary policy 14 times, but has actually raised interest rates only once.
Still, with stocks at high levels, there is little margin for error. Kevin Parke, chief equity officer at MFS Investment Management in Boston, talked last week about the possibility of a post-Goldilocks economy.
 
Q. Bond traders have been pushing up interest rates for some time now. Is this just a blip, or are we in an upward trend?
 
A. The fact is that bond traders overreacted to last fall's global financial crisis by pushing bond yields down too far. Now you are getting a bounce back up, but I think it is best measured from a floor of 5.25 percent, not the 4.75 percent level they reached during the crisis. We think the correct range for bond yields is between 5.25 percent and 6 percent.
The fact that bond yields went through 5.90 percent is fantastic, because it means that the market is not complacent. Bond traders are a policing mechanism, keeping a lid on inflation and economic growth.
 
Q. So do you still believe in Goldilocks?
 
A. The rise in bond yields and the Fed's announcement last week insures a continuation of the Goldilocks scenario. It will help keep us in the middle ground we have occupied for some time.
 
Q. The Fed didn't actually say it was going to raise rates, and many analysts say it is unlikely to do so this year. Do you agree?
 
A. I would be surprised if the Fed didn't eventually raise interest rates this year. As international economies recover, that puts more pressure on rates. And one of the main reasons the Fed cut rates three times last year was to help the world financial system. If they truly believe the patient is now healthy, they can turn off the I.V. machine.
We are not worried about consumer inflation, because there is no indication you can pass on price increases at all. In fact, companies are still cutting prices. Just look at what Amazon.com did with best sellers last week. And the competition followed.
 
Q. Does a change in rates warrant a change in how investors pick stocks?
 
A. You want to find companies that can thrive in a relatively slow-growth, low-inflation environment and companies with managements that can take advantage of opportunities. This will be more of a stock-picking market, not one you just throw money at.
 
Q. Can the hot growth stocks that have led the market thrive in this environment?
 
A. You have to be very careful what you pay for high-quality growth stocks.
This market has been helped by earnings, but it has also been helped by higher valuations for growth stocks. If interest rates are rising, I don't think these sorts of price-to-earnings multiples can be justified.
Stocks are the longest-duration financial instrument we have. They are like zero-coupon bonds. When rates are stable, price-to-earnings multiples will be stable. When rates are falling, which they have been for some time, the ratio will rise. The last thing you want to pay is 40 times earnings for a company whose growth rate is slowing.
 
Q. Name a few companies that fit your criteria for purchase at this point.
 
A. In the pharmaceutical area, a sector where most will experience a slowdown in growth, we see some companies whose growth rates are accelerating, like American Home Products and Pharmacia Upjohn.
In industrials, United Technologies will continue to be a very strong performer. About 25 percent of their business is in Asia, which will show an improvement.
 
Q. A number of companies saw the crisis in Asia as a chance to buy local businesses at bargain prices. Do you like any of them?
 
A. One industry that will benefit from those who bought on the cheap in Asia is investment banking. Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Citigroup all gained market share in these parts of the world.
 
Q. Some market forecasters say that with rates rising, a correction of 5 to 10 percent is quite possible in the next month to six weeks. Do you share that concern?
 
A. I don't know about the near term, but I do think the market is vulnerable, because there is an excess of speculation in the market. Things have been too easy for too long.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Check the Fed's Pulse. Call Us in the Long Term.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
JAMES W. PAULSEN, the chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, says he is only tilting. Marshall Acuff, the equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, is just moving at the margin. And Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers, is only trimming his expectations for returns.
These three strategists and others all had to review their outlooks last week to accommodate the fact that the Federal Reserve is now leaning toward raising its short-term interest rate target, the Federal funds rate. While no one knows when, or even if, the Fed will raise rates, the policy makers have made it clear that if inflation does tick up, they will move quickly. 
 But according to these strategists, this bias toward higher interest rates will not force them to make big changes in what they have been doing.
Even if the rally does not run wild, these analysts still expect stocks to rise. Mr. Applegate is betting that the Fed will not increase rates to slow growth and curb inflation. Mr. Paulsen doesn't think the Fed will have to raise rates -- though he says it is still a possibility. Mr. Acuff thinks any rate increase will be modest.
Mr. Paulsen has shifted his asset allocation slightly, to benefit from the bond rally he expects when it becomes clear that inflation will not get out of hand. So he is cutting his allocation to stocks to 60 percent, from 70 percent, while raising bonds to 40 percent, from 30 percent.
"I am not so negative on stocks," he said, explaining this shift. "I just think that bonds might meet them tick for tick."
He is also suggesting a small shift in the composition of stock portfolios. He thinks economic growth will slow, partly because of the rise in oil prices, the slower growth in real wages and the slump in mortgage refinancings. All three will curb consumer spending, which has been the driving force of the economy's still rapid growth.
For Mr. Paulsen, a slowdown makes growth stocks, especially the big-name companies that can produce solid earnings in a weaker economy, attractive again. He also likes financial stocks, which will benefit from declining market rates, and consumer staples, which also do well in a slower-growth environment.
But that does not mean he is dumping all his cyclical stocks, which have done very well this year. "I believe you should tilt in the direction you think the market is going," Mr. Paulsen said."But I am not selling all my cyclicals. I know I can be wrong."
Mr. Applegate is also shifting out of cyclicals and into growth stocks. "The cyclical trade has come and gone," he said. But he is holding his asset allocation at 80 percent stocks and 20 percent bonds.
The recent rise in interest rates has curbed the expansion in valuations that would help stocks move higher, he said, but corporate earnings forecasts are improving. His firm just raised its forecast for 1999 operating earnings gains to 10 percent, from 8 percent. His year-end target for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is unchanged at 1,450, 9 percent above Friday's close.
And Mr. Applegate would not think of trying to shift out of stocks to sidestep a slump. He did not even do that last summer and fall, when market indexes plunged 19 percent or more, because he worried that he would not get back in quickly enough.
Why so sanguine? Because there is confidence that the Fed will not let inflation get out of hand, which means that the long-term still looks fine. And because the investing environment had, in fact, changed long before the Fed announcement. Investors had worried most of this year about a Fed rate increase because the economy refused to slow down. The jump in long-term interest rates by a percentage point, to 5.92 percent since December, was a result.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, said, "If you have been an investor paying attention, there was no major news this week and the response of the markets says that." The Dow lost just 0.77 percent, while bonds rallied, with long-term yields falling to 5.75 percent.
What investors should focus on, she added, is the positive side of the Fed announcement. As she phrased it, the Fed said: "Look folks, our economy is strong and the rest of the world is out of danger."
