HEADLINE: Commencement;
Fordham Class Hears Magician and Peacemaker

 BODY:
In 1974, David Copperfield performed a vanishing act three weeks into his freshman year at Fordham University, dropping out to take the lead in a Chicago-based musical, The Magic Man.
Yesterday, at Fordham's 154th commencement, Mr. Copperfield completed the trick, reappearing on campus to deliver an address to the graduating class of 1999. 
 Mr. Copperfield's parents attended the ceremony for 3,654 graduates at the university's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. After Mr. Copperfield received an honorary doctorate, he said his parents were especially pleased -- they had always wanted him to become a doctor.
George Mitchell, the former United States Senator who helped broker a 1998 peace agreement in Ireland, also received an honorary degree. Mr. Mitchell told the students, "Real fulfillment in your life will come not from leisure, not from idleness, not from self-indulgence, but rather from striving with all your physical and spiritual might for a worthwhile objective."
Graduates applauded Mr. Mitchell, but many seemed more interested in levity than striving. "How 'bout a trick?" they shouted as Mr. Copperfield finished his speech.
 
Marist College
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 22 -- Fred Rogers, the creator and star of "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood" on public television, addressed 1,050 graduates and received an honorary degree at Marist College's 53d commencement today. Also receiving honorary degrees were the Director of the Peace Corps, Mark D. Gearan, and Dr. Anne E. Dyson, a children's advocate.
Though Mr. Rogers, 71, had prepared a 15-minute speech, the sight of an electronic piano on stage inspired a quick change.
"They have a little piano over here," he said to the graduates, who were already clapping with enthusiasm. "Do you want to sing?"
Mr. Rogers smiled and began: "It's a beautiful day in the neighborhood. A beautiful day for a neighbor. Would you be mine? Could you be mine?"
As more students joined in, Mr. Rogers shouted, "Good! Good for you!"
Mr. Rogers, an ordained Presbyterian minister, spoke of ethnic cleansing in Kosovo, the high school massacre in Littleton, Colo., and environmental destruction as he counseled graduates to make their choices carefully. And just as he says each day on television, Mr. Rogers assured the graduates that they were special, just by being themselves.
"It's such a good feeling to know you're alive," he finished, to applause that went on and on.
 
Bard College
 Graduates of Bard College in Annandale on Hudson, N.Y., were urged yesterday by Martha C. Nussbaum, a philosopher and scholar, to seek out "experiences of artful pain," as a way to "combat moral blindness and shape citizenship."
By exposing ourselves this way, Dr. Nussbaum, the Ernst Freund Professor of Law and Ethics at the University of Chicago, said, "We uncover our own weakness and acquire new motives to treat others decently."
At the college's 139th commencement, President Leon Botstein conferred 250 bachelor of arts degrees and approximately 50 master of arts, science and fine arts degrees. Honorary doctorates were awarded to Dr. Nussbaum, along with Anthony Alvarado, an educator; Chuck Close, an artist; Ornette Coleman, musician and composer; Ellen V. Futter, president of the American Museum of Natural History; David Landes, an economist, and Harvey Lichtenstein, performing arts executive at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

HEADLINE: City Council To Curtail Planned Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
City Council leaders announced yesterday that the State Legislature's repeal of the commuter tax had forced them to abandon proposals for at least $443 million in tax cuts for city residents, including $173 million worth of cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
The leaders said they had withdrawn plans to reduce the commercial rent tax and several other business taxes, as well as proposals to cut taxes paid by first-time home buyers. They also said the Council had rejected Mr. Giuliani's proposals to eliminate the sales tax on books, construction materials and clothing that costs more than $110, which would have saved taxpayers about $113 million a year. 
 Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said that he and Mr. Giuliani had no choice but to curtail their tax cut plans sharply, because the commuter tax repeal would cost the city $360 million in revenue next year and $400 million in 2001. The Speaker and the Mayor are negotiating a budget agreement, and say they hope to adopt a plan by early next month.
"We had worked for close to six months on coming together on a tax reduction package which would spur the economy," Mr. Vallone said yesterday in a news conference at City Hall, where Council members met to discuss the impact of the commuter tax repeal on Mr. Giuliani's $35.3 billion spending plan. "Now we have to, in 15 days, figure out how to readjust the entire budget."
Aides to Mr. Vallone and Mr. Giuliani said that despite the repeal, they still hoped to eliminate the sales tax on clothing that costs less than $110 and to provide a tax credit worth $48 million for the working poor. Other tax cut proposals that are still under consideration include a property tax reduction for owners of condominiums and co-ops, worth $166 million, and a tax credit for families who pay for child care.
While the Mayor and the Council usually negotiate a budget agreement together, the Council has the power to adopt a budget without the Mayor's consent. But Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, indicated yesterday that the Giuliani administration would probably not fight the Council's plan to abandon nearly half of Mr. Giuliani's $405 million tax cut package. "Their proposals are not inconsistent with what we are discussing during our negotiations," Mr. Lhota said.
Aides to Mr. Vallone also said yesterday that they hoped to restore the $165 million in cuts in city programs and services that Mr. Giuliani had proposed. But they said such restorations would be more difficult than usual because of the unexpected loss of the commuter tax revenue.
But Mr. Vallone said that with a $2.1 billion city surplus, he and the Mayor would almost certainly not resort to layoffs or further cuts in programs and services. "It's highly unlikely that we are going to do anything that is going to inflict unnecessary damage on the people of New York City," he said.

HEADLINE: Booming Job Market Draws Young Black Men Into Fold

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR with KIRSTEN B. MITCHELL 

 BODY:
For nearly three decades, in good times and in bad, young black men with little education and few skills lost ground. Facing high unemployment, falling pay and persistent discrimination, a depressingly large number never really joined the work force or drifted out of it, getting by on handouts, hustling or crime.
But now the nation's job boom is drawing many of these young men -- perhaps the most economically disadvantaged, socially alienated group in America -- back into the economic mainstream. 
 Low unemployment and tight labor markets have always encouraged upward mobility. The surprise, researchers say, is how dramatic the gains have been.
A new study of low-wage men in 322 metropolitan areas by Richard B. Freeman at Harvard University and William M. Rodgers 3d at the College of William and Mary shows that black men aged 16 to 24 with a high school education or less -- many saddled with prison records -- are working in greater numbers, earning bigger paychecks and committing fewer crimes than in the early 1990's.
"Poor blacks never lost faith in work, education and individual effort," said Jennifer L. Hochschild, a political scientist at Princeton University and author of "Facing Up to the American Dream: Race, Class and the Soul of the Nation." "What's different now is that they can do something about it."
Far too many young black men are still idle or in prison. But the surge in legitimate employment has gone hand in hand with a drop in criminal activity, which has long clouded the job prospects of young black men. Indeed, crime has fallen rapidly in regions where joblessness has fallen most.
In the 14 areas where unemployment has been below 4 percent in every year since 1992 -- places like the Raleigh-Durham area in North Carolina; Rochester, Minn., and Des Moines -- the percentage of young, less-educated black men who are working has jumped from 52 percent, to 64 percent. The figures exclude young men who are still in school and the 7 percent of those between the ages of 20 and 24 who are in prison. But the improvement does not simply reflect the fact that many of those with the worst job prospects are now behind bars.
"We used the variation across cities to see what might happen at a national level if we were able to get national unemployment below 4 percent for a long time," said Professor Rodgers, who pointed out that by 1998, 146 of the nation's 322 metropolitan areas had unemployment rates below 4 percent. In 1992, only 19 areas had jobless rates that low. "It allows us to see what kind of employment and wage gains these men might experience."
In 15 other metropolitan areas where unemployment fell by five percentage points or more -- places like Pittsfield, Mass., Flint, Mich., and Naples, Fla. -- the corresponding improvement was from 42 percent, to 51 percent. Uniformly, the gains for young black men outstripped the much more modest gains for all young men, including whites, and for black men in their prime working years.
Brian Burnett, 19, is typical of many young blacks who have benefited from the extended period of low unemployment in fast-growing parts of the United States. He graduated from an inner-city high school in Raleigh, N.C., in June 1997, when the local unemployment rate was 2.2 percent. After working at a series of temporary jobs for about a year and completing a federally financed job readiness program, he landed a $7- an-hour, full-time position as a front-desk clerk at an Embassy Suites hotel.
Now Mr. Burnett is planning to study hotel management part time with tuition help from his employer. "The sky's the limit," he said. "No one can hold me back but me."
Professor Freeman, one of the nation's top experts on black youth unemployment, said: "This shows how critical it is not to give up on these guys. If you give these kids a break, they come back."
The gains are coming at a time when affirmative action, preferential contracting for minorities and most job training programs are no longer expanding.
"The market is more powerful than any Government program," Professor Freeman said. "The question is: 'Can we keep it up?' "
In the sharply segregated 1950's -- hardly the best of times for young blacks -- there were more opportunities at the bottom of the economic ladder. Young blacks and young whites were equally likely to hold jobs, although young blacks' hourly pay was roughly one-third lower than that of whites. By the late 1960's, the earnings gap between young blacks and whites had narrowed to less than 10 percentage points, but the fraction of black youths with jobs had fallen sharply. At that point, the collapse in work among young black men in inner cities accelerated, the pay gap widened again, and neither the civil rights movement nor major Federal job training programs did much to reverse the devastation. The pay gap peaked in the early 1990's at more than 20 percentage points.
In the early 1990's, businesses drifted even farther away from cities, the computer revolution increased skill requirements, growing numbers of woman and immigrants competed for entry-level jobs, and the ranks of young black prison inmates continued to swell. To many people, the outlook for a turnaround in the job prospects of young black men seemed remote.
"They have so many strikes against them," said Hazel Logan, a grandmother of five who runs a jobs program in Raleigh. "Whatever the totem pole is, they are at the bottom."
Today, one of the most visible signs of change is on one basketball court at the Durham Y.M.C.A. Around 400 black men between ages 19 and 25 from the inner cities of Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill used to take part in a midnight basketball league where networking and interviewing tips were as much on the agenda as foul shots. Now, says James A. Johnson, director of the Urban Investment Strategies Center at the University of North Carolina, "We've had difficulty getting enough people to play because they are in the job market."
Michael Tavernise, manager of the Employment Security Commission office in Raleigh, said, "Employers are hiring people that two, three, five years ago they weren't hiring." The overall unemployment rate in the Raleigh-Durham region recently dipped to 1.5 percent.
As businesses struggle to fill jobs, other groups of poorly educated workers are reaping even bigger gains. Half of all single mothers, including many young black women, are working now compared with fewer than one-third at the start of the decade, according to David Ellwood, an economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University and a former adviser to President Clinton on welfare issues. He attributes the surge in work to new policies such as limits on welfare and pay subsidies for working parents as well as the vibrant job market. "It's unprecedented," he said. "Nothing like it has ever happened."
Few expect a revival of the naive optimism of the early 1960's, when some liberal policy makers predicted that just a few more years of strong economic growth would erase the problems of young black men. Those problems are still daunting. Although unemployment among young black men of all education levels is lower now than at the peak of the 1980's expansion -- 17 percent compared with 20 percent -- it is more than twice that for young white men.
And even though more young black men are staying in school longer and entering the work force later -- just like their white counterparts -- some 19 percent of all black men between ages 16 and 24 are not in school or working. That is a smaller proportion than in 1992, but still slightly higher than at the peak of the last expansion and twice the comparable figures for young white men.
"I see people I went to school with and I see them talking outside, hanging around, not doing anything," said Mr. Burnett, the hotel clerk.
Charles Murray, the conservative social analyst at the American Enterprise Institute and author of "Losing Ground: American Social Policy, 1950-1980" and, with Richard J. Herrnstein, "The Bell Curve: Intelligence and Class Structure in American Life," views the persistence of idleness during boom times as a sign that "the underclass is as big as it's ever been and may still be growing."
But these days few experts are as pessimistic as Mr. Murray.
One reason for cautious optimism is that overall unemployment has fallen further and stayed down longer than in the 1980's. The longer the labor markets stay tight, the more time the young have to acquire contacts, work experience and marketable skills with which to weather the next downturn. "The current job market is giving young men an opportunity to build up some confidence," Professor Rodgers said.
Another reason to expect some of the gains to last is that entry-level work has become more rewarding financially. Before the 1990's, pay for less educated men had been declining in real terms for more than two decades.
At the peak of the 1980's economic expansion, according to a now-classic survey conducted by Professor Freeman and Lawrence Katz, also at Harvard, more than half of young black men in hot job markets like Boston judged their prospects in the underground economy superior to any legitimate employment. Since 1992, by contrast, the hourly pay of young, less educated black men has climbed as much as 15 percent in the metropolitan areas with the tightest labor markets.
"There are still big racial differences in employment outcomes, but the improvements are encouraging because they show that these young men aren't totally isolated from the world of work," Ronald Ferguson, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government, said. "When the economy is hot enough, employers hire these folks."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Clemens Returns According To Form

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 22

 BODY:
Roger Clemens had waited 25 agonizing days for this day to arrive. While Clemens was on the disabled list, George Steinbrenner ignored Don Zimmer, Zimmer made incorrect predictions about Joe Torre's return as manager, Torre surprised everyone when he rejoined the team last Tuesday, and the Red Sox jumped over the Yankees into first place. Through it all, Clemens was merely an anxious spectator.
But that changed dramatically today as Clemens returned and helped the Yankees subdue the White Sox, 10-2, at Comiskey Park in Game 1 of a doubleheader. The Yankees almost forgot how he looked in his uniform, but Clemens returned and secured his 18th straight winning decision, establishing an American League record. And he reminded everyone why he was obtained and why he was able to give this plodding team a temporary boost. 
 Clemens's record was somewhat anticlimactic because he has had 10 no-decisions during the streak, including two this year in games in which the Yankees rescued him from defeat. But Clemens, a five-time Cy Young award winner, spoke glowingly about the mark after stifling Chicago on one earned run and six hits in six sharp innings. For Clemens, it was memorable to have 24 teammates congratulate him. For the Yankees, it was important that their ace was there to be congratulated.
"To pitch and to be undefeated for that long, that's pretty special," Clemens said. "Obviously, the guys helped me out in a couple of games I pitched. I'm sure if you look back there's some games I could have won and attained the streak just as easily earlier. I hope it continues. That means I'm doing the right things to help the team win." Clemens was not the most impressive pitcher at Comiskey today, however. That was Mike Sirotka, who limited the Yankees to two hits in eight innings in guiding the White Sox to a 2-1 victory in Game 2. Andy Pettitte, who defeated Sirotka, 2-1, last Sunday, was superb for seven innings, but Sirotka was better and exacted revenge.
The exciting game ended in controversy. After the Yankees parlayed three walks and a balk into their first run, Bill Simas replaced Bob Howry. With the bases loaded and two outs, Simas struck out the pinch-hitter Chili Davis on a 3-2 fastball that looked as if it was outside, enabling the White Sox to grab a split of the doubleheader. The Yankees, whose modest two-game winning streak fizzled, were upset with Umpire Tim Welke's call.
"That ball was not a strike," said Davis, who spiced his remarks with profanities. "Strike 2 was not a strike. Ain't no way I could hit that ball, strike 2 or strike 3. You don't dictate when the game ends. You play until the game is over."
Even Torre, who was pleased that Clemens and Pettitte combined to allow three earned runs in 13 innings, said, "It was a foot outside."
Buoyed by Jorge Posada's home run and five runs batted in and two-run homers from Tino Martinez and Bernie Williams in the opener, Clemens improved to 3-0 and now can pursue the major league record of 24 straight winning decisions by Carl Hubbell of the New York Giants (1936-37).
As excited as Torre was to see an offense that had mustered 14 runs in the last eight games explode for 10, the most critical aspect of the day was Clemens's 89-pitch effort.
Four days after the Yankees got their manager back, they got their ace back and his winning streak continued, shoving Cleveland's Johnny Allen and Baltimore's Dave McNally to the second line of the A.L. record book.
"You have to have a Hall of Fame-caliber guy," Torre said in describing the streak. "The whole thing about pitching is anyone can light it up for one or two starts. To do it over the course of a year, you have to be a superstar."
Fifteen years and two days after Clemens won his first game, he won his 236th to tie Whitey Ford, who is perhaps the best pitcher in Yankees history, for 49th on the career list. Clemens last lost on May 29, 1998, to Cleveland, and he will hurdle Ford soon.
"At this stage in my career, when I approach these guys, these great ones, the Hall of Famers, it's pretty mind-boggling," Clemens said. "You're happy about it. What can I say? Whitey Ford. What a great name. It's awesome."
One of Clemens's stickiest moments occurred when Mike Caruso tried to drag a bunt past him in the third. Clemens tumbled to his knees to field it and then threw to first for the out, but the Yankees worried about the left hamstring, which had been injured. But Clemens felt a cramp in his right hamstring and was relieved when it went away.
Clemens performed like the superstar that Torre says he is when Frank Thomas batted with men on first and second in the fifth. The Yankees were ahead, 6-2, but Thomas had three homers in 43 at-bats off Clemens. When Thomas grounded into a double play to make Chicago 0 for 6 with runners in scoring position, Clemens pumped his fist. The Yankees, who were 9-12 without Clemens, exhaled.
So 51 weeks after his last loss, Clemens is still unblemished. Does he even remember what it is like to lose?
"I don't want to talk about it," Clemens said. "I just hope this continues."
 
INSIDE PITCH
Because ROGER CLEMENS pitched economically, he is a strong candidate to start on three days' rest against the Red Sox on Wednesday. The sexy meeting that did not occur this week in Boston could occur at Yankee Stadium. Clemens, ANDY PETTITTE or RAMIRO MENDOZA will start. . . . JORGE POSADA's five runs batted in were half of what he had accumulated in his first 88 at-bats. . . . After JOE TORRE admitted that the Yankees were operating with 24 players because MIKE FIGGA had not played this season, he inserted Figga to catch in both games. . . . DEREK JETER extended his streak for reaching base to 41 games, the second-longest streak by a Yankee since 1961. PAUL O'NEILL reached in 42 straight in 1996. But Jeter's 16-game hitting streak ended in the second game when he was 0 for 2.

HEADLINE: May 16-22;
Another Drop in Crime

 BODY:
For the seventh consecutive year, crime in the United States fell sharply in 1998, according to preliminary data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Violent crimes and property crimes each fell 7 percent, declines criminologists attributed to several factors, including an expanding economy, a larger prison population and a lower demand for crack cocaine.

HEADLINE: A World of Ice Cream Waiting to Be Explored

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
ICE CREAM and summer go together like Mark McGwire and home runs, canoes and rivers, hamburgers and cookouts. Hard is the heart -- or strong the will power -- that can spot an ice cream place along the road and not slam on the brakes.
There is something especially summery about a no-frills roadside stand. Perhaps it is nostalgia for a simpler time, but it seems to add to the pleasure of the season to sit on a bench in the open air, nibbling at a sugar or waffle cone, licking fast to keep the melting ice cream from dribbling all over one's clothes. 
 Connecticut is blessed with its share of old-fashioned, independently owned ice cream shops (parlor is really too fancy a word for most of them). While vanilla is always popular, most shops offer unusual flavors, the better to tempt drivers to hit the brakes. Cones usually start at $1.50 or $2 and go on up with additional dips, and some places show the price including sales tax (which accounts for odd numbers in prices).
Following are a few favorite shops (listed alphabetically) among an estimated 70 statewide.
Although the original ASHLEY'S in New Haven is closed, there are three others: Hamden's is the largest, Branford's next, Guilford's the smallest. At all three, one will find 28 flavors daily (and 6 flavors of yogurt) from a list of more than 100. Mango (made from fresh mangoes) is the latest of many fresh fruit flavors popular in summer. Cones are $1.50 to $3.
DR. MIKE'S has been a Bethel institution since 1975. While there are 45 flavors in the repertory, 8 are available daily, including the very popular chocolate lace and cream. A second Dr. Mike's can be found in Monroe. Cone prices run from $1.96 for a single dip to $3.13.
After a day at the beach, a stop at the HALLMARK DRIVE-IN in Old Lyme is almost a given for a cone packed with ginger ice cream (a personal favorite), Toll House cookie or hockey fight (cherry vanilla with white chocolate chunks). These are among 22 choices available any given day as well as 2 or 3 weekly specials (all made on the premises), with cones priced from $1.85 to $2.20. The plain old-fashioned stand has been at the spot since the 1940's and recently expanded with grinders, quahogs and lobster rolls. There are eight tables with umbrellas in the rear, facing the sea marshes, a restful place to enjoy a refreshing cone.
THE ICE CREAM SHOPPE, its bright blue exterior making it very visible, has been a staple in Shelton for 29 years, originally as a Carvel stand. Soft ice cream is still on the menu, but the premises-made ice cream is now the big hit, especially chocolate chip mint, one of 31 flavors available in generously filled cones at $1.45 to $2.40.
The sign for MR. SHANE'S HOMEMADE ICE CREAM in Ridgefield is not much smaller than the premises of the tiny shop, in the rear of a Main Street building. Minuscule as it is, Mr. Shane's is worth the hunt for its rich chocolate ice cream. From a list of 60 flavors (all made on the premises), 16 are available at any given time. After vanilla, the most popular flavor is mud (coffee ice cream, Oreo cookies, fudge swirl and almonds), followed by chocolate malt and toasted coconut. Cones are $1.75 for a child's portion (more like a large single scoop), $2.50 for a single dip (really a pile-on of several dips) and $3.25 for the largest (so huge that a cone can't really contain it). Mr. Shane's also sells ice cream to Hay Day and other retail outlets.
Visitor or resident can tell summer is here by the lines on weekends at STOSH'S in the red depot, a landmark in Kent. Sit outside at a white table under a green umbrella and enjoy a turtle (vanilla ice cream, chocolate chips, pecans and caramel swirl) or chocolate-dipped apricot (apricot puree with fudge swirl) cones. There are 14 other flavors to choose from as well (from a list of 130, all made on the premises).
The up-market ice cream parlor has waffle cones dipped in imported French chocolate. Stosh's serves sundaes like Total Eclipse (a brownie with two scoops of chocolate ice cream, hot fudge and chocolate sprinkles) and Dippodopolus (16 scoops of ice cream, banana halves, rivers of toppings, nuts and whipped cream -- a feast for a group, at $18.95). Cones are $2.26 for one scoop, $3.21 for two. Stosh's also serves dazzle dogs (quarter-pound all-beef, skinless frankfurters on hand-rolled buns).
Finally, there is the INSIDE SCOOP in Trumbull, which sells its 48 flavors of ice cream by weight. At 50 cents an ounce, cones generally run from $1.80 to $3. The sparkling fresh looking one-year-old shop makes ice cream and sorbets on the premises. Among the most popular flavors, which one can eat at tables in the shop, are peanut butter swirl, banana Oreo, chocolate raspberry truffle and gianduia (Italian hazelnut chocolate).

HEADLINE: Taking a Dip, or Two, by the Shore

BYLINE: By JOSEPH D'AGNESE

 BODY:
AT the first hint of summer, the madness starts.
Seven days a week, the brothers Goff -- Bill and John -- will take turns on the early shift. By 5 A.M., one of them will start the gleaming stainless steel machine in the back room of their shop, Cone Zone, on Route 33 in Neptune. Five hours later, 100 gallons of ice cream will be chilling in the store's freezers, ready for customers craving a cool lick on a hot day. 
 At the days heat up, so does the ice cream business on the Jersey Shore.
The Goffs' business is typical of most homemade operations. A couple of freezers, a soft-serve machine, a row of toppings and a gaggle of teen-age employees occupy their roadside glass-front take-out place. The Goffs sell 26 flavors of hard ice cream, mountainous banana splits (one is called the pig sty), even ice cream sandwiches made with dog bones for customers' pooches.
"The challenge in the summer is just to keep people moving," said John Goff, a lanky man sporting a T-shirt reading Property of the Cone Zone. He added, "People like that it's a locally produced product."
In truth, though, the term "homemade" is relative. Most shore spots do not concoct their product in a quaint, hand-cranked wooden bucket. For a busy parlor, that scenario is unworkable. Instead, businesses buy a liquid base of cream, milk and sugar from distributors, then add it to their machines with flavoring, fruits and nuts.
The magic lies in coming up with flavors that sell reliably to a variety of customers. "Adults like butter pecan," John Goff said. "But kids like chocolate chip cookie dough. Seniors like old-fashioned flavors, but they stay away from the nuts."
At Seaview Sweets, another homemade operation on the Point Pleasant Beach boardwalk, Bruce Brand, the manager, said the "wacko flavors" he used to sell in his Montclair store just don't fly at the beach. "People on the boardwalk look for the basics," Mr. Brand said, "so we don't get too crazy or we're left with a lot that doesn't sell."
And make no mistake, taste sells. Hoffman's, a storied concession with locations in Point Pleasant Beach and Spring Lake Heights, has a spartan decor. But at the height of summer, every inch is crammed with eager customers. Behind a glass window, customers can see the shining tanks of ice cream mix that will be made into 40 flavors, including caramel nut cluster, chunky chimp and strawberry bonbon. The result is a dense, rich, creamy product, a bellwether on the shore.
Some ice cream outfits on the shore let others take the limelight. Arctic Ice Cream Company, based in Trenton, makes and distributes 6,000 gallons of ice cream each summer week to ice cream parlors, restaurants and convenience and grocery stores on the shore.
"We're a small company," said Tom Green, who bought the operation from his father-in-law in 1964. "And you have to have a niche. New Jersey is our niche."
Arctic sells "premium" ice cream -- not quite Haagen-Dazs, but light years beyond of the stuff found in supermarket freezers. A half gallon, sporting the distinctive penguin-and-cone logo, costs about $4.50, or $3.99 at the company's factory outlet on Arctic Parkway in Trenton.
One parlor that serves Arctic ice cream is Hurricane House in Barnegat. In this 1918 haunt, customers do not come merely for a Hurricane burger and a quick sundae; they linger to soak up the atmosphere. Ocean County's oldest ice cream parlor, it's the stuff of soda fountain dreams: high-backed booths, player piano, marble counters with wooden stools, ceiling fans, seltzer bottles and vintage magazine covers and ads framed on the walls. A true seaside gem.
If a business can't muster authentic atmosphere, zaniness will keep them coming in. At Showplace Ice Cream Parlour in Beach Haven, the attraction is the nightly show featuring singing waiters who exhort customers to perform offbeat dances and stunts in return for a signature dish. Want a Peter Pan sundae? Well, you'll just have to fly. Ask for the flavors, and the troupe belts them out to the tune of Handel's "Hallelujah Chorus."
Each night, the revue-style parlor performs about five shows, packing in 150 customers at each 60-minute seating.
At the low-key Crazees in Rumson, the attractions are the flavors of Princeton-based Thomas Sweets and the faint possibility that Bruce Springsteen will drop in for a cone.
But perhaps the sweetest shore tale is that of Dorcas Cotsworth, who at age 81 operates Dorcas of Bay Head, an elegant restaurant and soda fountain housed in a rambling white Victorian house. Once married to a steel magnate, Mrs. Cotsworth was forced to take over the Berry Steel Company in Edison when her husband died, leaving her with four small children.
But steel left her cold, as did playing bridge with her Short Hills neighbors. So, one summer day in 1964, while her company's boat was docked in Bay Head, she slipped away to the rooming house and restaurant she had eyed for years. "Please," Mrs. Cotsworth recalled pleading with the owners, "won't you sell me this place?"
The owners, a local police officer and his wife, had turned her down twice before. But that day, they said yes. Mrs. Cotsworth returned to the boat to share the news with her reveling cronies. "They'd been drinking all day," Mrs. Cotsworth recalled, "and they looked at me and said, 'What do you know about running a restaurant?' Nobody seemed to think it was odd that I was running a steel company."
Her life changed in one fell scoop. Thirty-five years later, the restaurant serves breakfast and lunch in season to the summer-share set, who sit under the green-and-white awnings ordering eggs benedict, sandwiches and Hershey's ice cream. Inside, there are dangling parasols, frilly curtains and paintings of the 1880's house created by visiting artists.
"This place has been like a dream for me," Mrs. Cotsworth said. "It keeps me alive. It's all happiness, not like bars where people maybe have too much to drink. We sell milk shakes and ice cream soda just like in olden days."
 
Sprinkles With That?
In the economics of the ice cream market, there is plenty of supply to meet the demand. Here are a few choices at the shore:

HEADLINE: Reaching the Beach on the Parkway Can Take a Toll

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE

 BODY:
FRIDAY afternoon, warm. The sea air beckons. The suitcases are in the trunk. Lighthearted, you race out of work, jump in the car and head down the parkway for a weekend at the shore. Five minutes later, you're stuck in traffic. 
 Why?
Well, all those other people left early too.
"It used to be a smaller peak period," said Roy W. Little, project development manager for the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the Garden State Parkway, "but the amount of traffic growth we've had has spread peak periods out and made it more difficult to find a time to get down to the shore without any congestion."
Mr. Little, who is also the chairman of the New Jersey Recreational Travel Committee, a group of 27 agencies that seeks solutions for transportation and tourist travel needs, said people living in the northern counties, like Bergen, were leaving earlier and earlier on Fridays.
"Anytime after noontime, traffic is starting to build," he said, "and anytime after 2 you could run into congestion. Not only do you have everybody who is going to the shore trying to get a jump on the weekend but you even have the commuters trying to get a jump on the weekend."
In 1998, travelers made 18.4 million trips to the Jersey Shore, 4.5 million of them overnight stays, according to Laura Otterbourg, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission. The shore region, including Greater Atlantic City, accounted for $14.3 billion of the $26.1 billion that tourism generated.
The 173-mile-long Garden State Parkway, begun in 1952 and completed in 1957, is the main north-south route to 127 miles of sandy beaches. Traffic volume just keeps going up. In 1989, there were 337.5 million car trips on the parkway, according to Jude T. Depko, principal traffic engineer for the New Jersey Highway Authority. By 1998, volume had increased 15.6 percent, to 390.2 million trips annually.
The Raritan toll plaza is as good a place as any to take the parkway's pulse. On an average day, 105,000 cars make trips through the plaza each way, Mr. Depko said. In February, the number drops to 93,000, but in August it goes up to 130,000. The difference is far greater at Great Egg toll plaza near Cape May, where 242,015 cars passed through last February, and 634,124 in August.
"The parkway is one of the heaviest trafficked commuter roadways in the world," handling over a million vehicles a day, Denis F. Ingoglia, the parkway spokesman, said.
That volume causes congestion, but it is not the only factor.
Most obviously, there are the toll plazas, 11 of them. No matter how many lanes officials add at the plazas or how speedily they manage to pass the cars through, the barriers still act as, well, barriers. There are 91 interchanges -- entrance-and-exit complexes -- 19 of which require a toll. However, 20 percent of those who use the road enter and exit without ever having to pay a toll, 30 percent pay one toll and 25 percent pay two. (The average trip length is 15 miles.)
Other bottlenecks: the Driscoll Bridge, over the Raritan River, has no shoulders, which means that whenever someone has car trouble, an active lane of the road gets clogged up. Add people afraid of heights who stop in midspan (150 feet above the water) and even an occasional horse like the one Mr. Ingoglia says stopped traffic one day when it escaped from a horse trailer involved in an accident.
Hot summer days mean more vehicle breakdowns, not to mention accidents caused by drowsy, drunken or distracted drivers. From June through September 1998, 21,055 incidents required trooper help or road service, Michael J. Cerisano, traffic analyst for Troop E of the New Jersey State Police, said.
When the traffic stops, most motorists just cope.
Mr. Ingoglia said, "You see people get out of their cars, take their lawn chairs, go up on the grassy berm, sit out there, put their suntan oil on and just veg out, because they know they're not going anywhere for a while."
Perhaps the largest traffic jam ever occurred on April 4, 1995, when a fast-moving brush fire in the Pine Barrens burned on both sides of the parkway near the Barnegat toll plaza.
"We closed the road down and had about a nine-mile back-up from about milepost 74 to milepost 83," said Mr. Ingoglia. "It took at least two hours for traffic to start moving."
A northeaster flooded and closed the Parkway in the Cheesequake flats near some marinas in 1994. Said Mr. Depko, "We ended up with a couple sailboats on the parkway."
The classic traffic jams on the northern end of the parkway begin almost immediately after the Bergen toll plaza and continue through Essex County.
"It is a commercial hot spot," said Mr. Ingoglia. "And because of the lack of right of way and the unique urban environment, it has been difficult to effect any real expansion, so you've got traffic there all the time."
Cars getting onto Route 280 from the southbound parkway add to the slowdown. There are three lanes in each direction at that point but below Route 280 it goes to four lanes. About 13,000 cars a day get off the southbound parkway on Route 280 and 35,000 get on the parkway from Route 280, Mr. Depko said.
The parkway leading to the Driscoll Bridge at the Raritan toll plaza also backs up, but across the bridge, the situation changes dramatically because of the dual local-and-express system between Sayreville and the Asbury Park toll plaza 22 miles to the south. The road ranges from five to seven lanes in each direction.
At this point, near Sandy Hook, cars begin to exit the parkway for shore points, thinning traffic out somewhat.
Once below Asbury Park, the road narrows again from five to four lanes, drops to three lanes at Manasquan-Point Pleasant and then to two lanes above Toms River.
The authority is adding three more toll lanes to the Barnegat plaza and using more reversible lanes, Mr. Depko said. The new configuration should be in full operation to handle the Memorial Day weekend crowd.
Traffic also slows along a stretch in Cape May County that has three traffic lights, the only ones on the parkway.
The authorities are working on ways to ease congestion on the parkway. Tokens have helped to move traffic at toll plazas, especially at rush hour when 50 percent of drivers use them, Mr. Ingoglia said. The E-Z Pass electronic toll-collection system should also help. It is to be installed incrementally on the parkway from north to south, possibly starting as early as next November and concluding in January 2000, said Edward Gross, executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, the agency assigned to oversee E-Z Pass. The turnpike plans to have the program in place in March 2000.
Traffic engineers using computer models estimated that if only 25 percent of drivers use E-Z pass at a parkway toll plaza that now has 10 minute-backups during rush hour, the wait would be eliminated. "And that's going to have a dramatic effect as well even for those who remain on the token and cash system," Mr. Gross said.
To keep things moving during shore season, the parkway bans contractors from working on the road from noon Friday to noon Monday. For short-term relief, it also uses electronic signs to advise motorists of traffic conditions at points of congestion like Gateway National Recreation area and Island State Park as well as approaches to the bridges to Staten Island, which can be bottlenecks on Sunday nights.
For longer-term solutions, it contracts for aerial photographs of the parkway as part of a study of traffic patterns.
For those driving to the shore, backups are less likely to occur on parkway exits than on roads leading from the highway to the shore, officials say. Such hot spots include Route 36 to Sandy Hook, Route 34 from interchange 98 to Manasquan-Point Pleasant, Route 37 from exit 82 at Seaside Heights, and Route 72 off exit 63 to Long Beach Island.
Improvements on such roads, as well as a major rehabilitation of the Driscoll Bridge and two nearby bridges sometimes used to get around it, are also expected to ease traffic flow when the three bridge projects are finished around 2004.
Richard M. Halczli, principal structural engineer for the parkway, said the authority will build a new span west of the current Driscoll Bridge and repair the current north and southbound sections. Once finished, all three spans constituting the bridge will have shoulders, wider lanes, and a total increase of lanes from 12 to 15.
The department is also going to build a new bridge between the four-lane Edison Bridge, which is 60 years old, and the Driscoll Bridge. And another alternative to the Driscoll, the two-lane Victory Bridge on Route 35, will be replaced by a higher bridge with two 12-foot lanes in each direction.
It may be that no roadway will ever be built that can handle maximum traffic volume all the time, Angus Kress Gillespie, associate professor of American studies at Rutgers University in New Brunswick and co-author of the book "Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike," said. Too wide, too expensive.
Citing an American Automobile Association travel guide from the 1920's, he said that getting to the shore was much more of "a production" in those days. "It's not hard to see how there was pressure in the 40's and 50's for a highway that would bypass the congestion of going from village to village all the way down to the shore," he said.
So, for the best possible trip, travel at off-times and try to keep things in perspective. If you do get stuck in a huge traffic jam, settle on the parkway's grass berm in your lawn chair and do a little reading, maybe a 1920's road guide to show how good you have it now.
 
The Bottleneck Bypass Is No Cure, But You May Feel Better
Traffic is backed up for three miles. Civil war is about to break out between back-seat passengers. And the engine is starting to overheat.
Isn't there an easier way to get to the shore?
The answer is maybe, though the relief may be more psychological than practical.
John P. Wallace, a lawyer who has a summer house in Surf City, tries to leave his office in Ridgewood early on Friday but usually doesn't get out until 5 P.M., the height of the rush hour.
To avoid parkway traffic, he takes a circuitous route down the New Jersey Turnpike to exit 8 in Hightstown, where he picks up 539 south to heavily traveled Route 72 east to Long Beach Island. His children kid him that the journey takes longer -- in miles and minutes -- than if he had just stayed on the parkway.
But Mr. Wallace retorts: "It's more interesting. I see people. I can stop and buy some vegetables and fruit. Besides, I get bored with the parkway."
Helene Grynberg, administrator of the American Studies Department at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, who has a cabin cruiser moored in Forked River, avoids rush-hour traffic by traveling later on Friday and also taking an alternate route. She leaves her Old Bridge home between 8 and 9 P.M. and takes Route 18 to Route 9 to a linkup with the Garden State Parkway in Toms River.
"It's perfect for people going to the shore below Toms River," she said.
Roy W. Little, project development manager for the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the Garden State Parkway, is skeptical about the value of alternative routes.
A traveler taking the New Jersey Turnpike or Route 287 to Woodbridge to pick up the parkway can run into heavy congestion. Route 9 is heavily traveled before and after the Edison Bridge, and Route 35 meanders through shore towns.
"You hear of people trying to take an all-back-road route," Mr. Little said. "I've tried it myself and I think, when all the dust settles, you're getting there about the same time you would on the main road." GEORGE JAMES
 
http://www.nytimes.com

A million motorists a day use the Garden State Parkway. Here are some facts to ponder while waiting in line at a toll booth:
 
Length: 173 miles from Montvale on the New York State border to the tip of Cape May. There are 313 entraces and exits, and 11 toll barriers.
 
Average Trip: About 15 miles
 
Tokens: Used by 50 percent of drivers in rush hours, 40 percent at other times.
 
Transactions: Toll collectors can handle an average of 450 cars an hour. Toll machines, which collect 70 percent of the parkway's tolls, can handle an average of 850 an hour.
 
Fines - For not paying tolls: $42, up to $200 for repeat offenders.
 
For vandalizing toll machines: $1,000, plus possible criminal prosecution (The parkway does not get the money from the fines; it is divided between the state and the local municipality in which the offense occurred.)

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 44; Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2010 words

HEADLINE: Strawberries Are Not Forever. The Time to Enjoy Is Now.

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
BONA fide strawberry lovers manage to keep their appetites for lush, sweet berries in check until June, when the local crop begins to perfume the fields and farm stands. Then, like the corn connoisseurs who insist on sticking to the season to risk a lapse of no more than eight hours from picking to plate, they are annually rewarded with an incomparable treat.
To most Americans, the notion that strawberries are seasonal would come as a surprise. The berries sold in those little green plastic baskets in produce markets all year have become as ubiquitous as potatoes. With their cottony taste they often seem more like potatoes, too. They might measure up cosmetically, with big, scarlet, glossy good looks. But the come-on is wasted. Without flavor and aroma they are easy to resist. 
 Then the ripe, juicy Long Island berries arrive. In the old days, their fleeting one-month season from late May to the end of June was a time for celebration. The annual strawberry festivals at churches and community halls all over the Island put the spotlight on strawberries. Bowls of berries fresh from the field were lavished with whipped cream and freshly churned ice cream. Dessert plates were piled with a rich indulgence of shortcakes and pies. Jars of homemade preserves were stacked for sale.
A few of these festivals survive, especially on the East End. But even without a party, today's strawberries are worth cheering and enjoying pretty much as they were 50 or 100 years ago. Bring on the cream.
The big change is not the way strawberries are eaten but in the way they are grown, and especially how they are harvested.
A decade or so ago on the Island, "pick-your-own" was hailed as the strawberry's savior. In the mid-1980's, when the Cauliflower Association, a farmers' group, discontinued the annual commercial strawberry auction, the demand for the berries by wholesalers, who would distribute them locally and in Manhattan, plummeted.
"It caused a major decline and the only way the farmers could continue to grow the berries and still make money was pick your own," said William Sanok, of the Cornell Cooperative Extension in Riverhead. "They're very labor-intensive to harvest, and finding enough workers to do the picking became a problem."
Attracted by the prospect of fresh strawberries for $1.50 a quart, vacationers, day-trippers to the North Fork and the Hamptons, people interested in saving a little money on a few quarts of berries, and other intrepid souls who did not mind stooping, crouching and coming away with stained fingertips, took to the fields.
At the peak of pick-your-own, there were more than 30 farms, including one in Nassau County and a few in Western Suffolk, in addition to those in the Riverhead area and on the North and South Forks, that opened their fields to pickers.
This season there will be fewer than 20 pick-your-own farms, about the same number as last year. The acreage planted in strawberries has shrunk to about 250, from several thousand a few decades ago.
And as with a good deal of the rest of agriculture on the Island, the future remains shaky. The prospect of planting homes instead of fruit and vegetable crops on the land that has not been deeded for farming, or nursery stock on land that has, becomes increasingly tempting for farmers.
Besides, with the thriving economy of the past few years, the notion of saving a few dollars by picking your own strawberries has lost its allure. "People still want strawberries and they're happy to buy them, but they can't be bothered to do their own picking," Mr. Sanok said. Fat wallets can easily handle the difference in price, while the less resilieant knees and hips of many of the aging baby boomers are not up to the physical stress of picking.
"I recently gave a talk to an elementary school class in Suffolk County," Mr. Sanok said. "When I asked how many of them had ever picked strawberries only four raised their hands. But almost all of them have picked pumpkins." Around Halloween going out to select the jack-o'-lantern from the field is fun. Picking strawberries, a task that requires an adult to pitch in, is not. It's work.
At the same time, appreciation for locally grown seasonal berries is growing. Consumers who do not drive out to farm stands can find the Island's strawberries at farmer's markets on the Island and greenmarkets in New York City. A few highly selective produce markets also carry them. Chefs, many of whom support local agriculture, demand them.
"There are more farmer's markets than ever in Westchester and up the Hudson Valley," said Bob Lewis, the chief marketing representative for the State Department of Agriculture and Markets. "It's important for the farms, and it has helped to increase the number of small farms."
Now, with the declining interest in pick-your-own, the industry is changing again. Farmers are experimenting to try to get a jump on the season to be able to deliver ripe berries by early to mid-May instead of around Memorial Day or later. "To get into the premium commercial market we have to extend the season," Mr. Sanok said.
Following the example set by New Jersey farms, strawberry plants are being set into the ground in July instead of in the fall so the fruit will begin to set earlier in the season.
The plants, which are viable for about two seasons at most before weeds take over and the plants become difficult to maintain, go through two flowerings. The flowers are removed the first time so no berries will set. But with the midsummer planting, a second flowering will occur at least 10 days earlier in the spring than with traditional cultivation, allowing for an earlier harvest.
More intensive planting will increase the crop. And the season will continue to run into June. It ends when summer's heat kicks in. Farmers say that three successive days of 90-degree weather is enough to put an end to it.
Another new kind of strawberry, called the Day-Neutral because it requires fewer hours of sunshine and continues to bear fruit throughout the summer, is grown in New York's Hudson Valley but not on a commercial basis on the Island because of the problem of finding labor to do the picking.
Strawberries, more or less as we know them, are a result of cross-breeding a large, juicy variety known as frago chiloensis, which came mostly from cool-temperature coastal areas of Chile, and fraga virginiana, a native American wild strawberry.
An 18th century French naval engineer and amateur botanist, Andre Francois Frezier, is credited with having been the first to bring the Chilean berries to Europe. They were planted in a garden in Brittany, where they hybridized naturally with the Virginia variety planted nearby. The result was a strawberry that looked and tasted much like our strawberries today. That fraisier, the French word for strawberry plant, sounds exactly like Frezier's name is sheer coincidence. The Latin term for the berry, fraga, refers to its fragrance.
The smaller Alpine strawberry, or fraise des bois, is of European origin.
The most popular strawberry under cultivation on the Island is the Raritan, which has been around for decades. It bears the name of a New Jersey river. Chandler is a newer variety being planted in the new system. It is larger and is said to have good flavor.
What sets the local strawberry crop apart from those grown in California, which is the source for more than half the national total, and Florida, the other major grower, is that it is not harvested mechanically. Local berries are not bred for their ability to withstand the battering inflicted by machines. They also do not have to be transported for many days over thousands of miles. And there are even some who raise their berries organically.
But that also makes these vine-ripened beauties highly perishable. Even with the most careful handling, they rarely last more than 24 hours.
Whether self-picked or purchased, they should be sorted carefully as soon as possible, to remove any that have soft spots. They should be refrigerated at once, but not rinsed until just before use. The hulls are best trimmed off after rinsing to prevent them from becoming water-logged. Unless they are destined for the jam pot, they can be served as a cocktail or with dessert.
In "The Compleat Angler," Izaak Walton wrote, "We may say of angling as Dr. Boteler said of strawberries: 'Doubtless God could have made a better berry, but doubtless God never did.' " Dr. Boteler, or Butler, a late 16th-century English physician, might well have been making his point about the seasonal berries grown on the Island.
A list of pick-your-own farms on the Island is available from the Cornell Cooperative Extension, Suffolk County, 245 Griffing Avenue, Riverhead, N.Y. 11901, (516) 727-7850. Information about pick-your-own farms and farm stands in New York State, including the Island, Westchester and the Hudson Valley, can be obtained be sending a postcard with your name and address requesting the New York State Guide to Farm Fresh Produce from the Department of Agriculture and Marketing, 55 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217. The information is also available on the Internet at: www.agmkt.state.us
 
Strawberry-Cream Sponge Roulade
Total time: 1 hour plus cooling and chilling
 
Butter for greasing pan
 3/4 cup cake flour
 3/4 teaspoon baking powder
Pinch of salt
4 eggs at room temperature
 1/2 cup granulated sugar
Confectioners' sugar
1 1/2 cups heavy cream, whipped
1 pint strawberries, hulled and halved
Superfine sugar to taste.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Butter a 10-by-15-inch jelly roll pan. Line it with a sheet of waxed paper cut to fit the width but extending a few inches at either end. Butter paper.
2. Sift flour, baking powder and salt together and set aside.
3. Beat eggs at high speed for 5 minutes, until very thick and light. Gradually beat in granulated sugar, then at low speed fold in flour mixture.
4. Spread batter in pan and bake 20 minutes, until puffed and golden. Run a knife around the edges.
5. Heavily dust a clean linen towel with sifted confectioners' sugar and invert cake, pan and all, onto the towel. Lift off pan and peel off paper. Roll cake in the towel and set aside to cool.
6. When cake is cool, gently unroll it and spread with whipped cream. Sweeten berries to taste and spread them over the cream. Reroll cake, wrap it in foil and refrigerate until ready to serve.
Yield: 8 servings.
 
Cornmeal-Strawberry Shortcakes
Total time: 1 1/2 hours
 
1 1/3 cup all-purpose flour
 1/2 cup yellow corn meal
4 teaspoons baking powder
Pinch of salt
3 tablespoons granulated sugar, plus extra for berries
 1/2 cup (1 stick) cold unsalted butter, in pieces
1 egg, lightly beaten
 1/2 cup buttermilk
1 quart strawberries, hulled and halved
1 tablespoon kirsch
 1/2 cup heavy cream
3 tablespoons sifted confectioners' sugar.
1. Preheat oven to 450 degrees. Cover baking sheet with foil.
2. Combine flour, corn meal, baking powder, salt and 3 tablespoons sugar in a food processor and process to blend. Add butter and pulse until mixture is uniformly crumbly. (Ingredients can be mixed by hand.) Transfer to a mixing bowl and lightly stir in egg and buttermilk, moistening ingredients so they can be gathered to make a soft dough.
3. Pat dough on a lightly floured board to three-quarter-inch thickness. Cut into 6 4-inch rounds. Place on baking sheet and bake until barely beginnng to brown, about 15 minutes. Cool on racks.
4. Place strawberries in a bowl and sweeten to taste. Add kirsch. Whip cream until thickened, fold in 2 tablespoons confectioners' sugar and continue whipping until nearly stiff. Refrigerate until ready to serve.
5. Split shorcakes. Spread bottom halves with some of the whipped cream and top with a layer of strawberries. Spread undersides of top halves with remaining whipped cream and place on cakes. Dust tops with remaining confectioners' sugar. Serve with additional berries spooned around cakes.
Yield: 6 servings.

HEADLINE: With a Nod to the Economy, the Art Market Is Flourishing

BYLINE: By HELEN A. HARRISON 

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, the East End's art galleries attracted more window shoppers than buyers, and were seldom patronized by serious collectors. As one local gallery owner remarked, what was for sale in the Hamptons was considered "second-rate art for second homes."
But many dealers now agree that the situation has changed significantly in the last few years. Most of today's art buyers are still people whose primary residences are elsewhere, but their attitude toward shopping at for art is as different as their approach to finding a loaf of high-quality bread. They used to bring it with them from the city, but now they can buy it locally. 
 Gallery owners see several reasons for the shift. The lure of the Hamptons, enhanced by widespread media coverage of high-profile residents and glamorous special events like polo, the horse show and the film festival, is attracting a new generation of potential art buyers. Specialized galleries have developed niche markets and cultivated a national, even international, clientele.
But the most decisive factor is the increasing number of affluent residents. The wealth generated by the surging stock market has fueled a building boom, creating hundreds of new homes with empty walls. Surrounding those homes are lavish gardens that provide the perfect backdrop for sculpture. And the proliferation of galleries demonstrates that the supply of art has increased to meet the demand.
The region's most venerable monitor of the art market, Mary Liberatore, has noted the trend and capitalized on it. "Last year," she said, "I counted 52 places listed in the papers where art can be seen." Her gallery, Clayton Liberatore, which she runs with her niece, Celeste Padilla, has been in business since 1961, selling representational work by established and lesser-known artists.
At the age of 88, Ms. Liberatore has been in the gallery business for 57 years, most of them at 2173 Montauk Highway in Bridgehampton. "I've seen the ups and downs," she said, adding that the last couple of years had been exceptionally good.
She is unusual among local dealers, however, because she has a stock of work by well-known early-20th-century artists, including Ernest Lawson, George Bellows, William Glackens and George Luks, who were represented by the gallery's New York City forerunner, which opened in 1920. Sales from this collection have been brisk, she said, ranging from $1,000 drawings and watercolors to major oils at $50,000.
A similar market is being tapped by the Wallace Gallery, which specializes in paintings of eastern Long Island from 1840 to 1940. The owner, Terry Wallace, began with an inventory he amassed over two decades. After selling to private clients and other dealers in New York City, he opened his gallery on Park Place Passage in East Hampton in 1996.
Realizing that, as he put it, "we're in an area that's going to grow continually," he focused on developing a market for historical depictions of the disappearing rural landscape by artists like Childe Hassam, the Moran family, the Tile Club and their contemporaries. He was aware, however, that previous ventures of this type had not survived, but he believed the time was ripe.
Mr. Wallace's optimism was sparked by the East End's influx of young, well-to-do Wall Streeters, who he said account for 70 percent of his sales. The rest, he said, are made to people in the entertainment industry. He concentrates on clients interested in the region's history as an attraction for painters working from nature. His prices start at about $3,000 for small works by lesser-known artists and go as high as $250,000 for a major oil, although his average sale, he said, is in the $10,000 to $20,000 range. In his first summer, he sold 120 paintings.
"I was surprised that I did as well in the retail market," he acknowledged, but pointed out that the market had expanded. In fact, it is less seasonal than he anticipated. Like many of his colleagues, he stays open year round. "My winter last year was better than my summer," he said.
A growing demand for academic painting is being met by the new Grenning Gallery, which opened last year at 1 Bay Street in Sag Harbor. The gallery's location, tucked between the Provisions health food store and the Corner Bar, seems unpromising, but the owner, Laura Grenning, said she gets increased visibility by being near the Bay Street Theater.
Ms. Grenning is a former stock analyst who left Wall Street five years ago to pursue art training in the Beaux-Arts tradition. Her gallery represents an international roster of artists she calls New Masters, some of whom she met while studying in Italy. Many of their paintings, priced from $1,000 to $15,000, are bought by second-home owners, but she also sells to people who come by boat to the adjacent marinas, and arranges portrait commissions for clients willing to pose in the traditional way for a painter working from life.
Despite her background in the stock market, Ms. Grenning said she did not promote art as an investment. Her emphasis is on "Old Master quality," which she believes is the only objective standard for judging art. "All the rest is subjective," she said.
Her attitude is echoed by other gallery owners, who stress the importance of a buyer's confidence in the dealer's taste and reputation as primary factors in successful marketing. Nevertheless, there is a feeling that many in the new generation of art collectors want work that will hold its value and has the potential to appreciate.
"I'm dealing a lot with resale, so I can give my clients resale value," said Ruth Vered, who with Janet Lehr is co-owner of the Vered Gallery, which celebrates its 25th anniversary this year. Originally the gallery, in East Hampton, handled a mixture of work by well-known and lesser-known painters and sculptors, many of them local, but the focus has now shifted to established names.
Many of Ms. Vered's buyers are established collectors who want to invest, and Europeans who visit regularly in the summer, she said. As she sees it, they are more comfortable with artists whose names they recognize, like Picasso, Chagall, de Kooning and other modern masters.
"It seems much easier for me to get $100,000 than to get $5,000, because at $5,000 it's much more difficult to convince them it's worth the money," she said.
Another gallery owner, Arlene Bujese, said, "I hear the word investment more often than I used to."
Ms. Bujese opened the gallery that bears her name at 66 Newtown Lane in East Hampton in 1994. Before that, she had run the Benton Gallery in Southampton for eight years, but found that most of her clients were in the East Hampton area. From its initial format of large group exhibitions, the gallery has evolved to a schedule of small group and solo shows, mostly by abstract artists of the region.
Notwithstanding the concern for investment value she has observed, Ms. Bujese believes there are more risk-takers among the younger generation of collectors, those in their late 30's or early 40's.
Catering to new buyers while retaining the loyalty of longstanding ones is a goal for the Elaine Benson Gallery, just starting its 35th season at 2317 Montauk Highway in Bridgehampton. Now operated by the late Ms. Benson's daughter, Kimberly Goff, the gallery has been thoroughly renovated but maintains its traditional May-through-September schedule of eclectic exhibitions, including work by regional and nonresident artists, ceramics, jewelry, and tribal art and artifacts.
As in the past, each show opens with a benefit for a local cause. The gallery has a devoted following among her mother's contemporaries, but Ms. Goff is mindful of the need to reach out to "a new generation of homeowners who want to start collecting."
With prices ranging from as low as $20 for a piece of eccentric jewelry to $50,000 for a large outdoor sculpture, there is something for everyone, but Ms. Goff pegs the "magic price" at $450. At that level, purchasers are comfortable trusting their own taste and can afford to buy on impulse.
"We do have some older people who are passionate about art and are true collectors," said Arnie Lizan, co-owner with his wife, Elizabeth Tops, of the Lizan Tops Gallery in the back tier of shops at 66 Newtown Lane in East Hampton. "But," he added, "we also see a lot of younger people building homes and wanting to decorate them."
For those clients, he and his wife like to serve less as gallery dealers than as art consultants, visiting homes and showing work suitable for specific living spaces. But they do not sell only to New York City people with second homes on the East End. Mr. Lizan said the gallery attracted many out-of-town visitors during the summer season; he has clients in the Middle West who visit each year, and he has had buyers from as far away as Italy and England.
After several years selling art privately from their Manhattan brownstone, Mr. Lizan, who has a corporate background, and Ms. Tops opened their East Hampton gallery five years ago. Prompted by their strong attraction to the local environment, they concentrate on landscape painters of the region, although they have also shown artists from elsewhere and some abstract work.
Two- or three-person shows are the norm, with pieces priced from $2,000 to $50,000. "Most of our sales have been in the $5,000 to $15,000 range," Mr. Lizan said, "but we have sold several at $40,000 to $50,000. We've had five really good years, and we're out here to stay."
On the strength of such reports, the Wally Findlay Galleries of Manhattan, established in 1871, will inaugurate an East Hampton branch next weekend. The gallery, which also has branches in Chicago and Palm Beach, opens next Saturday with an invitation-only benefit for Boys and Girls Harbor. It will occupy the 4,000-square-foot lower floor of the imposing Greek Revival building on Main Street that also houses London Jewelers.
According to the director, James Borynack, the gallery will remain open 10 months a years. "The East End is a year-round market," he said, "and many of our regular clients have homes there." Work by the gallery's regular stable of French and American Impressionist and representational painters will be featured, at prices starting around $2,000 and rising, in Mr. Borynack's words, "into the millions."
A number of art dealers agree that the client base has become more diverse in recent years. Potential buyers seem more willing to accept galleries in the Hamptons as serious professional businesses, not just seasonal venues, especially when they focus on a particular market.
One of the most specialized is Pritam and Eames, at 29 Race Lane in East Hampton, which sells hand-crafted studio furniture, often made of exotic woods or other rare materials. In fact, the gallery's location in the Hamptons is more or less irrelevant to its success, although it was vital to the owners, Bebe and Warren Johnson, who wanted to live in the area full time. Now in its 19th season, the gallery has a national clientele that the Johnsons have actively cultivated by seeking out people with an interest in the field.
Their roster of artists -- only two of whom, the woodworker David Ebner and Fran Taubman, a metal worker, are based on Long Island -- reflects the nationwide scope of the studio furniture movement and its following.
"The last couple of years have been very good for the field as a whole," Ms. Johnson said. "The American studio furniture movement is gaining in stature, with more pieces entering museum collections."
About half of their business is devoted to commissioned pieces, although their showroom is always stocked with one-of-a-kind furnishings that range in price from $300 for a handcrafted mirror to $50,000 for a marble bench in the shape of a polar bear.
Another specialist, Morgan Rank, has been selling American primitive art on Newtown Lane in East Hampton for 25 years. At first his gallery concentrated on 18th- and 19th-century work, with one show a year by a contemporary self-taught artist, but the proportions have reversed. Mr. Rank now has only one historical show a year, and focuses instead on living artists.
Like his colleagues, Mr. Rank said he often sold to second-home owners from New York City, but American primitive art has its own aficionados who seek it out wherever it is shown. They come from all over, he said, and include Europeans, who account for about a quarter of his sales.
Contrary to what is commonly believed, Mr. Rank does not think that the area has become more of a year-round residential neighborhood. From his vantage point at the corner of Main Street and Newtown Lane, he observes village traffic and notes the increase in day visitors and nonresident weekenders.
"Things changed when going to the country became going to the Hamptons," he remarked drily. But he pointed out that casual visitors may well become seasonal renters and then homeowners who will be needing art for their newly acquired walls.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Lodgings On the Cheap

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
GONE are the days when the family piled into the car and drove off willy-nilly, selecting roadside motels or cabins as they appeared. The tourist cabins on the blue highways are big resorts now, and in summer almost everything requires a reservation.
There are still economical ways to find housing on the road, although these, too, require planning ahead: in college dormitories vacated by their school-year inhabitants; hostels, either linked to an association or free-standing; and Y's or other youth-oriented organizations with downtown buildings. 
 At all these places what you get is more likely to be a single bed or bunk than a private room, and a private bathroom is a rarity. But sometimes early calls can produce the one or two family rooms in a hostel. Some universities that run subsidiary businesses in conferences will have nicer quarters.
Guides to places to stay on campuses and other no-frill lodgings are in accord with the places they depict: economically printed, devoid of glorious color pictures of tea on the veranda. The commercially sold guides may simply re-sort and print public-domain material that is otherwise available free. But the convenience of a single guide may make the cost worth it.
 
The Low-Rent Route
Here is a glance at guides to alternative housing on the road in the United States and for travelers taking the low-rent route overseas.
One of the least known here is the British Universities Accommodation Consortium, which annually prepares free brochures on facilities in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. This year's guide lists 62 universities, with grids showing what is available at what times of year, and the fees. As an example, bed-and-breakfast accommodations at Kings College in London, available from July 9 to Sept. 16, start at 25 a night, or $41 at a recent rate of exchange.
Some of the phrases on the chart may be a bit obscure, for example, "self-catering holiday flat," which means a vacation apartment where you may prepare your own meals. Prices are given in pounds. The guide is available free on request to B.U.A.C., Box 1756, University Park, Nottingham, England NG7 2RD; telephone (44-115) 950-4571. The guide is also on the Internet at www.buac.co.uk.
The Canadian University and College Conference Officers Association publishes similar free information about its dormitories, although the main thrust is toward conference planners. The leaflet "Vacationing on a Budget" covers nine universities in Atlantic Canada. "The Planners' Guide to Canadian Universities and Colleges" covers 60 places. They are both available from Christi Higginson, Dalhousie University Conference Services, 6136 University Avenue, Halifax, Nova Scotia B3H 4J2, Canada; (902) 494-3831, fax (902) 494-1219.
The organization also maintains a Web site at cuccoa.org with basic information and a number of links to the individual college pages. It includes color pictures; the photographs of Shirreff Hall at Dalhousie, built in 1923, show a lounge with a fireplace and a dining hall set for a meal. A single room there, with breakfast, is $25 a night, a double $37, about $17 and $25 in United States currency.
Another free publication is "Y's Way Accommodation and Reservation Guide," published by the Y.M.C.A. This slim pamphlet, with an introduction in five languages, focuses on places to stay in New York, such as the Vanderbilt Y.M.C.A. and the West Side Y.M.C.A., where singles with shared bath, with access to health facilities, cost $54 to $59 a night, depending on the season. Affiliated places in other cities and overseas are included. In the back is a form to request a reservation, which must be prepaid. Y's Way: 224 East 47th Street, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 308-2899, fax (212) 308-3161.
 
Guides to Hostels
Hostelling International-American Youth Hostels publishes "Passport to North America," which also has an introduction in four languages in addition to English. This 432-page annual guide to 220 hostels is free to members, or can be ordered by nonmembers for $3 a copy. Part of the publishing expense is met by the ads for guidebooks and car-rental and bus companies.
The hostels are organized by state, one listing to a page, with small black-and-white pictures and schematic maps. The book includes a list picking out 25 United States "sustainable living center" hostels that have been adapted to reduce waste and conserve water and that seek out nontoxic products.
Membership in the hosteling group is free for anyone under 18 and costs $25 a year for people 18 to 54, $15 for those over 54. For people going overseas, the organization sells two guides, one to Europe and the Mediterranean and the other to Africa, America, Asia and Australia. These are $13.95 each.
The organization is also distributing a free map of its 142 hostels in the United States, with addresses and telephone numbers. Hostelling International-American Youth Hostels, 733 15th Street, N.W., Suite 840, Washington, D.C. 20005; (202) 783-6171, fax (202) 783-6171.
"Hostels U.S.A." by Evan Halper and Paul Karr, a directory to all American hostels, whether affiliated or not, has just been published in its second edition by Globe Pequot Press. This 440-page book, in a tall narrow format slightly larger than the H.I.-A.Y.H. book, uses stars and icons to grade 300 places in the United States and parts of Canada.
Although A.Y.H. affiliates do not usually permit alcohol, this is not the case with independent hostels. So one of the useful icons in this book is the "party index," one to five New Year's hats for places that range from "downright quiet" to "rage all night." The Fort Lauderdale International Hostel, as an example, rates only two stars, or "barely adequate," and gets five hats on the party line. This book costs $14.95 in bookstores.
Globe Pequot has also published two overseas guides in the same format, "Hostels U.K.," which includes Northern Ireland ($14.95), and "Hostels France and Italy" ($14.95). A separate guide to Canada is due in the fall.
 
Campus Quarters
"Campus Lodging Guide," published by Robert C. Luckcuck and Jan Luckcuck in California, who operate as B. & J. Publications, contains a lot of supplemental material in its 334 pages: addresses of tourist offices, a collection of travel bargains and a dense list, three columns to the page, of hotels, motels and inns. The campus material is copious, starting with Australia and ending with Wyoming. The book also has a long list of Y's worldwide. The editors, who have been publishing this book for 18 years under various titles, earmark lodging places that have not responded to requests for up-to-date information.
B. & J. Publications has a Web site, campus-lodging.com, that contains an order blank. The price of the book is $14.95, and shipping is $2. B. & J. Publications, Post Office Box 5486, Fullerton, Calif. 92838; (800) 525-6633, fax (714) 525-6625.
 
http://www.nytimes.com
