HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with Glenn Collins and Elaine Louie 

 BODY:

Old Masters' Voice Is in 6 Languages
How do you tell the world that the voice of the Met is announcing that there will be a lot more of the voice at the Met? 
 Why, send out talking invitations featuring -- What else? -- the voice of the Met, a k a PHILIPPE DE MONTEBELLO, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the baritone who has guided more than 70 audio tours in the last 20 years.
Roughly 500 invitations with miniature audio units were mailed to the usual media suspects. When the cards were opened, the voice declared, "Welcome to the 'Key to the Met,' the Metropolitan's comprehensive Audio Guide program. . . ."
Nearly 60 reporters went to the museum yesterday to hear Mr. de Montebello, live and in person, as he voiced his pleasure at the Met's new digital CD-ROM audio guide, which will interpret the collections in six languages. He recorded in five (English, French, Spanish, Italian and German) but not Japanese.
The talking invitations "got the Met a nice turnout," said MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG, a museum trustee and the chief executive of Bloomberg L.P., the company that provided the recording studio where Mr. de Montebello taped the greeting heard in the invitations. Mr. Bloomberg not only paid for the talking cards at $5 apiece, but also underwrote the new audio-guide program with a $5 million donation.
His was not the only voice raised in support of the voice and its drawing power.
Mr. de Montebello's voice "is an incredible instrument," said Fran Reiter, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Maybe it should be landmarked."
 
Personal Days For a Royal Friend
RUTHIE HENSHALL, the actress who takes over the role of the murderous vaudevillian Velma Kelly in the Broadway musical "Chicago" tonight, insisted on three days off in June. She wants to attend Prince Edward's wedding to SOPHIE RHYS-JONES on June 18.
"He's a great friend of mine," she said, "so I wouldn't miss it for the world. When you love somebody as a friend, you're happy for them when they find happiness."
And no, she is not sorry that someone else will be walking down the aisle. "I wouldn't want that job," she said, sounding as if being a royal-by-marriage was as much about employment as romance. "I like my freedom too much. I like being able to do what I like to do."
One thing she does not like to do is watch television in this country. "I find it so irritating, all your adverts," she said. "I don't want to watch a film and be interrupted for 20 adverts that get louder."
 
Hostility in Beijing
"Almost no one in China believes it was a mistake," JULIA CHANG BLOCH, the executive vice chairwoman of the American Studies Center at Beijing University, said of the May 7 bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.
Ms. Bloch, in a talk at a Manhattan law firm on Friday, said that she had spoken with more than 100 Chinese since the bombing. "Only two believe it was a mistake," and neither of those were students, she said. The others, she said, "believe it was planned to test Chinese reaction, to destabilize China's rise as an economic power -- and that we're in Yugoslavia not to stop ethnic cleansing but to expand our global reach and that the bombing was to distract from the Kosovo peace process."
She also said that after the embassy bombing, some Americans prevaricated when taxi drivers asked if they were from the United States: "They say, 'No, I'm an Italian.' 'I'm a German.' "

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
New Giuliani Fund-Raiser and Her Handler

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
LAURA VAN HOVE, the new 32-year-old finance director for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's
likely Senate campaign, is considered such a pro that the Mayor's people are constantly saying how pleased they are to have her, etc. After all, she grew up in Iowa, where Presidential candidates turn up like corn borers, and where she met Bob Dole and the elder George Bush while she was at Iowa State. Since then, Ms. Van Hove has raised money for the 1996 Presidential race of Bob Dole, the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee and the Pennsylvania Republican Party. She has also worked for three Senate campaigns.
But talking with her last week was a challenge due to the concerned presence of Bruce Teitelbaum, the Mayor's former chief of staff and now the executive director of Solutions America, Mr. Giuliani's main political action committee.
Mr. Teitelbaum sat in on the interview with Ms. Van Hove, in a conference room at the Solutions America office near City Hall, but did more talking than sitting. 
 "Can I just make an observation?" Mr. Teitelbaum said, minutes into the interview, before Ms. Van Hove had a chance to answer a question about Mr. Giuliani's big fund-raising dinner tonight, the unofficial opening of his anticipated Senate campaign. "I'm just going to interject."
Mr. Teitelbaum then said it is "infinitely more difficult" to raise money under the $1,000-per-person Federal election limits of a Senate campaign than it was under the individual limits of $7,700 in a Mayor's race.So far, Mr. Teitelbaum said, Mr. Giuliani has raised $743,000 for a potential Senate campaign that would require at least $10 million against his likely opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton. But tonight's dinner -- Georgette Mosbacher, Donald Trump, Linda J. Wachner and various city real estate interests are on the committee -- is expected to reap more than $1 million.
"We definitely expect to have more than 1,000 people at this dinner," Mr. Teitelbaum said.
But they still need to raise $9 million more, no?
At this point, Ms. Van Hove managed to get a word in edgewise. "The election isn't until November of 2000," she pointed out.
Mr. Teitelbaum then said that once Mr. Giuliani formally announced for the Senate, "it'll be easier." He said that Mrs. Clinton's potential candidacy had not hurt and might be helping fund-raising, and that Ms. Van Hove, who replaces two finance directors deemed inadequate by the Mayor's underlings, has been in place only since March. "We planned this dinner a week or two after she started, and the fact that she's not from New York, and wasn't that familiar with the terrain here, that put us at a certain disadvantage," Mr. Teitelbaum said. "But I think we've been able to overcome that."
Ms. Van Hove, who has blond hair, wore a red suit and remained poised and calm throughout the interview, was raised on a 450-acre farm in Iowa, where her family grew soybeans, corn and oats and raised cattle and hogs.
"It's very similar to Brooklyn," said Mr. Teitelbaum, who has brown hair and ate two bananas during the interview.
Mr. Teitelbaum managed to remain quiet while Ms. Van Hove recounted her pre-Giuliani past.
SHE went to Forest City High School, where she was a nun in "The Sound of Music," played the saxophone and piano, sang in the choir and competed on the speech team. She was 13 when Ronald Reagan made his first Presidential campaign trip to Iowa, in 1980, and she thinks her parents may have met him at a political meeting. She was too young to go, but watched the televised caucus circus every night.
At Iowa State, she majored in political science and economics, graduated in 1989, then went to work for the unsuccessful Senate campaigns of Tom Tauke, who ran against Tom Harkin in Iowa in 1990, and Jan Stoney, who challenged Bob Kerrey in Nebraska in 1994. In between she was the finance director of the successful re-election campaign of Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa. After the 1996 Dole race, she raised money from big donors for the Republicans, then for Steve Forbes, who plans a second run for President.
The Mayor's people liked Ms. Van Hove in part because of her experience with national Republicans, whose money they want to harvest for the Senate run.
Ms. Van Hove said she heard about the job with Mr. Giuliani through a friend from Mr. Dole's campaign. In February, she called Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's communications director, who directed her to Mr. Teitelbaum. After an interview with the Mayor, Ms. Van Hove had the job, which she considers potentially more interesting than working in a Presidential campaign, particularly if Mrs. Clinton is in the race.
"I personally think she would be a great person to run against," she said.
Why?
"Because I think potentially,
ah ----."
Mr. Teitelbaum jumped in. "The reason I think it would be an interesting race, you could not get two people who are more polar opposites," he said. At another point, Mr. Teitelbaum spoke up as he was scribbling something.
"I'm making notes for you to do later," he said to Ms. Van Hove.
Ms. Van Hove glanced at the scratches.
"It's taken care of," she said.

NATO Bombs Disrupt Serbs' Water and Power
NATO warplanes hit electrical power transformers throughout Serbia in an effort to cut off the Yugoslav military's communication and supply links to Kosovo, according to Pentagon and NATO officials. But the attacks also had what the officials said was the unintended effect of disrupting water service to civilians, because the pumping system uses electrical power. A16
 
American and NATO officials said President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia was using money in Cyprus bank accounts and barges that come from Ukraine through Bulgaria and Romania to get oil. A17 

More than 10,000 ethnic Albanians fled from Kosovo into Macedonia overnight in the largest one-day exodus in three weeks. The rate of the expulsions suggested that Serbian forces might be making a final push to drive all ethic Albanians from Pristina, the provincial capital. A17
 
Gandhi to Lead Congress Party
Sonia Gandhi sent word to the Congress Party of India that she would lead them once again. An emergency meeting of party members, which had been called to try to woo her back, is now likely to turn into a coronation of Mrs. Gandhi as the party's unquestioned leader and its candidate for prime minister. A1

The Congressional report on Chinese espionage is to be issued today. Some officials at the Energy Department are challenging the findings that China stole nuclear weapons data and that the espionage is continuing at Government laboratories. A12

HEADLINE: Did We Ever Really Try Diplomacy on Kosovo?;
Marshall Plan for Serbia

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "A Just and Necessary War" (Op-Ed, May 23): President Clinton's remarks that the European Union and the United States "must do for southeastern Europe what we did for Western Europe" after World War II intimate that he will lead a Marshall Plan to rebuild the Balkans' industry and social fabric. 
 Just as the Versailles austerity led to the German depression and the Nazis' popularity, Serbia's depression has excited ethnic hatred and Slobodan Milosevic's rise. Serbia's hyperinflation of the early 90's was worse than Weimar Germany's. The resulting angst has overflowed into crime, hedonism and the rhetoric of hate.
 
MYLES DUFFY
Somerville, Mass., May 24, 1999

HEADLINE: Board Denies Bid by Doctors in New Jersey to Unionize

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In a setback to doctors' efforts to unionize, the National Labor Relations Board's regional office in Philadelphia ruled yesterday that more than 500 New Jersey doctors working for a health maintenance organization were independent contractors -- not employees -- and therefore could not form a union.
As labor unions have sought to persuade thousands of doctors nationwide to unionize, the New Jersey case was widely viewed as an important test case because it concerned whether doctors contracting with an H.M.O. should be considered employees and thus have the right to form unions. 
 This was the second time that the doctors had made their case to the labor board's Philadelphia branch. But last August, after the local board rejected the doctors' arguments, the national board overturned that ruling and ordered a hearing to get a "fuller picture" of the relationships between doctors and H.M.O.'s. It was the first time the board had heard testimony on the issue.
The union the doctors sought to join, the United Food and Commercial Workers, argued that the doctors were employees of the H.M.O., the Amerihealth Corporation of New Jersey, because Amerihealth controlled many of the details of their work, such as the maximum wait for patients, the size of their waiting room and whether patients should undergo surgery.
Rejecting the union's argument, the labor board's regional director, Dorothy L. Moore-Duncan, concluded that the doctors were independent businessmen because they ran their own practices, were free to contract with other H.M.O.'s and worked at their own offices. In addition, she noted that Amerihealth had little control over the doctors because its patients represented just a small fraction -- normally 4 percent -- of their overall practices.
"The physicians lack the close economic relations and integration with Amerihealth that would support a finding of employee status," she wrote.
With yesterday's decision, Ms. Moore-Duncan rejected a petition by Local 56 of the United Food and Commercial Workers to hold an election in which 515 primary care physicians and specialists in Atlantic and Cape May Counties were to vote on whether to join the union.
Robert F. O'Brien, the union's lawyer, said the union was still debating whether to appeal the decision to the labor board's main office in Washington.
"The decision contains pages and pages of facts that strongly point to these doctors' employee status," Mr. O'Brien said, "but then it wrongly concludes that they're entrepreneurs, which flies in the face of the evidence."
Several officials from other unions said the Amerihealth doctors' situation represented an unfavorable set of circumstances for a test case. These officials said unions would have been better off to have asked the national labor board to examine a case involving an H.M.O. that maintained far more control over their doctors than Amerihealth did and accounted for far more -- perhaps 50 percent -- of the doctors' caseload.
G. Fred DiBona Jr., chairman of Amerihealth, said in a statement that yesterday's ruling "clarifies a question of considerable importance."
"The N.L.R.B. decision agrees with virtually every point we have made over the past 18 months," Mr. DiBona said, "including the facts the doctors own their own businesses, compete with each other, contract with a large number of insurers, make their own hours and are the sole beneficiaries of their successes."
But the United Food and Commercial Workers repeatedly insisted that the doctors were tantamount to part-time employees because the H.M.O. controlled so many details of their practice. For instance, Amerihealth requires that the doctors' offices maintain certain records, be open a certain number of hours each week and allow visits by Amerihealth inspectors.
Ms. Moore-Duncan concluded that the doctors' extensive independence from Amerihealth outweighed the amount of control the H.M.O. had over them.
Labor experts estimate that 35,000 of the nation's 700,000 doctors are in unions. The recent acceleration of efforts to unionize doctors have focused on salaried staff physicians at hospitals.
Occasionally, when private-practice physicians have sought to bargain collectively with H.M.O.'s over reimbursements or other matters, the doctors have been accused of violating antitrust laws, charged with being independent businessmen conspiring to restrain trade. Many private-practice doctors are urging Congress to enact an antitrust exemption that would let them bargain with H.M.O.'s.

HEADLINE: N.H.L.: ROUNDUP;
Dallas Evens the Series

BYLINE: By TARIK EL-BASHIR, By The Associated Press 

 BODY:

STARS 4, AVALANCHE 2
Joe Nieuwendyk wristed in a short rebound with 8 minutes 8 seconds left in the third period and Mike Modano scored a few minutes later, giving the Dallas Stars a 4-2 victory over the visiting Colorado Avalanche last night and evening the Western Conference finals at one game apiece.
 Nieuwendyk's fourth game-winning goal of the post-season sent Colorado to its first road loss of the playoffs. The Avalanche had tied a National Hockey League record with seven straight road victories. 
 The series moves to Denver for Games 3 and 4 tomorrow and Friday. Colorado is 2-4 at McNichols Arena this post-season.
 Goaltender Patrick Roy, who had carried Colorado to five straight victories since being down 0-2 to Detroit, faded in the wake of 45 shots -- the most he has seen in the playoffs since 1997.
 It was the most fired by Dallas since taking 56 in a triple-overtime victory in the first round.
 The Stars had 15 shots in the third period to one for the Avalanche.
 Roy wasn't only beaten by the All-Stars Nieuwendyk and Modano. He gave up a first-period goal to Dave Reid, who hadn't scored in his last 20 post-season games and to Sergei Zubov, who was shut out this post-season.
 Stars goaltender Ed Belfour was tested 19 times and he stopped 17. The Avalanche may not have taken as many shots, but Belfour turned away many very good scoring opportunities.
 Both Colorado goals came on rebounds, just as they did in the Avalanche's 2-1 victory in Game 1 Saturday. The Game 2 scorers were Sandis Ozolinsh on a first-period power play that gave Colorado a 1-0 lead and a diving shot by Milan Hejduk that made it 2-2 in the second period.
 
PHOENIX
Schoenfeld Fired
 Unable to advance past the first round of the playoffs, the Phoenix Coyotes fired Coach Jim Schoenfeld yesterday after two seasons with the team.
 The Coyotes were knocked out of the opening round of the playoffs by the St. Louis Blues, who came back from a 3-1 deficit to win the next three games. This season, the Coyotes (39-31-12) finished with 90 points, the second-highest total in franchise history. But the club's inability to advance into the second round of the playoffs most likely cost Schoenfeld his job.
 
ISLANDERS
Free-Agent Snag
 Several restricted free agents -- goalie Felix Potvin and captain Trevor Linden are among them -- may not get qualifying offers from the Islanders if the team doesn't reach a deal soon for a new arena with Nassau County. But Islanders officials were not optimistic yesterday that an agreement would be in place before the July 1 free-agency deadline.
 The owners don't expect a new deal imminently, said John Sanders, the Islanders' new president. If a new deal was in place for, let's say four or five years from now, the owners might be willing to make an investment.
 Sanders stressed the importance of a new arena to the economic survival of the Islanders. We have to make personnel decisions that make sense, he said.
 The Islanders said they would lower ticket prices for next season. with more than 2,300 seats to be priced at $15. Only about 300 were in that price range last season. TARIK EL-BASHIR

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: FUEL;
Oil Flowing to Yugoslavia Despite NATO's Exertions

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
As part of the campaign against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, the Clinton Administration and NATO have tried to cut off his oil supply and his bank accounts.
It is a campaign that has not gone well, American and NATO officials said. Barges are filled with oil in Ukrainian ports and cross the Black Sea to chug up the Danube River through Bulgaria and Romania. To pay for it, Mr. Milosevic has been using money he secreted in banks in Cyprus during the earlier period of sanctions against Yugoslavia, the officials said. 
 The Administration and European Governments have appealed to Ukraine to shut down the trade and they have asked Cyprus to freeze Mr. Milosevic's bank accounts, American and NATO officials said.
During his visit to Washington last week, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, NATO's commander, raised alarms about the oil shipments traveling up the Danube and said that action needed to be taken to stop them. He said that route was increasingly being used because NATO had been somewhat successful in choking off the supply coming into Montenegro.
American officials said that they did not have a good fix on the volume of oil Mr. Milosevic was getting through the Danube route. But they did say that it was Russian oil, and that the deals were being arranged by middlemen who were making a tremendous profit because of the risks involved.
Asked how much oil Mr. Milosevic was getting, one Administration official said, "all he needs." Another official said that was an exaggeration, but he conceded that the Serbian leader was getting enough oil to keep his military machine going. A third official replied, simply, "too much."
The Clinton Administration and NATO have tried to deal with the matter quietly, fearing that making it a public issue could backfire.
When an oil embargo was last in effect against Yugoslavia, as part of a comprehensive sanctions regime from 1992 until the signing of the Dayton peace accords in 1995, Bulgaria and Romania were major conduits for oil in violation of the sanctions. (Greek and Italian oil companies were major suppliers, with most of their oil moving through Albania, a route that has now been largely shut down.)
But Washington and European capitals expect to have more success now. The Governments in Bulgaria and Romania have become more stable and have better-trained law enforcement agencies; above all, they have moved from their Communist pasts, expressing a strong desire to get into NATO and the European Union.
Still, Bulgaria and Romania have not done as much as the Administration believes they could.
Those Governments have argued that they cannot interfere with traffic on the Danube because it is an international waterway covered by the Danube Convention of 1948, which calls for free movement of ships. But American officials have dismissed those assertions, noting that the convention was signed by the Danube riparian states when they were part of the Soviet Union; West Germany was the one Danube state that did not sign.
Above all, American and NATO officials said, the major problem has been Ukraine, the source of the oil transportation.
Last week during meetings in Brussels, Boris Tarasyuk, Ukraine's Foreign Minister, was cordially but firmly told that his country must stop the barges from loading up with oil in the Ukrainian ports, a NATO official said.
Mr. Tarasyuk countered with complaints about the economic damage Ukraine was suffering because of the war against Serbia. He said that it had cost his country $220 million in lost trade, that Ukrainian ports alone had lost $12 million, and that a Danube shipping company in Ukraine was losing $313,000 a day. Who was going to compensate Ukraine for that, he demanded of NATO.
Nearly 90 percent of the Ukrainian population is against the NATO bombing, according to recent polls there, an American official said. For that reason, the Administration did not feel that it could make a public issue out of Ukraine's lack of cooperation.
In Cyprus, too, the Clinton Administration has been worried about upsetting the Government and so has not said anything publicly, but it is not happy that the Cypriots have refused to close the bank accounts belonging to Yugoslav companies.
With its secretive banking laws, Cyprus has become a major money-laundering center, especially for Russian organized criminal operations, American and European law enforcement officials said. European law enforcement officials said many of the continent's cigarette-smuggling operations use Cyprus.
American officials said they did not know how much Mr. Milosevic has in the accounts, in part because finding his assets has never been a priority of the C.I.A., several officials said.
But however much is in the accounts, the Cypriots have told the Clinton Administration and NATO that there is no legal basis for freezing them because there are no United Nations sanctions against Yugoslavia.
Of course when the earlier sanctions were in effect, Cyprus did not cooperate either, American and European officials said. "They always found loopholes," an American official said.
This evening, the Cypriot Embassy in Washington said that because of the country's desire to join the European Union, the Government was endeavoring to cooperate and was studying what it might do to freeze the accounts.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the continued flow of oil to Yugoslavia, despite NATO's cutoff efforts, referred incorrectly to the cold war political status of Bulgaria and Romania, signers of the Danube Convention of 1948 calling for free movement of ships. They were part of the Soviet bloc, not the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
NORTH KOREA: PERRY PAYS A VISIT -- Former Defense Secretary William J. Perry arrived in Pyongyang, the capital, to discuss the Clinton Administration's aims of easing North Korea out of its isolation. Mr. Perry, who is reviewing North Korea policy on behalf of President Clinton, is the highest-ranking American to visit North Korea since the Korean War. Although North Korea honored him with an evening reception, the highest officials it sent were deputy ministers. Nicholas D. Kristof (NYT)
 
NORTH KOREA: KEY AIDE PLANS CHINA TRIP -- North Korea's No. 2 leader will make an official visit to China from June 3 to June 7, Chinese officials announced. It will be the first high-level visit since China angered its ally by establishing relations with South Korea. Kim Yong Nam, head of the Supreme People's Assembly and No. 2 in the Workers' Party, is expected to seek more aid from China. Erik Eckholm (NYT) 

CHINA, PHILIPPINES: A CLASH AT SEA -- China accused the Philippine Navy of ramming one of its fishing boats and sinking it, but Manila said it was an accident and expressed regret. The sinking was the latest incident to mar relations between the two countries, already soured by squabbles over isles and reefs in the South China Sea. The sinking happened near Scarborough Shoal, which is claimed by Manila and Beijing. The shoal is north of the Spratly Islands, also the subject of dispute. (Reuters)
 
INDONESIA: 6 REBELS SLAIN IN SUMATRA -- Officials said separatist rebels killed six people in the northern Sumatran province of Aceh. Tensions have risen in advance of June 7 general elections, with rebels opposing participation in the vote. In a separate incident in Sumatra, witnesses said the police near the city of Medan fired into a crowd of people protesting for greater land rights, wounding a number of them. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
THAILAND: EUROPEAN TALKS OPEN -- Representatives of the European Union and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations opened a meeting in Bangkok that had been delayed for more than a year over Europe's objections to the participation of Myanmar, formerly Burma, a new member of the Asian bloc. In a compromise, Myanmar's representative is barred from taking part in formal meetings. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: A SHIFT ON DRUGS -- Citing new figures that show 30 percent of crime in Britain is committed by addicts seeking to support their drug habit, the Government said it was shifting resources from dealing with the consequences of abuse to its treatment and prevention. A report from Keith Hellawell, a former police constable who is Britain's first anti-drug czar, set targets of increasing offenders' participation in drug treatment programs by 66 percent in 2005 and 100 percent in 2008. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BRITAIN, ARGENTINA: FALKLAND TALKS -- Negotiators from the Falkland Islands and Argentina meet in London today for the first talks since Britain defeated an Argentine attempt to take over the British-ruled islands in 1982. Although the Foreign Office made it clear "sovereignty is definitely not on the agenda," the talks are considered remarkable for the shift they represent in the islanders' attitude toward Buenos Aires. (Agence France-Presse)
 
POLAND: SLAVE LABOR PACT REPORTED -- Germany has agreed that Nazi-era slave laborers from Poland should get the same compensation as those living in other countries, the Government chief of staff, Jerzy Widzyk, said after meeting with German officials. More than 400,000 Poles are seeking more than $2 billion in compensation. Poland and other East and Central European countries had feared that their slave laborers would receive less than those now living in the U.S. and Israel. (AP)
 
TURKEY: 8 REBEL KURDS REPORTED SLAIN -- Security forces killed eight Kurdish guerrillas loyal to the captured rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan in clashes in eastern Turkey, officials said. Three soldiers also died. More than 29,000 people have been killed in the 14 years of conflict with rebels of the Kurdistan Workers Party fighting for self-rule in the mainly Kurdish southeast. (Reuters)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: 3 KEY AIDES QUIT -- Three deputy Interior Ministers and several other officials quit their posts to join the campaign of Francisco Labastida Ochoa, left, who resigned last week as Interior Minister to seek the presidential nomination of the governing party. Newspaper editorials said the mass resignations had plunged Mexico's most important ministry into a state of chaos. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
PANAMA: A U.S. PULLOUT -- The U.S. withdrew the 400-soldier 245 Support Battalion, bringing the number of U.S. military personnel in Panama to about 3,200, officials said. The troops will be redeployed in the U.S. and Europe as part of Washington's efforts to comply with the 1977 Panama Canal treaty, under which the U.S. will hand over control of the waterway by Dec. 31. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: SETTLEMENT ACTIVITY -- The Peace Now movement said the nucleus of three new Jewish settlements had been set up near the Palestinian-ruled city of Nablus, in the northern West Bank, in a rush to grab occupied land before Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak takes office. The group said the move was intended to create "facts on the ground," and urged Mr. Barak to put a stop to illegal settlement activity. (Reuters)
 
IRAQ: U.S. JETS IN NEW ATTACK -- U.S. warplanes bombed a communications site after being fired on by antiaircraft artillery in the no-flight zone over northern Iraq, according to a statement from the Incirclik air base in southern Turkey. Iraq said buildings were damaged in the raids, but the Iraq News Agency did not say whether the buildings were used for civilian or military purposes. (Reuters)
 
IRAQ: U.N. TELLS OF DROUGHT -- The worst drought on record in Iraq has cut crop yields to half of last year's totals, a U.N. report said. The Iraqi Government usually refuses to give figures or estimates on agriculture, making the U.N. report particularly significant. The report predicts that feed will become more expensive, affecting livestock and poultry production. It also expected further increases in consumer prices of dairy and meat products. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
KENYA: PLAN FOR A FREE-TRADE ZONE -- Heads of state ended a meeting in Nairobi of the 21-nation Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa by announcing a plan to turn the regional trade bloc into a free-trade zone by Oct. 31 next year. The bloc, which stretches from Egypt to Swaziland, but excludes South Africa, has a population of some 380 million and a gross domestic product of around $155 billion. (Agence France-Presse)
 
NIGER: COUP OPPOSITION RETRACTED -- The 16-member Economic Community of West African States meeting in Togo backed down from punishing Niger for the assassination on April 9 of President Ibrahim Bare Mainassara. After overnight talks, the group's foreign ministers decided to retract an earlier call by Sierra Leone, Mali and Benin to deny recognition to the new military junta in Niger, led by Maj. Daouda Wanke, above. (Agence France-Presse)
 
CONGO: A THREAT TO BURUNDI -- The Congolese army chief, Faustin Munene, has threatened to attack the capital of neighboring Burundi and accused the Burundian Army of helping Congolese rebels. "Congo will not hesitate to attack Bujumbura, which, by the way, is only a few kilometers" from Congolese territory, he said. President Laurent Kabila has long accused Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda of supporting the rebels, who control much of eastern Congo. Mr. Kabila receives military support from Angola, Zimbabwe, Namibia and Chad. (AP)

HEADLINE: Lecture Trail In the U.S. Is Attracting Netanyahu

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 25

 BODY:
Withdrawing from active politics after his electoral defeat, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will give up his seat in Parliament and most likely write a book and go on the lecture circuit in the United States, his spokesman said today.
The spokesman, David Bar-Illan, said Mr. Netanyahu was planning to announce his resignation from Parliament on Thursday at a meeting of his Likud Party. Mr. Netanyahu stepped down as head of the Likud last week when he conceded defeat to Ehud Barak, the Labor Party leader. 
 "He's not going to be an active member of the party or in Parliament," Mr. Bar-Illan said. "He has a book contract, and he has very attractive offers for lectures. So I suspect that would be the route he will take."
Since conceding defeat barely half an hour after the polls closed on May 17, Mr. Netanyahu, 49, has said nothing in public and largely disappeared from public view.
A photograph issued by the Government Press Office showed him smiling and relaxed with his family at a staff farewell party in his official house, and a newspaper picture today showed him waving as he went house hunting here with his wife, Sara. Mr. Netanyahu is to remain in office until Mr. Barak forms a Government.
Mr. Bar-Illan said Mr. Netanyahu had bounced back in the week since his loss. "He's very buoyant, very up," Mr. Bar-Illan said. "He's internalized the defeat, and he's looking forward."
As Mr. Barak has begun talks on forming a Government, Mr. Netanyahu has cut back his work hours, canceling a Cabinet meeting on Sunday and an earlier gathering of aides to discuss security issues. Although those meetings will resume, they will not produce significant decisions, in deference to Mr. Barak's incoming administration, said another spokesman for Mr. Netanyahu, Aviv Bushinsky.
"Activity has gone down to a minimum," Mr. Bushinsky said in a radio interview. "I think the Prime Minister and the ministers are acting responsibly by avoiding decisions that will bind the incoming government."
Mr. Barak's One Israel bloc, which includes Labor and two allied parties, held its second day of exploratory talks with other parties on forming a coalition. Mr. Barak is said to be seeking as broad a coalition as possible to insure stability, including the Likud as well as Shas, an ultra-Orthodox party of Sephardic Jews, families from North African and Middle Eastern countries, that has grown to become the third largest in Parliament.
Mr. Barak's voters have flooded his office with faxes and E-mail that demand that Shas be kept out of the coalition. The Shas leader, Aryeh Deri, has been sentenced to jail after having been convicted of bribery, and the party's campaign was peppered with sharp attacks on the justice system. Mr. Deri remains free while he appeals his conviction to the Supreme Court.
Mr. Barak has refused to rule out Shas, provided that Mr. Deri resigns -- a demand that Shas negotiators resisted today. Likud members said Mr. Barak's team had told them that they would be senior partners in Government if they joined his coalition.
Shlomo Ben-Ami, a Labor lawmaker who is on the One Israel negotiating team, said by working for a broad coalition Mr. Barak was trying to avoid the mistakes of his predecessors.
"We've learned a lesson from the last seven years," Mr. Ben-Ami told Israel Radio. "During the four years of the Rabin Government, dramatic, important moves were made in the peace process and economic growth. But in the end they were perceived as rule by half of the people over the other half, and the moves were cut short."
"Then," Mr. Ben-Ami added, "there was a Government in which the other half ruled, and the result was a serious culture war, deep division and stalling of the peace process. The lesson is to try and heal these rifts, to build as wide a coalition as possible. But not one that is paralyzing. One that creates a consensus for solution of both internal and external problems."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE;
Going From Yogurt to Developing Office Space on Staten Island

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
"Yogurt is really sour milk," Richard Nicotra said a few days ago. Mr. Nicotra has become the leading private developer of office space on Staten Island in recent years, but as the man who founded the 250-store Everything Yogurt chain 23 years ago, his heart is still very much in the yogurt business.
The first store opened in 1976 at 51 Broadway in Manhattan. "We got the product in liquid form from Colombo Yogurt in Massachusetts and we put it into an ice cream machine to freeze it and whip it," Mr. Nicotra said. "We had vanilla, strawberry and peach. It was a big day when we could manufacture chocolate frozen yogurt." 
 More recently, his big days have come in the real estate line. Altogether, he has signed tenants for 500,000 square feet of office space -- 115,000 square feet completed, 75,000 square feet in construction and the rest in the development stage. The buildings are in the 415-acre Staten Island Corporate Park, in the northwest corner of the island near the West Shore Expressway.
As president of the privately owned Restaurant Systems International, Mr. Nicotra has brought his restaurant business beyond yogurt into juice bars and salads and wrapped sandwiches. The company and its franchisees had systemwide sales of $50 million last year. But it is as president of the Nicotra Group that this Staten Island native and resident has become a leading developer.
The project he has under construction is a four-story, 75,000-square-foot building nearing completion at 900 South Avenue amid much surrounding woodland. The building is named the Park, and occupancy is to start in August.
South Avenue within the corporate park is a broad street two miles long divided by a median with sizable trees. It was built mainly with city money 20 years ago when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was investing $70 million to develop the Teleport, a satellite transmission site and office center with a million square feet of office space and 3,000 workers. AT&T Local Services, with 2,400 employees, is the main tenant of the Teleport.
Driving south from the Staten Island Expressway to the Teleport, a visitor passes intermittent development sites on the right and then an expanse of 265 acres of wetlands and uplands that have been designated as city parkland.
Mr. Nicotra has been the leading customer for the commercial sites that the city was willing to sell for development. His first project, 1000 South Avenue, on city land bought in 1988, was a 40,000-square-foot building in which Everything Yogurt itself operates in 10,000 square feet. The rest of the space is leased by various service firms.
In 1995 Mr. Nicotra bought 4 1/2 acres of city land for a second building, the Atrium. "I saw there was a market on Staten Island for Class A space," he said.
He leased out 90 percent of the 75,000-square-foot building before completion, he said. There are nine tenants, including State Farm Insurance, Allstate Insurance and Metropolitan Life. The biggest tenant turned out to be Anthem Health and Life Insurance Company of New York, formerly Home Life Insurance. Anthem took 15,000 square feet when it moved from Piscataway, N.J.
The current project, 900 South Avenue, will have parking for 250 cars, some outdoors and some covered. The Nicotra Group bought the 2.5-acre site from the city for $1 million two years ago.
Four tenants have already signed leases, Mr. Nicotra said, at rents of about $23 a square foot a year. Among them is American Express, which is moving an office now on Forest Avenue in the Mariners Harbor section of Staten Island into 10,000 square feet, or half a floor, and doubling its space in the process. Merrill Lynch, now in New Springville, Staten Island, is expected to sign for 12,000 square feet, Mr. Nicotra said.
Major corporations are not alone in wanting Class A space. The Nicotra Group will build and operate executive suites suitable for sole-practitioner lawyers, who can use shared conference space and secretarial services and pay modest rents, normally about $1,000 a month. His most ambitious project lies ahead. Two years ago the Nicotra Group was selected by the city's Department of Economic Development, through a request for proposals process, to develop a 20-acre site in the park, formerly a stable and its grounds, with 300,000 square feet of new space.
The $50 million project is to include a six-story, 160-room business class hotel, a conference center, a day-care center, 300,000 square feet of office space and two restaurants, built in phases. As in other Nicotra projects, the architect is Land Planning and Engineering Consultants, a Staten Island firm.
Acting favorably on the request of the Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, the state's Department of Transportation has agreed to build a new exit on the northbound lane of the West Shore Expressway (Route 440) at Glenn Street to serve the project, which has been named the Gardens. At present, the nearest exit on the highway is two miles from the site.
The Nicotra Group is not the only park developer. Another project in the offing is called Southport Plaza, which is to have almost 200,000 square feet of space. George Kaye, the longtime owner of Superior Confections Inc., a Staten Island manufacturer of chocolate novelty products, is under contract to buy the site on South Avenue of 15 acres from the city.
Mr. Kaye said that about half the space would be used for manufacturing and exhibition space by a new family-owned company, Supreme Chocolatier Inc., and the rest would be leased out.
The land is near the prospective new service road to the expressway at Glenn Street.

HEADLINE: From Kosovo to 'Potato City,' Idaho, the Hard Way

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho, May 25

 BODY:
As Mirsade Bejiqi and her family flew from Fort Dix to their new home here, she braced herself for loneliness and isolation. Perhaps nobody would bother meeting them, a handful of near-penniless refugees from Kosovo hurtling toward Potato City, as she called Idaho's capital.
How would she find her family's luggage? the 20-year-old Ms. Bejiqi wondered. Maybe somebody would show up to meet the Bejiqis, but how would she recognize him? 
 As it turned out, Boise recognized her. Forty people showed up at the Boise airport on Thursday night to greet her; her father, Ajet Bejiqi, a factory worker driven out of Pristina less than two months ago; her mother, Bukurije, and her three brothers.
Leaders of the Islamic Community Center came out to meet them, bringing translators, and so did the head of the local refugee resettlement agency. Rabbi Daniel Fink of Boise's Congregation Ahavath Beth Israel and his wife, Laura Rappaport, also a rabbi, who led the push for the synagogue to sponsor some refugees from Kosovo, were there. The family that was to shelter the Bejiqis for their first two weeks here -- and chronicle the experience for a newspaper -- welcomed them along with reporters and television crews.
"It was for me, like, amazing," said Mirsade Bejiqi, the eldest of the Bejiqi children and the most proficient in English.
Overnight, it seems, the roughly 4,000 refugees who have landed at Fort Dix, N.J., in the last few weeks have become emblems of the Kosovo cause. Resettlement agencies across the country report the kind of overwhelming outpouring of sympathy for victims of the Serbian campaign against Albanians in Kosovo that eluded the 78,000 refugees from other wars and slaughters who reached the United States last year.
"I've never heard this before from people, this wanting to do something," said Lisa Reeves, director of the Agency for New Americans, which brought the Bejiqis here. "We're very excited to be the first city in America to settle the Kosovars."
Though more than 700 of the refugees had been settled with relatives across the United States, the Bejiqis and two families sent to Seattle and Sarasota, Fla., were the first to leave Fort Dix to make their way on their own in the United States.
"When we publicly said that we'll receive some families from Kosovo, people really did start to call," Ms. Reeves said. Her agency has sponsored refugees from Bosnia, Congo, Rwanda and Russia, and Kurds from Iraq. This year, it is bringing 165 refugees to this city of 150,000.
Many of the nonprofit groups that resettle refugees in the United States, accustomed to toiling in obscurity, were astounded by the flood of interest. Touched by the sight of families trudging from Kosovo over the mountains to Macedonia and Albania, Americans began showering resettlement agencies with donations, volunteers and offers of clothing, jobs, toys and places to stay.
"There is a certain amount of competition out there," said Richard Parkins, national director of the Episcopal Migration Ministries in New York. "The reality right now is there will not be a sufficient number of refugees for all of the groups that want to be involved in the resettlement."
Some resettlement officials believe the public has responded so strongly because the Albanians from Kosovo are seen as victims of a government with which the United States is at war. Others suggest that the interest, unlike the lesser concern for black refugees of, say, Sudan, is racial, although Bosnians, who are also European, never prompted the same outpouring.
All agree that daily television coverage of Serbian atrocities has fueled much of the reaction.
The selective sympathy does not go unnoticed by less-cared-for refugees of other conflicts.
Bashkim Selace, 29, a chip maker for Micron Technology, fled to the United States from Albania in 1988. Eager to help the Kosovo refugees, he went to the Boise airport to translate for the Bejiqis but could not help remembering his own landing in Boise. One man sponsored him, putting him alone with three other Albanian newcomers in an apartment.
"It was not quite a warm welcome," Mr. Selace said, "even though the guy tried. He did his best, but it wasn't anything like what the refugees now are receiving."
The people Mr. Selace met in his new home knew nothing of his ordeal to flee Communism by crossing the mountains into Yugoslavia. "Most people didn't even know where Albania was," Mr. Selace recalled. "They thought I meant Alabama."
Azad Abdullah, 22, fled Iraq 11 years ago, after Saddam Hussein killed 50,000 Kurds there with mustard gas. Before coming to the United States by way of Guam, he spent five years in Turkish refugee camps, where he said the authorities would shoot and sometimes kill refugees.
In Kosovo, "everybody knows what's going on," Mr. Abdullah said. "It's a hard story, a tragedy. But I feel like we've been through more, but we were not advertised."
For Boise, being among the first cities in America to embrace its own Albanian refugee family was a milestone.
Notwithstanding the Aryan Nation and other extremist groups living in the mountains of Idaho, Boise's leadership wants to shed its image as an insular, parochial place. Businesses like Micron Technology and Hewlett-Packard have begun a campaign to broaden people's attitudes about foreign cultures, many of which are finding a home in Boise.
Abdul Yunis, a Pakistani manager at Hewlett-Packard who heads the city's Islamic Community Center, said, "They're finding they can create a very tolerant and welcoming environment in the company, and recruit people from all over, but employees still have to deal with what's out there when they walk out the door at the end of the day."
Along the highways, billboards for Christianity warn motorists that it is the only avenue to heaven. Mr. Yunis figures that whoever put up the signs had not thought about how they looked to Boise's few thousand Muslims and Jews.
The city is already home to 1,000 or so Bosnian refugees. Unemployment here is low and housing is affordable. Because of low interest rates and a first-time homebuyer's program, scores of Bosnian refugees have bought houses for roughly the same amount they had been paying in rent.
Ajet Bejiqi, 45, said his first priority was to learn English and find a job. This week, resettlement workers will test the Bejiqis' English and help them apply for medical benefits, food stamps and cash assistance.
In the meantime, the family has been settling in, with members of Congregation Ahavath Beth Israel taking the Bejiqis on a retreat in the mountains over the weekend and to Ponderosa State Park.
The family seemed grateful for the attention and warmth but ached for the friends they had made on their journey from Kosovo.
"I need to thank these people," Mirsade Bejiqi said, "but they are not so close to me. I love my people more than anyone in the world."
Ajet Bejiqi said he had been struck by how much Boise looked like Pristina. But as he prepared to begin a new life, the home he lost felt more distant than ever. "Spiritually, Kosovo is very far away now," he said.
Mirsade Bejiqi offered advice for other refugees expected to follow them to Boise: "Forget all the bad things. Start a new life here. And whenever it's better, we'll go back."

HEADLINE: Housing and Confidence Data Buoy Realtors

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Home resales beat expectations in April, and consumer confidence rose for the seventh consecutive month, suggesting that the economy will continue to grow as consumers spend more on homes, cars and merchandise.
"All the economic indicators are still strong," said Fred Flick, vice president for research for the National Association of Realtors. "Consumers are carrying this economy." 
 Existing homes sold at an annual rate of 5.24 million last month, the realty group said. Although that is 3.3 percent less than the record rate of 5.42 million in March, it exceeded analysts' forecasts of a 4.99 million pace for April. A month ago, the realty group had estimated that the March rate would be 5.05 million.
Higher mortgage rates are not doing much to slow demand, the realty group said. It expects home resales for the year to top 5 million, which would exceed the 4.97 million resales last year and make this the fourth consecutive record year for that industry.
One reason for the optimism is that consumer confidence rose this month to 135.8 from a revised 135.5 in April, according to the Conference Board, which is based in New York. That is close to the 30-year high of 138.2 set last June.
The housing and confidence numbers could add to inflation concerns. Last week, the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee announced that it was leaning toward an increase in the overnight bank lending rate; the panel left that rate unchanged at 4.75 percent.
"If they continue at these levels, it really raises the chance that we're going to get a tightening of credit," said Carl Tannenbaum, chief economist with ABN Amro North America Inc.
Demand for housing has not been dented much by higher borrowing costs. Mortgage rates have risen five consecutive weeks, increasing the average for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage last week to 7.23 percent. That is the highest level in 18 months and up from 6.75 percent at the beginning of February, according to Freddie Mac.
The rise in consumer confidence suggests that consumer spending will not fall much from the 6.7 percent annual rate of growth in the first quarter, the largest since 1988.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Hope RidesHigh on $2.5 Billion Equity Issue by Korea Telecom

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 25

 BODY:
One of the surest signs that South Korea has won back the confidence of international investors will show up on Wednesday when shares of Korea Telecom, the country's leading telephone carrier, begin trading for the first time.
The company plans to sell $2.5 billion worth of stock, the first equity deal in South Korea to exceed $1 billion. It could have sold upward of $10 billion worth, said Alok Sama, head of the high-technology and telecommunications group for Asia at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, which is underwriting the deal. 
 The largest equity offering to come out of South Korea previously was by the Korea Electric Power Company, widely know as Kepco, which raised $655 million in March.
Kepco and Korea Telecom are among the 11 state-owned companies that the South Korean Government selected for privatization after the country's economic collapse in December 1997.
Less than a year ago, Mr. Sama said, Morgan Stanley would have had trouble coaxing investors into swallowing $600 million worth of Korea Telecom stock, but times have changed. "Korea is the flavor of the month, flavor of the year, whatever you want to call it," he said.
He said the offering was helped by the large quantities of investor cash sloshing around the globe, which have pushed even the depressed Japanese stock market to double-digit gains this year. Moreover, shares of telephone companies have outperformed most stock indices this year. Demand for wireless communications capacities like mobile telephones and wireless data transmission is huge and growing in South Korea.
Some analysts have mildly criticized the company for changing some of its corporate accounting policies in such a way as to improve its operating profits. But the changes Korea Telecom made were within those allowed by local regulations and were disclosed in the company's prospectus. In addition, although some of the changes would not be acceptable under United States accounting standards, similar practices are used by telephone carriers elsewhere.
Mr. Sama took issue with the suggestion that any accounting changes had inflated earnings, pointing to Korea Telecom's acceleration of depreciation charges on some assets and other restructuring charges. "If anything, earnings have been artificially depressed," he said, "and in any case, earnings aren't what people are looking at."
He said investors were more interested in what price the stock would be as a multiple of its cash flow, which is considered by some to be a more important measure of value.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Again Fall Steeply; Nasdaq Loses Nearly 3%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks slumped for the fourth consecutive session yesterday as a selloff continued in technology and Internet issues.
Aside from a further steep drop in Brazilian stock prices, traders had little fresh news to influence their decisions. While the threat of higher interest rates continues to hang over the stock market, bond prices actually edged up yesterday. 
 "The feeling that the Fed has moved toward a tighter stance doesn't give people much optimism, and Brazil is not in great shape," said Bob Gasser, head of United States equity trading at J. P. Morgan Securities. "But there is nothing on the horizon that would have suggested we couldn't have rallied back" from Monday's steep slide.
Indeed, few analysts were willing to view the recent pullback as more than a long-awaited correction, particularly in technology and Internet stocks, which have fallen from extraordinarily hih levels. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index has lost nearly 10 percent since its peak on April 26.
"This correction is largely a function of declining Internet stocks," said Laszlo Birinyi of the research firm Birinyi & Associates. "The market is fine, but for the time being pressure from Internet selling, both direct and indirect, and the fact there is no news lets gravity assert itself."
Technology and Internet stocks that trade on Nasdaq suffered most yesterday. Led by big declines in market favorites like Intel, Cisco Systems and Yahoo, the Nasdaq composite index fell 72.76 points, or nearly 3 percent, to 2,380.90.
Internet shares have been harder hit. TheStreet.com's Internet stock index fell 26.35 points, or 4.6 percent, to 550.33. Since a peak on April 12, the index has lost 30 percent of its value.
It was a bad day to varying degrees in almost every corner of the market. On the New York Stock Exchange, losers outnumbered winners by almost 2 to 1. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 123.58 points, or 1.16 percent, to 10,531.09, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 22.25 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,284.40. The Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks slumped 5.94, or 1.35 percent, to 434.45.
Particularly hard hit were issues like Amazon.com, Ebay and America Online. Amazon fell 5 15/16, to 111 9/16. Ebay dropped 19 5/16, to 163 15/16. And America Online declined 4 1/2, to 115.
Paul Cook, lead portfolio manager of the Munder NetNet Fund, which has a little more than $2 billion in assets under management, said profit taking, the threat of higher interest rates and a supply of new issues were putting pressure on stocks.
"The fourth and first quarters were particularly strong" for these stocks, he said, "and 38 new names have come public since the start of the year. And since these are high-multiple stocks, they are going to suffer if interest rates move higher."
Analysts said the weakness in Internet stocks was also a likely catalyst for a drop in the Dow and the S.& P. 500 during the final hour of trading. Investors facing margin calls in Internet stocks may have been forced to sell Dow stocks to meet them, Mr. Birinyi said.
A spokesman for Charles Schwab, Mo Shafroth, said: "In the last couple of days, when the Nasdaq takes a dip, it is often the case that there is an increase in margin calls. I can't quantify how much margin calls are up, but it is more than a little and less than a lot."
The Dow was led down by weakness in cyclical stocks like Alcoa, which fell 3 1/2, to 56 13/16, and financial shares like J. P. Morgan, down 3 11/16, to 133 1/16, and Citigroup, which dropped 2 3/8, to 62 3/4.
Intel led the Nasdaq and S.& P. 500 lower, falling 3 1/16, to 52 7/8. Cisco was another big loser, falling 5, to 104 3/8.
Bank and financial service stocks, punished on Monday after an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston put out a sell signal on several money-center banks, were losers again yesterday. Bank of America fell 2 7/8, to 62 3/4. First Union, which cut profit estimates yesterday for a second time this year, fell 4 5/16, to 45 5/8. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette shed 4, to 64 5/8. And Charles Schwab lost 9 3/4, to 96 5/8.
Utility stocks, often used as a safe haven during times of broad market weakness, did well again yesterday. The Dow Jones utilities average advanced to a fifth consecutive record, rising 1.05 points, to 328.48.
Among individual issues, American Electric Power rose 5/8, to 43 11/16. Con Edison gained 5/8, to 49 3/8. And Duke Energy rose 3/4, to 60 1/8.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Rise
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices were little changed yesterday, gaining support from falling stocks, declines in commodities and waning corporate debt demand.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 5/32, to 93. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.74 percent from 5.76 percent. Yields on two-year notes, the most actively traded Treasuries, rose to 5.26 percent from 5.24 percent.
Treasuries fell for most of the day as reports on consumer confidence and home sales suggested that the economy was going strong, keeping alive concerns that growth might spur inflation.
Bonds bounced back as stocks fell in afternoon trading, making less-risky Treasuries attractive. Waning demand for corporate debt also bolstered the Treasuries' appeal.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Warningby First Union Draws Heap of Scorn

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
In glitzy, futuristic television advertisements, the First Union Corporation has been proudly promoting itself as "The Mountain." But the ground beneath that mountain is trembling.
First Union, the nation's sixth-largest bank, which was built through costly, rapid-fire acquisitions, surprised investors and employees yesterday when it warned that profits for the second quarter and the year would fall far below previous estimates and that 1999 would be less profitable than 1998. It was the second time this year that the bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., has had to revise its earnings estimates sharply downward -- leaving the bank's credibility in tatters, its financial outlook clouded and its ability to remain independent in doubt. 
 "For years I complained about the prices they paid for acquisitions, but I always said they ran a good bank," said Thomas K. Brown, a money manager with Tiger Management in New York. "But now they're having serious problems running the basic bank -- the wheels are coming off the cart."
The bank, citing difficulties generating revenue and looming problems in its loan portfolio, said earnings for the year would be $3.3 billion to $3.4 billion, or $3.40 to $3.50 a share. Those figures are well below revised projections made by the bank in January that caused bank stock analysts to lower their estimates to $4.02 a share for the year, from $4.29. Last year, First Union earned $3.7 billion, or $3.77 a share.
The stock market was unforgiving yesterday. In almost seven times the normal trading volume, First Union shares plunged 8.6 percent, to $45.625, the biggest drop in eight years and well below the stock's 52-week high of $65.9375.
First Union, along with its rival, the Bank of America Corporation, has been one of the most free-spending acquirers in banking. Its acquisition spree has contributed to a merger boom that has put the bulk of the country's banking assets at a handful of banks with national ambitions. So heated is the competition between First Union's chief executive, Edward E. Crutchfield Jr., and Bank of America's chief executive, Hugh L. McColl Jr., that each appears to be trying to outdo the other with ever-bigger purchases. Their rivalry even extends to dueling skyscrapers. First Union is building a 30-story office tower in Charlotte and has hinted that a 100-story tower may be on the way. Bank of America is busy erecting a 45-story skyscraper in Charlotte.
But the towering First Union facade cloaks a failure to attain the financial goals promised in its merger binge, mounting managerial woes and low morale amid the layoff of thousands of workers -- layoffs deemed necessary for the bank to meet earnings goals associated with acquisitions.
First Union's $17 billion takeover of the Corestates Financial Corporation last year was one of the most expensive in banking history relative to the size of the target. First Union acknowledged yesterday that a financial payoff from that merger "lags original expectations."
Last year, First Union also bought Money Store Inc., which lends to people with troubled credit histories, for $2.1 billion. In a maneuver criticized by many stock analysts, First Union later took a $2.2 billion "accounting adjustment" for the takeover that allowed it to spread the cost of the acquisition over 25 years and thus avoid an earnings hit. First Union said yesterday that the Money Store acquisition had also disappointed.
Nonetheless, until earlier this year many analysts were willing to give First Union the benefit of the doubt and accept earnings projections proffered by the company.
"This is a tale of ego run amok," Mr. Brown said, "and it says a lot about how easily Wall Street buys into whatever earnings figures management feeds it." He was referring to the ego of Mr. Crutchfield, who once derided Mr. Brown as "that little red-haired boy" and banned the stock analyst from company headquarters because of Mr. Brown's skepticism about First Union's acquisition strategy.
Other analysts were also critical yesterday of First Union's performance. "This company has squandered its credibility with Wall Street," said David Berry at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. "You cannot escape the conclusion that they have trouble doing budgets over there."
A First Union spokeswoman said Mr. Crutchfield was taking questions only from analysts yesterday and declined to be interviewed. But analysts said he had told them in a conference call that the bank would now forgo acquisitions because they no longer made economic sense. But the hunter could become the hunted, with Wells Fargo & Company, the Bank One Corporation or the Chase Manhattan Corporation eventually putting the depressed stock of First Union in their sights.
John R. Georgius, First Union's president, said in an interview that his job was secure. He said First Union's board had supported every acquisition and was "very confident that our business fundamentals are solid." He also said his bank had had "many years of consistent performance" and planned to meet its revised earnings projections.
Though First Union said it would add $90 million to $110 million to its loan loss reserves of $600 million, Mr. Georgius noted that that figure was still relatively small given the bank's $130 billion loan portfolio.
Encouraging investors and analysts to look on the bright side, First Union made one surprising announcement yesterday. The bank, which has invested so heavily in brick-and-mortar branches through its acquisitions, said that its best opportunities for growth would be on the Internet.

HEADLINE: Clinton Sets Safety Goals For Truckers

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today set a goal of reducing deaths from truck crashes by 50 percent over 10 years and promised quick action on safety questions that had stymied it for years, including revising the 62-year-old rules on how many hours a day a driver can work.
"Up to this point, very little focus has been placed on the needs of the drivers,"Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater said in announcing the goal. "It's always been, for the most part, the bottom line." 
 The current rules, written long before the age of transcontinental truck routes, call for drivers to have 8 hours off after 10 hours of driving or 15 hours of work, which can include loading and unloading or other duties. The rest hours can be split into two parts, the shorter as little as 2 hours, and can be taken in a cab's sleeper berth.
The National Transportation Safety Board, which estimates that 750 to 1,500 deaths annually occur in crashes in which trucker fatigue is a factor, has put new rules on hours on its "most wanted" list of safety improvements since 1990.
The Transportation Department proposed new rules in 1995 but, unable to win consensus among labor, business and safety groups, has not moved forward. Mr. Slater said that unless the pace was increased, no new rule would be written before President Clinton's term ends.
And the existing rule is widely disobeyed, Transportation Department officials say.
Kenneth Mead, the inspector general of the department, said the industry's economic structure, with drivers widely paid by the mile instead of the hour, would have to change to make the system safer.
"They don't drive till they're exhausted because they want to," Mr. Mead said.
He has recently detailed a series of problems with the department's Office of Motor Carriers. In 1998, Mr. Mead said, more than 20,000 violations were cited by investigators, but only 11 percent resulted in fines; and of those, fines paid were only 46 percent of the dollar amounts initially assessed. The average final payment was $1,500, he said.
Under legislation that took effect this year, fines for serious violations of trucking rules, formerly limited to $1,000 each and $10,000 per accident or incident, are now set at $10,000 each, with no ceiling. And fines for record-keeping violations, formerly $500 each with a cap of $2,500, are now $5,000 each, with no ceiling.
Federal statistics show that the number of accidents per million miles traveled has fallen steadily, but the number of deaths is stubbornly high, because the industry is booming.
According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, 5,398 people died in crashes involving heavy trucks in 1997, nearly all of them in a car, van, pickup or other light vehicle, not the heavy truck.

HEADLINE: Philanthropy Rose 11% in 1998, Report Says

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Pushed by a healthy economy and the rising stock market, charitable giving by Americans climbed 11 percent to a record $175 billion last year, according to estimates in a report made public yesterday.
The figures represented the third consecutive year of double-digit growth and strong gains for many charitable organizations. The only area that showed a decline was arts, culture and humanities. In contrast, donations to environmental and wildlife groups and health and human service organizations grew by 20 percent or more. 
 "Many people speculate that we're entering the golden age of philanthropy, and as practitioners, many of us are experiencing that," said Jimmie R. Alford, chairman of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, whose nonprofit arm, the AAFRC Trust for Philanthropy, publishes the report, Giving USA.
"We're seeing some unprecedented gifts," added Mr. Alford, a fund-raising consultant in Skokie, Ill.
Despite the gains, the new figures are sure to stir debate over how generous Americans really are. Although charitable giving kept pace with rising incomes last year, it did not come close to matching the hefty increases in the stock market in 1998, when the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 27 percent.
"The very top group could be giving 10 times more than they do and not impair their wealth at all," said Claude Rosenberg, a former investment adviser in San Francisco who set up the Newtithing Group, a nonprofit group that encourages people to think of donations in terms of their wealth, not their income.
Individuals did raise their giving 10 percent last year to $135 billion, according to the 1999 edition of Giving USA. As always, individuals accounted for most of the giving: 77 percent of the total in 1998.
Bequests added $13.6 billion, an 8 percent increase. Giving by foundations showed the biggest gain last year, rising 23 percent to $17 billion. Foundations are required by law to give away an amount equal to 5 percent of their assets. Corporate giving, $9 billion, rose 9 percent, and amounted to 1 percent of corporate pretax income in 1998.
While individual giving rose slightly relative to personal income last year, reaching 1.9 percent for the first time since 1973, officials of the association acknowledged yesterday that income might not be as useful a yardstick as it has been in the past.
"Income is almost beside the point when personal wealth has increased so sharply," said Nancy L. Raybin, chairwoman of the AAFRC Trust for Philanthropy.
Paul G. Schervish, director of the Social Welfare Research Institute at Boston College, called wealthy individuals a sleeping giant for philanthropy. He said many such people were planning for future philanthropy through bequests or programs like Fidelity Investments' Charitable Gifts fund, which lets individuals create tax-deductible pools of money that function somewhat like personal foundations.
Ms. Raybin said many individuals also contributed directly to personal foundations last year. Gifts to foundations totaled $17 billion in 1998, a 16 percent increase.
Four other areas of giving showed especially large gains: environmental and wildlife organizations (up 28 percent to $5.3 billion), human services (up 27 percent to $16.1 billion), health organizations (up 20 percent to $16.9 billion), and public benefit organizations, including civil rights, public affairs, consumer protection and scientific development groups (up 30 percent to $10.9 billion).
The only area of giving that declined was arts, culture and the humanities, where contributions fell almost 1 percent from the previous year, to $10.5 billion.
Religion remained the largest area of giving, with $76.1 billion in donations last year, up about 5 percent from 1997.
Education represented the second largest area of charitable donations, with $24.6 billion in gifts, an increase of 11 percent from 1997.

HEADLINE: Clinton Has a Few Fine Words for Gore

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: EDINBURG, Tex., May 25

 BODY:
President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore crossed paths here today, a public pairing that inadvertently highlighted just how far the Vice President had to go in matching his mentor's political skills.
The President, in a warmly received 19-minute introductory speech, heaped praise on his designated heir. The Vice President followed, giving a speech about economic development in poor neighborhoods that went on twice as long as Mr. Clinton's and was laden with bureaucratic phrases about applications, blueprints and empowerment. 
 It was less than two weeks ago that the President openly told a reporter that he was worried about Mr. Gore's so-far-undeclared Presidential campaign and that Mr. Gore needed to loosen up. Today was their first joint appearance since, creating a moment that invited comparisons.
Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who is close to Mr. Gore, accompanied the President here for the Fifth Annual White House Community Empowerment Conference and could not help acknowledging the gap in their communications skills.
The President is "a master communicator of historic proportions," Mr. Cuomo said. Mr. Gore, he added, meaning to praise him, is "a very effective communicator."
The President and his tutee met here at this sun-baked border town for an event intended to promote the Administration's establishment of "empowerment zones," depressed areas where tax breaks and investment have lured businesses and helped create thousands of jobs.
It was also a platform for Mr. Gore to promote his candidacy, and he was the host. Mr. Clinton stopped by on his way to a vacation in Florida.
The conference setting was an effort to boost Mr. Gore's standing with Hispanic voters. It was here in the backyard of Gov. George W. Bush, the leading contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, in a heavily Hispanic area.
The stage was set, unusually, with the official seals of both the President and the Vice President. And Mr. Clinton spent most of his introduction praising Mr. Gore as an equal partner in the successes of the empowerment zones across the country.
"Because of his unparalleled combination of creativity and energy, experience and determination, I asked the Vice President to take the lead in turning this vision we had into reality," Mr. Clinton told the audience of a few hundred people assembled from these zones.
"It was a challenge, as all of you have seen, that he embraced passionately," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Gore then held the podium for 40 minutes. While Mr. Clinton had spoken vividly, with flowing hand gestures, about the Administration's efforts at economic development, Mr. Gore focused on the grant applications and the theory of community.
Mr. Cuomo, son of another recognized master orator, said that while Mr. Gore had had "a very factual, technical area" to cover, he had still been effective.
"You have the material you have," Mr. Cuomo said. "We all have our own style."

HEADLINE: Do State Lotteries Dupe the Poor?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Living Off the Daily Dream of Winning a Lottery Prize" (front page, May 22): 
 It is one thing to "allow" individuals to gamble as they wish; it is quite another for states to encourage such proclivities when the costs bear so heavily on the poor.
Moreover, the example of New Jersey's property tax as a more equitable way of increasing state revenue is misleading. The data you report show that low-income households pay a little more than $400 a year in property taxes while those with at least twice that income pay less than $600. Property taxes paid by high-income families are likely to include taxes on rental property. Such taxes are regularly shifted to renters when housing is in high demand, thus disguising the actual regressive nature of the tax.
 
DAVID E. KAUN
Santa Cruz, Calif., May 23, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; Foreign Desk
